projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

A Catalogue of all the Shires, Citties, Bi≈øhoprickes, Market Townes, Ca≈øtles, Pari≈øhes, Rivers, Bridges, „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Forre≈øts, and Parkes, conteyned in every particuler ≈øhire of the Kingdom of England.

div.head: THE GENERALL OF GREAT BRITAINE. CHAPTER I.
div.p: THE State of euery Kingdome well managed by prudent gouernment, ≈øeemes to me to repre≈øent a Humane Body, guided by the ≈øoueraigntie of the Rea≈øonable Soule: the Country and Land it ≈øelfe repre≈øenting the one, the Actions and State-affaires the other. Sith therefore the excellencies of the whole are but vnperfectly laid open, where either of the≈øe Parts is defectiue, our intendment is to take a view as well of the outward Body and Lineaments of the now-flouri≈øhing Briti≈øh Monarchy (the Ilands) Kingdomes and Prouinces thereof in actuall po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, (for with others, no le≈ø≈øe iu≈øtly claimed in the Continent, we meddle not) which ≈øhall be the content of our fir≈øt or Chorographicall Tome, containing the foure fir≈øt Bookes of this our Theater: as al≈øo of its ≈øucce≈ø≈øiue gouernment and vitall actions of State, which ≈øhall be our ≈øecond or Hi≈øtoricall Tome, containing the fiue la≈øt Bookes. And here fir≈øt we will (by example of the be≈øt Anatomi≈øts) propo≈øe to the view the whole Body and Monarchy intire (as farre as conueniently we could compri≈øe it) and after will di≈ø≈øect and lay open the particular Members, Veynes, and Ioynts, (I meane the Shires, Riuers, Cities, and Townes) with ≈øuch things as ≈øhall occurre mo≈øt worthy our regard, and mo≈øt behouefull for our v≈øe.

(2) The Iland of Great Britaine (which with her adioyning I≈øles is here fir≈øt pre≈øented) containeth the Kingdomes of England and Scotland, and is of many accounted the greate≈øt I≈øland in the World, though Iu≈øtus Lyp≈øius giues that pray≈øe to Cuba in America, as the Orientall Nauigatores doe vnto Sumatra (taken for Ptolomees Taprobana) or to Madaga≈øcar, the I≈øland of S. Laurence, both which are neere vnto, or vnder the Equinoctiall line; In which we will not contend; as plea≈øing our ≈øelues
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
with her other pray≈øes greater then her Greatnes; yet with this honour al≈øo, that it was (without que≈øtion) the greate≈øt I≈øland of the Romane World, and for any thing yet certainly knowne, of all the re≈øt. Concerning who≈øe ‚Ä¢ o≈øiture in re≈øpect of Heauen, Lueretius (the fir≈øt of the Latine Writers that names Britaine) ≈øeemeth to place it in the ≈øame Parallel with Pontus, where he ≈øaith:
Nam quid Britannum coelum differre putamus, &c.
What differs Britaines heauen from that of Nile?
Or Pontus welkin, from Gadz warmer I≈øle?
In which, by a certaine cro≈ø≈øe compari≈øon, he oppo≈øeth two likes again≈øt two vnlikes, Britaine and Pontus again≈øt Egypt and Gads. But to ≈øeeke into profound Antiquitie, rather then pre≈øent practi≈øe, for matters, in which V≈øe makes perfectne≈ø≈øe, were to affect the giuing light by ≈øhadowes, rather then by Sunne-≈øhine.

(3) It is by experience found to lie included from the degree fiftie, and thirtie ≈øcruples of Latitude, and for Longitude extended from the 13. degree, and 20. minutes, vnto the 22. and 50. minutes, according to the ob≈øeruation of Mercator. It hath Britaine, Normandy, and other parts of France vpon the South, the Lower Germany, Denmarke, and Norway vpon the Ea≈øt; the I≈øles of Orkney and the Deucaledonian Sea, vpon the North; the Hebrides vpon the We≈øt, and from it all other Ilands and Ilets, which doe ≈øcatteredly inuiron it, and ≈øhelter them≈øelues (as it were) vnder the ≈øhadow of Great Albion (another name of this famous Iland) are al≈øo accounted Britanni≈øh, and are therefore here de≈øcribed altogether.

(4) Britaine thus ≈øeated in the Ocean hath her pray≈øes, not onely in the pre≈øent ≈øen≈øe, and v≈øe of her commodities, but al≈øo in tho≈øe honorable Eulogies, which the learned≈øt of Antiquaries hath collected out of the noble≈øt Authors, that he ≈øcarce ≈øeemeth to haue left any gleanings: neither will „Äà‚óä„Äâ
tran≈øplant them out of his flouri≈øhing Gardens, but as nece≈ø≈øitie compels, ≈øith nothing „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
or other ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ be ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øaid.

(5) That Britaine therefore is the Seas High Admirall, is famou≈øly knowne: and the Fortunate I≈øland ≈øuppo≈øed by ≈øome, as Robert of Anesbury doth ≈øhew: who≈øe ayre is more temperate (≈øaith Cae≈øar) then France; who≈øe Soile bringeth forth all graine in abundance, ≈øaith Tacitus; who≈øe Seas produce orient Pearle, ≈øaith Suetonius; who≈øe Fields are the ≈øeat of a Summer Queene, ≈øaith Orpheus; her wilde≈øt parts free from wilde bea≈øts, ≈øaith the ancient Pa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ gyricke, and her chiefe Citie worthily named Augu≈øta, as ≈øaith Ammianus: So as we may truely ≈øay with the royall P≈øalmi≈øt, Our lines are fallen in plea≈øant places, yea we haue a faire inheritance. Which what≈øoeuer by the goodne≈ø≈øe of God, and indu≈øtry of man it is now, yet our Engli≈øh Poet hath truely de≈øcribed vnto vs the fir≈øt face thereof, thus;
The Land which warre-like Britaines now po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe
And therein haue their mightie Empire rai≈øde,
In ancient times was ≈øaluage Wilderne≈ø≈øe,
Vnpeopled, vnmanur'd, vnprou'd, vnprai≈øde.

(6) And albeit the Ocean doth at this pre≈øent thru≈øt it ≈øelfe betweene Doue, and Callis, diuiding them with a deepe and va≈øt entrenchment; ≈øo that Britaine thereby is of a ≈øuppo≈øed „Äà‚óä„Äâ made an Iland: yet diuers haue ≈øtifly held, that once it was ioyned by an arme of land to the Continent of Gallia. To which opinion Spencer farther alluding, thus clo≈øeth his Stanza.

q.l: Ne was it Iland then, ne was it pai≈øde
Amid the Ocean waues, ne was it ≈øought
Of Merchants farre, for profits thererem prai≈øde,
But was all de≈øolate, and of ≈øome thought
By Sea to haue beene from the Celticke Mainland brought.

div.p:
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ as a matter meerly coniecturall (becau≈øe it is not plaine that there „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Ilands nor hils
before Noahs floud) I leaue at large: Virgill ≈øurely (of all Poets the mo≈øt learned) when de≈øcribing the Shield which Vulcan forged (in Virgils braine) for Aeneas, he cals the Morini (people about Callis) the outmo≈øt men, doth onely meane that they were We≈øtward, the furthe≈øt Inhabitants vpon the Continent, ≈øignifying withall that Britaine as being an Iland, lay out of the world: but yet not out of the knowledge of men, for the Commodities thereof inuited the famous Greeke Colonies of Merchants, which dwelt at Ma≈øsilia in France, to venture hither, as hath beene well ob≈øerued out of Strabo.

(7) And as Iulius Cae≈øar was the fir≈øt Romane which euer gaue an attempt to conquer it, ≈øo will we clo≈øe its pray≈øes with a late Epigram, concerning the outward face of the I≈øle, and the motiue of Cae≈øars comming.

q.l: ALBIONIS vertex frondo≈øo cri ‚Ä¢ e ≈øuperbit.
Arboreas frondes plurimas ales habet.
Graminean Montes & ‚Ä¢ undunt pa≈øeua p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ em;
Et carpunt, circum pa≈øeua, gramenoues:
Sed LATII caruit potioribus In≈øula donis,
Victori potior Gloria ni LATIO.
Albions high tops her woody lockes farre ≈øhew,
With quiers of chanting Birds the≈øe Woods re≈øounding.
Her Downes and Meadowes cladin verdant hew,
Meadowes and Downes with flockes and heards abounding.
Latium had greater Wealth, yet Cae≈øar thought,
To Britti≈øh Glory, Latiums Wealth worth nought.

div.p:
(8) The diui≈øion of Britaine concerning the gouernment and Territories thereof; at ≈øuch time
„Äà‚óä„Äâ
Cea≈øer here arriued, doth not ≈øufficiently appeare. Cae≈øar him≈øelfe makes ≈øo ≈øparing mention therein, that we haue little cau≈øe to beleeue Florus, where he makes Lauie ≈øay, that after Cae≈øar had ≈ølaine
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ multitude of Britaines, he ≈øubdued the re≈øidue of the Ile, but rather with exqui≈øite Hora ‚Ä¢ e, that he did not at all touch them, as the word intactus doth in him purport.

(9) Kings they were, and therefore that diui≈øion which was here in Cae≈øars time, was into Kingdomes; the old names of whole Nations, as al≈øo the knowledge of their ≈øeuerall abodes, hidden vnder the rabbi≈øh of ≈øo many ages, haue of late with infinite labours and exqui≈øite iudgement, beene probably re≈øtored and abounded; yet that no mans expectation and de≈øire be too much fru≈øtrated, rea≈øon wils that we briefly ≈øet forth ≈øuch diui≈øions of the Land, as many repute not ancient onely, but authenticke.

(10) Our ≈øeeming ancient Hi≈øtorians begin it at Brute, who to euery of his three ≈øonnes gaue a part, called pre≈øently after their names; as Loegria to L ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rme his elde≈øt ≈øonne: Cambria to Camber his ≈øecond ≈øonne; and Albama to Albani≈øt his third ≈øonne: And doubtle≈ø≈øe, if there had beene more Nations of fame in this Iland, Brute ≈øhould haue had more ≈øonnes fathered on him: which conceit ≈øome a≈øcribe to Monmouth, holding that before him it was neuer ≈øo diuided.

(11) Ptolemie naming Britaine the Great and the Le≈ø≈øe, hath beene by ≈øome mi≈øtaken, as ≈øo diuiding this Iland into two parts; but his proportion and di≈øtance from the Aequator, compared with his Geographicall de≈øcription will euince, that he calleth this our Iland Great Britaine, and Ireland Britaine the Le≈ø≈øe.

(12) Howbeit ≈øome later doe make indeed the South and more Champion to be called Great Britaine, and the North more Mountainous, Britaine the Le≈ø≈øe; who≈øe Inhabitants anciently were di≈øtingui≈øhed into the Maiatae, and Caledonij, and now by the Scots are into Heghlandmen and Lawlandmen.
But that Northerne clime being more piercing for the Romans con≈øtitutions, and le≈ø≈øe profitable or fruitfull, they ≈øet their bounds not farre from Edenburgh, and altogether neglected the other parts more Northward.

(13) This neerer part of Britaine they then diuided into two parts; for the more Southerne tract, together with Wales, Dio termeth the Higher, and that more Northward the Lower, as by the ≈øeate of their Legions doth appeare; for the ≈øecond Legion Augu≈øta (which kept at Caerleon in South-Wales) and the twentieth called Victrix (which remained at Che≈øter) he placeth in the Higher Britaine: but the ≈øixt Legion ≈øurnamed al≈øo Victrix, re≈øident at Yorke, ≈øerued (as he writeth) in the Lower Britain; which diui≈øion, as ≈øeemeth, was made by Seuerus the Emperour, who hauing vanqui≈øhed Albinus, Generall of the Britaines, and reduced their State vnder his obedience, diuided the gouernment thereof into two Prouinces, and placed two Prefects ouer the ≈øame.

(14) After this againe the Romanes did apportion Britaine into three parts, who≈øe limits our great Antiquary a≈ø≈øigneth by the ancient Archiepi≈øcopall Seates, grounding his coniecture on the ≈øaying of Pope Lucius, who affirmes that the Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iuri≈ødictions of the Chri≈øtians, accorded with the precincts of the Romane Magi≈øtrates, & that their Archbi≈øhops had their Sees in tho≈øe Cities wherein their Pre≈øidents abode: ≈øo that the ancient Seates of the three Archbi≈øhops here, being London in the Ea≈øt, Caerleon in the We≈øt, and Yorke in the North; Londons Dioce≈ø≈øe (as ≈øeemeth) made Britaine prima; Caerleon, Britaine ≈øecunda; and Yorke, Maxima Cae≈øarien≈øis.

(15) But in the next age, when the power of their Pre≈øidents began to grow ouer-great, they againe diuided Britaine into fiue parts, adding the three former Valentia and Flauia Cae≈øarie ‚Ä¢ ≈øis: the fir≈øt of which two ≈øeemeth to haue beene the Northerly part of Maxima Ca≈øarie ‚Ä¢ ≈øis, recouered from the Picts and Scots by Theodo≈øius the Generall, vnder Valence the Emperour, and in honour of him, named Valentia: and Flauia may be coniectured to receiue the name from Flauius the Emperour (≈øonne of Theodo≈øius) for that we reade not of the name Britaine Flauia, before his time.

(16) So the≈øe fiue partitions had their limits a≈ø≈øigned after this manner: Britaine prima contained tho≈øe coa≈øts that lay betwixt Thame≈øis, the Seuerne, and the Briti≈øh Sea: Britaine ≈øecunda extended from Seuerne vnto the Iri≈øh Seas, containing the Country that we now call Wales: Flauia Cae≈øarien≈øis, was that which lay betwixt the Riuers Humber and Tyne: and Valentia from the ≈øaid Riuer, and Picts wall reached vnto the Rampire neere Edenburgh in Scotland, the farthe≈øt part that the Romanes po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed when this diui≈øion was in v≈øe. For the ≈øeuerall people inhabiting all tho≈øe parts, with their ancient Names & Borders (whether de≈øigned by the Romans, or the old Britaines) together with our moderne Names and Shires, an≈øwerable to each of them: we will referre you to the Tables thereof el≈øewhere.

(17) This whole Prouince of Britaine, as in our Hi≈øtory ≈øhall appeare, was highly e≈øteemed of the Emperours them≈øelues, a≈ø≈øuming as a glorious ≈øurname Britanicus: comming thither in per≈øon ouer tho≈øe dangerous and ≈øcarce knowne Seas; here marrying, liuing, and dying; enacting here Lawes for the whole Empire, & giuing to tho≈øe Captaines that ≈øerued here, many En≈øignes of great honor; yea Claudius gaue Plantius (the fir≈øt Prefect of that Prouince) the right hand, as he accompanyed him in his Triumph: and his owne Triumph of Britaine was ≈øet out with ≈øuch magnificence, that the Prouinces brought in golden Crownes of great waight, the Gouernours commanded to attend, and the very Capt ‚Ä¢ ines permitted to be pre≈øent at the ≈øame: A Nauall Coronet was fixed vpon apinnacle of his Pallace, Arches and Trophees were ray≈øed in Rome, and him≈øelfe on his aged knees mounted the ≈øtaires into the Capitoll, ≈øupported by his two ≈øonnes in Law: ≈øo great a ioy conceiued he in him≈øelfe for the Conque≈øt of ≈øome ≈ømall portion of Britaine.

(18) How the Romans found it, held it, and left it, as times ripened and rottened their ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, with the Names, the Inhabitants, Manners & Re≈øi≈øters, I leaue to be pur≈øued in the following Hi≈øtories: and will onely now ≈øhew thee the≈øe three Kingdomes, that are (in pre≈øent) the chiefe Bodies of Great Britaines Monarchie; two of which (Scotland and Ireland) ≈øhall in their due places haue their farther and more particular De≈øcriptions.

div.head: ENGLANDS GENERALL DESCRIPTION. CHAPTER II.
div.p: THE Saxons glory now neere to expire, by his appointment who holdeth both times and Kingdomes in his all ordering hand; their owne Swords being the In≈øtruments, and the Danes the maules that beat their beautifull Diadem into pieces; the Normans, a ≈øtirring Nation, (neyther expected, nor much feared) vnder the leading of William their Duke, and encouragement of the Romane Bi≈øhop (an v≈øuall promoter here of broken titles) made hither ≈øodainly into England, who in one onely battell, with the title of his ≈øword and ≈ølaughter or Herold, ≈øet the Emperiall Crowne thereof vpon his owne head: which no ≈øooner was done, but the Engli≈øh went downe, and the Normans lording it, became Owners of tho≈øe Cities which them≈øelues neuer built; po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed tho≈øe Vineyards which they neuer planted; dranke of tho≈øe Wells which they neuer had digged; and inhabitted tho≈øe hou≈øes, filled with riches, for which they neuer had laboured: for they found it to be as the land whereupon the Lord ≈øet his eye, euen from the beginning to the end of the yeare: not onely drinking water of the raine of heauen, but hauing al≈øo riuers of waters and fountaines in her valleyes, and without all ≈øcar≈øitie, who≈øe ≈øtones are yron, and out of who≈øe mountaines is digged bra≈ø≈øe. This made them more re≈øolute at fir≈øt to ≈øettle them≈øelues in this faire≈øt and fruitfulle≈øt part of the Iland; the Conquerour v≈øing all policie both Martiall and Ciuill, to plant his po≈øteritie here for euer. How he found the Land gouerned we ≈øhewed in the Heptarchy; but his re≈øtle≈ø≈øe thoughts were not contented with conquering the Nation and their Land, vnle≈ø≈øe he al≈øo ouercame their very Cu≈øtomes, Lawes, and Language.

(2) Touching the di≈øtribution of the Kingdome, whereas other Kings before him made v≈øe of it, chiefly for the good of the people, and better mini≈øtring of Iu≈øtice, he made v≈øe of it, to know the wealth of his Subiects, and to enrich his Coffers: for he cau≈øed a de≈øcription to be made of all England,
how much land euery one of his Barons po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, how many Knights fees, how many Plow. lands, how many in villenage, how many head of bea≈øts, yea how much money euery man from the greate≈øt, to the lea≈øt did po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe, and what rents might be made of entry mans po≈ø≈øe≈øsion, the Booke of which inqui≈øition (yet in the Exchequer) was called Dome≈øday, for the generalitie of that Iudgement on all the Land: Whereunto we may adde his other di≈øtribution of this Land (wor≈øe then any former) when thru≈øting the Engli≈øh out of their po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, he di≈øtributed their inheritances to his Souldiers; yet ≈øo, that all ≈øhould be held of the King, as of the onely true Lord and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor.

(3) For the Lawes by which he meant to gouerne, he held one excellent rule and purpo≈øe, which was, that a People ought to be ruled by Lawes written and certaine: for otherwi≈øe new Iudges would ≈øtill bring new Iudgements: and therefore he cau≈øed twelue to be cho≈øen out of euery Countie, which ≈øhould on their oath, without inclining one way or other, neither adding nor detracting, open vnto him all their ancient Lawes and Cu≈øtomes. By who≈øe relation vnder≈øtanding that three ≈øorts of Lawes formerly were in the Land, Merchenlage, We≈øt Saxonlage, Danelage; he had preferred the≈øe la≈øt, (him≈øelfe and people being anciently deriued from tho≈øe Northerne people) had not all the Barons bewayling to the King, how grieuous it was for a Land to be iudged by tho≈øe Lawes which they vnder≈øtood not, altered his re≈øolute purpo≈øe: yet in bringing in the ≈øtrange formes of Norman Proce≈ø≈øe, and pleading in the French tongue (which continued till Edward the thirds time,) that grieuance was but ≈ølenderly preuented. So likewi≈øe did he much alter the old Courts of Iu≈øtice, where the≈øe Lawes ≈øhould be mini≈øtred: but whereas the ancient Kings of England, according to Mo≈øes his example, ≈øate in per≈øon in the ≈øeate of Iu≈øtice, to right the greater affayres of their Subiects, as William La ‚Ä¢ bert ≈øheweth in King Alfred, Edgar, Canutus, &c. and proues out of the Kings Oath, out of Bracton, Britaine, Saxon Lawes, &c. King William not onely continued this; but be≈øides erected ≈øome other Courts of Iu≈øtice, as the Exchequer, and certaine Courts and Se≈ø≈øions to be held foure times euery yeare: appointing
both Iudges (≈øome to heare cau≈øes, others to whom appeales ≈øhould be made, but none from them) and al≈øo Prefects to looke to good orders. Tho≈øe la≈øt Polydor calleth Iu≈øtices of Peace; but their in≈øtitution ≈øeemes to be farre later: and no le≈ø≈øe is his errour on the other ≈øide, in ≈øaying the Conquerour fir≈øt in≈øtituted Sheriffes, and the tryall by twelue men, which were both ancienter.

(4) And becau≈øe the Conquerour, for honour of Bi≈øhops, cau≈øed them to remoue from ≈ømall ob≈øcure places to Cities of more renowne; we haue therefore re≈øerued to this la≈øt place that diui≈øion of this Kingdome, which is according to Iuri≈ødiction Epi≈øcopall. Formerly in the yeare of ≈øaluation, 636 Honorius the fift Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, fir≈øt diuided England into Pari≈øhes, which at this day are contained vnder their ≈øeuerall Dio ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øans, and the≈øe againe vnder their two Metropolitanes, (Canterbury and Yorke) in manner following.

(5) To ≈øpeake nothing of the≈øe twentie-eight Flamins the Prie≈øts of Idolatry, and the three Arch-Flamins, who≈øe ≈øeates were at London, Caerlion, and Yorke; all of them conuerted by King Lucius into Chri≈øtian Bi≈øhops Sees: let vs onely in≈øi≈øt vpon the three la≈øt, by the ≈øame King appointed to be Metropolitanes ouer the re≈øt; among whom London is ≈øaid to be chiefe: who≈øe fir≈øt Chri≈øtian Arch-bi≈øhop was Thean, the builder of S. Peters Church in Cornehill for his Cathedrall, as by an ancient Table there lately hanging, was affirmed, and tradition to this day doth hold. Our Briti≈øh Hi≈øtorians doe bring a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of fifteene Arch-bi≈øhops, to haue ≈øate from his time vnto the comming of the Saxons, who≈øe la≈øt was Vodius, ≈ølaine by King Vortiger, for reprehending his heatheni≈øh marriage with R ‚Ä¢ w ‚Ä¢ n, the Daugher of Hengi≈øt. At what time began the mi≈øery of the Land, and of holy Religion,
both which they layd wa≈øt vnder their prophane feete: vntill Ethelbert of Kent, the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian Saxon King, aduanced Chri≈øtainitie, & Augu≈øtine to the Arch-bi≈øhopricke of Canterbury, when London vnder Melitus became ≈øubiect to that See.

(6) At Caerlion vpon Vske, in the time of great Arthur, ≈øate Dubritius, a man excellently learned, and of an holy conuer≈øation: he had ≈øate Bi≈øhop of Landaffe a long time, and with Germanus and Lupus, two French Bi≈øhops greatly impugned the Pelagian Here≈øie, infecting at that time the Iland very farre, who≈øe fame and integritie was ≈øuch, that he was made Arch-bi≈øhop of all Wales: but growne very old, he re≈øigned the ≈øame vnto Dauia his Di≈øciple, a man of greater birth, but greater au≈øteritie of life, who by con≈øent of King, Arthur, remoued his Arch-bi≈øhops See vnto Meneuia, a place very ≈øolitary and meete for meditation: the miracles of the man, (which are ≈øaid to be many) changed both the name of the place into his owne, and robbed Caerlion of her Archiepi≈øcopall ≈øeate: This See of S Dauids, (as in an ancient Regi≈øter belonging to that Church is recorded) had ≈øeauen Bi≈øhops Suffraganes ≈øubiect vnto it which were Exceter, Bathe. He eford, Landaffe, Bangor, S. A≈øaph, and
‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ nes in Ireland: notwith≈øtanding, eyther for want of Pall, carried into Britanny by Arch-bi≈øhop Sam ‚Ä¢ ≈øon, in a dangerous infection of ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, either by pouertie or negligence, it lo≈øt that Iuri≈ødiction, and in the dayes of King Henry the fir≈øt, became ≈øubiect to the See of Canterbury.

(7) Yorke hath had better ≈øucce≈ø≈øe then eyther of the former, in retayning her originall honour, though much impaired in her circuit, challenging to haue beene ≈øome time Metropolitane ouer all the Bi≈øhops in Scotland: and although it was made equall in honour and power with Canterbury, by Pope Gregory, as Beda relateth; and had twelue Suffragan Bi≈øhoprickes that owed obedience, onely foure now acknowledge Yorke their Metropolitane, but Canterbury the Superiour: for William the Conquerour thinking it dangerous to haue two in like authoritie, lea≈øt the one ≈øhould ≈øet on his Crowne, and the other ≈øtrike it off, left Yorke to be a Primate, but Canterbury onely the Prin ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ of all England.

(8) The Lichfield was made an Archiepi≈øcopall See by Pope Hadrian the fir≈øt, at the ≈øuit of Offa, the great King of Mercia, is manife≈øted by Mathew of We≈øtmin≈øter, vnto who≈øe Iuri≈ødiction were a≈ø≈øigned the Bi≈øhoprickes of Winche≈øter, Hereford, Leice≈øter, Sidnace≈øter, Helm ‚Ä¢ am, and Dunwich, and who≈øe fir≈øt and la≈øt bi≈øhop was Aldwin. That Winche≈øter al≈øo had intended an Archiepi≈øcopall Pall, the ≈øame Author recordeth, when Henry Bloys, of the bloud royall, greatly contended with the Arch bi≈øhop of Canterbury for ≈øuperioritie, vnder the pretence of being Cardinall de latere; to him an Archiepi≈øcopall Pall was ≈øent, with power and authoritie ouer ≈øeauen Churches, but he dying before that the de≈øigne was done, the See of Winche≈øter remained in ≈øubiection to Canterbury. And that (long before) the See of Dorche≈øter by Oxford, had the Iuri≈ødiction of an Arch-bi≈øhop, is apparant by tho≈øe Prouinces that were vnder his Dioce≈ø≈øe, which were Winche≈øter, Oxford, Lincolne, Salisbury, B ‚Ä¢ e≈øtow, Wells, Lichfield, Che≈øter, and Exce≈øter; and the fir≈øt Bi≈øhop of this great circuit, Berinu ‚Ä¢ , was called the Apo≈øtle and Bi≈øhop of the We≈øt-Saxons: which in his next ≈øucce≈ø≈øor was diuided into two parts, Winche≈øter and Dorche≈øter, and not long after into Lichfield, Sidnace≈øter, and Legece≈øter; and la≈øtly, the See remoued from Dorche≈øter to Lincolne, as now it is And thus farre for the diui≈øion of this Realme, both Politicke and Eccle≈øia≈øticke, as it hath ≈øtood and ≈øtands at this day.

(9) But the whole Ilands diui≈øion, by mo≈øt certaine Record was anciently made, when Iulius Agric ‚Ä¢ la drew a trench or fortification vpon that narrow ≈øpace of ground betwixt Edenbrough Frith, and Dunbretton Bay, making the Southerne part a Prouince vnto the Romane Empire. Afterwards Hadrian the Emperour ≈øeeing perhaps the Prouince too ≈øpacious to be well gouerned without great expen≈øe, drew backe the≈øe limits almo≈øt foure≈øcore miles ≈øhotter, euen to the mouth of the Riuer Tyne, whence he fortified with a wall of admirable worke vnto Carlile, which ≈øtood the Lands border, while it ≈øtood as a Romane Prouince: yet the conquering Saxons did ≈øpread againe ouer tho≈øe bounds, and (as ≈øeemeth) enlarged their gouernment to that fir≈øt Tract, as by this in≈øcription in a Stone Cro≈ø≈øe, ≈øtanding vpon a Bridge ouer the water of Frith, appeareth.

q.l: I am a free March as Pa≈ø≈øengers may ken,
To Scots, to Britaines, and to Engli≈øhmen.

div.p: (10) But afterward William the Conquerour, and Malcolme King of Scotland, falling to an agreement for their limits, arreared a Cro≈ø≈øe vpon Stanemore, where on the one ≈øide the portraiture and Armes of the King of England was ≈øculptured, and of the King of Scots on the other (a piece whereof is yet remaining there neere to the Spittle) thence called the Rev-Cro≈ø≈øe, there erected to be a Meare-≈øtone to either Kingdome. His ≈øucce≈ø≈øors al≈øo aboli≈øhed the two partitions in the We≈øt, whereby the Wel≈øh became one Nation and Kingdome with the Engli≈øh It is al≈øo ≈øaid that King Stephen to purcha≈øe friend≈øhip with the Scotti≈øh Nation, gaue vnto their King the Countie of Cumberland who with it held both We≈øtmorland and Northumberland; but as Newbrigen≈øis writeth, he re≈øtored them to King Henry the ≈øecond, wi≈øely con≈øidering his great power and right to tho≈øe parts.

(11) The la≈øt knowne borders were from the Sulway in the We≈øt bay, along the Cheuiot hills, vnto the water of Tweed by Barwicke in the Ea≈øt, no maintaine which, on each part many Lawes haue beene made, and many inrodes, robberies, and fewdes practi≈øed; all which by the hand of God is now cut off, and by the rightfull ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of King IAMES our Soueraigne, who hath broken downe the partition of this great I≈øland, and made the extreames of two Kingdomes, the very mid≈øt of his great vnited Empire.

div.head: KENT. CHAPTER III.
div.p: KENT, the fir≈øt Prouince appearing in the South of this Kingdome, is bounded vpon the North with the famous Riuer Thami≈øis: on the Ea≈øt with the Germane Ocean: on the South with Su≈ø≈øex and the narrow Seas: and vpon the We≈øt and Su≈ø≈øex and Surrey. The length thereof extended from Langley in the We≈øt, vnto Ram≈øgate Ea≈øtward in the I≈øle of Thanet, is about 53. Engli≈øh miles. From Rother in the South, vnto the I≈øle of Graine Northward, the bredth is not much aboue 26. and the whole circumference about 160. miles.

(2) Informe it ≈øomewhat re≈øembleth the head of a hammer or Battle-axe, and lyeth corner-wi≈øe into the Sea: by Strabo, Cae≈øar, Diadorus, and Ptolemie, called Cantium, of Cant or Angle or Corner: either of Caine a Briti≈øh word, which ≈øignifieth Bu≈øhes or Woods, whereof that Countie in tho≈øe former times was plentifully ≈øtored.

(3) The ayre, though not very cleere, becau≈øe of the vapours ari≈øing from the Sea, and Riuer: that enuiron the ≈øame, is both whole≈øome and temperate, as ≈øeated neere≈øt to the Equino ‚Ä¢ ticall, and the furthe≈øt from the North Pole, not touched with cold as the other parts of the Land are.

(4) The ≈øoile towards the Ea≈øt is vneuen, ri≈øing into little hils, the We≈øt more leuell and woody, in all places fruitfull, and in plentie equals any other of the Realme, yea, and in ≈øome things hath the be≈øt e≈øteeme: as in Broad-clothes, Fruits, and feedings for Cattell. Onely Mines (except Iron) are wanting: all things el≈øe deliuered with a prodigall heart and liberall hand

(5) Sundry nauigable Riuers are in Kent, whereof Medwey, that diuideth the ≈øhire in the mid≈øt, i ‚Ä¢ chiefe; in who≈øe bo≈øome ≈øecurely rideth his Maje≈øties Nauy Royall, the walls of the Land, and terrours of the Seas; be≈øides ten others of name and account, that open with twenty Creeks and Hauens
for Ships arriuage into this Land, foure of them bearing the name of Cinque Po ‚Ä¢ t ‚Ä¢ , are places of great ≈øtrength and priuiledges, which are Do ‚Ä¢ er Sandwich, Rumney, and Winchel≈øey: among which Douer with the Ca≈øtle is accounted by Mathew Paris the Monke, the locke and key to the whole Realme of England; and by Iohn Ro≈ø≈øe and Lidgate is ≈øaid to be built by Iulius Cae≈øar, fatall onely for the death of King Stephen, and ≈øurrender of King Iohn therein hapning.

(6) A conceit is, that Goodwin Sands were ≈øunke for the ≈øinnes of him≈øelfe and his ≈øonnes. Shelues indeed that dangerou≈øly lye on the North ea≈øt of this Countie, and are much feared of all Nauigators. The≈øe formerly had beene firme ground, but by a ≈øodaine inundation of the Sea were ≈øwallowed vp, as at the ≈øame time a great part of Flanders and the Low Countries were: and the like al≈øo at the ≈øame time befell in Scotland, as Hector Boetius their Hi≈øtoriographer writeth A like accident hapned in the yeare 1586 the fourth day of Augu≈øt, in this Countie, at Mottingham, a Towne eight miles from London, ≈øodainly the ground began to ≈øinke, and three great Elmes thereon growing, were carryed ≈øo deepe into the bowels of the earth, that no part of „Äà‚óä„Äâ could any more be ≈øeene, the hole left in compa≈ø≈øe foure≈øcore yards about, and a line of fiftie fadomes plummed into it doth finde no bottome.

(7) The Kenti≈øh people in Cae≈øars time were accounted the ciuille≈øt among the Britaines: and as yet e≈øteeme them≈øelues the free≈øt Sub ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ cts of the Engli≈øh, not conquered, but compounded with by the Normans: and herein glory, that their King and Commons of all the Saxons were the fir≈øt Chri≈øtians, conuerted in Anno 596. yea, and long before that time al≈øo Kent receiued the faith: for it is recorded that Lucius the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian Briti≈øh King in this Iland, built a Church to the name and ≈øeruice of Chri≈øt, within the Ca≈øtle of Douer, endowing it with the Tolle of the ≈øame Hauen.

(8) This Countie is enriched with two Cities and Bi≈øhops Sees, ≈øtrengthened with 27. Ca≈øtles, graced with 8. of his Maje≈øties mo≈øt Princely Hou≈øes, traded with 24. Market-Townes, and
beautified with many ≈øtately and gorgeous buildings The chiefe≈øt Citie thereof, the Metropolitan and Arch bi≈øhops See, is Canterbury, built (as our Briti≈øh Hi≈øtorians report) 900. yeares before the birth of Chri≈øt; by Henry of Huntington, called Caier Kent, wherein (as M. Lambard ≈øaith) was erected the fir≈øt Schoole of profe≈ø≈øed Arts and Sciences, and the ≈øame a patterne vnto Sigibert King of the Ea≈øt-Angles, for his foundation at Cambridge: notwith≈øtanding by the computation of time, this Sigibert was ≈ølaine by P ‚Ä¢ n ‚Ä¢ a King of Mercia, thirtie yeares before that Theodore the Grecian was Bi≈øhop of Canterbury, who is ≈øaid to be the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ector of that Academie. But certaine it is, that Au≈øt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
the Monke had made this Citie famous before that time, by the conuer≈øion of the≈øe Saxons vnto Chri≈øtianitie, and in building a mo≈øt magnificent Church to Gods ≈øeruice, wherein eight of their Kings haue beene interred, but all their Monuments ≈øince ouer ≈øhadowed by the height of Beckets Tombe, that for glory, wealth, and ≈øuper≈øtitious wor≈øhips, equalized the Pyramides of A ‚Ä¢ gypt, or the Oracle of Delphos, yet now with Dagon is fallen before the Arke of God.

This Citie hath beene honoured with the pre≈øence and Coronations of King I ‚Ä¢ hn and Queene I≈øabell his wife, with the marriages of King Henry the third, and of King Edward the fir≈øt, and with the interments of Edward the Bl ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ke P ‚Ä¢ ince, King Henry the fourth, and of Queene „Äà‚óä„Äâ his wife: as Feuer≈øham is with the burials of King Stephen, and of Maud his Queene and wife But as in glory ≈øo in aduer≈øitie hath this Citie borne a part, being d ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ers times affl ‚Ä¢ cted by the Danes, but mo≈øt e≈øpecially in the dayes of King Eth ‚Ä¢ red, who in that r ‚Ä¢ uenge of their ma≈ø≈øacre made hauock of all, and herein ≈ølew forty three thou≈øand and two hundred per≈øons, the tenth be≈øides re≈øerued to liue. Afterward it recouered breath and beautie by th ‚Ä¢ liberalitie of B ‚Ä¢ ≈øhop „Äà‚óä„Äâ ; Charters and „Äà‚óä„Äâ by King Henry the third; ≈øtrength in Trench and Fortifications from king Richard the ≈øecond; and la≈øtly, Wals for her defence by Simon Sudbury Arch-bi≈øhop of that See: who≈øe Gradu ‚Ä¢ tion is placed for Latitude 51. 25. and parallelized for Longitude 22 8. her ≈øi≈øter Roche≈øter differing not much in either degree.

(9) Which Citie (as Beda ≈øaith) was built by one Rof, Lord of the ≈øame, though ≈øome a≈øcribe the foundation of the Ca≈øtle Iulius Cae≈øar, and hath beene often ruinated by the iniuries of warre, both in the times when the Saxons ≈øtroue for ≈øuperioritie among them≈øelues, wherein this Citie was layd wa≈øte, Anno 680. as al≈øo in the a≈ø≈øaults of their common enemy the Danes, who about the yeare 884. from France ≈øailed vp the Riuer Medwey, and be≈øieged the ≈øame, ≈øo that had not King Elfred ≈øpeedily come to the re≈øcue, it had beene ouerthrowne by tho≈øe Pagans. And againe in Anno 999. the Danes mi≈øerably ≈øpoiled this Citie in the time of King Ethelred: neither hath it ≈øtood ≈øafe from danger ≈øince (though not defaced ≈øo much by warre) for twice hath it beene ≈øore endammaged by chance of fire: the fir≈øt was in the raigne of King Henry the fir≈øt, Anno 1130. him≈øelfe being pre≈øent with mo≈øt of his Nobilitie, for the con≈øecration of the Cathedrall Church of S. Andrew And againe almo≈øt wholly con≈øumed about the latter end of the Raigne of King Henry the ≈øecond, Anno 1177. Yet after all the≈øe calamities it recouered ≈øome ≈øtrength againe, by the bountie of King Henry the third, both in buildings, and in ditching her about for defence.

(10) Ciuill broyles and diffentions hath this Countie beene burdened with, and that not onely vnder the Saxons and Danes, who≈øe de≈øolations were many and grieuous, but al≈øo by other rebellions ≈øince the Normans Conque≈øt, both in tho≈øe infamous in≈øurrections, called The Barons Warres, in the raigne of King Henry the Third, wherein much harme was done: as al≈øo vnder King Richard the ≈øecond, when Wat Tiler, Captaine of a dreadfull commotion, a≈ø≈øembled at Black-heath, Mile end, and in London, doing many outrages, where in Smithfield he was la≈øtly ≈øtrucke downe by William Walworth then Maior of the Citie, and worthily ≈ølaine for his notorious trea≈øons. Againe, vpon Black-heath, Michael Io≈øeph, the Lord Dawbeny, with their Corni≈øh Rebels, were ouerthrowne by King Henry the ≈øeauenth, Anno 1497.

(11) Kent in the time of Iulius Cae≈øar was gouerned by foure ≈øeuerall Kings. Vnder V ‚Ä¢ rtigern the Britaine, by a Lieutenant called Gu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ong, from whom the ≈øaid King gaue it to Hengi≈øt the Saxon, in fauour of his Daughter Rowen, who ≈øeeking to make him≈øelfe ab≈øolute King thereof, e ‚Ä¢ ght yeares after his fir≈øt entrance, fought a victorious battle again≈øt the Britaines neere vnto Crayford, and thenceforth accounted that Prouince his owne. Yet afterward Vortimer the valiant Britaine, gaue him battle at Aylesford in the which bo ‚Ä¢ h Horsa and Ca ‚Ä¢ gern, brethren to both the Generals, were ≈øla ‚Ä¢ ne, and the Saxons driuen into the I≈øle of Thanet, their fir≈øt a≈ø≈øigned habitation, not daring to enter the Continent ≈øo long as Vortimer liued Cot ‚Ä¢ ger ‚Ä¢
was inter ‚Ä¢ ed vpon that plaine, where to this day remaineth his Monument, being foure ≈øtones pitched in manner of the S ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ henge, and is vulgarly called Cit≈øcotchou≈øe The like Monument was of Horfa at Ho ‚Ä¢ ≈øted, which ≈øtormes and time haue now deuoured. Hengi≈øt made this Prouince a Kingdome for him≈øelfe and ≈øucce≈ø≈øors, which name and power it retained the ≈øpace of three hundred and twentie yeares, when Egbert King of the We≈øt Saxons ≈øubdued and ioyned it to his owne: in which ≈øubiection it ≈øtood vntill the time of the Normans. Then it was giuen vnder the title of an Earledome by the Conquerour, vnto Ot ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
bi≈øhop of Baye ‚Ä¢ x his halfe-brother, who≈øe ≈øucce≈øors in that diginite were tho≈øe mo≈øt honourable Families, who≈øe Armes and Names within this plot are blazed and expre≈ø≈øed. It is diuided principally into fiue Lathes, ≈øubdiuided into 66. Hundreds, and them againe into 398. Pari≈øhes‚ñ™ and wherein had beene ≈øeated twentie-three Religious Hou≈øes.

div.head: SVSSEX. CHAPTER IIII.
div.p: SVTH-SEX, a word compounded of the ≈øire th ‚Ä¢ reof Southward; lyeth ≈øtretched along the Briti≈øh Seas. The North confronts vpon Sur ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y and Kent, and the We≈øt butteth vpon Ha ‚Ä¢ ap≈øhire.

(2) For forme it lyeth long and narrow, ≈øo that all her R ‚Ä¢ pes doe runne quite through the Shire, & containeth from We ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ harting in the We≈øt, to Kent-ditch that diuides it from Kent in the Ea≈øt, ≈øixtie foure miles, but in the broade≈øt part little aboue twentie, the whole in circumference about one hundred fiftie eight miles.

(3) The ayre is good, though ≈øomewhat clouded with wi≈øts, which ari≈øe forth of her South bordering Sea, who is very prodigall vnto her for Fi≈øh and Sea-≈øowle, though as ≈øparing for Harbours or Ships ariuage, and tho≈øe which ≈øhe hath, as vncertaine for continuance, as dangerous for entrance.

(4) Rich is the Soile and yeeldeth greatplentie of all things nece≈ø≈øary, but very ill for trauellers, e≈øpecially in the winter, the Land lying low and the wayes very deepe, who≈øe middle tract is garni≈øhed with meadowes, pa≈øtures, and Corn-fields: the Sea-coa≈øt with Hilles which are called the Downs, abundantly yeelding both Graint and Gra≈ø≈øe, and the North ≈øide ouer≈øhadowed with plea≈øant Groues and thicke Woods, where ≈øometimes ≈øtood the famous wood Andrad≈øwald, containing no le≈ø≈øe then an hundred and twentie miles in length, and thirtie in bredth, taking the name of Anderida a Citie adioyning: both which were wonne from the Britaines by Llla the fir≈øt Saxon King of this Prouince, and the place made fatall to Sigebert King of the We≈øt-Saxons, who being depo≈øed
from his Royall Throne, was met in this Wood by a Swine-heard, and ≈ølaine in reuenge of his Lord, whom Sigebert had murdered.

(5) The ancient people in the Romans time were the Regni, of whom we haue ≈øpoken, and who were ≈øubdued by Ve≈øpa≈øian the Leader of the ≈øecond Legion vnder A ‚Ä¢ lus Plautius, Liceutenant in Britaine for Claudius the Emperour. But after the departure of the Romanes, this, with Surrey was made the South-Saxons Kingdome: yet that giuing place to the We≈øt-Saxons, as they in time to the Normans, it became a Prouince vnder the Conquerours power, who gaue to his followers much Land in the≈øe parts‚ñ™

(6) The place of mo≈øt account in this Shire is Chiche≈øter, by the Britaines called Caercei, a Citie beautifull and large, and very well walled about, fir≈øt built by Ci≈ø≈øa the ≈øecond King of the South-Saxons, wherein his Royall palace was kept. And when King William the Fir≈øt had enacted that Bi≈øhops Seas ≈øhould be tran≈ølated out of ≈ømall Townes vnto places of greater re≈øort, the Re≈øidence of the Bi≈øhop (vntill then held at Sel≈øey) was remoued to this Citie, where Bi≈øhop Raulfe began a mo≈øt goodly Cathedrall Church: but before it was fully fini≈øhed, by a ≈øudden mi≈øchance of fire was quite con≈øumed. Yet the ≈øame Bi≈øhop, with the helping liberalitie of King Henry the Fir≈øt, began it againe, and ≈øaw it wholly fini≈øhed; who≈øe beautie and greatne≈ø≈øe her fatall enemy ≈øtill enuying, againe ca≈øt downe in the dayes of King Richard the Fir≈øt, and by her raging flames con≈øumed the buildings both of it and the Bi≈øhops Palace adioyning, which Seffrid the ≈øecond Bi≈øhop of that name reedified and built a new. And now to augment the honour of this place, the Citie hath borne the Title of an Earledome; whereof they of Arundell were ≈øometimes ≈øo ≈øtiled. Who≈øe Gradu≈øtion for Latitude, is remoued from the Equator vnto the degree fiftie, fiftie fiue minutes; and for Longitude, ob≈øeruing the ≈øame point in the We≈øt, whence Mercator hath mea≈øured, are twentie degrees.

(7) With whom for frequencie, bigne≈ø≈øe, and building, the Towne Lewes ≈øeemeth to contend, where King Athel≈øtan appointed the mintage of his Moneyes, and William de Warron built a ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle, whereunto the di≈øloyall Barons of King Henry the Third in warlike manner re≈øorted, and fought a great Battle again≈øt their owne Soueraigne and his ≈øonne, wherein the King had his Hor≈øe ≈ølaine vnder him, Richard, King of the Romans ≈øurpri≈øed and taken in a Wind-mill, and Prince Edward deliuered vnto them vpon vnequall conditions of peace. But a greater Battle was fought at Battle, when the hazard of England was tryed in one dayes fight, and Harold the King gaue place to his Conquerour by lo≈øing of his life, among ≈øixtie ≈øeuen thou≈øand nine hundred ≈øeuentie-foure Engli≈øh men be≈øides; who≈øe bloud ≈øo ≈øpilt, gaue name to the place, in French, Sangue lac. And the ≈øoile naturally after raine becomming of a reddi≈øh colour, cau≈øed William of Newbery vntruely to write, That if there fell any ≈ømall ≈øweet ≈øhowers in the place where ≈øo great a ≈ølaughter of the Engli≈øh-men was made, pre≈øently ≈øweateth forth very fre≈øh bloud out of the earth, as if the euidence thereof did plainly declare the va ‚Ä¢ ce of bloud there ≈øhed, and cryed ≈øtill from the earth vnto the Lord.

(8) But places of other note in this Shire are the≈øe: from Ba≈øham, Earle Harold taking the Sea for his delight, in a ≈ømall Boat, was driuen vpon the Coa≈øt of Normandie, where by Duke William he was retained, till he had ≈øworne to make him King after Edward Confe≈ø≈øors death; which oath being broken, the Ba≈øtard arriued at Pen≈øey, and with his ≈øword reuenged that Periurie at We≈øt-Wittering al≈øo Ella the Saxon before him had landed for the conquering of tho≈øe parts and gaue name to the ≈øhore from Cimen his ≈øon. But with greater glory doth Gromebridge rai≈øe vp her head, where Charles Duke of Orleaunce, father to Lewes the twelfth, King of France, taken pri≈øoner at Agincourt, was there a long time detained.

(9) The commodities of this Prouince are many and diuers, both in Corne, Cattle, Woods, Iron, and Gla≈ø≈øe; which two la≈øt, as they bring great gaine to their po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors, ≈øo doe they impoueri≈øh
the Countie of Woods, who≈øe want will be found in ages to come, if not at this pre≈øent in ≈øome ≈øort felt.

(10) Great haue beene the deuotions of religious Per≈øons in building and con≈øecrating many hou≈øes vnto the v≈øe and onely ≈øeruice of Chri≈øt; who≈øe Beadmen abu≈øing the intents of their Founders, hath cau≈øed tho≈øe Foundations to lament their owne ruines: for in the tempe≈øtuous time of King Henry the Eight, eighteene of them in this Countie were blowne downe, who≈øe fruit iell into the ‚Ä¢ appes of ≈øome that neuer meant to re≈øtore them againe to the like v≈øe.

This Countie is principally diuided into ≈øixe Rapes, euery of them containing a Riuer, a Ca≈øtle, and Forre≈øt in them≈øelues, be≈øides the ≈øeuerall Hundreds whereunto they are parted, that is, the Rape of Chiche≈øter into ≈øeuen, of Arundell into fiue, of Bramber into ten, of Lewes into thirteene, of Peuen≈øey into ≈øeuenteene, and of Ha≈øtings into thirteene, in all fiftie ≈øixe; wherein are ≈øeated ten Ca≈øtles, eighteene Market-Townes, and three hundred and twelue Pari≈øh-Churches.

div.head: SVRREY. CHAPTER V.
div.p:
SVRREY, by Beda called Suthri, lieth ≈øeparated vpon the North from the Counties of
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
kingham and Mia ‚Ä¢ le≈øex, by the great Riuer Tha ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈ø ‚Ä¢ s; vpon the Ea≈øt Kent doth inbound it; vpon the South is held in with Su≈ø≈øex and Hamp≈øhire: and her We≈øt part is bordered vpon by Hamp-≈øhire and Bark-≈øhire.

(2) The forme thereof is ≈øomewhat ≈øquare, and lieth by Northand by Ea≈øt, whereof Redrith and Fren≈øham are the oppo≈øites, betwixt whom are extended thirtie-foure miles. The broade≈øt part is from Awfold Southward, to Thami≈øis by Stanes, and them a≈øunder twentie two: the whole in circumference is one hundred and twelue miles.

(3) The Heauens breathing ayre in this Shire is mo≈øt ≈øweet and delectable, ≈øo that for the ≈øame cau≈øe many royall Palaces of our Princes are therein ≈øeated, and the Countrey better ≈øtored with game then with graine, in≈øomuch that this Countie is by ≈øome men compared vnto a home-≈øpunne freeze cloth, with a co≈øtly faire lift, for that the out-verge doth exceed the middle it≈øelfe. And yet is it wealthy enough both in Corne and Pa≈øturage, e≈øpecially in H ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e≈ødale, and towards the Riuer of Thami≈øis.

(4) In this Shire the Regni (an ancient people mentioned by Ptolemie) were ≈øeated, whom he brancheth further thorow Su≈ø≈øex and ≈øome part of Hamp-≈øhire And in the wane of the Romans gouernment, when the Land was left to the will of Inuaders, the South-Saxons vnder Ella here erected their Kingdome, which with the fir≈øt was rai≈øed, and ≈øoone≈øt found end. From them no doubt the Courtie was named Suth-rey, as ≈øeated vpon the South of the Riuer; and now by contraction is called Surrey.

(5) And albeit the Countie is barren of Cities or Townes of great e≈øtate, yet is ≈øhe ≈øtored with many Princely Hou≈øes, yea and fiue of his Maje≈øties, ≈øo magnificently built, that of ≈øome ≈øhe may well ≈øay, no Shire hath none ≈øuch, as is None-≈øuch indeed. And were not Richmond a fatall place of Englands be≈øt Princes, it might in e≈øteeme be ranked with the riche≈øt: for therein died the great Conquerour of France, King Edward the Third, the beautifull Anne daughter to Charles the Fourth, Emperour, and intirely beloued wife to King Richard the Second; the mo≈øt wi≈øe Prince King Henry the Seuenth, and the rare≈øt of her Sexe, the Mirrour of Princes, Queene Elizabeth, the worlds loue, and Subiects joy.

(6) At Merton likewi≈øe Kenulph King of the We≈øt-Saxons came to his vntimely end: and at Lambeth the hardre Canute, and la≈øt of the Dani≈øh Kings, died among his Cuppes But as the≈øe places were fatall for the la≈øt breath of the≈øe Princes, ≈øo other in this Countie haue beene graced with the body and beginning of other worthy Monarkes: for in Chert≈ø ‚Ä¢ y Abbey King Henry the Sixth, who was depo≈øed and made away in the Tower of London, was fir≈øt interred without all funerall pompe, but for his holy life was imputed a Saint, and la≈øtly tran≈ølated, and intombed at Wind≈øore. At Kingston likewi≈øe ≈øtood the Chaire of Maie≈øtic, wherein Athel≈øtan, Edwin, and Ethelred ≈øate at their Coronation, and fir≈øt receiued their Seepter of Imperiall Power Guildfor ‚Ä¢
likewi≈øe hath beene farre greater then now it is, when the Place of our Engli≈øh-Saxon King ‚Ä¢
was therein ≈øet. And ≈øeeing it is the mid≈øt of the Shire, the Graduation from hence ≈øhall be ob≈øerued, where for Latitude the Pole is rai≈øed from the degree 51. 22. ≈øcruples: and her Longitude from the We≈øt in the degree 20. and 2. ≈øcruples.

(7) Neither can we account Okam and Ripley, two ≈ømall Villages, the lea≈øt in this Shire, which haue brought forth the well knowne men, William de Okam, that deepe Philo≈øopher, and admirable Scholar, and George de Ripley, the rung leader of our Alchymi≈øts and my≈øticall impo≈øtors; both of
them borne in this Countie, and very neere together. But why ≈øpeake I of the≈øe, ≈øith a place neerer to ≈øight, and greater for fame, euen Lambeth, is the High Seat of Eccle≈øia≈øticall Gouernment, Pietie, and Learning, and Palace of Canterburies Arch-bi≈øhops, the Metropolitan ‚Ä¢
of England. Fir≈øt erected by Archbi≈øhop Daldwin, and euer ≈øince hath beene the re≈øiding of all tho≈øe worthy Prelates of our Church, who in a long ≈øucce≈ø≈øion (euen from Anno 596) haue continued to him that now mo≈øt worthily ≈øits at the Churches ≈øterne, Richard by Gods prouidence Lord Archbi≈øhop of that See, a mo≈øt faithfull and prudent Coun≈øellor vnto King IAMES, and a mo≈øt learned and prouident Guide of our mo≈øt flouri≈øhing Church: who≈øe gracious fauour vnde≈øeruedly conferred vpon me, hath beene a great encouragement to the≈øe my poore endeuours.

(8) Memorable places for Battles ≈øought before the Conque≈øt, were Wembledon, where (when the fulne≈ø≈øe of pro≈øperitie bur≈øt forth into Ciuill Di≈ø≈øen≈øions among the Saxons) a bloudy Battle was fought betwixt Cheau ‚Ä¢ in the We≈øt-Saxon and young Ethelbert of Kent, wherein he was di≈øcomfited, and two of his principall Leaders ≈ølaine, about the yeare of Chri≈øt 560. and three hundred thirtie three yeares after, King Elfred with a ≈ømall power ouercame the Danes with a great ≈ølaughter at Faruham in this Countie, which ≈øomewhat quelled the courage of his ≈øauage enemy.

(9) Religious Hou≈øes erected in this Shire by the deuotion of Princes, and ≈øet apart ffom publike v≈øes to Gods Diuine Seruice, and their owne Saluation, as then was taught, the be≈øt in account were Sbene, Chert≈øey, Merton, Newarke, Rygate, Wauerley, Hor≈øleg; and in Southwarke, Bermund≈øey, and S. Maries. The≈øe all flouri≈øhed with increa≈øe, till the ripe ‚Ä¢ e≈ø≈øe of their fruit was ≈øo plea≈øing in ≈øight and ta≈øte vnto King HENRY the Eight, that in beating the boughes he brake downe body and all, ruinating tho≈øe hou≈øes, and ≈øeazing their rich po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions into his owne hands. So jealous is GOD of his honour; and ≈øo great vengeance followeth the ≈øinne of Idolatrie.

(10) In this Shire haue ≈øtood eight faire and ≈øtrong Ca≈øtles: ≈øuch were „Äà‚óä„Äâ , Darking, Starburg, Rygate, Guilford, Fara ‚Ä¢ am, Go≈øeford, and Brenchingley: but of greater State are Oking, O ‚Ä¢ lands, Non-≈øuch, and Richmond, his Maje≈øties royall Mannors. And for ≈øeruice to the Crowne or Common-wealths imployments, this Counties diui≈øion is into thirteene Hundreds, wherein are ≈øeated eight Market-Townes, and one hundred and fortie Pari≈øh-Churches.

div.head: HANT-SHIRE. CHAPTER VI.
div.p: HANT-SHIRE, lying vpon the We≈øt of England, Is bordered vpon the North by Bark≈øhire, vpon the Ea≈øt with Surrey and Su≈ø≈øex, vpon the South with the Briti≈øh Seas, and Ile of Wight, and vpon the We≈øt with Dor≈øet and Wilt-≈øhires.

(2) The length thereof from Blackwater in the North vpon Surrey, vnto Ba≈øcomb in the South vpon the Sea, extended in a right line, is fiftie foure Engli≈øh miles: and the breadth drawne from Peters-field in the Ea≈øt, vnto Tidworth in the We≈øt, and confines of Wilt-≈øhire, is little le≈ø≈øe then thirtie miles, the whole Circumference about one hundred fiftie and fiue miles.

(3) The Aire is temperate, though ≈øomewhat thicke by rea≈øon of the Seas, and the many Riuers that thorow the Shire doe fall, who≈øe plentie of fi≈øh and fruitfull increa≈øe, doe manifoldly redeeme the harmes which they make.
(4) The Soile is rich for Corne and Cattle, plea≈øant for pa≈øturage, and plenteous for woods; in a word, in all commodities either for Sea or Land, ble≈ø≈øed and happy.

(5) Hauens it hath, and tho≈øe commodious both to let in, and to loo≈øe out Ships of great burthen in trade of Merchandi≈øe, or other imployments: whereof Port≈ømouth, Tichfield, Hamble, and South-hampton are chiefe: be≈øides many other creeks that open their bo≈øomes into tho≈øe Seas, and the Coa≈øt ≈øtrengthned with many ≈øtrong Ca≈øtles, ≈øuch as Hur≈øt, Cal≈øhot, South-hampton, S. Andrewes, Worth, Porche≈øter, and the South Ca≈øtle, be≈øides other Bulwarkes, or Blockhou≈øes that ≈øecure the Country: and further in the Land, as Malwood, Winche≈øter, and Odiam, ≈øo ≈øtrong, that in the time of King Iohn, thirteene Engli≈øh-men onely defended the Fort for fifteene dayes again≈øt Lewis of France, that with a great Ho≈øt a≈ø≈øaulted it mo≈øt hotly.

(6) Anciently it was po≈ø≈øe≈øt vpon the North by the Segontians, who yeelded them≈øelues to Iulius Cae≈øar, and who≈øe chiefe Citie was Vindonum, Caer Segonte, now Silce≈øter; and vpon the South by the Belga, and Regni, who were ≈øubdued by Plau≈øius and Ve≈øpa≈øian the Romans, where Titus re≈øcuing his Father, ≈øtraitly be≈øieged by the Britaines, as Dio and Forcatulus doe report, was gra≈øped about with an Adder, but no hurt to his per≈øon, and therefore taken for a ≈øigne of good lucke. Their chiefe Towne was Rincewood, as yet ≈øounding the name: and more within Land inhabited the Manures, as Beda cals them, who≈øe Hundreds al≈øo to this day giue a reli≈øh of their names.

(7) Neere Ringwood, and the place once Y ‚Ä¢ EN ‚Ä¢ , from God and peoples ≈øeruice, to Bea≈øt and luxury, thirtie-≈øixe Pari≈øh-Churches were conuerted and pulled downe by the Conquerour, and thirtie miles of circuit inforre≈øted for his game of Hunting, wherein his ≈øonnes Richard and Rufus, with Henry the ≈øecond ≈øonne to Duke Robert, his fir≈øt, felt by ha≈øty death the hand of Iu≈øtice & Reuenge: for in the ≈øame Forre≈øt, Richard by bla≈øting of a pe≈øtilent ayre, Rufus by ≈øhot taken for a bea≈øt, and Henry as Ab≈øalom hanged by a bough, came to their vntimely ends At ≈øo deare a rate the plea≈øures of dogs, and harbour for bea≈øts were bought in the bloud of the≈øe Princes.

(8) The generall commodities gotten in this Shire, are Woolls, Clothes, and Iron, whereof great ≈øtore is therein wrought from the Mines, and thence tran≈øported into all parts of this Realme, and their Clothes and Kar≈øies carried into many forraine Countries, to that Countries great benefit, and Englands great pray≈øe.

(9) The Trade thereof, with other proui≈øions for the whole, are vented thorow eighteene Market-Townes in this Shire, whereof Winche≈øter, the Britaines Caer Gwent, the Romans Venta Belgarum, is chiefe, ancient enough by our Briti≈øh Hi≈øtorians, as built by King Rudhudibras, nine hundred yeares before the Natiuitie of Chri≈øt: and famous in the Romans times for the weauings and embroderies therein wrought, to the peculiar v≈øes of their Emperours owne per≈øons. In the Saxons time, after two
Calamities of con≈øuming fire, her walles was rai≈øed, and the Citie made the Royall Seate of their We≈øt-Saxons Kings, and the Metropolitan of their Bi≈øhops See, wherein Egbert and „Äà‚óä„Äâ their mo≈øt famous Monarchs were Crowned: and Henry the third, the Normans longe≈øt „Äà‚óä„Äâ , fir≈øt tooke breath: And here King Aethel≈øtane erected ≈øix hou≈øes for his Mint ‚Ä¢ but the Dani≈øh de≈øolution ouer-running all, this Citie felt their fury in the dayes of King Ethelbright, and in the Normans time, twice was defaced by the mi≈ø-fortune of fire, which they againe repaired and graced with the tru≈øt of keeping the publike Records of the Realme. In the ciuill warres of Maud and Stephen, this Citie was ≈øore ≈øacked, but againe receiuing breath, was by King Edward the third appointed the place for Mart of Wooll and Cloth. The Cathedrall Church built by Kenwolf King of the We≈øt-Saxons, that had beene Amphibalus, S. Peters, Swithins, and now holy Trinitie, is the Sanctuarie for the a≈øhes of many Engli≈øh Kings: for herein great Egbert, Anno 836. with his ≈øonne King Ethelwolfe, 857. Here Elfred, Oxfords founder, 901 with his Queene El≈øwith, 904. Here the fir≈øt Edmund before the Conque≈øt, 924. with his ≈øonnes Elfred and El≈øward: Here Edred, 955. and Edwy, 956 both Kings of England: Here Emme, 1052. with her Dani≈øh Lord Canute, 1035. and his ≈øonne Hardicanute, 1042. And here la≈øtly the Normans, Richard and Rufus, 1100. were interred; their bones by Bi≈øhop Fox were gathered and ≈øhrined in little guilt coffers fixed vpon a wall in the Quire, where ≈øtill they remaine carefully pre≈øerued.

This Cities ≈øituation is fruitfull and plea≈øant, in a vally vnder hils, hauing her River on the Ea≈øt, and Ca≈øtle on the We≈øt, the circuit of who≈øe walls are well neere two Engli≈øh miles, containing one thou≈øand eight hundred and eightie paces; thorow which openeth ≈øixe gates for entrance, and therein are ≈øeauen Churches for diuine Seruice, be≈øides the Mini≈øter, and tho≈øe decayed; ≈øuch as Callender,
‚Ä¢ uell Chappell, S. Maries Abbey, and the Friers, without in the Suburbes, and Soo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ; in the Ea≈øt is S. Peters, and in the North Hyde Church and Mona≈øterie, who≈øe ruines remaining, ≈øhew the beautie
that formerly it bare. The Graduation of this Citie by the Mathematickes, is placed for Latitude in the degree 51. 10. minutes, and for Longitude 19. 3. minutes.

(10) More South, is South-hampton, a Towne populous, rich and beautifull, from whom the whole Shire deriueth her name, mo≈øt ≈øtrongly walled about with ≈øquare ≈øtone, containing in circuit, one thou≈øand and two hundred paces, hauing ≈øeauen Gates for entrance, and twentie-nine Towres for defence, two very ≈øtately Keyes for Ships arriuage, and fiue faire Churches for Gods diuine ≈øeruice, be≈øides an Ho≈øpitall, called G ‚Ä¢ ds hou≈øe, wherein the vnfortunate Richard, Earle of Cambridge, beheaded for trea≈øon, lieth interred. On the We≈øt of this Towne is mounted a mo≈øt beautifull Ca≈øtle, in forme Circular, and wall within wall, the foundation vpon a hill ≈øo topped, that it cannot be a≈øcended but by ≈øtaires, carrying a goodly pro≈øpect both by Land and Sea, and in the Ea≈øt without the walles a goodly Church ≈øometimes ≈øtood, called S Maries, which was pulled downe, for that it gaue the French direction of cour≈øe, who with fire had greatly endangered the Towne: in ≈øtead thereof, is newly erected a ≈ømall and vnfini≈øhed Chappell. In this place, ≈øaith learned Cambden, ≈øtood the ancient Clau≈øentium, or fort of the Romans, who≈øe circuit on that ≈øide extended it ≈øelfe to the Sea: this ≈øuffered many depredations by the Saxon Pirates, and in Anno 980. was by the Danes almo≈øt quite ouerthrowne. In King Edward the thirds time, it was fired by the French, vnder the Conduct of the King of Sicils ≈øonne, whom a Country man encountred and ≈øtrucke downe with his Club, He crying Rancon, that is, Ran≈øome: but he neither vnder≈øtanding his language, nor the Law that Armes doth allow, laid on more ≈øoundly, ≈øaying: I know thee a Frankon, and therefore ≈øhalt thou dit: and in Richard the ≈øeconds time it was ≈øomewhat remoued, and built in the place where now it ≈øtandeth In this Clau≈øentium, Canute to euict his flatterers, made triall of his Deitie, commanding the Seas to keepe backe from his ≈øeat: but being not obeyed, he acknowledged God to be the onely ≈øupreame Gouernour, and in a religious deuotion gaue vp his Crowne to the Rood at Winche≈øter.
More ancient was Silce≈øter, built by Con≈øtantius, great Con≈øtantines ≈øonne, who≈øe Monument (they ≈øay) was ≈øeene in that Citie, and where another Con≈øtantine put on the purple roabe again≈øt Hono
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , as both Ni ‚Ä¢ ius and Gerua≈øe of Canterbury doe witne≈ø≈øe. Herein by our Hi≈øtorians record, the warlike Arthur was Crowned. Who≈øe greatne≈ø≈øe for circuit contained no le≈ø≈øe then foure≈øcore Acres of ground, and the walles of great height, yet ≈øtanding two miles in compa≈ø≈øe about. This Citie by the Dani≈øh Rouers ≈øuffred ≈øuch wracke, that her mounted tops were neuer ≈øince ≈øeene, and her Hulke (the wals) in mured to the middle in the earth, which the rubbi≈øh of her owne de≈øolations hath filled.

(11) Chiefe Religious hou≈øes within this Countie erected and againe ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed were the≈øe, Chri≈øts-Church, Beautieu, Whorwell, Rum≈øey, Redbridge, Winche≈øter, Hyde, South-hampton, and Tichfield. The honour of this Shire is dignified with the high Titles of Marques, and them Earles of Winche≈øter and South-hampton; who≈øe Armes of Families are as thou ≈øee ‚Ä¢ t, and her diui≈øion into thirtie ≈øeauen Hundreds, and tho≈øe againe into two hundred fiftie three Pari≈øhes.

div.head: VVIGHT ILAND. CHAPTER VII.
div.p: VVIGHT ILAND was in times pa≈øt named by the Romans Vecta, Vectis, and Vecte≈øis, by the Britaines, Guyth, and in the≈øe dayes v≈øually called by vs, The Ile of Wight. It belongeth to the Countrie of South-hampton, and lyeth out in length ouer again≈øt the mid≈øt of it South-ward. It is encompa≈ø≈øed round with the Briti≈øh. Seas, and ≈øeuered from the Maine land. that it may ≈øeeme to haue beene conjoyned to it, and thereof it is thought the Britti≈øh name (Guyth) hath beene giuen vnto it, which betokeneth ≈øeparation, euen as „Äà‚óä„Äâ being broken off and cut from Italy, got the name from Secando (which ≈øignifieth cutting.)

(2) The forme of this I≈øle is long, and in the midde≈øt farre more wide then at eyther end: from
„Äà‚óä„Äâ Ile in the „Äà‚óä„Äâ , to „Äà‚óä„Äâ Ca≈øtle in the We≈øt it ≈øtretcheth out in length 20. miles, and in
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Northward, to „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Southward 12. miles. The whole in circumference
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ .

(3) The ay ‚Ä¢ e is commended both for health and delight, whereof the fir≈øt is witne≈ø≈øed by the
„Äà‚óä„Äâ continuance of the Inhabitants in the ≈øtate of then bodies before they be decayed, and the other for quantitie giues place to no neighbouring Country.

(4) The ground (to ≈øay nothing of the Sea, which is exceeding full of fi≈øh) con≈øi≈øteth of ≈øoile very fruitfull; yet the husbandmans labour de≈øerues to be thankfully remembred, by who≈øe paines and indu≈øtry it doth not onely ≈øupply it ≈øelfe, but affords ‚Ä¢ orne to be carryed forth to others. The ‚Ä¢ and is plenteou≈øly ≈øtored with Cattle and Graine, and breeds euery where ≈øtore of Conies,
Hares, Patridges and Phe≈øants, plea≈øant for medow, pa≈øturage, and Parkes; ≈øo that nothing is wanting that may ≈øuffice man. The midde≈øt yeelds plentie of pa≈øture; and forrage for Sheepe; who≈øe wooll the Clothiers e≈øteeme the be≈øt; next vnto that of Lein≈øter and Cotte≈øwold: If you ca≈øt your eyes towards the North, it is all ouer garni≈øhed with Meadowes, Pa≈øtures, and Woods: If towards the South ≈øide, it lyeth (in a manner) wholy bedecked with Cornefields enclo≈øed, where at each end the Sea doth ≈øo incroach ‚Ä¢ t ≈øelfe. that it maketh almo≈øt two Ilands be≈øides, namely, Fre≈øhwater I≈øle, which looketh to the We≈øt, and B ‚Ä¢ nbridge i≈øle an≈øwering it to the Ea≈øt.

(5) The Commodities of the whole chiefly con≈øi≈øt of Cattle, Sea fowle, Fi≈øh, and Corne, whereof it hath ≈øufficient: Woods are not here very plentifull; for that it is onely ≈øtored with one little Forre≈øt; yet the Country of Ham≈øhire for vicinitie of Site, is a friendly neighbour in that behalfe; ≈øo (as it were being tyed together in affinitie) they are alwayes readie, and propen≈øe to adde to each others wants and defects by a mutuall ≈øupply.

(6) The ancient Inhabitants of this Iland were the Belga, ≈øpoken of in the ≈øeuerall Prouinces of S ‚Ä¢ mer≈øet-≈øhire, Wilt-≈øhire, and Ham≈øhire. Such as did then po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe it were called Lords of the I≈øle of wight, till it fell into the Kings hands, by R ‚Ä¢ ger (Sonne to William Fits Osburne, ≈ølaine in the warre of Flanders) that was driuen into exile. And Henry the fir≈øt King of England gaue it vnto Richard Riduers, with the ≈øee or Inheritance of the Towne of Chri≈øts-Church, where (at in all other places) he built certaine Fortre≈øtes.

(7) The principall Market-Towne in the I≈øle is Newport, called in times pa≈øt Medena, and Novus Burgus de Meden; that is, the new Burgh of Meden, whereof the whole Countrey is diuided into Ea≈øt-Meden, and We≈øt Meden. A Towne well ≈øeated, and much frequented; vnto who≈øe Burge≈øles his Maje≈øtie hath lately granted the choy≈øe of a Major, who with his Brethren, doe gouerne accordingly. It is populous with Inhabitants, hauing an entrance into the I≈øle from the Hauen, and a
pa≈ø≈øage for Ve≈ø≈øels of ≈ømall burden vnto the Key. Not farre from it is the Ca≈øtle Caresbrooke, who≈øe founder is ≈øaid to haue beene Whitgar the Saxon, and from him called White-Garesburgh: but now made ≈øhorter for ea≈øier pronunciation; the graduation whereof for Latitude is in the degree 50. 36. minutes: and her Longitude in 19. 4. minutes, where, formerly hath ≈øtood a Priory, and at Quarre a Nunnery; a nece≈ø≈øary neighbour to tho≈øe Penitentiaries. And yet in their merry mood, the Inhabitants of this Iland doe boa≈øt, that they were happier then their neighbour Countries, for that they neuer had Monke that euer wore hood, Lawyers that cauilled, nor Foxes that were craftie.

(8) It is reported, that in the yeare of mans ≈øaluation, 1176. and twentie-three of King Henry the ≈øecond, that in this Iland it rained a ≈øhowre of bloud, which continued for the ≈øpace of 2 houres together to the great wonder and amazement of the people that beheld it with feare.

(9) This I≈øle of Wight is fortified both by Art and Nature: for be≈øides the ≈øtrength of Artificiall Forts and Blocke-hou≈øes (wherewith it is well furni≈øhed) it wants not the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of naturall Fences, as being enriched with a continuall ridge and range of craggy Cliffes and Rockes, and Bankes very dangerous for Saylers, as the Needles, ≈øo called by rea≈øon of their ≈øharpne≈ø≈øe: The Shingles, Mixon, Brambles, &c.

(10) Ve≈øpa≈øian was the fir≈øt that brought it to the ≈øubiection of the Romaenes, while≈øt he ≈øerued as a priuate per≈øon vnder Claudius Cae≈øar. And Cerdic was the fir≈øt Engli≈øh Saxon that ≈øubdued it, who granting it vnto S ‚Ä¢ uffe and Whitgar, they joyntly together ≈ølew (almo≈øt) all the Britti≈øh Inhabitants (being but few of them, there remaining) in the Towne afore≈øaid, called of his Name Whitgaresburgh. Wolpher King of the Merciam reduced this Iland afterwards vnder his obedience, and at that time when he became God-father to Edelwalch King of the South-Saxons, and an≈øwered for him at his Bapti≈øme; he a≈ø≈øigned it ouer vnto him, with the Prouince al≈øo of the Menuari. But when
Edelwalch was ≈ølaine, and Aruandus the petty King of the Iland was made away, Coedwalla King of the We≈øt-Saxons annexed it to his Dominion, and in a tragicall and lamentable Ma≈ø≈øacre put to the ≈øword (almo≈øt) euery mothers childe of the in-borne Inhabitants.

The thing that is be≈øt worthy note and ob≈øeruation is this, That Bi≈øhop Wilfrid was the fir≈øt that in≈øtructed the Inhabitants of this Iland in Chri≈øtian Religion, and brought them from Idolatrous Super≈øtition, with the which (vnto that time) they were ob≈øcurely blinded.

For Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iuri≈ødiction, this Countrey belongeth to the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter, and for Ciuill gouernment to the Countie of South-hampton. It is fortified with the ≈øtrength of ≈øixe Ca≈øtles, traded with three Market-Townes, and hath 36. Pari≈øh-Churches planted in it.

div.head: DORCESTER-SHIRE. CHAPTER VIII.
div.p: DORCESTER, from her ancient people DVROTRIGES, is mo≈øt likely to haue receiued that name: by the Britaines called DVVRGVVEIR, lyeth bounded vpon the North-≈øide with Somer≈øet and W ‚Ä¢ lt-≈øhire; vpon the We≈øt with D ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øhire, and ≈øome part with Somer≈øet; vpon the Ea≈øt altogether with Hamp≈øhire: and her South part is wholly bounded with the Briti≈øh Seas.

(2) The forme growes wider from the We≈øt, and ≈øpreads her ≈øelfe the broade≈øt in the mid≈øt, where it extends to twentie-foure miles, but in length is no le≈ø≈øe then fortie-foure: the whole in Circumference about, is one hundred and fiftie miles.

(3) The ayre is good, and of an healthfull con≈øtitution: the ≈øoyle is fat, affording many commodities, and the Countrey mo≈øt plea≈øant in her ≈øituation: for the In-land is watered with many ≈øweet and fre≈øh running Springs, which taking pa≈ø≈øage thorow the plaine Vallies, doe la≈øtly in a louing manner vnite them≈øelues together, and of their many branches make many bigge bodied ≈øtreames: neither doth the Sea deny them entrance, but helpeth rather to fill vp their Bankes, whereby Ve≈ø≈øels of burden di≈øcharge their rich Trea≈øures, and her ≈øelfe with open hand di≈øtributeth her gifts all along the South of this Shore.

(4) Anciently it was po≈ø≈øe≈øt by the Durotriges, whom Ptolemie placeth along in this Tract, who being ≈øubdued by the Romans, yeelded them roome, and vnwilling ≈øubiection. After them the Saxons ≈øet foot in the≈øe parts, whereof Portland ≈øeemeth from that Port to take name, who in this place arriued in Anno 703. and did ≈øorely infe≈øt and annoy all the South Tract. And at Bindon before him
Kinegillus King of the We≈øt-Saxons, in the yeare of Chri≈øt 614. in a doubtfull and dangerous Battle vanqui≈øhed the Britaines Neither were the Saxons ≈øo ≈øurely herein ≈øeated, but that the Danes ≈øought to defeat them thereof: for twice the≈øe bold Rouers landed at Chartmouth, the fir≈øt was in Anno 831. and raigne of King Egbert; and the other eight yeares after, when Ethelwulfe was King: in both which they went away Victors. Yet when the Iron-≈øide wore the Engli≈øh Diademe, and the≈øe fierce people ≈øought to plucke it from his Helmet, he met them at Pen ham in Gillingham Forre≈øt, and with a ≈ømall power obtained a great victory, cau≈øing their King Canute with di≈øcourage to retire.

(5) Commodities ari≈øing in this Countie are chiefly Wools and Woods in her North, where the Forre≈øts are ≈øtored with the one, and the plea≈øant greene Hilles with the other. The inner part is ouer-≈øpread both with Corne and Gra≈ø≈øe, and the Sea yeeldeth the I≈øidis Plocamos, a Shrub growing not vnlike the Corrall without any leafe; be≈øides her other gifts, turning all to great gaine: which the more is made manife≈øt by the many Market. Townes in this Shire, whereof Dorche≈øter is the chiefe, in Antonius his „Äà‚óä„Äâ termed Durnouaria, ≈øituated vpon the South ≈øide of Frome, and the „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ called
‚Ä¢ o≈ø≈øe-way, wherein ≈øome of their L ‚Ä¢ gions kept, a, by the Rampiers and Coines there daily digged vp is probably coniectured; at which time it ≈øeemeth the Citie was walled, whereof ≈øome part yet ≈øtandeth, e≈øpecially vpon the We≈øt and South ≈øides, and the Tract and Trench mo≈øt apparent in a Quadrant-wi≈øe almo≈øt meeteth the Riuer, containing in circuit one thou≈øand and ≈øeuen hundred pa≈øes, but were ca≈øt downe by the Danes, who≈øe tran ‚Ä¢ pling feete de≈øtroyed all things where≈øoeuer they came, and hands here razed the Trenches Mandbury and Poundbury, the≈øeales of their Siege, and ≈øignes of times mi≈øerie. About three hundred pa≈øes Southward from hence, ≈øtandeth an old Fortification of Earth, trenched about, and mounted aboue the ordinary plaine, thirtie pa≈øes, containing ≈øome fiue Acres of ground; wherein (at my there-being) plentie of Corne grew. This the Inhabitants call The Maiden-Ca≈øtle, hauing entrance thereunto onely vpon the Ea≈øt and
We≈øt This is thought to haue beene a Summer-Campe or Station of the Romans, when their Garri≈øons kept the Frontiers of this Prouince.

The gouernment of this City is yearely committed to two Bailiffes, elected out of eight Magi≈øtrates or Aldermen, a Recorder, Towr ‚Ä¢ -Clerke, and two Sergeants attending them: whence the North-pole is eleuated 50. degrees 48. minutes in Latitude, and for Longitude is remooued from the fir≈øt We≈øt-point vnto the Meridian of 18. degrees.

(6) Other places al≈øo are memorable through the actions therein happening, or antiquities there yet remaining: ≈øuch is Badbury, now nothing but a Trench and decayed Ca≈øtle, hardly ≈øeene, though ≈øometimes it was the Court of the We≈øt-Saxons Kings. Such al≈øo is Cerne, where Augu≈øtine the Engli≈øh Apo≈øtle brake downe the Altars and Idols of the Saxons God HELL, whom they deuoutly honoured as the onely con≈øeruer of their health. Shaftesbury al≈øo, wherein one Aquila (whether a Man or Eagle I know not) by our Hi≈øtorians report, is ≈øaid to haue prophecied the future times of this our Empire, and that after the raignes of the Saxons and Norman‚ñ™ it ≈øhould againe returne vnto the gouernment of the Briti≈øh Kings. But with ≈øuch vaine predictions our Nation is more then once taxed by Philip „Äà‚óä„Äâ
the famous French Writer. In this Citie Edward the ≈øonne of great Edgar, and one and thirtieth Monarch of the Engli≈øh-men, was interred, being murdered at Corfe, a Ca≈øtle ≈øeated in the Ile of Purbeck, by his Step-mother Aelfrith, to make way for her ≈øonne to enioy his Crowne: in repentance whereof, and to pacifie Heauen for his bloud, ≈øhe built the Mona≈øteries of Ambresbury and Whorwell, in the Countie of Wilt-≈øhire and South-Hamton. In the former of which with great penitency ≈øhe ≈øpent the re≈øt of her life.

(7) As vpon the like occa≈øion the Mona≈øtery of Middleton was laied in this Shire by King Ethel≈øtan to appea≈øe the Gho≈øt of Edwine his innocent brother, and to expiate the ≈øinne of his owne ≈øoule for the bloud of that iu≈øt Prince, whom mo≈øt vniu≈øtly he cau≈øed to die: and with the like deuotion,
though not to ≈øatisfie for the like blo ‚Ä¢ die ≈øinnes‚ñ™ did Queene Cuthbarga ≈øue a Diuorce from her ≈øecond husband the Northumberlands King, and it Winburne built her a Nunnery, whereof her ≈øelfe bec ‚Ä¢ me Abbe≈ø≈øe, where afterward was rai≈øed a mo≈øt ≈øtately Min≈øter, which added not onely more glory to the place, but withall enlarged the name, and made it to be called Wimburn-min≈øter, where King Ethel ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . a mo≈øt vertuous Prince, after much di≈øqu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ne≈ø≈øe had with the Danes, in peace here re≈øteth, with his Tombe and In≈øcription, as in his Hi≈øtory (Chri≈øt a≈ø≈øi≈øting) ≈øhall be further ≈øeene. Neither among the≈øe may I omit Sherburne, which in the yeare of grace 704. was made a Bi≈øhops See, in who≈øe Cathedrall Church were interred the bodies of Ethelbald and Ethelbert, brethren, both of them Monarkes of the Engli≈øh-men.

(8) Seuen more be≈øides the≈øe were ≈øet apart from worldly imployments, con≈øecrated onely to God and his ≈øeruice in this Shire; which were Came≈øtern, Cranborn, Ab ‚Ä¢ ottesbury, Bindon, Sturmi≈øter, Tarrant, and Warham The≈øe with the others came to their full period vnder the hand of King Henry the Eight, which lay with ≈øuch waight vpon their fai ‚Ä¢ e buildings, that he cru≈øhed the iuyce thereof into his owne Coffers.

(9) Ca≈øtles for defence in repaire and decayed, were at Sherburne, Dorche≈øter, Brank≈øey, Portland, Corfe, Newton, Woodford. and Wareham. So that with the≈øe and others the County hath beene ≈øtrengthned with twelue Religious Hou≈øes, their poore relieued, with eighteene Market-Townes at this day is traded, and principally into fiue diui≈øions parted, ≈øubdiuided into thirtie-foure Hundreds, and them againe into two hundred fortie-eight Pari≈øhes.

div.head: DEVON-SHIRE. CHAPTER IX.
div.p: DEVON-SHIRE, by the Corni≈øh Britaines called Deuinan; and by contraction of the vulgar Den≈øhire, is not deriued from the Danes, as ≈øome would haue it, but from the people Danmonij, the ≈øame we will ≈øpeake of in Cornwall, and whom Ptolemie hath ≈øeated in the≈øe We≈øterne Borders.

(2) The We≈øt of this County is bounded altogether by the Riuer Tamar: the Ea≈øt is held in with the verge of Somer≈øet-≈øhire: and the North and South ≈øides are wa≈øhed wholy with the Briti≈øh and Severne Seas: Betwixt who≈øe ≈øhoares from Cun≈øhere in the North, vnto Salcombe Hauen entering in at the South, are fiftie fiue miles: and from the Hartland Point We≈øt, to Thorncombe Ea≈øt, are fiftie foure: the whole Circumference about two hundred and two miles.

(3) The Ayre is ≈øharpe, healthfull and good: the Soile is hilly, wooddy and fruitfull, yet ≈øo as the hand of the Manurer mu≈øt neuer be idle, nor the pur≈øe of the Farmer neuer fa≈øt ≈øhut, e≈øpecially of them that are farre from the Sea, whence they fetch a ≈øand with charge and much trauell, which being ≈øpread vpon the face of the earth, bettereth the leanne≈ø≈øe thereof for graine, and giueth life to the Glebe with great efficacy.

(4) As Cornwall, ≈øo this hath the ≈øame commodities that ari≈øe from the Seas: and being more inlanded hath more commodious Hauens for Sh ‚Ä¢ ppings entercour≈øe, among whom Totnes is famous for Brutes fir≈øt entrance, if Geffry ≈øay true, or if Hau ‚Ä¢ llan the Poet tooke not a Poeticall libertie, when ≈øpeaking of Brute, he wrote thus:
The Gods did guide his ≈øayle and cour≈øe: the winds were at command:
And Totnes was the happie ≈øhoare where fir≈øt he came on land.
