But with more credit and lamentable euent, the Danes at Teigne-mouth fir≈øt entred for the inua≈øion of this Land, about the yeare of Chri≈øt 787. vnto whom Brightrik King of the We≈øt-Saxons ≈øent the Steward of his hou≈øe to know their intents, whom re≈øi≈øtantly they ≈ølew: yet were they forced backe to their Ships by the Inhabitants, though long they ≈øtayed not, but eagerly pur≈øued their begun enterpri≈øes‚ñ™

With more happie ≈øucce≈ø≈øe hath Plimouth ≈øet forth the purcha≈øers of ≈øame, and ≈øtopped the entrance of Englands Inuaders, as in the Raigne of that eternized Queene, the mirrour of Princes, Elizabeth of euerla≈øting memory: for from this Port Sir Francis Drake, that potent man at Sea, ≈øetting forth Anno 1577 in the ≈øpace of two yeares and ten moneths did compa≈ø≈øe the circle of the earth by Sea. And the Lord Charles Howard, Englands high Admirall, did not onely from hence impeach the entrance of the proud inuincible Spani≈øh Nauy, intending inua≈øion and ≈øubuer≈øion of State, but with his Bullets ≈øo ≈øigned their pa≈ø≈øage; that their ≈øides did well ≈øhew in who≈øe hands they had beene, as ≈øeales of their owne ≈øhame, and his high honour.

(5) The commodities of this Shire con≈øi≈øt much in Wools and Clothings, where the be≈øt and fine≈øt Ker≈øies are made in the Land Corne is mo≈øt plenteous in the fruitfull Vallies, and Cattle ≈øpreading vpon the topped Hils; Sea Fi≈øh and Fowle exceedingly abundant. Veynes of Lead, yea and ≈øome of Siluer in this Shire are found: and the Load-≈øtone (not the lea≈øt for v≈øe and e≈øteeme) from the Rocks vpon Dart-more hath beene taken Many fre≈øh Springs doe bubble from the Hils in this Prouince, which with a longing de≈øire of Socretie ≈øearch out their pa≈ø≈øage, till they meete and conjoyne in the Vallies, and gathering ≈øtill ≈øtrength with more branches, la≈øtly grow bodyed able to beare Ships into the Land, and to lodge them of great burthen in their Bo≈øomes or Fals: whereof Tamar, Taue, and Ex are the faire≈øt and mo≈øt commodious‚ñ™

(6) Vpon which la≈øt the chiefe Citie and Shire-Towne of this Countie is ≈øeated, and from that
Riuer hath her name Exce≈øter: this Citie by Ptolemie is called I≈ø ‚Ä¢ a; by the „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
Emperour, I≈ø ‚Ä¢ a Danmoniorum; and by the We ≈øo „Äà‚óä„Äâ . It is plea≈øantly ≈øeated vpon the gentle ‚Ä¢ ≈øcent of an hill, ≈øo ≈øtately for building, ≈øo rich with „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ≈øtrangers, that a man can de≈øire nothing but
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . The walls of this Citie fir≈øt built by King „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ but towards the Ex rangeth almo≈øt in a ≈øtraight line hauing ≈øix Gates for entrance, and many „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
betwixt, who≈øe compa≈ø≈øe containeth about fifteene hundred paces: vpon the Ea≈øt part of this Citie ≈øtandeth a Ca≈øtle called Rugemont, ≈øometimes the Palace of the We≈øt-Saxon Kings, and after them of the Earles of Cornwall, who≈øe pro≈øpect is plea≈øant vnto the „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ magnificent Cathedrall Church, founded by King Athel≈øtan al≈øo, in the honour of S. Peter, and by Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor made the Bi≈øhops See, which the remoued from „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ in this Countie vnto the Citie of Exce≈øter (as ≈øaith the priuate Hi≈øtory of that place:) who≈øe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ apidations the reuerend Father in God William now Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe with great co≈øt hath repaired; whom I may not name without a mo≈øt thankfull remembrance for the great benefits receiued by his carefull prouidence toward me and mine. This Citie was ≈øo ≈øtrong and ≈øo well ≈øtored of Britaines, that they held out again≈øt the Saxons for 465. yeares after their fir≈øt entrance, and was not ab≈øolutely „Äà‚óä„Äâ vntill Athel≈øtan became Monarch of the whole, who then peopled it with his Saxons, and „Äà‚óä„Äâ the beautie thereof with many faire buildings: but in the times of the Dani≈øh de≈øolations this Citie with the re≈øt, felt their de≈øtroying hands; for in the yeare 875. it was by them fore afflicted, ≈øpoyled, and ≈øhaken, and that mo≈øt grieuou≈øly by Swane in the yeare of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus 1003. who razed it downe from Ea≈øt to We≈øt, ≈øo that ≈øcarcely had it gotten breath before William the ba≈øtard of Normandy be≈øieged it, again≈øt whom the Citizens with great manhood ≈øerued, till a part of the wall fell downe of it ≈øelfe, and that by the hand of Gods prouidence, ≈øaith mine Author: ≈øince when it hath beene
three times be≈øieged, and with valiant re≈øi≈øtance euer defended. The fir≈øt was by Hugh Courtney, Earle of Deuen≈øhire, in the Ciuill broyles betwixt Lanca≈øter and Yorke: then by Perbin Warbeck, that counterfeited Richard Duke of Yorke: and la≈øtly, by the Corni≈øh Rebels, wherein although the Citizens were grieuou≈øly pinched with ≈øcar≈øitie, yet continued they their faithfull allegeance vnto King Edward the ≈øixt; and at this day flouri≈øheth in tranquillitie and wealth, being gouerned by a Major, twentie-foure Brethren, with a Recorder, Towne-Clerke, and other Officers their Attendants. This Cities graduation is ≈øet in the degree of Latitude from the North-Pole 50. and 45. ≈øcruples: and for Longitude from the We≈øt, to the degree 16. and 25. ≈øcruples. Neither is Io≈øeph that excellent Poet, who≈øe birth was in this Citie, the lea≈øt of her Ornaments, who≈øe Writings bare ≈øo great credit, that they were divulged in the Germane language vnder the name of Cornelius Nepos.
The like credit got Crediton in her birth-child Winefred the Apo≈øtle of the Ha≈øsians, Thuringers, and Fri≈øians of Germany, which were conuerted by him vnto the Go≈øpell and knowledge of Chri≈øt.

(7) Places memorable in this Countie remaining for ≈øignes of Battles, or other antiquities are the≈øe: vpon Exmore certaine Monuments of Anticke-worke are erected, which are ≈øtones pitched in order, ≈øome triangle-wi≈øe, and ≈øome in round compa≈ø≈øe: the≈øe no doubt were trophies of victories there obtained, eyther by the Romans, Saxons, or Danes, and with Dani≈øh letters one of them is in≈øcribed, giuing direction to ≈øuch as ≈øhould trauell that way. Huble≈øtowe likewi≈øe neere vnto the mouth of Tawe, was the buriall place of Hubba the Dane, who with his Brother Hungar, had harried the Engli≈øh in diuers parts of the Land: but la≈øtly was there encountred with, and ≈ølaine by this Shires Inhabitants, and vnder a heape of copped ≈øtones interred, and the Banner Rea≈øen there and then taken, that had ≈øo often beene ≈øpread in the Danes quarrell, and wherein they repo≈øed no ≈ømall confidence for ≈øucce≈ø≈øe.

(8) A double dignitie remaineth in this Countie, where Princes of State haue borne the Titles both of Deuon≈øhire and Exce≈øter: of which Citie, there haue beene entituled Dukes, the la≈øt of whom, namely, Henry Holland, Grand-childe to Iohn Holland, halfe-brother to King Richard the ≈øecond; ≈øiding with Lanca≈øter again≈øt Edward the fourth, who≈øe Si≈øter was his wife, was driuen to ≈øuch mi≈øery, as Philip Comineus reporteth, that he was ≈øeene all torne and bare-footed to beg his liuing in the Low Countries: and la≈øtly, his body was ca≈øt vpon the ≈øhore of Kent (as if he had peri≈øhed by ≈øhipwracke) ≈øo vncertaine is Fortune in her endowments, and the ≈øtate of man, notwith≈øtanding his great birth.
(9) Religious hou≈øes in this Shire built in deuotion, and for Idolatry pulled downe, were at Exce≈øter, Torbay, Tanton, Taue≈øtoke, Kirton, Ford, Hartland, Axmi≈øter, and Ber≈øtable.
(10) And the Counties diui≈øions are parted into thirtie-three Hundreds, wherein are ≈øeated thirtie-≈øeauen Market-Townes, and three hundred ninetie foure Pari≈øh-Churches.

div.head: CORNWALL. CHAPTER X.
div.p: CORNWALL (as Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter affirmeth) is ≈øo named partly from the forme, and partly from her people: for ≈øhooting it ≈øelfe into the Sea like a Horne (which the Britaines call Kerne) and inhabited by them whom the Saxons named Willia; of the≈øe two compounded words it became Cornwallia. Not to trouble the Reader with the Fable of Corineus, cou≈øin to King Brute, who in free gift receiued this Countie in reward of his prowe≈ø≈øe, for wra≈øtling with the Grant Gogmagog, and breaking his necke from the Cliffe of Deuer, as ‚Ä¢ e of Monmouth hath fabuled.

(2) Touching the temperature of this Countie, the ayre thereof is clean≈øed as with Bellowes, by the Billowes that euer worke from o ‚Ä¢ t her enuironing Seas, where thorow it becommeth pure and ≈øubtill, and is made thereby very healthfull, but withall ≈øo „Äà‚óä„Äâ and ≈øhar ‚Ä¢ e, that it is apter to pre≈øerue then to recouer health. The ≈øpring is not ≈øo early as in the more Ea≈øterne parts; yet the Summer with a temperate heat recompenceth his ≈ølow fo≈øtering of the fruits, with their mo≈øt kindly ripening. The Autumne bringeth a ≈øomewhat late harue≈øt: and the Winter, by rea≈øon of the Seas warme breath, maketh the cold milder then el≈øe-where. Notwith≈øtanding that Countrey is much ≈øubiect to ≈øtormy bla≈øts, who ‚Ä¢ e violence hath freedome from the open waues, to beat vpon the dwellers at Land, leauing many times their hou≈øes vncouered.

(3) The Soile for the mo≈øt part is lifted vp into many hilles, parted a ≈øunder with narrow and ≈øhort vallies, and a ≈øhallow earth doth couer their out-≈øide, which by a Sea-weede called Orewood, and a certaine kinde of fruitfull Sea-≈øand, they make ≈øo ranke and batten, as is vncredible. But more are
the riches that out of tho≈øe hilles are gotten from the Mines of Copper and Tinne; which Countrey was the fir≈øt, and continueth the be≈øt ≈øtored in that Merchandize, of any in the world Timaeus the Hi≈øtorian in Plinie reporteth, that the Britaines fetched their Tinne in wicker-boats, ≈øtitched about with Leather And D ‚Ä¢ octo ‚Ä¢ us „Äà‚óä„Äâ
of Augu≈øtus Cae≈øars time writeth, that the Britaines in this part digged Tinne out of „Äà‚óä„Äâ ground, which by Merchants was carried into Gallia, and thence to Narborne, as it were to a Ma ‚Ä¢ : Which how≈øoeuer the Engli≈ø-Saxons neglected, yet the Normans made great benefit thereof, e≈øpecially Richard brother to King Henry the third, who was Earle of Cornwall, and by tho≈øe Tinne- „Äà‚óä„Äâ
became exceedingly rich: for the in ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øions of the Mo ‚Ä¢ res hauing ≈øtopped vp the Tinne-Mines
„Äà‚óä„Äâ , and them in Germany not di≈øcouered before the yeare of Chri≈øt 1240. the≈øe in Cornwall
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ the want in all parts of the world. This Earle made certaine Tinne-Lawes, which with liberties and priuiledges were confirmed by Earle Edmund his ≈øonne. And in the dayes of King Ed
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
the third the Common-weale of Tinne-workes from one body was diuided into foure, and a
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ of the Stan ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rs appointed then Iudge.

(4) The Borders of this Shire on all parts but the Ea≈øt is bound in with the Sea: and had Tamer
„Äà‚óä„Äâ his cour≈øe but foure miles further to the North, betwixt this Countie and Deuon≈øhire, it might haue beene rather accounted an Iland, then ≈øtood with the May ‚Ä¢ e Her length is from Laun≈øton to the „Äà‚óä„Äâ , containing by mea≈øure 60 miles: and the broade≈øt part, ≈øtretching along by the Tamer, is fully fortie, l ‚Ä¢ ≈ø ‚Ä¢ ening thence ≈øtill le≈ø≈øer like a horne.

(5) The ancient Inhabitants knowne to the Romans, were the Danmonij, that ≈øpread them≈øelues
„Äà‚óä„Äâ into Deuon≈øhire al≈øo, by the report of Diodorus Siculus, a mo≈øt courteous and ciuill people: and by Mechael their Poet extolled for
„Äà‚óä„Äâ and ≈øtrength of lim ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ es: nor therein doth he take the libertie that Poets are allowed, to adde to the ≈øubiect whereof they write, but truly reporteth what we ≈øee by them performed, whom actiuitie ≈øurmount many other people.

When the Heathen Saxons had ≈øeated them≈øelues in the be≈øt of this Land, and forced the Chri≈øtian Britaines into the≈øe rockie parts, then did Cornwall abound in Saints, vnto who≈øe honor mo≈øt of the Churches were erected, by who≈øe names they are yet knowne and called. To ≈øpeake nothing of Vr≈øula that Counties Dukes daughter, with her company of canonized Virgin-Saints, that are now reputed but to trouble the Calendar. The≈øe Britaines in Cornwall ≈øo fenced the Countrey, and defended them≈øelues, that to the raigne of King Athel≈øtant they held out again≈øt the Saxons, who ≈øubduing tho≈øe We≈øtern Parts, made Tamar the Bounder betwixt them and his Engli≈øh, who≈øe la≈øt Earle of the Briti≈øh Bloud was called Candorus.

(6) But William the Ba≈øtard created Robert (his halfe-brother by Herlotta their mother) the fir≈øt Earle of the Normans race: and Edward the Blacke Prince, the ninth from him, was by his Father King Edward the third inue≈øted the fir≈øt Duke of Cornwall, which Title euer ≈øince hath continued in the Crowne.

(7) The commodities of this Shire, mini≈øtred both by Sea and Soile, are many and great; for be≈øides the abundance of Fi≈øh that doe ≈øuffice the Inhabitants, the Pilchard is taken, who in great skuls ≈øwarme about the Coa≈øt, whence being tran≈øported to France, Spaine, and Italie. yeeld a yearely reuenew of gaine vnto Cornwall: wherein al≈øo Copper and Tinne ≈øo plentifully grow in the vtmo≈øt part of this Promontory, that at a low water the veynes thereof lie bare, and are ≈øeene: and what gaine that commoditie begets, is vulgarly knowne. Neither are the≈øe Rockes de≈øtitute of Gold nor Siluer, yea and Diamonds ≈øhaped and pointed Angle-wi≈øe, and ≈ømoothed by Nature her ≈øelfe, whereof ≈øome are as bigge as Walnuts, inferiour to the Orient onely in blackne≈ø≈øe and hardne≈ø≈øe.

Many are the Ports, Bayes, and Hauens that open into this Shire, both ≈øafe for arriuage, and commodious tran≈øport; whereof Falmouth is ≈øo copious, that an hundred Ships may therein ride at Anchor apart by them≈øelues, ≈øo that from the tops of their highe≈øt Ma≈øts, they ≈øhall not ≈øee each other, and lie mo≈øt ≈øafely vnder the winds.

(8) This Countie is fruitfull in Corne, Cattle, Sea-fi≈øh, and Fowle: all which, with other proui≈øions for plea≈øures and life, are traded thorow twentie-two Market-Townes in this Shire, whereof Laun≈øton and Bodman are the be≈øt; from which la≈øt, being the middle of the Shire, the Pole is eleuated to the degree of Latitude 50‚ñ™ 35. minutes, and for Longitude from the fir≈øt We≈øt point, 15. 13. minutes, as Mercator hath mea≈øured them.

(9) Memorable matters both for antiquitie and ≈øtrangene≈ø≈øe of ≈øight, are the≈øe: At Boske ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
vpon the South-we≈øt of her Promontorie, is a Trophy erected, which are eighteene Stones placed round in compa≈ø≈øe, and pitched twelue foot each from others, with another farre bigger in the very center. The≈øe doe ≈øhew ≈øome Victory there attained, either by the Romans, or els King Athel≈øtane. At the foot of the Rockes neere vnto S. Michaels Mount, in the memory of our fathers, were digged vp Speare-heads, Axes, and Swords of Bra≈ø≈øe, wrapped in linnen, the weapons that the Cimbrians and ancient Britaines anciently v≈øed.

At Camelford likewi≈øe peices of Armours both for hor≈øe and man, are many times found in digging of the ground, imputed to be the ≈øignes of that fight wherein Mordred was ≈ølaine, and wherein great Arthur receiued his deaths wound. And at Ca≈ø ‚Ä¢ le-Dennys are the Trenches wherein the Danes lodged when they fir≈øt minded to ≈øubdue the Land, In the Pari≈øh S Clare, two ≈øtones are pitched, one of them in≈øcribed with a ≈øtrange Character, and the other called the other halfe ≈øtone The Hurlers al≈øo, fabuled to be men metamorpho≈øed into ≈øtones; but in truth ≈øhew a note of ≈øome Victory, or el≈øe are ≈øo ≈øet for Land-markes Bounders. There al≈øo the Wring-chee≈øe doth ≈øhew it ≈øelfe, which are huge Rockes heaped one vpon another, and the lowe≈øt of them the lea≈øt, fa≈øhioned like a Chee≈øe, lying pre≈ø≈øed vnder the re≈øt of tho≈øe Hils, which ≈øeemeth very dangerous to be pa≈ø≈øed vnder „Äà‚óä„Äâ neere to Pen≈øans, and vnto Mounts-bay, a fa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e more ≈øtrange Rocke ≈øtandeth, namely, Main Amber, which
lyeth mounted vpon others of meaner ≈øize, with ≈øo equall a counterpoize, that a man may moue it with the pu≈øh of his finger, but no ≈øtrength remoue it out of his place.

(10) Religious hou≈øes built, and ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed within the limits of Cornwall, the faire≈øt and greate≈øt for account, were Laun≈øton, S. Neotes, S. Buriens, S. Michaels Mount, and S. Germans a Bi≈øhop ‚Ä¢
See: ≈øo was Bodman al≈øo, from whence King Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor remoued it vnto the Citie of Ence≈øter.
(11) The diui≈øion of this Shire is into nine Hundreds, wherein are ≈øeated twentie-two Market-Townes, and 161. Pari≈øh-Churches.

div.head: SVMMERSET-SHIRE. CHAPTER XI.
div.p: SVVMMERSET-SHIRE is both a rich and ≈øpacious Countrey, hauing the Seuerne Sea beating vpon it on the North-≈øide, the South part bordering vpon Deuon and Dor≈øet ≈øhires, the We≈øt confined with Deuon-≈øhire, and the Ea≈øt and North-Ea≈øt vpon Wilt≈øhire, and Glouce≈øter-≈øhire. It tooke the name of Sommerton (≈øometime the chiefe Towne of this Shire) whence in the ancient Hi≈øtorian A≈ø≈øerius, this Countie is called Sommertunen≈øis, that is, Sommertun-≈øhire.

(2) The forme thereof is large, bearing it ≈øelfe ≈øtill wider as it ≈øtretcheth into the middle part thereof, and containes in length from Brackley neere vnto Frome-Selwood Ea≈øtward, to Oure in the We≈øt, Miles 55. In breadth from Por≈øhut point in the North, to Chard Southward, is ≈øomewhat aboue fortie miles. The whole circumference is about 204. miles.

(3) The ayre is milde and plea≈øing, and for the mo≈øt part ≈øubiect to ≈øuch temperate di≈øpo≈øitions as the Sommer-≈øea≈øon affordeth, whence ≈øome haue erroniou≈øly conceited, that the Region borrowed her name from the nature of her Clime: yet how delightefull ≈øo euer it is in the time of Sommer, with change of the ≈øea≈øon it may well change her plea≈øing name, and borrow ≈øome Winterly denomination; ≈øo full of wet, ≈øo myrie and moori≈øh it is; in ≈øo much as the Inhabitants can hardly trauell to and fro without their great encumbrance.

(4) Howbeit they pa≈ø≈øe ouer this with all patience, knowing their en≈øuing ≈øea≈øonable profits farre to exceede any pre≈øent detriments and di≈øplea≈øures: for as it is foule, ≈øo it is fruitfull, which makes them comfort them≈øelues with this Prouerbe, that What is wor≈øt for the Rider, is be≈øt for the Abider: the Soyle and Globe thereof being very fertile, and euery ≈øide garni≈øhed with Pa≈øtures and
delightfull Meadowes, and beautified with Mannor hou≈øes both many and fayre; and (in a word) hath euery thing in it to content the pur≈øe, the heart, the eye, at home: and ≈øufficient Ports to giue entertainment to commodities from abroad.

(5) The ancient Inhabitants that po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed this Prouince were the Belgae, who ≈øpread them≈øelues farre and wide, as well here as in Wilt≈øhire, and the inner parts of Ham≈øhire: who being branched from the Germans, conferred the names of tho≈øe places from whence they came, vpon the≈øe their ≈øeats where they re≈øided.

(6) The generall profits of this Prouince are Corne and Cattle, wherewith it is ≈øo plentifully ≈øtored, as it may challenge any neighbouring Country for the quantitie to make ≈øhew of Cattle ≈øo fat, or Graine ≈øo rich. Some places are peculiarly enriched by Lead-mines, as Mindiphiis, (perchance ≈øo called of the deepe Mynes) by Leiland aptly tearmed Minerarij, Minerall-hils, which yeeld plenty of Lead, the mo≈øt Merchantable Commoditie that is in England, and vented into all parts of the world Some are beautified with Diamons, as S Vincent Rocke, whereof there is great plentie, and ≈øo bright of colour, as they might equalize Indian Diamonds, if they had their hardne≈ø≈øe yet being ≈øo many and ≈øo common, they are le≈ø≈øe ≈øought after or commended

(7) This Country is famou≈øed by three Cities, Bath, Wels, and Bri≈øtow The fir≈øt takes name of the hot Bathes, which Antonine called Aqua Solis, The waters of of the Sunne; Stephanus, Badiza; we at this day Bathe, and the Latini≈øts Bathonia: a place of continuall concour≈øe for per≈øons of all degrees, and almo≈øt of all di≈øea≈øes, (whence it was ≈øometimes called Ak ‚Ä¢ man ce≈øter) who by diuine prouidence doe very often finde reliefe there, the Springs thereof by rea≈øon of their Minerall and ≈øulphurous pa≈ø≈øage, being of ≈øuch exceeding power and medicinable heat, as that they cure and conquer the rebellious ≈øtubbornne≈ø≈øe of corrupt humors, in re≈øpect of which admirable vertues, ≈øome haue fabled, that they were fir≈øt conuayed by Magicke Art. To te≈øtifie the antiquitie of this place,
m ‚Ä¢ ny Images and Romane In≈øcriptions are found in the walles, which can now be hardly read, they are ≈øo worne and eaten into by age. Wels (as Leiland reporteth) was ≈øometimes called Theodorodunum, but from whence it had that denomination he makes no mention: The name it now beareth is taken (as ≈øome thinke) from the Riuer there, which King Kinewulph in his Charter An 766. calleth Welwe, or (as others) from the Wel ‚Ä¢
or Springs which there breake forth, and whereupon that See (vnder who≈øe Iuri≈ødiction is al≈øo the Citie of Bath) hath beene anciently called Pontanen≈øis Eccle≈øi ‚Ä¢ , the Fountaine-Church: where the Cathedrall built by King Inas to the memory of S. Andrew, is very beautifull and richly endowed. The Citie is likewi≈øe well repleni≈øhed both with Inhabitants and ≈øeemly buildings. Who≈øe gouernment is managed by a Major yearely elected, a Recorder, and ≈øeuen Mai≈øters, hauing the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of ≈øixteene Burge≈ø≈øes, a Towne-Clerke, and two Sergeants at Mace. Who≈øe Latitude is 51. 20. minutes, and Longitude 17. 31. minutes. Bri≈øtow is not ≈øo ancient, as it is faire and well ≈øeated: The beautie of it being ≈øuch, as for the bigne≈ø≈øe thereof, it ≈øcarce giues place to any Citie of England, and doth worthily de≈øerue the Saxon name Bright-≈øtad: who≈øe plea≈øantne≈ø≈øe is the more, by rea≈øon that the Riuer Auon ≈øcowres through the mid≈øt of it, which together with the benefit of Sewes vnder all the ≈øtreets, cleares the Citie of all noy≈øome filth and vncleanne≈ø≈øe. It is not wholly ≈øeated in this Countie of Sommer≈øet, but one part thereof in Glouce≈øter≈øhire but becau≈øe it is an entire Countie of it ≈øelfe, it denyes ≈øubiection vnto eyther, hauing for its owne gouernment both a Bi≈øhop, with a well furni≈øhed Colledge, and a Major, with a competent a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Aldermen, and other Officers for Ciuill affaires.

(8) This Prouince hath beene the Theater of many Tragicall euents and bloudy Battels: the Danes did grieuou≈øly afflict Porlock by cruell Piracies, in the yeare eight hundred eight ‚Ä¢ e ≈øixe. Yet neere vnto Pen a little village ‚Ä¢ eighbouring vpon North Cadbury, Edmund, ≈øurnamed Iron-≈øide, gaue them a notable ≈øoyle, as he was pur≈øuing Ca ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tus from place to place, for v≈øurping the Crowne of
England. And Keniwalth (a We≈øt-Saxon) in the ≈øame place had ≈øuch a day again≈øt the
‚Ä¢ ritaines, that they euer after ≈øtood in awe of the Engli≈øh-Saxons prowe≈ø≈øe. Marianus relateth that not farre from Bridge-water as the D ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ es were ≈øtragling abroad, Eal≈øtan Bi≈øhop of Sherbourne did ≈øo foyle their Forces in the yeare 845 as their minds were much di≈øcomfited, and their powers vtterly di≈øabled. Ni ‚Ä¢ ius al≈øo writeth, that King Arthur did ≈øo defeat the Engli≈øh-Saxons in a battell at Cadbury, that it de≈øerued to be made perpetuou≈øly memorable. Neither is Mo ‚Ä¢ s Badonicus (now Banne≈ødowne) le≈ø≈øe famous for Arthurs victories. And King Elfred in another battell not farre from hence gaue the Danes ≈øuch an ouerthrow, as he forced them to ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, and induced Godrus their King to become a Chri≈øtian, him≈øelfe being God-father to him at the ‚Ä¢ ont. So happie is this Region, and ≈øo beholding to Nature and Art for her ≈øtrengths and fortifications, as ≈øhe hath alwayes beeene able to defend her ≈øelfe, and offend her enemies.

(9) Neither hath it beene le≈ø≈øe honoured with beauteous hou≈øes con≈øecrated to Religion: ≈øuch was that of Black-Charons at Barelinch in the fir≈øt limit of this Shire We≈øtward: and King Athel≈øtan built a Mona≈øtery in an Iland called Muchelney (that is to ≈øay) the great Iland, which is betweene the Riuers Iuel and Pedred, running together, where the defaced walles and ruines thereof are yet to be ≈øeene King Henry the third al≈øo erected a Nunnery at Witham, which was afterwards the fir≈øt hou≈øe of the Carthu≈øian Monkes in England, as Hin ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ n not far off was the ≈øecond. But aboue all other for antiquitie, glory, and beautie was the Abbey of Gla≈øte ‚Ä¢ bury, who≈øe beginning is fetcht euen from Io≈øeph of A ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ athea, which Deni Bi≈øhop of S. Dauids repaired, being fallen to ruine, and King Inas la≈øtly builded a fayre and ≈øtately Church in this Mona≈øtery, though it be now made euen with the ground, the ruines onely ≈øhewing how great and magnificant a Seat it hath anciently beene; which ≈øeuerall hou≈øes were thus beautified by bounteous Princes, for religious purpo≈øes, and to retire the mind from worldly ≈øeruices, though blinded times and guides diuerted them to ≈øuper≈øtitious and lewd abu≈øes.

(10) Other memorable places are the≈øe, Camal ‚Ä¢ t a very ≈øteepe hill hard to be a≈øcended which appeares to haue beene a worke of the Romans by diuers Coynes digd vp there, on the top whereof are ≈øeene the lineaments of a large and ancient Ca≈øtle, which the Inhabitants report to haue beene the Palace of King Arthur. Ilche≈øter, which at the comming of the Normans was ≈øo populou ‚Ä¢ , that it had in it an hundred and ≈øeuen Burge≈ø ‚Ä¢ es, and it appeares to be of great antiquitie by the Romane Cae≈øars Coynes, oftentimes ≈øound there. The Church yard of Aualonia or Gla≈øtenbury, wh ‚Ä¢ re King Arthurs Sepulcher was ≈øearcht for by the command of King Henry the ≈øecond, which was found vnder a ≈øtone, with an In≈øcription vpon it fa≈øtned, almo≈øt nine foote in the ground. Al≈øo Dun≈øtere, where (as is reported) a great Lady obtained of her husband ≈øo much Pa≈øture ground in common by the Towne ≈øide, for the good and benefit of the Inhabitants, as ≈øhe was able in a whole day to goe about bare-foote.

This Countie is diuided into 42. Hundreds for the di≈øpo≈øing of bu≈øine≈ø≈øe needfull to the State thereof, wherein are placed 33. Market-Townes, fit for buying and ≈øelling, and other affayres of Commerce. It is fortified with foure Ca≈øtles, and planted with 385. Pari≈øhes, for concour≈øe of diuine ≈øeruice.

div.head: VVILT-SHIRE. CHAPTER XII.
div.p: VVILT-SHIRE, is enclo≈øed vpon the Northwith Gloce≈øter-≈øhire, vpon the Ea≈øt is bounded with Bark-≈øhire, vpon the South with Dor≈øet and Hamp≈øhire, and vpon the We≈øt is confronted again≈øt partly by Gloce≈øter, and the re≈øt by Somer≈øet ≈øhires.

(2) The forme thereof ‚Ä¢ s both long and broad; for from Ingle≈øham vpon Thami≈øis in the North, to Burgat Damarum in the South, are thirtie nine miles: the broade≈øt part is from Bu ‚Ä¢ termer Ea≈øtward, to the Shire-≈øtones in the We≈øt, being twentie nine; the whole in Circumference is one hundred thirtie nine miles.

(3) For Ayre, it is ≈øeated in a temperate Climate, both ≈øweet, plea≈øant, and whole≈øome; and for ≈øoile (≈øaith Iohn of Sarisbury) is exceeding fertile and plentifull, yea, and that with va ‚Ä¢ ietie.

(4) The Northerne part which they call North Wilt ≈øhire, ri≈øeth vp into delectable hilles, attired with large Woods, and watered with cleare Riuers, whereof I≈øis is one, which ≈øoone becommeth the mo≈øt famous in the Land. The South part is more euen, yeelding abundently gra≈ø≈øe and corne; and is made the more fruitfull by the Riuers Wily, Adder, and Au ‚Ä¢ n. The mid≈øt of this Countie is mo≈øt plaine, and thereby is knowne and commonly called Salesbury
„Äà‚óä„Äâ , and lie ≈øo leuall indeed, that it doth limit the Horizon: or hardly can a man ≈øee from the one ≈øide to the other. The≈øe Plaines gra≈øe an infinite number of ≈øheepe, who≈øe fleeces and fle≈øh bring in an yearely reuenew to their owners.

(5) Anciently this Countie was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Belga, who are ≈øeated by Ptolemie in Hamp≈øhire, Somer≈øet ≈øhire, and in this Tract; and they (as it ≈øeemeth by Ca≈øar) were of the Belga in Gaul The≈øe
(as ≈øome hold) were ≈øubdued by Ve≈øpa≈øian, Lieutenant of the ≈øecond Legion under Claudius, when the foundations of his future greatne≈ø≈øe were in the≈øe parts fir≈øt laid by his many Victories ouer the Britaines. And herein ≈øurely the Romans ≈øeated; for be≈øides Yan ‚Ä¢ sburie Trench, by Tradition held to be his, in many other Forts in this Shire the Tract of their footing hath beene left, and the ≈øtamped Coines of their Emperours found, an apparent te≈øtimony of their abode.

(6) After them the We≈øt-Saxons made it a part of their Kingdome, whole border was Auon, as witne≈ø≈øeth Athelward, though the Mercians many times encroched vpon them, whereby many great Battles, as Malmesbury tels vs, betwixt them were fought, when in the young yeares of their Heptarchie each ≈øought to enlarge his, by the le≈ø≈øening of the next: but growne vnto more ripene≈ø≈øe, they a≈ø≈øigned their limits by a great and long ditch cro≈ø≈øing thorow the midde≈øt of the≈øe Plaines, which for the wonder thereof is ≈øuppo≈øed by the vulgar to be the worke of the Deuill, and is called of all, Wan≈ødike, vndoubtedly of Woden, the Saxons Ance≈øtor and great reputed God, where a little village yet ≈øtandeth, and retaineth to name Wodens-burg At this place, in Anno 590. Ceaulin the We≈øt-Saxon, receiued ≈øuch a foyle of the Britaines and his Countrey-men, that he was forced to for≈øake his Kingdome, and to end his dayes in exile, becomming a pittifull ≈øpectacle euen vnto his enemies. And in this place Ina the We≈øt-Saxon joyned Battle with Ceolred the Mercian, whence both of them departed with equall lo≈ø≈øe. The like was at Bradford by Ke ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ lwach and Cuthred; at Wilton, betwixt Egbert and Beornwolfe; at Edindon, where King Elfred was vanqui≈øher of the Danes; and at Wilton, where the Danes wonne the day again≈øt him. With as bloudy ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, though not happening by ≈øword, was the i≈ø≈øue of that Synod a≈ø≈øembled at Colne, a ≈ømall Towne in this Countie, in the yeare of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus 977 where being hotly debating for the ≈øingle life, and again≈øt the marriages of the Clergie, what wanted by the Word to proue their diuorce, was ≈øupplyed by a Stratagem, and that very bloudy; for ≈øuddenly the maine timber brake, and downe fell the floore with the Nobles and
Prelates, the Gentlemen and Commons, whereby a great number were hurt, and many more ≈ølaine; onely Dun≈øtan the Pre≈øident and mouth for the Monkes, e≈øcaped vntouched, the Ioi≈øt whereon his Chaire ≈øtood remaining mo≈øt firme: which confirmed the ≈øentence of their ≈øeparations, whom God had conioyned, and became the fall and ≈ønare of much incontinencie in both ≈øexes.

(7) The chiefe≈øt Citie of this Shire is Salesburie, remoued from a higher, but a farre more conuenient place; who≈øe want of water was not ≈øo great in the mother, as is ≈øupplied and repleni≈øhed in the daughter, euery ≈øtreet almo≈øt hauing a Riuer running thorow her midde≈øt; and for ≈øumptuous and delicate buildings, is inferiour to none. The Cathedrall, a mo≈øt rich magnificent Church, was begun by Richard Poore, Bi≈øhop, and with fortie yeares continuante was rai≈øed to her perfect beautie: wherein are as many windowes as there are dayes in the yeare, as many ca≈øt pillars of Marble, as there are houres in the yeare, and as many gates for entrance as there are moneths in the yeare. Neither doth this Citie retaine true honour to her ≈øelfe, but imparteth hers, and receiueth honour from others, who are intituled Earles of Salesburie, whereof eight noble Families haue beene dignified ≈øince the Normans C ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ que≈øt. This Cities ≈øituation is in the degree of Latitude 51. 10 minutes, and from the fir≈øt We≈øt point ob≈øerued by Mercator, 18 Degrees, and 31. minutes of Longitude.

(8) Ouer this, old Salesburie ≈øheweth it ≈øelfe, where K ‚Ä¢ n ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ k ouercame the Britaines, and where Canutus the Dane did great dammage by fire. This formerly had beene the Seat of the Romans: as likewi≈øe was Lecham, as by their Coines digged vp is apparant: ≈øo were Brokenbridge and Co≈øham, the Courts of the Saxon Kings But Fortune long ≈øince hath turned her face from all the≈øe, as lately ≈øhe did from many ancient and religious foundations planted in this Prouince, whereof Mal ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e≈øburie was the mo≈øt famous I will not with Monmouth auouch the foundation thereof vnto Mulmutius,
but by true Records from Maidulph a Scot, a man of great learning, that therein built a Cell, and lead an Hermits life, whereof Beda calleth it the Citie of Maidulph, and we by contraction, Malmesburie, Adelme his Di≈øciple and Succe≈ø≈øor, built here a faire Mona≈øtery, which Athel≈øtan the Monarch richly endowed, and left his body after death there to re≈øt. Neither hath any graced this more then William her Monke, in recording to po≈øterities the Chronicles of our Land, concerning both the Church and Common-weale, wherein him≈øelfe liued and wrote tho≈øe Hi≈øtories.

(9) Ambresburie for repute did ≈øecond this, built by A ‚Ä¢ fritha, King Edgar his wife, to expiate the ≈øinne of murder which ≈øhe committed vpon yong Edward her ≈øonne in law, that hers might be King. In this place Queene Eleanor, widow to King Henry the third, renounced all royall pompe, and deuoted her ≈øelfe vnto God in the habit of a Nunne. Other places erected for pietie, were at Salesburie, Lacock, Stanley, Wilton, Luichurch, Farnleg, Brad≈øtole, Briopune, and Brombore. The≈øe grafts growne to full greatne≈ø≈øe, were cut downe by the Pruiner, lea≈øt the cankers thereof ≈øhould infect the whole body (as by them was alledged) and their Reuenewes be≈øtowed vpon farre better v≈øes, both for the bringing vp of youth, and the maintenance of e≈øtate.

(10) With eight ≈øtrong Ca≈øtles this Countie hath beene guarded; in nineteene Market-Townes her commodities are traded: into twentie-nine Hundreds for bu≈øine≈ø≈øe is diuided, and in them are ≈øeated three hundred and foure Pari≈øh-Churches.

div.head: BARK-SHIRE. CHAPTER XIII.
div.p: BARK-SHIRE, whether of the Eo ‚Ä¢ -woods there ≈øited, according to the cen≈øure of A≈ø≈øerius Meneuen≈øis, or from a naked and beare-le≈ø≈øe Oke-tree, whereunto the people v≈øually re≈øorted in trouble≈øome times, to conferte for the State, I determine not: onely the Countie a long time hath beene ≈øo called, and bounded with other in manner as followeth: The North-part is parted by Thami≈øis from Buckingham and Oxford-≈øhires; the South neere Kennet doth tract vpon Hamp≈øhire; the Ea≈øt is confined with the Countie of Surrey; and the We≈øt with Wilt≈øhire and Gloce≈øter≈øhire is held in.

(2) The forme of this Shire doth ≈øomewhat re≈øemble a Sandall for a mans foot, lying long-wi≈øe from Ea≈øt to We≈øt, in which part ≈øhe is broade≈øt, the middle mo≈øt narrow, and then ≈øpreading wider like to the heele: though for her rich endowments and ≈øtately magnificence, it may be well accounted the heart of the whole.

(4) The Ayre is temperate, ≈øweet, and delightfull, and pro≈øpect for plea≈øure inferiour to none; the Soile is plenteous of corne, e≈øpecially in the Vale of White-hor≈øe, that yeeldeth yearely an admirable encrea≈øe. In a word, for Corne and Cattle, Waters, and Woods, of profit and plea≈øure, it giues place vnto none.

(5) Her ancient Inhabitants, by Ptolemie and Cae≈øar, were the Attrebat ‚Ä¢ , and them of tho≈øe that de≈øcended from Gallia, among whom Comius (conquered by the Dictator) was of good re≈øpect,
and could doe much with the Britaines, who (as Frontinus reporteth) v≈øed this ≈øtratagem, though it proued nothing at la≈øt: he flying before Cae≈øar to recouer ayd of the≈øe Attrebatians, light bedded vpon a ≈øhelfe in the Sea, whereupon hoy≈øting his ≈øailes as before a fore-winde, gaue ≈øhew to his pur≈øuer that they were in ≈øwift flight; ≈øo that hopele≈ø≈øe to hayle them, he gaue ouer the cha≈øe: yet no ≈øooner had Cae≈øar made ouer among them, but that ≈øome of the≈øe people, by name the Bibroces, yeelded him ≈øubiection, which prued the ruine of all former libertie But when the Romans had rent their owne Empire, and retired their Legion into a narrower circuit, the Sa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ns ≈øet foot where their forces had beene, and made this Countie a parcell of their We≈øterne Kingdome.

The Danes then ≈øetting their de≈øire vpon ≈øpoiles, from their ‚Ä¢ oauing Pinnaces pierced into the≈øe parts, and at Redding fortified them≈øelues betwixt the Riuers Kennet and Tham ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øis, whither after their great ouerthrow receiued at Inge ‚Ä¢ efield by the hand of King Ethelwolfe, they retyred for their further ≈øafetie.

(6) This Towne King Henry the fir≈øt mo≈øt ≈øtately beautified with a rich Mona≈øtery and ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle, where, in the Collegiate Church of the Abbey, him≈øelfe and Queene (who lay both veiled and crowned) with their daughter Maud the Empre≈ø≈øe, called the Lady of England, were interred, as the priuate Hi≈øtory of the place auoucheth, though others be≈øtow the bodies of the≈øe two Queenes el≈øe-where. The Ca≈øtle King Henry the ≈øecond razed to the ground, becau≈øe it was the refuge for the followers of King Stephen From whence the North-pole is rai≈øed in Latitude 51 degrees and 40 minutes, and in Longitude from the fir≈øt We≈øt-point ob≈øerued by Mercator 19 degrees and 35. minutes.

(7) A Ca≈øtle and Towne of greater ≈øtrength and antiquitie was Wallingford, by Antonie and Ptolemie called Galtena, the chiefe≈øt Citie of the Attribatians, who≈øe large circuit, and ≈øtrong fortifications, ≈øhew plainly, that it was a place of the Romans abode, and ≈øince in a conceiued ≈øafetie hath
made many very bold, e≈øpecially when the ≈øparkes of Englands ciuill di≈ø≈øentions were forced to flame in ca≈øe of the Crowne betwixt Maud the Empre≈ø≈øe and King Stephen, whither her ≈øelfe and a≈ø≈øociates re≈øorted as their ≈øure≈øt defence.

(8) But of farre greater magnificence and ≈øtate is the Ca≈øtle of Wind≈øor, a mo≈øt Princely Palace and Man≈øion of his Maie≈øtie. I will not with Ieffrey affirme it to be built by King Arthur, but with better authoritie ≈øay, it was ≈øo thir≈øted after by the Conquerour, that by a compo≈øition with the Abbat of We≈øtmin≈øter, who≈øe then it was, he made it to be the Kings Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, as a Place be≈øides the plea≈øures, very commodious to entertaine the King In this Ca≈øtle that victorious Prince King Edward the third was borne; and herein after he had ≈øubdued the French and Scots, held he at one and the ≈øame time, as his Pri≈øoners, Iohn King of France, and Dauid King of Scotland Neither was it euer graced with greater Maie≈øtie then by the in≈øtitution of the mo≈øt honourable Order of the Garter, a ≈øignall Ornament of Martiall Prowe≈ø≈øe: the inuention thereof ≈øome a≈øcribe to be from a Garter falling from his Queene, or rather from Ioan Counte≈ø≈øe of Salisbury, a Lady of an incomparable beautie, as ≈øhe danced before him, whereat the by-≈øtanders ≈øm ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ing, he gaue the impre≈ø≈øe to checke all euill conceits, and in golden Letters imbeli≈øhed the Garter with this French Po≈øie, HONI SOIT QVI MALY PENSE. And yet that worthy Clarenceaux alledging the booke of the fir≈øt in≈øtitution, findes the inuention to be more ancient, as when King Richard the fir≈øt warred again≈øt the Turkes, Saracens, Cypres, and Acon, he girt the legs of certaine choi≈øe Knights with a tache of leather, which promi≈øed a future glory to the wearers. The mo≈øt Princely Chappell thereof is graced with the bodies of tho≈øe two great Kings, Henry the ≈øixt, and Edward the fourth, whom the whole Kingdome was too little to containo, the one of Lanca≈øter, the other of Yorke, where they re≈øt now vnited in one mould, with a branch of both tho≈øe Hou≈øes, euen King Henry the eight, who there lyeth al≈øo interred, and re≈øts in the Lord.

(9) Other places of note in this Shire are Sinodum in the North, and Watham in the Ea≈øt, both of them places of the Romans re≈øidence, as by their monyes the≈øe oftentimes found appeareth. Neither was Sunning the lea≈øt in this Tract, that had beene the Seat of eight Bi≈øhops before the See was tran≈ølated thence vnto Shirburne, or that to Salisbury‚ñ™ Wantage al≈øo is not wanting of honour, in bringing to life that learned and mo≈øt valiant King Ealfred, the ≈øcourge of the Danes, and great Monarch of the Engli≈øh. And Finchham≈øted for wonder inferiour to none, where (as our Writers doe witne≈ø≈øe) that in the yeare, a thou≈øand one hundred, a Well boyled vp with ≈øtreames of bloud, and fifteene dayes together continued that Spring, who≈øe waters made red all others where they came, to the great amazement of the beholders.

(10) The riches and ≈øweet ≈øeats that this Country affordeth, made many deuout per≈øons to ≈øhew their deuotions vnto true pietie, in erecting places for Gods diuine ≈øeruice, and their exemptions from all worldly bu≈øine≈ø≈øe: ≈øuch were Abington, Redding, By≈øham, Bromehall, Hen ‚Ä¢ ey, Hamme, and Wallingford, who≈øe V ‚Ä¢ tarie abu≈øing the intents of their Founders, ouerthrew both their owne Orders and places of profe≈ø≈øions; all which were di≈ø≈øolued by Act of Parliament, and giuen the King to di≈øpo≈øe at his will.

This Shires diui≈øion is into twentie Hundreds, and hath beene ≈øtrengthened with ≈øix ≈øtrong Ca≈øtles, is yet graced with three of his Maie≈øties mo≈øt Princely Hou≈øes, and traded with twelue Market Townes, and is repleni≈øhed with one hundred and fortie Pari≈øhes.

div.head: MIDDLESEX. CHAPTER XIIII.
div.p: MIDDLESEX, ≈øo called in regard of the ≈øituation, as ≈øeated betwixt the We≈øt-Saxons and Ea≈øt-Angles, was ≈øometimes, together with E≈ø≈øex and Hartford-≈øhire, that part and portion which the Ea≈øt Saxons enioyed for their Kingdome: it lyeth bordered vpon the North with Hartford ≈øhire; vpon the We≈øt by Colne, is ≈øeuered from Buckingham; the South, by Thame≈øis from Surrey and Kent; and on the Ea≈øt from E≈ø≈øex, by the Riuer Lea.

(2) The length thereof extended from „Äà‚óä„Äâ in the Ea≈øt, to Morehall vpon Colne in the We≈øt, is by mea≈øure nineteene Engli≈øh miles; and from South
„Äà‚óä„Äâ in the North, to his Maje≈øties Mannour of Hampton-Court in the South, are little aboue ≈øixteene miles, the whole Circumference extending to ninetie miles

(3) In fo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e it is almo≈øt ≈øquare, for ayre pa≈ø≈øing temperate, for ≈øoile abundantly fertile, and for pa≈øturage and graine of all kindes yeelding the be≈øt, ≈øo that the Wheat of this Countie hath ≈øerued a long time for the manch ‚Ä¢ t to our Princes Table.

(4) It lyeth ≈øeated in a vale mo≈øt whole≈øome and rich hauing ≈øome hils al≈øo, and them of good
„Äà‚óä„Äâ , from who≈øe tops the pro≈øpect of the whole is ≈øeene like vnto Zoar in Egypt, or rather like a Paradi≈øe and Garden of God.

(5) The ancient Inhabitants knowne to Cae≈øar, were the Trinobants, whom he nameth to be the mo≈øt pui≈ø≈øant in the Iland; who≈øe chiefe Citie and State yeelding him ≈øubiection, made the whole, with le≈ø≈øe lo≈ø≈øe to the Romans, to beare the yoke of their owne bondage, and to come in vnder termes of truce. But when their forces in the≈øe parts were ≈øpent, and the Empire ≈øhaken by inte≈øtine
warres, the Saxons ≈øetting their eyes vpon ≈øo faire a ≈øoile, made their footing as ≈øure herein; which la≈øtly with Hartford and E≈ø≈øex, was the portion of the Ea≈øt-Saxons Kingdome.

(6) Fiue Princely Hou≈øes, inheritable to the Engli≈øh Crowne, are ≈øeated in this Shire, which are, Enfield, Hanworth, White-hall, S. Iames, and Hampton-Court, a Citie rather in ≈øhew then the Palace of a Prince, and for ≈øtately Port and gorgeous building, not inferiour to any in Europe. At Thi≈øtleworth once ≈øtood the Palace of Richard King of the Romans, Earle of Cornewall, which the Lond ‚Ä¢ ner in a tumultuous broile, burned to the ground: many other ≈øtately Hou≈øes of our Engli≈øh Nobilitie, Knights, and Gentlemen, as al≈øo of the wor≈øhipfull Citizens of London, are in this Shire ≈øo ≈øumptuou≈øly built and plea≈øantly ≈øeated, as the like in the like circuit are no where el≈øe to be found. Neere vnto Thame≈øis entrance into this Countie, is kept the remembrance of Cae≈øars entrance ouer Thame≈øis, by the name of Coway-Stakes, ≈øtucke fa≈øt in the bottome to impeach his de≈øignes; and further at Stanes a Maire-≈øtone once ≈øtood for a marke of Iuri≈ødiction, that London had ≈øo farre vpon Thame≈øis

(7) Which Citie is more ancient then any true record beareth, fabuled from Brute, Troynouant, from Lud, Lud≈øtone: But by more credible Writers, Tacitus, Ptolemy, and Antonine, Londinium, by Aminian ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Mercellinus for her ≈øucce≈ø≈øiue pro≈øperitie, Augu≈øta, the greate≈øt title that can be giuen to any: by Britaines, Londayn, by Strangers, Londra, and by vs London. This Citie doth ≈øhew as the Cedars among other trees, being the ≈øeat of the Briti≈øh Kings, the chamber of the Engli≈øh, the modell of the Land, and the Mart of the world: for thither are brought the ≈øilke of A≈øia, the ≈øpices from Africa, the Balmes from Grecia, and the riches of both the Indies Ea≈øt and We≈øt: no Citie ≈øtanding ≈øo long in ≈øame, nor any for diuine and politicke gouernment may with her be compared Her walls were fir≈øt ≈øet by great Con≈øtantine the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian Emperour, at the ≈øuit of his mother, Qu: Helen, reared with rough ≈øtone and Briti≈øh Bricke three Engli≈øh miles in compa≈ø≈øe: thorow which are now
made ≈øeauen mo≈øt faire gates, be≈øides three other pa≈ø≈øages for entrance. Along the Thame≈øis, this wall at fir≈øt ranged and with two gates opened, the one Doure-gate, now Dowgate, and the other Billin≈øgate, a receptacle for Ships. In the mid≈øt of this wall was ≈øet a mile-marke (as the like was in Rome) from whence were mea≈øured their ≈øtations, for carriage or otherwi≈øe; the ≈øame as yet ≈øtandeth, and hath beene long knowne by the name of London Stone. Vpon the Ea≈øt of this Citie, the Church of S. Peters is thought to be the Cathedrall of Re≈øtitus, the Chri≈øtians Bi≈øhops See, who liued in the raigne of Great Con≈øtantine; but ≈øince S. Pauls in the We≈øt part, from the Temple of Diana, a≈ø≈øumed that dignitie, who≈øe greatne≈ø≈øe doth exceed any other at this day, and ≈øpires ≈øo high that twice it hath beene con≈øumed by lightning from heauen. Be≈øides this Cathedrall, God is honoured in one hundred twentie one Churches more in this Citie: that is, ninetie ≈øix within the wals; ≈øixteene without, but within the Liberties; and nine more in her Suburbs; and in F ‚Ä¢ z. Stephens time, thirteene Conuents of religious Orders. It is diuided into 26 Wards, gouerned by ≈øo many graue Aldermen, a Lord Maior, and two Sherifs, the yearely choice whereof was granted them by Patent from King Iohn; in who≈øe time al≈øo a Bridge of ≈øtone was made ouer Thames, vpon nineteene Arches, for length, breadth, beautie, and building, the like againe not found in the world.

(8) This London (as it were) di≈ødaning bondage, hath ≈øet her ≈øelfe on each ≈øide, far without the walls, and hath lefther We≈øt-gate in the mid≈øt, from whence with continuall buildings (≈øtill affecting greatne≈ø≈øe) ≈øhe hath continued her ≈øtreets vnto a Kings Palace, and ioyned a ≈øecond Citie to her ≈øelfe, famous for the Seat and Sepulchre of our Kings; and for the Gates of Iu≈øtice, that termely there are opened, onely once a Bi≈øhops See, who≈øe title died with the man. No walls are ≈øet about this Citie, and tho≈øe of London are left, to ≈øhew rather what it was, then what it is: Who≈øe Citizens, as the Lacedemonians did, doe impute their ≈øtrength in their men, and not in their wals, how ≈øtrong toeuer. Or el≈øe for their multitude, cannot be circulated, but (as another Ieru≈øalem) is inhabited
without walls, as Zachary ≈øaid. The wealth of this Citie (as I≈øay once ≈øpake of Nilus) growes from the Reuenewes and harue≈øt of her South-bounding Thames; who≈øe traffique for merchandizing, is like that of Tyrus, whereof Ezekiel ≈øpeakes, and ≈øtands in abundance of Siluer, Iron, Tinne, and Lead, &c. And from London her channell is nauigable, ≈øtraitned along with medowing borders, vntill ≈øhe taketh her full libertie in the German Seas. Vpon this Thame≈øis the Ships of Thar≈øis ≈øeeme to ride, and the Nauy, that rightly is termed the Lady of the Sea, ≈øpreads her ≈øaile. Whence twice with luckie ≈øucce≈ø≈øe hath beene accompli≈øhed, the compa≈ø≈øing of the vniuer≈øall Globe. This Riuer, Canutus, laying ≈øiege again≈øt London, ≈øought by digging to diuert, and before him the Danes had done great harmes in this Citie, yet was their State recouered by King Elfred, and the Riuer kept her olde cour≈øe, notwith≈øtanding that co≈øt. In the times of the Normans, ≈øome ciuill broiles haue beene attempted in this Citie, as in the dayes of King Iohn, whereinto his Barons entred, and the Tower yeelded vnto Lewis. And againe, Wat Tyler herein committed outragious cruelties, but was worthily ≈øtruck downe by the Maior and ≈ølaine in Smithfield. This Cities graduation for Latitude is the degree 51. 45. minutes, and in Longitude 20. degrees 39. minutes.

(9) In this Countie at Barnet, vpon Ea≈øter-day, a bloudy battell was fought, betwixt Henry the ≈øixt and Edward the fourth, wherein were ≈ølaine one Marques, one Earle, three Lords, and with them ten thou≈øand Engli≈øhmen.

(10) The diui≈øion of this Shire is into ≈øeuen Hundreds, wherein are ≈øeated two Cities, foure Market-Townes, and ≈øeuenty-three Pari≈øh-Churches, be≈øides them in London; wherein the Church of Gray-Fryers, now called Chri≈øt-Church, three Queenes lye interred, which were, Queene Margaret, the D. of Phil. the hardy, King of France, ≈øecond wife to King Edward the fir≈øt; the ≈øecond was Queene I≈øabel, wife to King Edward the ≈øecond, and D. to Philip the faire King of France; and the third was Queene Ioan, their daughter, married to Dauid King of Scotland.

div.head: ESSEX. CHAPTER XV.
div.p: ESSEX, by the Normans ex≈øe≈ø≈øa, and by the vulgar E≈ø≈øex; is a Countie large in compa≈ø≈øe, very populous, and nothing inferiour to the be≈øt of the Land.

(2) The ‚Ä¢ orme thereof is ≈øomewhat Circular, excepting the Ea≈øt part, which ≈øhooteth her ≈øelfe with many Promontories into the Sea; and from Hor≈øey Iland to Haidon in the We≈øt, (the broade≈øt part of the Shire) are by mea≈øure fortie miles; and the length from Ea≈øt-Ha ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
vpon Thame≈øis in the South, to S ‚Ä¢ urmere vpon the Riuer Stow in the North, are thirtie-fiue miles; the whole in Circumference one hundred fortie ≈øixe miles.

(3) It lyeth bounded vpon the North, with Suffolke and Cambridge-Shires, vpon the We≈øt with Hertford and Middle≈øex, vpon the South by Thame≈øis is parted from Kent, and the Ea≈øt-≈øide thereof is altogether wa≈øhed with the German Sea.

(4) The ayre is temperate and plea≈øant onely towards the waters ≈øomewhat agui≈øh: the ≈øoile is rich and fruitfull, though in ≈øome places ≈øandy and barren; yet ≈øo that it neuer fru≈øtrates the husbandmans hopes, or fils not the hands of her harue≈øt-labourers: but in ≈øome part ≈øo fertile, that after three yeares glebe of Saffron, the Land for 18. more, will yeeld plentie of Barley, without either dung or other fatning earth

(5) Her ancient Inhabitants knowne to the Romanes, were by Cae≈øar called the Trinobants, of whom in the former Chapter we haue ≈øpoken, and in our Hi≈øtory ≈øhall ≈øpeake more at large. But this name peri≈øhed with the age of the Empire, the Saxons pre≈øently framed a new; and with Hertford and Middle≈øex made it their Ea≈øt-Saxons Kingdome, vntill that Egbert brought this and the whole into an entire and ab≈øolute Monarchy: the Daues after them laid ≈øo ≈øore for this Prouince, that at
‚Ä¢ eamfleet
and Hauenet (now Shobery) they fortified mo≈øt ≈øtrongly; and at Barklow, (be≈øides the hils mounted for their burials) the Danewort with her red beryes, ≈øo plentifully grow, that it is held and accounted to ≈øpring from the bloud of the Danes which in that place was ≈øpilt, and the hearb as yet is called from them the Dane≈ø-bloud; neither yet were they quelled to ≈øurcea≈øe that quarrell; but at A≈øhdowne abode the Iron-≈øide in fight, wherein ≈øo much bloud of the Engli≈øh was ≈øpilt, that Canutus their King in remor≈øe con≈øcience, built a Church in the place, to pacifie God for the ≈øinnes of his people: But when the Normans had got the garland of the whole, many of their Nobles there ≈øeated them≈øelues, who≈øe po≈øterities ≈øince, both there and el≈øe-where, are ≈øpread further abroad in the Realme.

(6) The Commodities that this Shire yeeldeth, are many and great, as of Woods, Corne, Cattle, Fi≈øh, Fore≈øts, and Saffron; which la≈øt groweth with ≈øuch gaine and increa≈øe vpon her North parts, that from a ≈øplit cloue much like vnto Garlicke, a white blewi≈øh Flower ≈øhortly ≈øpringeth, from whence fillets of Saffron are gathered before the Sunne, and dryed, are ≈øold as ≈øpice with great gaine. From the Ilands Canuey, Mer≈øey, Hor≈øey, Northly, O≈øey, Wallot, and Foulne≈ø≈øe, great ≈øtore of Fi≈øh and Fowle are daily gotten: and ≈øo from their Cattle haue they continuall increa≈øe, which men and boyes milke; as well the Ewe as the Kine; whereof they make great and thicke Chee≈øe, ≈øold abroad in the Land, and much thereof tran≈øported into other Countries. Their Oy≈øters which we call Walfleete, the be≈øt in e≈øteeme, and are thought from Pa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e to haue beene ≈øerued in the Romans Kitchins. But lea≈øt we ≈øhould exceed mea≈øure in commending, or the people repo≈øe their tru≈øt in the ≈øoyle; behold what God can doe, to fru≈øtrate both in a moment, and that by his meane≈øt creatures: for in our age and remembrance, the yeare of Chri≈øt 1581. an Army of Mice ≈øo ouer ranne the Mar≈øhes in Dengey Hundred, neere vnto South-min≈øter in this Countie, that they ≈øhore the gra≈ø≈øe to the very roots, and ≈øo tainted the ≈øame with their venemous teeth, that a great Murraine fell vpon the Cattle which gra≈øed thereon, to the great lo≈ø≈øe of their owners.

(7) The chiefe≈øt Citie for account at this day, in this Shire, is Colche≈øter, built by Coilus the Briti≈øh Prince, one hundred twentie-foure yeares after the birth of our Sauiour Chri≈øti (if he of Mo ‚Ä¢ mouth ≈øay true) wherein his ≈øonne Lucius, Helena, and Con≈øtantine, the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King, Empre≈ø≈øe, and Emperour in the world, were borne: which made Necham for Con≈øiantine to ≈øing as he did.

q.l: From Colche≈øter there ro≈øe a Starre,
The Rayes whereof gaue glorious light
Throughout the world in climates farre,
Great Con≈øtantine, Romes Emperour bright.

div.p: And the Romanes to the great honour of Helena in≈øcribed her, Pi ‚Ä¢ ≈øsima Venerabilis Augu≈øta. But of the≈øe we ≈øhall be occa≈øioned to ≈øpeake more hereafter. This Citie is ≈øituated vpon the South of the Riuer Coln; from whence it hath the name, and is walled about, rai≈øed vpon a high Trench of earth, though now much decayed, hauing ≈øix gates of entrance, and three po≈øternes in the We≈øt wall, be≈øides nine Watch-Towers for defence, and containeth in compa≈ø≈øe 1980 paces; wherein ≈øtand eight faire Churches, and two other without the walls, for Gods diuine ≈øeruice: S Tenants and the Blacke Fryers decayed in the Suburbs; Mary Magdalins, the Nunnery, S Iohns, and the Cruched Fryers, all ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed: within towards the Ea≈øt is mounted an old Ca≈øtle, and elder ruines vpon a trench containing two Acres of ground, whereas yet may be ≈øeene the prouident care they had again≈øt all en≈øuing a≈ø≈øaults.

The trade of this Towne ≈øtandeth chiefly in making of Cloth and Baies, with Saies, and other like Stuffes daily inuented; and is gouerned by two Bailiffes, twelue Aldermen, all wearing Scarlet; a Recorder, a Towne-Clerke, and foure Sergeants at Mace. Who≈øe po≈øition for Latitude is in the degree 52. 14. minutes; and for Longitude, in the degree 21. and 50. minutes.

(8) Places of antiquitie and memorable note in this Countie, I ob≈øerue the mo≈øt famous to be Camalodumum, by vs Maldon, which was the Royall Seat of Cunobel ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
King of the Trino ‚Ä¢ antes, as by his money therein minted appeareth, about the time of our Sauiours birth: which Citie afterwards Claudius wonne from the Britaines, and therein placed a Colony of Souldiers, which were called Victricen≈øis. This Citie Queene Boduo, in reuenge of her wrongs, raced to the ground, what time ≈øhe ≈øtirred their people again≈øt Nero, with the ≈ølaughter of ≈øeuentie thou≈øand of the Romanes. Of ≈øome later and le≈ø≈øer account was Ithanche≈øter, now S. Peters vpon the wall, where the Forteu≈øes with their Captaine kept, towards the declination of the Romane Empire. In the Ea≈øt Promontory of this Countie, in the Raigne of Richard the ≈øecond, the teeth of a Giant were found (if they were not of an Elephant) of a marueilous ≈øize (≈øaith Raph Cogge≈øhall) and not farre thence, in the raigne of Elizabeth, more bones to the like wonder were digged vp.

(9) I purpo≈øely omit the me≈ø≈øage of a Pilgrim from S. Iohn Bapti≈øt, by whom he ≈øent a Ring to King Edward Confe≈øsor; for which cau≈øe his hou≈øe tooke the name Hauering: ≈øeeing the Monkes of tho≈øe times made no great daintie daily to forge matter for their owne aduantage: who in this Shire ≈øo ≈øwarmed that they had hou≈øes erected at Waltham, Pritlewell, Tiltey, Dun ‚Ä¢ ow, Leeye, Hatfeild Peuerell, Chelmesford, Cogge≈øhall, Maldon, Earls. coln, Col ‚Ä¢ he≈øter, S O≈øths, Saffron-Walden, Hatfield-Bradocke, and more, with great reuenewes thereto belonging; all which felt the Axes and Hammers of de≈øtruction, when the re≈øt of ≈øuch foundations fell vnder the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ile of King Henry the eight, who with Hezekiah brake downe all the≈øe Brazen Serpents.
(10) This Shire is diuided into 20. Hundreds, wherein are ≈øeated 21 Market-Townes, 5. Cattles, 5. Hauens, 2 of his Maje≈øties Mannours, and 415. Pari≈øh-Churches.

div.head: SVFFOLKE. CHAPTER XVI.
div.p: SVFFOLKE, in regard of them which were ≈øeated in Norfolke, is a Country mo≈øt plenteous and plea≈øant for habitation. It is ≈øeparated from Norfolke, by the Riuers of the le≈ø≈øer Ou≈øe, and Waueney, who≈øe heads meet almo≈øt in the mid≈øt of her Verge, and that very neere together: the one taking cour≈øe Ea≈øt, and the other full We≈øt, vpon which part Cambridge-≈øhire doth wholly confront. The South ≈øide is ≈øeuered by Stoure from E≈ø≈øex, and the Ea≈øt together wa≈øhed with the Germane Seas.

(2) The Ayre is good, ≈øweet, and delectable, and in ≈øome parts, of ≈øome of our be≈øt Phy≈øitians, held to be the be≈øt in the Land: the Soile is rich, fruitfull, and with all things well repleni≈øhed; in a word, nothing wanting for plea≈øure of profit.

(3) The forme thereof is ≈øome what Cre≈ø≈øant, ≈øhooting vp narrower into the North, and ≈øpreading wider towards the South, who≈øe broade≈øt part is about twentie miles: but from Ea≈øt to We≈øt much more; for from Ea≈øton point (the furthe≈øt of this Shire, yea of all Britaine into the Sea) vnto great Ou≈øe Riuer, her We≈øterne bounder, are fortie fiue miles, and the whole in circumference, about one hundred fortie ≈øixe miles.

(4) Anciently this part of the Iland was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Iceni, who as it ≈øeemeth by Tacitus, ioyned in Amitie with the Romans, a mightie people (≈øaith he) and neuer ≈øhaken with warres before the raigne of Claudius, but then by O≈øtorius were vanqui≈øhed, though not without great ≈ølaughter of the Romans; and in a Battle again≈øt them, M. O≈øtorius the ≈øonne of the Generall, wonne great honour in ≈øauing of a Roman Citizens life; ≈øo ready were they to giue and receiue Honours to them≈øelues, but ≈øleightly to pa≈ø≈øe ouer, and to ≈ømoother farre greater exployts of the Britaines: which notwith≈øtanding
long in the≈øe parts they could not doe; for the wrongs of the Icenians growing intolerable, who by the Romane Souldiers were put out of their rightfull po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, their Princes accounted no better then Slaues, and their Queene whipped in mo≈øt ignominious manner; vnder Boduo they wrought their reuenge, as in the Hi≈øtory (Chri≈øt a≈ø≈øi≈øting) ≈øhall be further related.

Next to the≈øe Icenians, were the Saxons that got their footing into the≈øe parts, and of them, this with Norfolke, Cambridge ≈øhire, and the Ile of Ely, was made their Ea≈øt-Angles Kingdome; though as it ≈øeemeth euer in ≈øubiection either to the Mercians, or to the Kings of Kent who≈øe off-≈øpring ending in S Edmund the Martyr, after the Danes had laid it mo≈øt de≈øolate, Edward the Elder ≈øubdued it vnto his We≈øt-Saxons Monarchy: and that likewi≈øe ending in King Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor, many Noble Normans got their po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions in the≈øe parts, who≈øe off-≈øpring are plenteou≈øly repleni≈øhed in this Shire to this day.

(5) The commodities of this Shire are many and great, whereof the chiefe≈øt con≈øi≈øteth in Corne, in Cattle, Cloth, Pa≈øturage, Woods, Sea-fi≈øh and Fowle; and as Abbo Floricen≈øis hath depainted, this Countie is of a greene and pa≈øsing fre≈øh hue, plea≈øantly repleni≈øhed with Orchards, Gardens and Groues ‚Ä¢
thus he de≈øcribed it aboue ≈øix hundred yeares ≈øince, and now we finde as he hath ≈øaid; to which we may adde their gaine from the Pa ‚Ä¢ le, who≈øe Chee≈øes are traded not onely thorowout England, but into Germany, France, and Spaine, and are highly commended by Pantaleon the Phy≈øitian, both for colour and ta≈øte.

(6) And had Ip≈øwich (the onely eye of this Shire) beene as fortunate in her Surname, as ≈øhe is ble≈ø≈øed with Commerce and buildings, ≈øhe might „Äà‚óä„Äâ haue borne the title of a Citie: neither ranked in the „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ and ≈øeat, doth equall mo≈øt places of the Land be
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ about, both by a Rampire of earth, mounted along her
North and We≈øt parts, and places of entrance where gates haue ≈øtood; which no doubt, by the Danes were ca≈øt downe, in the yeare of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt 991. when they ≈øacked with ≈øpoyle all the≈øe Sea-coa≈øts: and againe in the yeare one thou≈øand, laid the ≈øtreets de≈øolate, and the hou≈øes on heapes: yet afterwards recouering both breath and beautie, her buildings from St ‚Ä¢ ke-Church in the South, to Saint Margarets in the North, now containe 19 ‚Ä¢ 0 paces, and from S Helens in the Ea≈øt, to S. Matthewes Church in the We≈øt, are no le≈ø≈øe then 2120. full of ≈øtreets plenteou≈øly inhabited, wherein are twelue Pari≈øh-Churches ≈øeated, be≈øides them ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed; ≈øuch were Chri≈øt-Church, S Georges, S. Iames, the White, the Blacke, and Gray Fryers‚ñ™ The Site of this Towne is remoued from the Equator, vnto the degree 52. 25 minutes: and by Mercators ob≈øeruation, from the fir≈øt We≈øt points 22. degrees, 9 minutes: and is yearely gouerned by two Bailiffes, and ten Port-men, all wearing Scarlet with twenty-foure of their Common-Councell in purple: a Recorder, a Towne-Clerke, fiue Sergeants, whereof one is for the Admiraltie, a Beadle, and Common Cryer, all in blew, with the Townes Armes on their Sleeue.

The other Eye of this ≈øhire is S. Edmund ‚Ä¢ bury. By Abbo the Royall Towne, wherein at the day-breake of the Saxons conuer≈øion, Sigebert King of the Ea≈øt-Angles founded a Chri≈øtian Church: and vpon the occa≈øion of King Edmounds buriall (who at Hoxon was ≈øhot to death) hath beene euer ≈øince called S Edmunds-bury, where was built to his honour one of the faire≈øt Mona≈øteries in the world, begun by King Canute, much affrighted with the ≈øeeming appearance of that Martyrs Gho≈øt, who to expiate the Sacrilegious impietie of his Father Suenus, enriched the place with many endowments, and offred vp his owne Crowne vpon the „Äà‚óä„Äâ Martyrs Tombe. For the beautie and buildings of this Abbey and Towne, let Leyland for me declare: „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
finely ≈øeated, ≈øo delicately, vpon the ea≈øie a≈øcent of an hill,
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
≈øtately Abbey, either for reuenewes or incomparable
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
then a Mona≈øtery, ≈øo many Gates for entrance, and ≈øome of them bra≈ø≈øe, ≈øo many Towers, and a mo≈øt glorious Church, vpon which attend three others, ≈øtanding all in the ≈øame Church-yard, all of them pa≈øsing fine, and of a curious workman≈øhip. Who≈øe ruines lie in the du≈øt, lamenting their fall, mouing the beholders to pietie their ca≈øe.

Neere vnto this Towne a great Battle was fought by Robert Bo≈ø≈øu, Earle of Leice≈øter, again≈øt his Soueraigne King Henry the ≈øecond: but was worthily ouercome by Richard Lucy, the Kings high Iu≈øtice, him≈øelfe and wife taken, with many Flemings and Engli≈øhmen ≈ølaine.

(7) Other places worthy of remembrance this Countie affords; ≈øuch is Ex ‚Ä¢ ing in the We≈øt, formerly famous for the birth of S. Andrey, daughter to King Anna, one of the three names of the Shires diui≈øion. Rendl ‚Ä¢ ≈øham in the Ea≈øt, where Redwald the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian in this Kingdome held his Court: and Hadley in her South, where Guthrum the Dane whom Elfred baptized, was buried. And things of ≈øtranger note are the limits of the Ea≈øt-Angles Territories, running along New-market heath, vulgarly called the Diuels-ditch: the like fable is formally told by Nubrigen≈øis, that at Wulpet in the heart of this Shire, two greene boyes of Satyres kinde aro≈øe out of the ground, from the Antipodes; beleeue it if you will: and Ralfe Cogge≈øhall in the Monuments of C ‚Ä¢ l ‚Ä¢ he≈øter, declareth, that a Fi≈øh in all parts like a man was taken neere Orford, and for ≈øixe moneths was kept in the Ca≈øtle, whence after he e≈øcaped againe to the Sea.

As ≈øtrange, but mo≈øt true, was a crop of Pea≈øe, that without tillage or ≈øowing grew in the Rockes, betwixt this Orford and Aldebrough, in the yeare 1555 when by vn≈øea≈øonable weather a great dearth was in the Land: there in Augu≈øt were gathered aboue one hundred Quarters, and in blo≈ø≈øoming remained as many more, where neuer gra≈ø≈øe grew, or earth euer ≈øeene, but hard ≈øolide Rockes three yards deepe vnder their rootes.

(8) Places ≈øeparated from common v≈øe, and deuoted to God and his ≈øeruice by religious Princes, were at S. Edmunds, Ip≈øwich, Ikleworth, Blithborow, Clare, Iae≈øton, Burgh Ca≈øtle, wherein Sigebert King of the Ea≈øt-Angles entered the profe≈ø≈øion of a Monke: but was thence forced by his people, to fight again≈øt the Mercians: in which Battle he was ≈ølaine. And Dunwich, where Foelix founded his Epi≈øcopall See. The≈øe with many others in this Countie were ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed in the fall of the Mona≈øteries, and their Reuenewes a≈ø≈øumed by King Henry the Eight.

(9) This Shire is principally diuided into three parts, which are called the Celdable, S. Edmunds, and S. Audreys Liberties, ≈øubdiuided into twentie-two Hundreds and them againe into 575. Pari≈øh-Churches, wherein are ≈øeated ≈øeauen Ca≈øtles, and twentie-eight Market-Townes.

div.head: NORTHFOLKE. CHAPTER XVII.
div.p: NORTHFOLKE is an Iland inclining to an ouall forme, clo≈øed on the South part with the Riuers of Waueney and the l ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øer Ou≈øe, which diuides it from Suffolke. On the Ea≈øt and North with the Germane Ocean; on the We≈øt toward Cambridge-≈øhire, with ≈øome branches of the greater Ou≈øe; toward Lincolne-≈øhire with that part of the neue which pa≈ø≈øeth from Wi≈øbitch into the Wa≈øhes.
It containeth in length (from Yarmouth to Wi≈øbitch) about fiftie miles‚ñ™ In breadth (from Thetford to Wels) about thirtie. The whole Circuit is about two hundred fortie two miles.
The Name ari≈øeth from the ≈øituation of the people, who being the Norther-mo≈øt of the Kingdome of Ea≈øt-Angles, are therefore called the Northfolke, as the Souther-mo≈øt of the Southfolke‚ñ™

The Ayre is ≈øharpe and piercing, e≈øpecially in the Champion, and neere the Sea ‚Ä¢ therefore it delaieth the Spring and Harue≈øt, the ≈øituation of the Country inclining thereto, as being vnder the 53. degree of Latitude.

The So ‚Ä¢ e diuers: about the Townes commonly good; as Clay; Chalke, or ≈øa ‚Ä¢ earth, well watered, and with ≈øome wood: vpward to the Heaths naked, dry, and barren: Mar≈øland and Flegg exceeding rich; but Mar≈øland properly for Pa≈øtere, Flegg for Corne.

(2) The parts from Thetford to Buruham, and thence We≈øtward, as al≈øo along the Coa≈øt, be counted Champion: the re≈øt (as better furni≈øhed with woods) Woodland. The Champion aboundeth with Corne, Sheepe, and Conies, and here in the barren Heaths (as the prouidence of our Ance≈øtors hath of old di≈øpo≈øed them) are very profitable. For on them principally lie our Fould cour≈øes, called
of the Saxons (who≈øe in≈øtitution they therefore ≈øeeme to be) Paldyoeun, that is, Libertie of fold or fouldage. The≈øe Heaths by the Compa≈øture of the ≈øheepe (which we call Tath:) are made ≈øo rich with Corne, that when they fall to be ≈øowne, they commonly match the fruitfulle≈øt grounds in other Countries and laid againe, doe long after yeeld a ≈øweeter and more plentifull feed for ≈øheepe: ≈øo that each of them maintaine other, and are the chiefe≈øt wealth of our Country. The Woodland (fitter for gra≈ø≈øe) is maintained chiefly by feeding of Cattell, yet well ≈øtored with Corne and Sheepe.
The Coa≈øt is fortunate in Fi≈øh‚ñ™ and hath many good Harbours, whereof Lenn and Yarmouth be the mother-ports, and of great traffique: Wels and Blakeney next in e≈øtimation.

The whole Countie aboundeth with Riuers and plea≈øant Springs, of which the Ou≈øe is chiefe≈øt, by who≈øe plentifull branches, the I≈øle of Fly, the Townes and Shires of Cambridge, Humington, and the Countie of Suffolke vent and receiue Commodities. The next is Hierus or Yere, pa≈ø≈øing from Norwich to Yarmouth, where it receiueth the Bure comming from Ayl≈øham, both of them of great ≈øeruice for water-carriages, but very notable for their plenty of „Äà‚óä„Äâ for ≈øome one man out of an hold vpon the Bure, hath drawne vp ordinarily once a yeare, betweene two Nets, about fiue or ≈øix ≈øcore bu≈øne≈øs of Fi≈øh at one draught. The Waueney and the le≈ø≈øer Ou≈øe are al≈øo Nauigable and of great v≈øe. The re≈øidue I omit.

(3) I he people were anciently called ICENI, as they al≈øo of Suffolke, Cambridge-≈øhire, and Huntington-≈øhire, and ≈øuppo≈øed to be of them whom Cae≈øar nameth Cenimagni; Ptolemie, Simeni; ≈øome T ‚Ä¢ gens. Their manners were likely to be as the re≈øt of the Britaines, barbarous at tho≈øe times, as appeareth by Cae≈øar and Tacitus, Neither can I otherwi≈øe commend their Succe≈ø≈øors the Saxons: for ≈øo al≈øo their owne Countryman Ethelwerd termeth them. Since the entry of the Normans, they haue beene accounted ciuill and ingenious, apt to good Letters, adorning Religion with more Churches and Mona≈øteries, then any Shire of England, and the Lawes and Seats of Iu≈øtice (for many ages)
with ≈øome excellent men; from whom mo≈øt of our chiefe Families, and ≈øome of the greate≈øt Nobility of the Kingdome, haue taken aduancement And herein is Northfolke fortunate, that as Crete boa≈øted of an hundred Cities, ≈øo may ≈øhe of an hundred Families of Gentlemen, neuer yet attainted of high Trea≈øon. How the gouernment of this Country was about Cae≈øars time, is vncertaine, but (agreeable no doubt to the re≈øt of the Britaines) vnder ≈øome peculiar Toparch or Regulus, as Tacitus termeth him. The latter Romans held it by two Garri≈øons, one at Gariannum neere Yarmouth; the other at Branedunum, now called Branca≈øtre, both of hor≈øe, and commanded by the Comes Maritims Tractus, as Marcellinus calleth him, termed after Comes Littoris Saexonici Vpon the entry of the Saxons, this Countie with Suffolke fell in the portion of the Angles, and about the yeare fiue hundred ≈øixtie one, were together erected into a Kingdome by Vffa, of whom the ≈øucceeding Kings were tituled Vffines. But hauing ≈øuffred many Tempe≈øts of Fortune, it was in the yeare 870. vtterly wa≈øted and extinct by Hungar and Hubba the Danes, who ouerthrew the vertuous King Edmund about Thetford, and after martyred him at S. Edmundsbury. Yet they did not long enioy it: for King Edward ≈øhortly recouered it from them, and annexed it to his other Kingdomes. The Danes notwith≈øtanding inhabited abundantly in the≈øe parts, ≈øo that many of our Townes were founded by them, and a great part of our people and Gentry are ri≈øen out of their bloud.

(4) This Kingdome of Ea≈øt-Angles was after allotted to an Earledome of that name by William the Conquerour, who made Radulph a Britaine, marying his kin≈øwoman, Earle thereof; but gaue the greate≈øt parts of this Countie about Wimondham, Keninghall, Lenn, Buruham, Fulmer≈øtone, &c. to W. de Albany, Pincernae, and W de Warranna Forre≈øtario, who to ≈øtrengthen them≈øelues (according to the v≈øe of that time) with the homage and ≈øeruice of many tenants, diuided large portions of the ≈øame among≈øt their friends and followers; ≈øo that mo≈øt of the Manours and Lands in the parts afore≈øaid, were in tho≈øe dayes either mediately or immediately holden of one of them. And as Northfolke
and Suffolke were fir≈øt vnited in a Kingdome, then in an Earledome, ≈øo they continued vnited in the Sheriffe-wicke till about the fifteenth yeare of Queene Elizabeth.

(5) The Townes here are commonly well built, and populous; three of them being of that worth and qualitie, as no one Shire of England hath the like, Norwich, Lenn, and Yarmouth: to which for ancient reputation (as hauing beene a ≈øeat of the Kings of Ea≈øt-Angles) I may adde Thetford, knowne to Antonius, Ptolemie, and elder ages, by the name of Sitemagus, when the other three were yet in their infancie, and of no e≈øteeme: for I accept not the Relations of the Antiquitie and State of Norwich in the time of the Britaine and Saxons, though Alexander Neuil hath well graced them. Her very name abridgeth her Antiquitie, as hauing no other in Hi≈øtories but Norwich, which is meere Saxon or Dani≈øh, and ≈øignifieth the North-Towne or Ca≈øtle. It ≈øeemeth to haue ri≈øen out of the decay of her neighbour Vinta, now called Ca≈øtor, and as M. Cambden noteth, not to haue beene of mar ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
before the entry of the Danes, who in the yeare 1004. vnder Sweno their Captaine, fir≈øt ≈øackt, and then burnt it, euen in her infancie‚ñ™ Yet in the dayes of Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor it recouered 1320. Burge≈ø≈øet. But maintaining the cau≈øe of Earle Radulph afore≈øaid again≈øt the Conquerour, they were by famine and ≈øword wa≈øted to 560 at which time the Earle e≈øcaping by ≈øhip, his wife vpon compo≈øition yeelded the Ca≈øtle, and followed „Äà‚óä„Äâ
William Ru≈øu ‚Ä¢
time it was growne famous for Merchandi≈øe and concour≈øe of people; ≈øo that Herbert then tran≈ølating the Bi≈øhopricke from Thetford thither, made each of them an ornament to other. In varietie of times it felt much varietie of Fortune: By fire in Anno 1508. By extreame plagues, whereof one in An. 1348. was ≈øo outragious, as 17104. are reported to haue died thereof betweene the Calends of Ianuary and of Iuly. By mi≈øery of warre, as ≈øacked and ≈øpoyled by the Earle of Flaunders and Hugh Big ‚Ä¢ d, Anno 1174. In yeelding to Lewis the French, again≈øt their naturall Lord King Iohn, Anno 1216. By the di≈øinherited Barons, An. 1266. By tumult and in≈øurrection betweene the Citizens and Church-men: once about the yeare 1265.
which if Henry the third had not come in per≈øon to appea≈øe, the Citie was in hazard to be ruined: The ≈øecond time in Anno 1446. for which the Major was depo≈øed, and their Liberties for a while ≈øelfed. In Edward the ≈øixths time, by Ketts rebellion, who≈øe fury chiefly raged again≈øt this Citie. Since this it hath flouri≈øhed with the ble≈ø≈øings of Peace, Plentie, Wealth and Honour: ≈øo that Alxander Neu ‚Ä¢
doubteth not to preferre it aboue all the Cities of England, except London. It is ≈øituate vpon the Riuer Hierus, in a „Äà‚óä„Äâ valley, but on u≈øing ground, hauing on the Ea≈øt the Hilles and Heath called Mu≈ø≈øold for Mo≈øt-would, as I take it. In the 17 yeare of King Stephen it was new founded, and made a Corporation‚ñ™ In Edward the fir≈øts time, clo≈øed with a ≈øame Wall, ‚Ä¢ auing on a part that the Riuer defendeth. Fir≈øt gouerned by foure Bayliffes; then by Henry the fourth in An 1403. erected into a Majoraltie and County; the limits whereof now extend to Eatonb ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ge‚ñ™ At this pre≈øent it hath about thirtie Pari≈øhes, but in ancient time had many more.

(6) Lenn hauing beene an ancient Borrough vnder the Gouernment of a Bayliffe or Reue, called Praepo≈øitus, was by King Iohn in the ≈øixt yeare of his Raigne made Liber Burgus, and (be≈øides the gift of his memorable Cup, which to this day honoureth this Corporation) endowed with diuers faire Liberties. King Henry the third in the 17 yeare of his Raigne (in recompence of their ≈øeruice again≈øt the out-lawed Barons in the I≈øle of Ely) enlarged their Charter, and granted them further, to choo≈øe a Major Loco Prapo≈øiti: vnto whom King Henry the Eight, in the ≈øixteenth yeare of his Raigne, added twelue Aldermen, a Recorder, and other Officers, and the bearing of a ≈øword before the Major. But the Towne comming after to the ≈øame King, he in the twentie-ninth of his Raigne, changed their name, from Mator & Burge ‚Ä¢ ≈øes Lenn Epi≈øcopi, to Mator & Burge ‚Ä¢ ≈øes Lenn Regis.

(7) Yarmouth is the Key of the Coa≈øt, named and ≈øeated by the mouth of the Riuer Yere. Begun in the time of the V ‚Ä¢ nes, and by ≈ømall acce≈ø≈øions growing populous, made a Corporation vnder two
Bayliffes by King Henry the third‚ñ™ and by his Charter, about the fifteenth yeare of his Raigne, walled It‚ñ™ It is an ancient member of the Ci ‚Ä¢ que Ports, very well built and fortified, hauing onely one Church (but faire and large) founded by Bi≈øhope Herbert, in William Rufus dayes. It maintaineth a Peere again≈øt the Sea, at the yearely charge of fiue hundred pound, or thereabout: yet hath it no po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, as other Corporations, but like the children of Aeol ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
and Thetis: Maria & 4. ventos, as an Inqui≈øitor findeth An. 10. Hen 3. There is yearely in September the worthie≈øt. Herring-fi≈øhing in Europe, which draweth great concour≈øe of people, and maketh the Towne much the richer all the yeare, but very vn≈øauoury for the time. The Inhabitants are ≈øo curteous, as they haue long held a cu≈øtome to fea≈øt all per≈øons of worth, repairing to their Tovvne.

(8) The Bi≈øhopricke of Norwich had fir≈øt here≈øeat at Dunwich in Suffolke, and was there begun by Foelix, who conuerted this Countie, and the Ea≈øt-Angles) to the Faith. Being brought out of Burgundie by Sigeber ‚Ä¢
(the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King of the Ea≈øt-Angles) he landed at Babingley by Lenn, and there builded the fir≈øt Church of the≈øe Countries, which in his memory, is at this day called by his Name. The ≈øecond he built at Shar ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ bourn then of wood, and therefore called Stock-Chappell. After Foelix and three of his Succe≈ø≈øors, this Bi≈øhopricke was diuided into two Sees: the one with eleuen Bi≈øhops in ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, continuing at Dunwich; the other with twelue at Elmham in Norfolke. Then vnited againe in the time of King Edwyn, the entire See for twelue other Bi≈øhops remained at Elmham, and in the Conquerours time was by his Chaplaine Arfa≈øtus (being the thirteenth) tran≈ølated to Thetford, from thence by Herbert (his next Succe≈ø≈øor ≈øaue one) bought of W. Ru≈øus for 1900. pounds, and brought to Norwich. This Herbert (≈øurnamed Lo≈øinga a Norman) builded the Cathedrall Church there, and endowed it with large po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions. Not far from thence he al≈øo builded another Church to S. Leonard, a third at Elmham, a fourth at Lenn, (S. Margarets, a very faire one) and the
fifth at Yarmouth before mentioned. By the Cathedrall Church he builded a Palace for the Bi≈øhops, and founded the Priory there (now conuerted to Deane and Chapter) and another Priory at Thetford.
