Since his time the Bi≈øhops See hath immoueably remained at Norwich, but the ancient Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion are ≈øeuered from it, and in lieu thereof the Abbey and Lands of S Benedict of Holme annexed to it. The Commodities of this Countie I haue contained in the≈øe four Ver≈øes.

q.l: Ingenio & populi cultu Norfolcia clari e≈øt;
Hinc fluvijs, illine In≈øula clau≈øa mari;
Qua ratis, & vellus, frumenta, cuniculus, agnus.
Lac ≈øcatet, & pi≈øces, pabula, mella, crocus.

div.p: This De≈øcription of Northfolke, I reciued from the Right Wor≈øhipfull, Sir HENRY SPELMAN Knight.

div.head: CAMBRIDGE-SHIRE. CHAPTER XVIII.
div.p: (2) This Prouince is not large, nor for ayre greatly to be liked, hauing the Fennes ≈øo ≈øpread vpon her North, that they infect the ayre far into the re≈øt: From who≈øe furthe≈øt point vnto Roy≈øton in the South, are thirtie-fiue miles; but in the broade≈øt is not fully twentie: the whole in Circumference, traced by the compa≈ø≈øe of her many indents, one hundred twentie and eight miles.

(3) The Soile doth differ both in ayre and commodities; the Fenny ≈øurcharged with waters: the South is Champion, and yeeldeth Corne in abundance, with Meadowing. Pa≈øtures vpon both the ≈øides of the Riuer Came, which diuides that part of the Shire in the mid≈øt, vpon who≈øe Ea≈øt-bancks the Mu≈øes haue built their mo≈øt ≈øacred Seat, where with plenteous increa≈øe they haue continued for the≈øe many hundred yeares.

(4) For from ancient Grantce≈øter, Camboritum by Antonine, now famous Cambridge, the other bre≈øt and Nur≈øe-mother of all pious literature, haue flowed full ≈øteames of the learned Sciences into all other parts of this Land, and el≈øe-where: ancient indeed, if their Story be rightly writ, that will haue it built by Cantaber a Spaniard, three hundred ≈øeauenty fiue yeares before the birth of our Sauiour, who thither fir≈øt brought and planted the Mu≈øes. This Citie Grantce≈øter by the tyranny of time lo≈øt both her owne beautie and her profe≈ø≈øed Athenian Students, ≈øo that in Bedaes dayes, ≈øeauen hundred yeares after the Word became fle≈øh, it is de≈øcribed to lye a little de≈øolate Citie, and as yet retaineth the name, without any memory of circuit by wals.

Of this Citie, in the yeare of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus 141. as the Monke of Barton doth report, nine Scholars receiued their Bapti≈øme, and became Preachers of the Go≈øpell among the Britaines; which (as he ≈øaith) happened in the Raigne of Hadriant the Emperour. But when the „Äà‚óä„Äâ , Stors, His ‚Ä¢ nes and Saxons had laid all things wa≈øte, and with their ≈øauage ≈øwords cut out the leaues of all ciuill learning, this as the re≈øt yeelded to de≈øtruction, and ≈øo lay forlorne till the Saxons them≈øelues became likewi≈øe ciuill; when S ‚Ä¢ gebert the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King of the Ea≈øt-Angles, from the example of France, whither he had beene bani≈øhed, built Schooies in his Kingdome, and here at Grance≈øter the chiefe, recalling thither the Profe≈ø≈øors of Arts and Sciences, as the Story recordeth, and Traditions doe hold.

But afterwards, as it ≈øeemeth, their increa≈øe being ≈øtraightned, the Students complained (as the Prophets did to Eli≈øha) that the place was too little for them to dwell in, therefore inlarging more North-ward, ≈øeated them≈øelues neere vnto the Bridge, whereupon the place began to be called Grantbridge, though others from the crooked Riuer Came will haue it named Cambridge. This place (though ≈øacred and exempted from Mars, as Sylla once ≈øpake; when he ≈øpared Athens,) the Danes in their de≈øtructions regarded no whit, wherein they often wintered after their ≈øpoyles, and left the ≈øcatres of their ≈øauage ≈øores euer behinde them. And in the yeare 1010 when Suen in his fiercene≈ø≈øe bare downe all before him, this place was no place for Scholars to be in: Warres loud Alarums ill con≈øorting the Mu≈øes milde Harmonies. Yet when the Normans had got the Garland on their heads, and the≈øe Dani≈øh ≈øtormes turned into Sun-≈øhine dayes, Gi≈ølebert the Monke, with Odo, Terricus, and William, all three of the like Mona≈øticall Profe≈øsion, in the Raigne of King Henry the Fir≈øt, re≈øorted vnto this place, and in a publike Barne read the Lectures of Grammar, Logicke, and Rhetoricke, and Gi≈ølebert Diuinitie vpon the Sabbath and Fe≈øtiuall dayes. From this little fountaine (≈øaith Peter Ble≈ø≈øen≈øis) grew a great Riuer, which made all England fruitfull, by the many Ma≈øters & Teachers proceeding out of Cambridge, as out of a holy Paradi≈øe of God. The fir≈øt Colledge therein endowed with Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions was Peterhou≈øe,
built by Hugh Bal≈øham Bi≈øhop of Ely, in the yeare of Grace, 1284. who≈øe godly example many others followed, ≈øo that at this day there are ≈øixteene mo≈øt ≈øtately Colledges and Hals, for building, beautie, endowments, and ≈øtore of Students ≈øo repleni≈øhed, that vnle≈ø≈øe it be in her other Si≈øter Oxford, the like are not found in all Europe.

But at what time it was made an Vniuer≈øitie, let Robert de Remyngton tell you for me. Do the Raigne (≈øaith he) of King Edward the fir≈øt, Grantbridge, of a Schoole, by the Court of Rome, was made an Vniuer≈øitie, ≈øuch as Oxford is. La≈øtly, the Meridian Line cutting the Zenith ouer this Citie, is di≈øtant from the furthe≈øt We≈øt-poynt, according to Mercator, 20 degrees, 50 ≈øcruples, and the Arch of the ≈øame Meridian, lying betweene the Aequator and Verticall point, is 52. degrees, 20 ≈øcruples.

(5) Another Citie formerly in great fame is Elie, had in account for the repute and holine≈ø≈øe of Votary Nunnes there re≈øiding; built fir≈øt by Audrey wife to one Tombret a Prince in this Prouince, who had this place as a part of her Dowry: ≈øhe hauing departed from her ≈øecond Husband Egbert King of Northumberland deuoted her ≈øelfe to the ≈øeruice of God, and built here a Mona≈øtery, whereof ≈øhe became the fir≈øt Abbe≈ø≈øe. This in the Dani≈øh de≈øolations was de≈øtroyed, but ≈øoone after reedified by Ethelwold Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter, who ≈øtored it with Monkes; vnto whom King Edgar granted the iuri≈ødiction ouer foure Hundreds and a halfe, within the≈øe Fennes and the Ea≈øt-Angles limits, which to this day are called The Liberties of S. Audrey, after who≈øe example many Nobles ≈øo enriched it with large Renexewes, that as Malmesbury ≈øaith, the Abbat thereof laid vp yeerely in his owne Coffers a thou≈øand and foure hundred pounds And of latter times the Monkes thereof became ≈øo wealthy, that their old decayed Church they renued with new and mo≈øt ≈øtately buildings, which is now the Cathedrall of the Dioce≈ø≈øe, and for beautie giueth place to no other in the Land Eight other foundations ≈øet apart from ≈øecular v≈øe in this Prouince, were at Thorney, Charteres, Denny, El≈øey, Beach, Barnwell, Swa≈øey, and Shengey, all which in the dayes of King Henry the eight came to the period of their ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing wealth, and left their Lands to the di≈øpo≈øe of his Will.

(6) The generall commoditie of this Shire is Corne, which in the South, and Champion-part doth abundantly grow, as al≈øo Saffron, a very rich Spice. Some Woods there are, and Pa≈øture both plea≈øant and profitable. The North part thereof is Fenny, but withall fruitfull, whereof Henry of Huntington and William of Malinesbury thus doe write: This Fenny Country is pa≈øsing rich and plenteous, yea, and beautifull al≈øo to behold, whereiwis ≈øo great ≈øtore of fi≈øh, that ≈øtrangers doe wonder, and water-fowle ≈øo cheape, that fiue men may therewith be ≈øatisfied with le≈ø≈øe then an halfe-penny.

(7) Places of ancient note in this Shire are the≈øe, the Ermin≈øtreet way, which vpon the lower We≈øt parts of this County, thorow Roi≈øen, runneth forthright vnto Huntingdon. And from Reach a Market-Towne ≈øtanding neere to the Riuer Came, a great Ditch and Trench is ca≈øt all along Newmarket-Heath, which for the wonder receiued thereat, is of the vulgar called The Deu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Ditch, being in truth made for a defence again≈øt the Mercians by the Ea≈øt-Angles, who≈øe Kingdome it inuerged. The Gogmagog Hils neere Cambridge retaine the remembrance of the Dani≈øh Siaetion, where as yet on their tops is ≈øeene a Rampior, ≈øtrengthened with a three-fold Trench, whereof Gorua≈øe of Tillury tels vs many a pretio Tale.

(8) This Shire is diuided into ≈øeuenteene Hundreds, wherein are ≈øeated eight Market-Townes, and hath beene ≈øtrengthended with ≈øeauen Ca≈øtles, and God diuinely honoured in one hundred ≈øixtie three Pari≈øh-Churches.

div.head: HERTFORD-SHIRE. CHAPTER XIX.
div.p: HERTFORD-SHIRE is bordered vpon the North with Bedford and Cambridge-≈øhires; vpon the Ea≈øt, is altogether bounded by E≈ø≈øex; vpon the South, is confined with Middle≈øex; and her We≈øt butteth vpon Buckingham and Bedford-≈øhires.

(2) The forme thereof is ≈øomwhat circular, with many indents to fetch in tho≈øe Townes that are di≈øper≈øedly ≈øtragled into her next Shire: whereof Roi≈øton and Totteridge are the two extreames from North to South, betwixt whom in a ≈øtrait drawne line are twenty ≈øeuen Engli≈øh miles, and from Putnam We≈øtward, to Che≈øton Nunnery in the Ea≈øt, are twenty eight; the whole circumference, about an hundred and thirtie miles.

(3) The ayre is temperate, ≈øweet, and healthfull, as ≈øeated in a Climate neither too hot, nor too cold: the ≈øoile is rich, plenteous, and delightfull, yeelding abundance of Corne, Cattle, Wood, and Gra≈ø≈øe, de≈øtitute of nothing that mini≈øtreth profit or plea≈øures for life, which are more augmented by the many Riuers that ari≈øe and run thorow this Shire, watering her owne and others, till they emptie them≈øelues into the Sea.

(4) Her ancient Inhabitants in the time of the Romans were the Cattieuchlanians, or Ca≈øsijans, and the Trinobantes, as their Writers declare, and in the Heptar ‚Ä¢ hy was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Ea≈øt-Saxons, excepting ≈øome ≈ømall portion thereof, that the Mercian Kings enioyned. The Danes al≈øo in their ouerrunnings, ≈øought to ≈øtay them≈øelues in this Shire, and at Ware (then Weare) pitched downe their re≈øt and hope: for pa≈ø≈øing the Lea in their light Pinnaces and Shallops, rai≈øed therein a Fort, which maugre the Engli≈øh they kept, vntill that by the wi≈øe police of King Elfred, that Riuer was parted into
to more running ≈øtreames, whereby their Ships peri≈øhed, and they intercepted both of proui≈øion and farther ≈øupply.

(5) The Romans before them had made Verolaxium in this Shire their greate≈øt for account, which in Neroes time was a Municipiall, as Nimus in his Catalogue of Cities doth call it, or as Tacitus, a Free Towne; ≈øacked by Boduo that euer eternized Queene of the Ictanians, when ≈øeuenty thou≈øand of the Romans and Con≈øecrates by her reuenging ≈øword peri≈øhed: the ≈øite and circuit whereof, in this Card we haue ≈øet according to our view and mea≈øure there taken: who≈øe magnificence for Port and ≈øtately Architecture, were found by her large and arched Vaults in the dayes of King Edgar, which were digged into and ca≈øt downe by „Äà‚óä„Äâ and „Äà‚óä„Äâ , Abbots of S. Albanes, for that they were the receptacles and lurking holes of „Äà‚óä„Äâ and „Äà‚óä„Äâ : the ruines of which, haue rai≈øed the beautie of her ≈øuruiuing and faire S. Albanes, where „Äà‚óä„Äâ the great Mercian, in great deuotion, built a mo≈øt ≈øtately
„Äà‚óä„Äâ who≈øe Church yet ≈øtanding, retaineth the a≈øhes of many Nobles, there ≈ølaine in the quarrell of Yorke and Lanca≈øter; and a Font of ≈øolid bra≈ø≈øe brought out of Scotland by Sir Richara Lea, from the ≈øiege of L ‚Ä¢ eth

(6) Many other Townes, both for Commerce, ≈øtately Buildings, and of ancient Record, this Shire affordeth, whereof Hertford, though the Shire-Towne, is not the riche≈øt; the pa≈ø≈øage thorow Ware hath left her wayes ≈øo vntrodden: to preuent which, in former times that Riuer at Ware was chained vp, and the Bayliffe of Hertford had the cu≈øtody of the Key: which how≈øoeuer they haue lo≈øt, yet hath the Towne gotten her Gouernour to be preferred from the name of a Bili≈ø≈øe, vnto a Maior, a≈ø≈øi≈øted with nine Burg ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øes, a Recorder, and two Sergeants their Attendants. Herein a Ca≈øtle, for ≈øituation plea≈øant, for Trench, Walles, and Riuer, ≈øufficiently fenced, was lately ≈øeene; but marked to de≈øtinie, as the Towne to decay, hath found the hand of Fortune to ouermatch her ≈øtrength, and to ruinate the Priory, S. Nicholas, and S. Maries Churches, be≈øides a Cell of S. Albanes Monkes, that therein
were ≈øeated. The like fate fals vnto Hem≈øled, and her faire Ca≈øtle, wherein Richard King of the Romans left his life Yet Lingely is graced both in the birth of Prince Edmund the fifth ≈øonne to King Edward the third, and the buriall of Richard the ≈øecond that vnfortunate King, who in the Cell of Fryers Preachers was there fir≈øt buried, but afterwards remooued and en≈øhrined at We≈øtmin≈øter. And in another Langley, neere the Ea≈øt from thence, was borne that Pontificall Break-≈øpeare, Bi≈øhop of Rome, knowne by the name of Hadrian the fourth, (and famous for his ≈øtirrup-holding by Fredericke the Emperour) who≈øe breath was la≈øtly ≈øtopped by a Flie that flew into his mouth.

(7) The ciuill Battles that in this Shire haue beene ≈øought, in the Map it ≈øelfe are in≈øerted, and therefore here omitted, but the more ancient remembred vnto vs by O≈øi≈øter-hill neere S. Albans, whom the judicious Combden ≈øuppo≈øeth to haue beene the Campe of O≈øtorius the ≈øecond Lieutenant, and Subdue ‚Ä¢
of great Caractatus; as al≈øo ≈øeuen ≈ømall round Hils betwixt Sieuennedge and Ku ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ worth, in which are ≈øuppo≈øed ≈øome Romane Souldiers to lie buried.

(8) Religious Hou≈øes built and ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, the chiefe≈øt for account in this Shire, were S. Albans, Ro ‚Ä¢ ≈øton, Ware, Sopwell, Langeley, be≈øides them at Hertford, whom Beda cals Horudford: which Cities graduation is di≈øtant and remoued from the Equator 52. degrees 5. minutes of Latitude, and ≈øet from the fir≈øt point of the We≈øt, according to Mercator, in the 20 degree 29. minutes of Longitude. The
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
domes whereof, were enioyed onely by tho ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ two honourable „Äà‚óä„Äâ who≈øe atchieuements we haue al≈øo therein expre≈ø≈øed.
(9) This Counties diui≈øion is into eight Hundreds, wherein are ≈øeared eighteene Market-Townes, and one hundred and twentie Pari≈øh-Churches.

div.head: BEDFORD-SHIRE. CHAPTER XX.
div.p: BEDFORD-SHIRE, ≈øeated in the South-Ea≈øt of this Iland, is a plaine and champion Country, and lyeth bounded vpon the North with Huntington-≈øhire; vpon the Ea≈øt with Cambridge and Hartford-≈øhires; vpon the South with Hartford and Buckingham-≈øhires; and vpon the We≈øt with Buckingham and Northampton-≈øhires.

(2) The forme thereof is ≈øomwhat ouall, and not very large: for from Tilbroke in the North, vnto Stu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ am in the South, are but twentie-foure Engli≈øh miles; and from Turny in the We≈øt, vnto Hatley Coking in the Ea≈øt, are not fully foureteene; the whole in Circumference, about ≈øeauenty three miles.

(3) The Ayre is temperate, and the Soile bounteous, e≈øpecially the North, who≈øe Borders the fruitfull Ou≈øe with her many windings watereth. The South is more leane, and with greater indu≈øtry bringeth forth Barley, no better el≈øe-where. Generally, this County is Champion, though ≈øome places be ≈øprinkled with Pa≈øturage and Woods.

(4) The ancient Inhabitants knowne to the Romanes, that held in this Shire, were part of the Cattieuchlani, a ≈øtout and warre-≈øtrring people: and yet vpon the report of Cae≈øars proceeding, ≈øent him their ≈øubiection for peace. But when that conquering Nation had brought Britaine into a Prouince vnder Rome, their Legions lay at Selenae and Magintum, which are now Sandy and Dun≈øtable, places of memorable note in this Shire. After them the Saxons coueting for ≈øo faire a Seate, fir≈øt di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the Britaines, vnder the leading of Cuthwulfe the We≈øt-Saxon, about the yeare of Grace 572. who making it their owne, was la≈øtly enioyed by the Mercians, as a part of their Kingdome.

(5) In the yeare of Chri≈øts Incarnation 1399 immediately before tho≈øe Ciuill Warres, that rent in pieces the peace of this Land, betweene the Princes of Lanca≈øter and Yorke, the Riuer Ou≈øe neere vnto Harwood, ≈øtood ≈øodainly ≈øtill, and refrained to pa≈ø≈øe any farther; ≈øo that forward, men pa≈ø≈øed three miles together on foot in the very depth of her Channell; and backward, the waters ≈øwelled vnto a great height: which was ob≈øerued by the judicious, to foretell ≈øome vnkinde diui≈øion that ≈øhortly ≈øhould ari≈øe.

(6) This Countie, among the common calamities of the Land, when it lay trampied vnder the fect of the Danes, ≈øu≈øtained a part: and after that, in the time of King Stephen, when the Ciuill Warres thundred betwixt Maud the Empre≈ø≈øe and him≈øelfe, the Shire-Towne was ≈øore wa≈øted, with great ≈ølaughter of men: So when the Barons for≈øooke their allegeance to King Iohn, the Towne and Ca≈øtle were rendred vp vnto their hands: and la≈øtly, by King Henry the third, laid leuell euen with the ground, ≈øome ruinous walles appearing towards the Ou≈øe, but not a ≈øtone left vpon the Mount where ≈øtood his foundation.

(7) This Towne by the Britaines was called Lettidur; and of vs, Bedford: being the chiefe≈øt in the Countie, from whom it taketh the name, and is mo≈øt fruitfull, and plea≈øantly ≈øeated, hauing the Ou≈øe running thorow the Towne in the midde≈øt, and a faire Stone-bridge built ouer the ≈øame, whereon are two Gates to locke and impeach the pa≈ø≈øage, as occa≈øion ≈øhall ≈øerue. At the fir≈øt entrance ≈øtandeth S. Leonards Ho≈øpitall for Lazars: and further inwards, S. Iohns and S. Maries Churches: within the Towne, S. Pauls, a mo≈øt beautifull Church, S. Cuthberis, and S. Peters: without the Towne ≈øtandeth the Fryers, S. Loyes, Alhallowes, and Caudwell Abbey: not farre whence ≈øometimes ≈øtood a Chappell vpon the Banke of Ou≈øe, wherein (as Florilegus affirmeth) the body of Offa the great Mercian King was interred, but by the ouer-≈øwelling of that Riuer, was borne downe, and ≈øwallowed vp; who≈øe Tombe of Lead (as it were ≈øome phanta≈øticall thing) appeared often to them
that ≈øeeke it not, but to them that ≈øeeke it (≈øaith Ro≈ø≈øe) it is inui≈øible. This Towne is gouerned yearely by a Mator, two Bailiffes, two Chamberlaines, a Recorder, a towne-Clerke, and three Sergeants with Ma≈øes.

(8) A tale of vaine credit is reported of Dun≈øtable, that it was built to bridle the outragiou≈øne≈ø≈øe of a theefe named Dun, by King Henry the fir≈øt: but certaine it is the place was formerly held by the Romanes, who≈øe Legions there lay, as appeareth by the Coines there v≈øually found, which from Magmium are corruptly called Madning-money.

(9) Ca≈øtles in this Shire are Woodhill, Eaton, Tem≈øford, and Amphill, an honour now appertaining to the Crowne. And places of Religion, built by deuout per≈øons, but for Idolatrous Abu≈øes againe aboli≈øhed, were at Bedford, Harwood, Helenflow, Newenham, Chick≈øand, Wardon, Woborne, and Dun≈øtable. All the≈øe, with their like, felt the hand of Henry the Eight to lie ≈øo heauie vpon them, that they were not able to ≈øu≈øtaine the waight, but were cru≈øhed to peices, and fell to the ground.

(10) The Graduation of this Countie, taken for the Shire-Towne, is placed from the Equator in the degree of 52. and 30. minutes for Latitude, and is remoued from the fir≈øt We≈øt point of Longitude, 20. degrees and 16. minutes.

div.head: BVCKINGHAM-SHIRE. CHAPTER XXI.
div.p: BVCKINGHAM, for the plentie of Beech-trees there growing, and tho≈øe in the elder times of the Saxons called Eucken, may well be ≈øuppo≈øed from them to haue the name, as afterwards the whole Shire had hers from this Towne Buckingham.

(2) In forme it ≈øomewhat re≈øembleth a Lyon Rampant, who≈øe head or North-point toucheth the Counties of Northampton and Bedford; who≈øe backe or Ea≈øt-part is backed by Bedford and Hertford-≈øhires: his loines or South-borders re≈øt vpon Bark ≈øhire, and his brea≈øt the We≈øt ≈øide is butted vpon wholly by Oxford-≈øhire The length thereof from Waisbury in the South, to Bradfeild in her North, are thirtie nine miles: the breadth at the broade≈øt, from A≈øhridge in the Ea≈øt, to
„Äà‚óä„Äâ -wood Forre≈øt in the We≈øt, are eighteene; the whole in Circumference one hundred thirtie „Äà‚óä„Äâ
miles.

(3) The ayre is pa≈ø≈øing good, temperate, and plea≈øant, yeelding the body health, and the minde content. The ≈øoile is rich, fat, and fruitfull, giuing abundance of Corne, Gra≈ø≈øe and Meate. It is chiefly diuided into two parts by the Chiltren billes, which run thorow this Shire in the midde≈øt, and before tim ‚Ä¢ where ≈øo po≈øtered with Be ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ h, that they were altogether vnpa≈ø≈øable, and became a receptacle and refuge for theeues, who daily endammaged the way-faring man; for which cau≈øe „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Abbot of S. A ‚Ä¢ ba ‚Ä¢ s cau≈øed them to be cut downe: ≈øince when tho≈øe parts are pa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ able, without any great incumbrances of trees; from who≈øe tops, a large and mo≈øt plea≈øing pro≈øpect is „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚ñ™ The Vale beneath is plaine and champion, a clayie ≈øoile, ≈øtiffe, and tough, but withall marueilous „Äà‚óä„Äâ
full naked of woods, but abounding in medowes, pa≈øtures, and tillage, and maintaining an infinite number of ≈øheepe, who≈øe ≈øoft and fine fleeces are in great e≈øteeme with the Turkes as farre as, A≈øia.

(4) The ancient Inhabitants that were ≈øeated in this Shire, were the Catlieuchlani, mentioned by Ptolemie, and them di≈øper≈øed thorow the Tract of Bedford, Hertford, and this. The≈øe yeelded them≈øelues with the fir≈øt to Cae≈øar vnder the Romanes ≈øubiection, who≈øe ouer-worne Empire ending in Britaine, the Saxons by ≈øtrong hand attained this Prouince, and made it a part of their Mercian Kingdome: yet was it fir≈øt ≈øubdued vnto them by Cherdike the We≈øt-Saxon, who≈øe memory is in part continued in the Towne Cher≈øey, vpon the We≈øt of this Countie, where in a ≈øharpe and bloudy battle he was Victor ouer the Britaines. So al≈øo Cuthwulfe a We≈øt-Saxon at Alesbury in the yeare of Grace 592. ouer came the Britaines, and bare downe all things before him: yet no ≈øooner was their Hep ‚Ä¢ archie wained, and their Monarchie able to ≈øtand alone, but that the Danes, before their ≈øtrength and growth was confirmed, waxed vpon them; and they not able in ≈øo weake a hand to hold fa≈øt that weight of greatne≈ø≈øe they had ≈øo gra≈øped, gaue place to their conquerours, who did many harmes in this Prouince: for in the yeare 914. the Danes furiou≈øly raged as farre as Brenwood, where they de≈øtroyed the City Burgh, the ancient ≈øeat of the Romanes, afterwards a royall hou≈øe of King Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor, which they vtterly de≈øtroyed.

(5) The Shire-Towne Buckingham, fruitfully ≈øeated vpon the Riuer Ou≈øe, was fortified with a Rampire, and Scon≈øes on both bankes, by King Edward the elder, ≈øaith Marianus the Scoti≈øh Writer; where in the heart of the Towne hath ≈øtood a ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle, mounted vpon a high hill, which long ≈øince was brought to the period of her e≈øtate, now nothing remaining be≈øides the ≈øignes, that there ≈øhe had ≈øtood. The Riuer circulates this Towne on euery ≈øide, that onely on the North excepted, ouer which three faire ≈øtone-bridges lead, and into which the ≈øprings of a Well run, called S. Rumalds, a child-≈øaint borne at Kings-Sutton, canonized, and in the Church of this Towne en≈øhrined, with many conceited miracles and cures: ≈øuch was the happe of tho≈øe times, to produce Saints of all ages and ≈øexes. This Towne is gouerned by a Bayliffe and twelue principall Burge≈ø≈øes;
and is in the degree remoued from the fir≈øt point of the We≈øt for Longitude 19. 33. ≈øcruples, and the North-pole elenated in Latitude for the degree of 52. 18. ≈øcruples.

(6) A Towne of ancient note is Stony-Stratford, the Romans Lactorodum, being built vpon that ancient Cau≈øey-way which is called Watling-≈øtreet, where remaine the markes thereof euen vnto this day At this place Edward the elder ≈øtopped the pa≈ø≈øage of the Danes, whiles he ≈øtrengthened Torce≈øter again≈øt them: and herein, King Edward the elde≈øt ≈øince the Conque≈øt, reared a beautifull Cro≈ø≈øe in memory of Eleanor his dead Queene, as he did in euery place where her Corps re≈øted, from Herdby in Lincolne-≈øhire, till it was receiued and buried at We≈øtmin≈øter.

(7) Places intended for Gods true wor≈øhip, built by deuout per≈øons, and ≈øeque≈øtred from worldly imployments, were at Launden, Luffeld, Bidle≈øden, Bradwell, Nothey, Ankerne, Mi≈ø≈øenden, Tekeford, Partrendune, A≈øhridge, and Alesburie: A≈øhridge in great repute for the bloud (≈øuppo≈øed out of Chri≈øts ≈øides) brought out of Germany by Henry the elde≈øt ≈øonne of Richard King of the Romanes, and Earle of Cornwall, whereunto re≈øorted great concour≈øe of people for deuotion, and adoration thereof. But when the Sunne-≈øhine of the Go≈øpell had pierced thorow ≈øuch clouds of darkene≈ø≈øe, it was perceiued apparantly to be onely hony clarified and coloured with Saffron, as was openly ≈øhewed at Pauls Cro≈ø≈øe by the Bi≈øhop of Roche≈øter, the twentie-fourth of Februarie, and yeare of Chri≈øt 1538. And Alesbury for the holine≈ø≈øe of S. Edith, was much frequented, who hauing this Towne allotted for her Dowrie, bad the world and her husband fa ‚Ä¢ ewell, in taking vpon her the veile of deuotion, and in that fruitfull age of Saints became greatly renowned, euen as farre as to the working of miracles. The≈øe all in the ≈øtormes and rage of the time, ≈øuffred ≈øuch ≈øhipwracke, that from tho≈øe turmoiled Seas, their merchandi≈øe light in the right of ≈øuch Lords as made them their owne for wreacks indeed.

(8) With foure Ca≈øtles this Shire hath beene ≈øtrengthned, and thorow eleuen Market-Townes her Commodities traded; being diuided, for ≈øeruice to the Crowne and State, into eight Hundreds, and in them are ≈øeated one hundred foure≈øcore and fiue Pari≈øh-Churches.

div.head: OXFORD-SHIRE. CHAPTER XXI.
div.p: OXFORD-SHIRE receiueth her name from that famous Vniuer≈øitie and mo≈øt beautifull Citie Oxford, and this of the Foord of Oxen, ≈øay our Engli≈øh-Saxons; though Leiland vpon a ground of coniecture will haue it Ousford, from the Riuer Ou≈øe (by the Latines called I≈øis) which giueth name likewi≈øe to the adioyning Iland Ou≈øney. The North point of this Shire is bordered vpon by the Counties of Warwicke and Northampton, the Ea≈øt with Buckingham, the We≈øt by Gloce≈øter-≈øhire, and the South altogether is parted from Bark-≈øhire by Thami≈øis, the Prince of Briti≈øh Riuers.

(2) The ble≈ø≈øings both of the ≈øweet-breathing heauens, and the fruitfull ≈øite of this Counties ≈øoile, are ≈øo happie and fortunate, that hardly can be≈øaid whether exceeds. The aire milde, temperate and delicate; the Land fertile, plea≈øant, and bounteous; in a word, both Heauen and Earth accorded to make the Inhabitants healthfull and happie: The hils loaden with woods and Cattle, the vallies burthened with Corne and Pa≈øturage, by rea≈øon of many fre≈øh ≈øpringing Riuers which ≈øportingly there-thorow make their pa≈ø≈øage, whereof England, Char ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ll, „Äà‚óä„Äâ
and I≈øis are chiefe: which two la≈øt making their Bed of Marriage „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ together in one channell and name.

(3) The length of this Shire is from Cleydon in the North-we≈øt, vnto „Äà‚óä„Äâ in her South-Ea≈øt, neere vnto Thami≈øis, and amounteth almo≈øt to fortie miles; the broade≈øt part is in her we≈øterne Borders, which extending from the ≈øaid Cleydon in the North, vnto Faring ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ the Riuer I≈øis in the South, are ≈øcarcely twentie ≈øixe: and thence growing narrower „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
in Circumference about one hundred and thirtie miles.

(4) The ancient Inhabitants knowne to the Romans, were the Dobuni, part whereof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed further We≈øternly into Gloce≈øter-≈øhire, and nearer Ea≈øtward, betwixt the bowing of Thami≈øes, were ≈øeated the Ancalites, who ≈øent their ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion vnto Iulius Cae≈øar, when report was made that the Trinobantes had put them≈øelues vnder his protection; whereof followed the Britaines ≈øeruitude vnder the proud yoke of the all-coueting Romans: yet afterwards this Counties people, being very pui≈ø≈øant (as Tacitus termes them) and vn≈øhaken by warres, with≈øtood O≈øtorius Scapula the Roman Lieutenant, choo≈øing rather to yeeld their liues in battle, then their per≈øons to ≈øubiection. Of latter times it was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Mercian Saxons, as part of their Kingdome, though ≈øometimes both the We≈øt-Saxons and the Northumbrians had the di≈øpo≈øe of ≈øome part thereof: for Beda affirmeth that K. O≈øwold gaue the then-flouri≈øhing Citie D ‚Ä¢ rche≈øter vnto Berinus the We≈øt-Saxons Apo≈øtle, to be his Epi≈øcopall See: whence the good Bi≈øhop comming to Oxford, and preaching before Wulpherus the Mercian King (in who≈øe Court Athelwold the South-Saxons heatheni≈øh King was then pre≈øent) he with all his Nobles were conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt, and there baptized, whereby Berinus became the Apo≈øtle al≈øo of the South Saxons.

(5) Otherplaces of memorable note either for actions therein happening, or for their owne famous e≈øteeme, are the R ‚Ä¢ ll-rich-≈øtones, ≈øtanding neere vnto Eni≈øham in the South of this Shire: a monument of huge ≈øtones, ≈øet round in compa≈ø≈øe, in manner of the Stonch ‚Ä¢ nge: of which, fabulous tradition hath reported for≈øooth, that they were metamorphi≈øed from men, but in truth were there erected vpon ≈øome great victory obtained, either by, or again≈øt Rollo the Dane, who in the yeare 876. entred England, and in this Shire fought two Battles, one neere vnto Hoch-Norton, and a ≈øecond at the Scier-Stane.

(6) Rod ‚Ä¢ os likewi≈øe remaineth as a monument of Oxfords high-≈øtiled Barle, but vnfortunate Prince, Robert de Vere, who be≈øides the Earledome, was created by King Richard the ≈øecond, Marque≈ø≈øe
of Dublin, and Duke of Ireland: but at that Bridge, di≈øcomfited in fight by the Nobles, and forced to ≈øwimme the Riuer, where began the downefall of his high mounted fortunes; forbeing driuen forth of his Country, la≈øtly died in exile and di≈øtre≈ø≈øed e≈øtate. But more happie is this Countie in producing farre more glorious Princes, as King Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor, who in I≈ølip was borne; Edward the victorious blacke Prince, in Wood≈øtocke; and in Oxford that warlike Coeur de Lion, King Richard the fir≈øt, the ≈øonne of King Henry the ≈øecond, fir≈øt tooke breath.

(7) Which Citie is, and long hath beene the glorious ≈øeat of the Mu≈øes, the Briti≈øh Athens, and learnings well-≈øpring, from who≈øe buing fountaine the whole≈øome waters of all good literature ≈øtreaming plenteou≈øly, haue made fruitfull all other parts of this Realme, and gained glory among≈øt all Nations abroad. Antiquitie auoucheth, that this place was con≈øecrated vnto the ≈øacred Sciences in the time of the old Britaines, and that from Greeke-lad, a Towne in Wilt-≈øhire, the Academie was tran≈ølated vnto Oxford, as vnto a Plant-plot, both more plea≈øing and fruitfull: whereto accordeth the ancient Burlaus and Necham, this latter al≈øo alledging Merlin. But when the beautie of the Land lay vnder the Saxons prophane feete, it ≈øu≈øtained a part of tho≈øe common calamities, hauing little re≈øerued to vphold its former glory, ≈øaue onely the famous monument of S. Fride≈øwids Virgin Conque≈øt, no other Schoole then left ≈øtanding be≈øides her Mona≈øterie: yet tho≈øe great bla≈øts, together with other Dani≈øh ≈øtormes, being well blowne ouer, King Elfred, that learned and religious Monarch, recalled the exiled Mu≈øes to their ≈øacred place, and built there three goodly Colledges for the ≈øtudies of Diuinitie, Philo≈øophie, and other Arts of humanitie, ≈øending thither his owne ≈øonne Ethelward, and drew thither the yong Nobles from all parts of his Kingdome. The fir≈øt reader thereof was his ≈øuppo≈øed brother Neote, a man of great learning, by who≈øe direction King Elfred was altogether guided in this his goodly foundation. At which time al≈øo, A≈ø≈øerius Meneuen≈øis, a writer of tho≈øe times affaires, read the Grammar and Rhetoricke, and affirmeth that long before them, G ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ das,
Melkin, Ninius, Kentigern, S. German, and others, ≈øpent there their liues in learned ≈øtudies. From which time that it continued a Seed plot of learning till the Norman Conque≈øt,
‚Ä¢ ugul ‚Ä¢ us recordeth, who him≈øelfe then liued. No maruell then if Matthew Paris calleth Oxford, the ≈øecond Schoole of Chri≈øtendome, and the very chiefe Pillar of the Catholike Church And in the Councell holden at Vienna, it was ordained, that in Paris, Oxford, Bononia, and Salamanca (the onely Vniuer≈øities then in Europe) ≈øhould be erected Schooles for the Hebrew, Greeke, Arabicke, and Chaldean tongues, and that Oxford ≈øhould be the generall Vniuer≈øitie for all England, Ireland, Scotland, and Wales: which point was likewi≈øe of ≈øuch weight with the Councell of Con≈øtance, that from this precedent of Oxford Vniuer≈øitie, it was concluded, that the Engli≈øh Nation was not onely to haue precedence of Spaine in all Generall Councels, but was al≈øo to be held equall with France it ≈øelfe. By which high prerogatiues this of ours hath alwayes ≈øo flouri≈øhed, that in the dayes of King Henry the „Äà‚óä„Äâ thirtie thou≈øand Students were therein re≈øident, as Archbi≈øhop Armachanus (who then liued) „Äà‚óä„Äâ writ, and
‚Ä¢‚Ä¶
ger (then al≈øo liuing) ≈øheweth, that for all the ciuill warres which hindered ≈øuch „Äà‚óä„Äâ of quiet ≈øtudie, yet 15000. Students were there remaining, who≈øe names (≈øaith he) were „Äà‚óä„Äâ in matricula, in the matriculation booke. About which time. Iohn Baltol (the father of Baltol King of Scots) built a Colledge, yet bearing his name, Anno 1269. and Walter Merton Bi≈øhop of Roche≈øter, that which is now called Merton Colledge; both of them beautified with buildings, and enriched with lands, and were the fir≈øt endowed Colledges for learning in all Chri≈øtendome. And at this pre≈øent „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øixteene Colledges (be≈øides another newly builded) with eight Hals, and many mo≈øt „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
Churches, all adorned with mo≈øt ≈øtately buildings, and enriched with great endowments, noble Libraries, and mo≈øt learned Graduates of all profe≈ø≈øions, that vnle≈ø≈øe it be her ≈øi≈øter Cambridge, the other nur≈øing brea≈øt of this Land, the like is not ≈øound againe in the world. This Citie is al≈øo honoured with an Epi≈øcopall See. As for the ≈øite thereof, it is remoued from the Equator in the degree
52. and one minute, and from the We≈øt by Mercators mea≈øure, 19. degrees, and ‚Ä¢ 0. minutes.

(8) As this Countie is happie in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of ≈øo famous an Academie, ≈øo is it graced with mo≈øt Princely Palaces appertaining to the Engli≈øh Crowne, whereof Wood≈øtocke is the mo≈øt ancient and magnificent, built to that glory by King Henry the fir≈øt, and enlarged with a Labyrinth of many windings by King Henry the ≈øecond, to hide from his jealous Iuno, his intirely beloued Concubine Ro≈øamond Clifford, a Damo≈øell of ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing beautie; where notwith≈øtanding, followed by a clew of ≈øilke that fell from her lap, ≈øhe was ≈øurpri≈øed and poi≈øoned by Queene Eleanor his wife, and was fir≈øt buried at God≈øtow Nunnery, in the mid≈øt of the Quire vnder a Hear≈øe of ≈øilke, ≈øet about with lights, whom Hugh Bi≈øhop of Lincolne (thinking it an vnfit obiect for Virgins deuotion) cau≈øed to be remoued into the Church yard: but tho≈øe cha≈øte ≈øi≈øters liked ≈øo well the memory of that kinde Lady, as that her bones they tran≈ølated againe into their Chappell.

Ben≈øington is another of his Maje≈øties Mannours, built by William de la Pole Duke of Suffolke, but now in neglect through the anno ‚Ä¢ ance ari≈øing from the waters or mari≈øhes adioyning Hou≈øes built for deuotion, and for abu≈øe ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed and againe put downe, the chiefe in account were Eni≈øham, O≈øney, Bru ‚Ä¢ rn, God≈øtow, Burche≈øter, and Tame, be≈øides S. Fride≈øwides, and very many other ≈øtately Hou≈øes of Religion in the Citie.
The Diui≈øion of this Shire is into fourteene Hundreds, wherein are ≈øeated ten Market-Townes, and two hundred and foure≈øcore Pari≈øh-Churches.

div.head: GLOCESTER-SHIRE. CHAPTER XXIII.
div.p: GLOCESTER-SHIRE, lyeth bordered vpon the North with Worce≈øter and Warwicke-≈øhires, vpon the Ea≈øt with Oxford and Wile≈øhire; vpon the South altogether with Sommer≈øet-≈øhire: and vpon the We≈øt with the Riuer Wye and Hereford-≈øhire.

(2) The length thereof extended from Bri≈øtow vpon the Riuer Auon in her South, vnto Clifford vpon another Auon in her North, are about fortie eight miles; and her broade≈øt part from Ea≈øt to We≈øt, is from Lechlad vnto Pre≈øton, containing twentie eight: the whole circumference about one hundred thirtie eight miles.

(3) The forme whereof is ≈øomewhat long and narrow: the Ayre thereof is plea≈øant, ≈øweet and delectable: and for fruitfulne≈ø≈øe of Soile heare Malmesbury and not me: The ground of this Shire throughout (≈øaith he) yeeldeth plentie of Corne, and bringeth forth abundance of fruits; the one through the naturall goodne≈ø≈øe onely of the ground, the other through the diligent manuring and tillage, in ≈øuch wi≈øe, that it would prouoke the lazie≈øt per≈øon to take paines Here you may ≈øee the High-wayes and Common Lanes clad with Apple trees and Peare trees, not ingrafted by the indu≈øtry of mans hand, but growing naturally of their owne accord: the ground of it ≈øelfe is ≈øo inclined to beare fruits, and tho≈øe both in ta≈øte and beautie farre exceeding others, and will endure vntill a new ≈øupply come. There is not any Country in England ≈øo thicke ≈øet with Vineyards as this Prouince is, ≈øo plentifull of increa≈øe, and ≈øo plea≈øant in ta≈øte. The very wines made thereof carry no vnplea≈øant tartne≈ø≈øe, as being little inferiour in ≈øweet verdure to the French wines; the hou≈øes are innumerable, the Churches pa≈øsing faire, and the Townes ≈øtanding very thicke. But that which addeth vnto all good gifts (a ≈øpeciall glory) is the Riuer Seuerne, then which there is not any in all the Land, for
Channell broader, for Streame ≈øwifter, or for Fi≈øh better ≈øtored. There is in it a daily rage and fury of waters, which I know not whether I may call a Gulfe or Whirle-pole of waues, rai≈øing vp the ≈øands from the bottome, winding and driuing them vpon heapes: ≈øometimes ouerflowing her bankes, ro ‚Ä¢ eth a great way vpon the face of her bordering grounds, and againe retyreth as a Conquerour into the v≈øuall Channell. Vnhappy is the Ve≈ø≈øell which it taketh full vpon the ≈øide: but the Water-men well ware thereof, when they ≈øee that Hydra comming, turne the Ve≈ø≈øell vpon it, and cut thorow the mid≈øt of it, whereby they checke and auoyd her violence and danger.

(4) The ancient people that po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed this Prouince, were the DOBVNI, who ≈øpread them≈øelues further into Oxford ≈øhire. But betwixt the Seuerne and Wye were ≈øeated part of SILVRES, or Inhabitants of South Wales. And vpon what ground I know not, let Lawyers di≈øpute it, the Inhabitants in ≈øome part of this Shire enioy a priuate cu≈øtome to this day, that the Goods and Lands of Condemned Per≈øons fall vnto the Crowne but onely for a yeare and a day, and then returne to the next heires, contrary to the cu≈øtome of all England be≈øides‚ñ™

(5) The general Commodities of this Shire, are Corne, Iron, and Wools, all pa≈ø≈øing fine, be≈øides Pa≈øturage, Fruits, and Woods, which la≈øt are much le≈ø≈øened by making of Iron, the onely bane of Oke, Elme, and Beech.

(6) The≈øe, with all other proui≈øions are traded thorow twenty fiue Market-Townes in this County, whereof two are Cities of no ≈ømall import: the fir≈øt is Gloce≈øter, from whom the Shire taketh name, ≈øeated vpon Seuerne, neere the midde≈øt of this Shire, by Antonine the Emperour called Gleuum, built fir≈øt by the Romans, and ≈øet as it were vpon the necke of the Silures, to yoake them, where their Le ‚Ä¢ ion called Colonia Gleuum, lay. It hath beene walled about (excepting that part that is defended by the Riuer) the ruines whereof in many places appeare; and ≈øome part yet ≈øtanding, doth well witne≈ø≈øe their ≈øtrength. This City was fir≈øt won from the Britaines by Cheulin the fir≈øt King
of the We≈øt-Saxons, about the yeare of Chri≈øt, 570. and afterwards vnder the Mercians it flouri≈øhed with great honour, where Of ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ k King of Northumberland, by the ≈øufferance of Ethelred of Mercia, founded a mo≈øt ≈øtately Mona≈øtery of Nunnes, whereof Kineburgh, Eadburgh, and Eue, Queenes of the Mercians, were Priore≈ø≈øes ≈øucce≈ø≈øiuely each after other.

(7) Edel≈øted a mo≈øt renowned Lady, ≈øi≈øter to King Edward the elder, in this Citie built a faire Church, wherein her ≈øelfe was interred; which being ouerthrowne by the Danes, was afterwards rebuilt, and made the Cathedrall of that See, dedicated vnto the honour of S. Peter. In this Church the vnfortunate Prince, King Edward the ≈øecond, vnder a Monument of Alabla≈øter doth lye; who being murdered at Barkley Ca≈øtle, by the crueltie of French I≈øabel his wife, was there intombed And not farre from him another Prince as vnfortunate, namely, Robert Curthole, the elde≈øt ≈øonne of William the Conquerour, lyeth in a painted woodden Tombe in the midde≈øt of the Quire; who≈øe eyes were pluckt out in Cardiffe Ca≈øtle, wherein he was kept pri≈øoner twenty ≈øix yeares, with all contumelious indignities, vntill through extreame angui≈øh he ended his life. And before any of the≈øe, in this Citie ≈øay our Briti≈øh Hi≈øtorians, the body of Lucius our fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King was interred: and before his dayes the Britaines Aruiragus.
The graduation of this County I ob≈øerue from this Citie, whence the Pole is eleuated in the degree of Latitude 52 and 14. minutes, and in Longitude from the We≈øt, 18. and 5. minutes.

(8) The other Citie is Pri≈øtow, fa ‚Ä¢ re, but not very ancient, built vpon the Riuers Auon and Froome, for trade of Merchandize a ≈øecond London, and for beautie and account next vnto Yorke. This Citie ≈øtandeth partly in this Countie, and partly in Sommer≈øet ≈øhire: but being a Countie of it ≈øelfe, will acknowledge ≈øubiection to neither.

(9) A Citie more ancient hath beene Ci ‚Ä¢ ce≈øter, by Ptolomie called Corinium; by Antonine, Duro
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ no ‚Ä¢ ium; by Giraldus, Pa≈ø≈øerum Vi ‚Ä¢ em, The Sparrowes Citie, vpon a flying report, that Gu ‚Ä¢ mund
a Tyrant from Africks, be≈øieging this Citie, tyed fire vnto the wings of Sparrowes, who lighting in the Towne vpon light matter, ≈øet flame vpon all. The circuit of who≈øe wal ‚Ä¢ extended two miles about, wherein the Con≈øular Port or wayes of the Romans met and cro≈ø≈øed each other. This Citie was wonne from the Britaines by Cheulin fir≈øt King of the We≈øt-Saxons: afterwards it was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Mercians; and la≈øtly, by the Danes vnder Gurmund (the former no doubt mi≈øtaken for him) wherein a rable of them kept the ≈øpace of a yeare, Anno 879. and neuer ≈øince inhabited, according to the circuit of her walles.

(10) Places of memorable note are the≈øe: the Iland Al ‚Ä¢ ey neere vnto Gloce≈øter, wherein Edmund Iron-≈øide the Engli≈øh, and Canutus the Dane, after many battles and bloud, fought in ≈øingle Combat hand to hand alone, vntill they compounded for the Kingdomes partition: Barkley Ca≈øtle, where King Edward the ≈øecond was thorow his fundament runne into his bowels with a red burning Spit: Tewkesbury the fatall period of King Henry the ≈øixt his gouernment, and the wound of the Lanca≈øtrian Cau≈øe; for in a Battle there fought in Anno 1471. Prince Edward, the onely Sonne of King Henry, had his braines da≈øhed out in a mo≈øt ≈øhamefull manner, the Queene his mother taken pri≈øoner, and mo≈øt of their fauorites ≈ølaine and beheaded. And at Alderley, a little Towne ≈øtanding eight miles from the Seuerne, vpon the hilles to this day are found Cockles, Periwincles, and Oy≈øters of ≈øolid ≈øtone, which whether they haue beene Shel-fi≈øh and liuing creatures, or el≈øe the ≈øports of Nature in her workes, let the Naturall Philo≈øophers di≈øpute of and judge.

(11) The places of pietie, ≈øet apart from other worldly Seruices, and dedicated to religious v≈øes by the deuotions of Princes, erected in this Shire, were Tewkesbury, Deorhu≈øt, Gloce≈øter, Minching, Barkley, Kin≈øwood, Circe≈øter, Winchcombe, and Hales; which la≈øt was built with great co≈øt by Richard Earle of Cornwall, King of the Romans, wherein him≈øelfe, and his Dutche≈ø≈øe were interred. Their ≈øon Earle Edmund brought out of Germany the bloud of Hales, ≈øuppo≈øed and ≈øaid to be part of that which
Chri≈øt ≈øhed vpon his Cro≈ø≈øe. In this place with great confluence and deuotions of Pilgrimage it was ≈øought to and wor≈øhipped, till time proued it a meere counterfeit, when the glorious light of the Go≈øpell reuealed to eye-≈øight ≈øuch gro≈ø≈øe Idolat ‚Ä¢ ies, and the skirts of Super≈øtition were turned vp, to the ≈øhew of her owne ≈øhame.

(12) Dukes and Earles that haue borne the title of Gloce≈øter, the fir≈øt of euery Family art by their Armes and Names expre≈ø≈øed, euer fatall to her Dukes, though the greate≈øt in bloud and birth. The fir≈øt was Thomas Wood≈øtocke, ≈øonne to King Edward the third, who in Ca ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ is was ≈ømoothered in a Feather-bed to death. The ≈øecond was Humfrey brother to King Henry the fift, by the fraudulent practi≈øe of the malignant Cardinall and Queene, made away at S. Edmundsbury. And the la≈øt was Richard, brother to King Edward the fourth, who by the iu≈øt hand of God was cut off in Battle by King Henry the ≈øeauenth.
(13) This Shires diui≈øion is principally into foure parts, ≈øubdiuided into thirtie Hundreds, and them againe into two hundred and eight Pari≈øh-Churches.

div.head: HEREFORD-SHIRE. CHAPTER XXIIII.
div.p: HEREFORD-SHIRE, (formerly accounted within the limits of Wales) lyeth circulated vpon the North with Worce≈øter and Shrop-≈øhire; vpon the Ea≈øt with Maluerne Hils is parted from Gloce≈øter-≈øhire; vpon the South is kept in with Monmouth-≈øhire; and vpon the We≈øt in part with the Hatterall Hilles is diuided from Brecknok; and the re≈øt confined with Radnor≈øhire.

(2) This Counties Climate is mo≈øt healthfull and temperate, and Soyle ≈øo fertile for Corne and Cattle, that no place in England yeeldeth more or better conditioned: ≈øweet Riuers running as veynes in the body, doe make the Corne bearing grounds in ≈øome of her parts rightly to be tearmed the Gilden Vale: and for Waters, Wooll, and Wheate, doth contend with Nilus, Colchos, and Egypt: ≈øuch are Lem≈øter, Irchenfeild, the bankes of Wye, Luge, and Frome.

(3) The ancient people knowne to the Romanes, (who≈øe power they well felt before they could ≈øubdue them) were the Silures, placed by Ptolemie in this tract, and branched further into Radnor, Brecknok, Monmouth, and Glamorgan-≈øhires, at this day by vs called South-Wales, and by the Wel≈øh Debeubarth. Their Originall, as Tacitus coniectureth by their ≈øite, coloured countenances and curled haire, was out of Spaine, and as both he and Plinie de≈øcribes them, were fierce, valiant, and impatient of ≈øeruitude, which well they ≈øhewed vnder Cara ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ cus their Captaine, and nine yeares ≈øcourge to the Roman a≈ø≈øaulters, for who≈øe onely Conque≈øt (and that made by treachery) the Victor in Rome triumphed with more then a v≈øuall A≈øpect; and with ≈øo equall an hand bare the Scoale of Re≈øi≈øtance, that their owne Writers euermore terme it a dangerous Warre. For the Legion of Marius Valens
they put to flight, and that with ≈øuch hauock of the A≈ø≈øociates, that O≈øterius the Lieutenant of Britaine for very griefe gaue vp his gho≈øt: and Veranius vnder Nero a≈ø≈øaulted them in vaine. But when Ve≈øpa≈øian was Emperour, and expert Souldiers imployed in euery Prouince, Iulius Frontinus ≈øubdued the≈øe Silures vnto the Romans, where continually ≈øome of their Legions afterward kept, till all was abandoned in Valentinians time.
(4) The Saxons then made them≈øelues Lords of this Land, and this Prouince a part of their Mercians Kingdome; yea, and Sutton the Court of great Offa their King.

(5) But Hereford after, rai≈øed of the ruines of old Ariconium (now Kenche≈øter, ≈øhaken in pieces by a violent Earth quake) grew to great fame, through a conceiued ≈øanctity by the buriall of Ethelbert King of the Ea≈øt-Angles, ≈ølaine at Sutton by Offa, at what time he came thither to haue e≈øpou≈øed to his Daughter; who≈øe graue was fir≈øt made at Marden, but afterwards canonized and remoued to this Citie, when in honour of him was built the Cathedrall Church by Milfrid, a pettie King of that Country, which Gruffith Prince of South-Wales, and Algar an Engli≈øhman, rebelling again≈øt King Edward Confe≈ø≈øor, con≈øumed with fire; but by Bi≈øhop Reme≈øiu was re≈øtored at now it is, at what time the Towne was walled, and is ≈øo remaining in good repaire, hauing ≈øixe Gates for entrance, and fifteen Watch-towers for defence, extending in compa≈ø≈øe to fifteen hundred paces: and whence the North-Pole is ob≈øerued to be rai≈øed 52. degrees, 17. minutes in Latitude, and is ≈øet from the fir≈øt point of the We≈øt in Longitude, 17. degrees and 30. minutes; being yearely gouerned by a Maior, cho≈øen out of one and thirtie Citizens, which are commonly called the Election, and he euer after is knowne for an Alderman, and clothed in Scarlet, whereof foure of the elde≈øt are Iu≈øtices of Peace, graced with a Sword-bearer, a Recorder, a Towne-Clerke, and foure Sergeants with Mace.

The greate≈øt glory that this Citie receiued, was in King Athel≈øtans dayes; where (as Malmesbury doth report) he cau≈øed the Lords of Wales by way of Tribute, to pay yearely (be≈øides Hawkes and
Hounds) twenty pound of Gold, and three hundred pound of Siluer by waight; but how that was performed and continued I finde not.

(6) Things of rare note in this Shire are ≈øaid to be, Bone well, a Spring not farre from Richards Ca≈øtle, wherein are continually found little Fi≈øhes bones, but not a ≈øinne ≈øeene; and being wholly clean≈øed thereof, will notwith≈øtanding haue againe the like, whether naturally produced, or in veynes thither brought, no man knoweth.

(7) But more admirable was the worke of the Omnipotent, euen in our owne remembrances, and yeare of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus 1571. when the Mareley hill in the Ea≈øt of this Shire, rouzed it ≈øelfe out of a dead ≈øleepe, with a roaring noi≈øe remoued from the placewhere it ≈øtood, and for three dayes together trauelled from her fir≈øt ≈øite, to the great amazement and feare of the beholders. It began to journey vpon the ≈øeuenth day of February, being Saturday, at ≈øixe of the Clocke at night, and by ≈øeauen in the next morning had gone fortie paces, carrying with it Sheepe in their coates, hedgerowes, and trees; whereof ≈øome were ouer-turned, and ≈øome that ≈øtood vpon the plaine, are firmely growing vpon the hill, tho≈øe that were Ea≈øt, were turned We≈øt; and tho≈øe in the We≈øt „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øet in the Ea≈øt: in which remoue it ouerthrew K ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ na≈øten Chappell, and turned two high-wayes „Äà‚óä„Äâ hundred yards from their v≈øuall paths formerly trod. The ground thus trauelling, was abo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ≈øix Acres, which opening it ≈øelfe with Rockes and all, bare the earth before it for foure hundred yards ≈øpace without any ≈øtay, leauing that which was Pa≈øturage in place of the Tillage, and the Tillage ouer≈øpread with Pa≈øturage. La≈øtly, ouerwhelming her lower parts, mounted to an hill of twelue fadomes high, and there re≈øted her ≈øelfe after three dayes trauell: remaining his marke, that ≈øo laid hand vpon this Rocke, who≈øe power hath poy≈øed the Hils in his Ballance.

(8) Religious Hou≈øes built by the deuotions of Princes, and ≈øtored with Votaries and reuenewes for life, were in this Shire no le≈ø≈øe then thirteene, mo≈øt ≈øweetly ≈øeated in the places as followeth: at
both the Herefords, Barron, Ewayot, Clifford, Mone ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e, Acornebury, Lem≈øter, Linbroke, Peterchurch, Kilpek, Dore, and Wiggemore: and ≈øu≈øpected of hypocri≈øie, were called in que≈øtion by King Henry the eight, and ≈øo ≈øtrictly pur≈øued, that ≈øome faults were apparant, whereby they were laid open to the generall Deluge of the Time, who≈øe ≈øtreame bare downe the walles of all tho≈øe foundations, carrying away the Shrines of the dead, and defacing the Libraries of their ancient Records.

(9) This Countie before the Conque≈øt being accounted in Wales, was then ≈øtrengthened with Forts again≈øt the Engli≈øh: and being once made a Prounce to England, was fortified with Ca≈øtles again≈øt the Wel≈øh, wherein we finde no le≈ø≈øe then twentie eight, though many of them now are ruinated to nothing. Such were Alban, at both the Ewyats, Godridg, Gro≈ømond, Herdley, Hereford, Old Ca≈øtle, Dor≈øton, Brampton, Bredwarden, Saint Biruels, Ledbury, Lenals, Snowdel, Harlewais, Huntington, Wilton, Wigmore, Richards, Monemue, Corft, Kilbeck, Clifford, Skensfred, Witeney, Radenwer, and Ke ‚Ä¢ euenleis; and is traded with eight Market-Townes, being diuided into eleuen Hundreds, and in them ≈øeated one hundred ≈øeauentie and ≈øixe Pari≈øh-Churches, containing in compa≈ø≈øe an hundred and two miles.

div.head: VVORCESTER-SHIRE. CHAPTER XXV.
div.p:
VVORCESTER-SHIRE, is a Countie both rich and populour, and lyeth circulated vpon the North with Stafford
„Äà‚óä„Äâ vpon „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Ea≈øt with Warwicke and Oxford≈øhires; vpon the South with Glace≈øter ≈øhire, and the We≈øt by Maluerne Hils is parted from Hereford ≈øhire: the re≈øt lyeth confronted vpon and in part diuided from Sh ‚Ä¢ op-≈øhire by the Riuer Dowles.

(2) The forme thereof is triangle, but not of equall proportion; for from North to South are thirtie two miles, from South to North-We≈øt twenty two, and from thence to her North-Ea≈øt point are twenty eight: the whole in Circumference is one hundred and twentie miles.

(3) The Ayre in this Shire is of a fauourable temperature, that giues an appetite for labour, diet, and re≈øt: the Soyle is fertile, and to me ≈øeemed inferiour to notice other in this Land: for be≈øides the abundance of Corne in euery place ≈øpread, the Woods and Pa≈øturage in her hils and plaines, ≈øweet Riuers that water the vallies below, and Cattle that couer the tops of higher ground; the Fields, Hedge-rowes, and High-wayes are be≈øet with fruitfull Peare-trees, that yeeld great plea≈øure to ≈øight, and commodious v≈øe: for with their iuyce they make a ba≈øtard kinde of Wine, called Perry, which is both plea≈øant and good in ta≈øte. Many Salt Springs al≈øo this County affordeth; yea, and more then are commonly in v≈øe: ≈øuch with the Germans, our ancient Predece≈ø≈øors, were e≈øteemed mo≈øt ≈øacred and holy; ≈øo that (as Tacitus writeth) to ≈øuch they wontedly re≈øoted to ≈øupplicate their Gods with their deuout prayers, as to places neere≈øt the heauens, and therefore the ≈øooner to be heard. And Poets in their faynings will haue the Nymphs re≈øidence in ≈øhady greene groues, and bankes of
≈øweet Springs: if ≈øo, then (as Hellicon) this County affords both: ≈øuch are the Forre≈øts of W ‚Ä¢ re and Feckenham, the great woods of Norton, and mo≈øt faire Cha≈øe of Maluerne. And for waters, to witne≈ø≈øe what I ≈øay, is the Seuera ‚Ä¢
that cuts this Shire in the mid≈øt, Teme, Salwarp, and Auon, all of them making fruitfull their pa≈ø≈øage, and ≈øtored with Fi≈øh of mo≈øt delicious ta≈øte.

(4) The ancient people, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors of this Shire, were the CORNAVII, inhabitants of Che≈ø≈øe-≈øhire, Shrop-≈øhire, Stafford, and Warwicke-≈øhires, ≈øubdued by the Romanes in Claudius Cae≈øars time, and after their departure, made a portion of the Mercian-Saxons Kingdome, and in Bedaes time were called the Wicij, whereof it may be this Shire had the name: vnle≈ø≈øe you will haue it from the Salt-Pits, which in old Engli≈øh are named Wiches; or from the famous Forre≈øt of Wyre. How≈øoeuer, true it is that the County doth hold the name from her chiefe Citie Worce≈øter.

(5) Which is mo≈øt plea≈øantly ≈øeated, pa≈ø≈øing well frequented, and very richly inhabited. This was the Branouium, mentioned by Antouine and Ptolemie, called by the Britaines, Caer-Wrangon; by Ninius, Caer-Cuorcon; and by the Latines, Vigornia. This Citie is ≈øeated vpon the Ea≈øt banke of Seuerne, and from the ≈øame is walled in triangle-wi≈øe about, extending in circuit one thou≈øand ≈øixe hundred and fiftie paces: thorow which ≈øeauen Gates enter, with fiue other Watch Towers for defence. It is thought the Romanes built this to re≈øtraine the Bertaines that held „Äà‚óä„Äâ beyond Seutr ‚Ä¢ e. This Citie by Hardy Canute in the yeare of Chri≈øt 1041. was ≈øorely endangered, and ≈øet on fire, and the Citizens ≈ølaine almo≈øt euery one, for that they had killed his Collector of the Dani≈øh Tribute: yet it was pre≈øently repaired and peopled, with many Burge≈ø≈øes. and for fifteene Hides di≈øcharged it ≈øelfe to the Conquerour; as in his Doome≈ødayes is to be ≈øeene. But in the yeare 1113. a ≈øodaine fire happened, no man knew how, which burnt the Ca≈øtle and Cathedrall Church. Likewi≈øe in the ciuill hroyles of King Stephen it was twice lighted into a flame, and the later laid it hopele≈ø≈øe of recouery. Notwith≈øtanding from tho≈øe dead A≈øhes a new Phenix aro≈øe, and her building rai≈øed in a more
≈øtately proportion, e≈øpecially the Cathedrall dedicated to S. Mary, fir≈øt laid by Bi≈øhop Sexwolfe, in Anno 680 ≈øince when it hath beene augmented almo≈øt to the Riuer: In the mid≈øt of who≈øe Quire, from his many turmoiles, re≈øteth the body of King Iohn (the great with-≈øtander of the Popes proceedings) vnder a Monument of white Marble, in Princely Ve≈øtures, with his portraiture thereon according to life. And in the South-≈øide of the ≈øame Quire lyeth intombed Prince Arthur the elde≈øt Sonne to King Henry the ≈øeauenth, his Monument is all blacke Iette, without remembrance of him by Picture.

This City is gouerned by two Bailiffes, two Aldermen, two Chamberlaines, and two Con≈øtables, yearely elected out of twentie-foure Burge≈ø≈øes clothed in Scarlet, a≈ø≈øi≈øted with fortie-eight other Citizens, whom they call their Common Coun≈øellors, clad in Purple, a Recorder, Towne-Clerke, and fiue Sergeants with Mace their Attendants Who≈øe Geographichall Po≈øition is di≈øtant in Longitude from the We≈øt-Meridian 18. degrees, 10. ≈øcruples, hauing the North-Pole cleuated in Latitude 52. degrees, and 32. ≈øcruples.

(6) Places of further note for memorable antiquitie, is Vpton, of great account in the Romane time, where≈øome of their Legions kept, as witne≈ø≈øe their Monies there often found: the admirable Ditch vpon Maluerne hils, drawne by Gilbert Clare, Earle of Gloce≈øter, to diuide his Lands from the Church of Worce≈øter: the Saxons our Augu≈øtines Oke, where he the Engli≈øh Apo≈øtle met with the Briti≈øh Bi≈øhops for the vniforme celebration of Ea≈øter, from whence both parts departed with di≈øcontented minds, after many hot word and thwarting di≈øputes.

(7) Neither is it without admiration to me, that many places of this Shire lye farre within the Precincts of other Prouinces, as Aul≈øton, Wa≈øhbornes, Cutte≈øden, Paxford, Hanging Ea≈øton, Northwick ‚Ä¢ , Blockley, Burlode in Gloce≈øter-≈øhire, and Goldcote, Aldermer≈øton, Newbold, Treddenton, Armi≈øcote, Blackwell, Darlings-cote, Shi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , Tyd ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ton, Olbarrow in Warwick-≈øhire; Dudley in Stafford-≈øhire, and
Rochford in Hereford-≈øhire, whither I mu≈øt referre the Reader to finde out the≈øe and the like in the≈øe We≈øterne Tracts.

(8) Religious places erected in this Shire and deuoted vnto God by deuout per≈øons, were Bredon, Brodlege, Eue≈øholme, Alnece≈øter, Cochell, Fladbury, Maluerin, Per≈øhore, Stodlege, We≈øtwoods, and Worce≈øter, plenteou≈øly prouided for, and further ≈øecured by many priuiledges, both which they abu≈øed, as were the inditements of all ≈øuch in the dayes of King Henry the eight, at who≈øe Barre (him≈øelfe being Iudge) they were found guiltie, and receiued ≈øentence of their ends and de≈øtruction.
(9) Ca≈øtles for defence built in this County, ruinate or in ≈øtrength, were Hartlebury, Holt, Handley, Norton, Elmeley, and Worce≈øter, be≈øides his Maje≈øties Mannour of Tichnell.
(10) This Shires diui≈øion is into ≈øeauen Hundreds, wherein are ≈øeated ten Market-Townes, and one hundred fiftie two Pari≈øh-Churches.

div.head: VVARWICKE-SHIRE. CHAPTER XXVI.
div.p: VVARVVICKE-SHIRE, (≈øo called from her Shire-Towne) is bounded vpon the North with the Countie of Stafford; vpon the Ea≈øt, with Watling-≈øtreet-way is parted from Leice≈øter ≈øhire, and the re≈øt bordered vpon by Northampton ≈øhire: the South part is butted by Oxford and Gloce≈øter ≈øhires; and all her West with the Countie of Worce≈øter.

(2) The forme thereof is not much vnlike to a Scallop ≈øhell, growing from her We≈øterne head, and ≈øpreading her body wider, with many indents. The length thereof from Newton in the North, to L ‚Ä¢ ug Compton in the South, are miles thirtie and three: and the broade≈øt part of this Shire, is from H ‚Ä¢ well grange in the We≈øt, vnto Hill morton in the Ea≈øt, di≈øtant a≈øunder twentie fiue miles; the whole in Circumference, about one hundred thirtie and fiue miles.

(3) This Shire is ≈øited neere vnto the heart of all England, and therefore participates with her in the be≈øt both for ayre and ≈øoyle, wanting nothing for profit or plea≈øure for man. The South part from Auon (that runneth thorow the mid≈øt of this Countie) is called the Feldon, as more champion and tractable to be ≈øtirred for Corne, which yearely yeeldeth ≈øuch plentifull harue≈øt, that the hu≈øbandman ≈øm ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ th in beholding his paines, and the medowing pa≈øtures with their greene mantles ≈øo imbrodred with flowers, that from Edg-hill we may behold another Eden, as Lot did the Plaine of Iordon, before that Sodome fell. The Woodland lyeth vpon the North of Auon, ≈øo called in regard of the plentie of Woods; which now are much thinner by the making of Iron, and the ≈øoile more churli≈øh to yeeld to the Plough.

(4) The ancient people that po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed this Prouince, are by Ptolemies de≈øcription called the Corna ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ij, wherein after were ≈øeated the Mercian-Saxons, a part of who≈øe Kingdome it was, and greatly ≈øought after by the We≈øt-Saxons, who≈øe King Cuthred, about the yeare of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus 749 in Battle ≈ølew Ethelbald at Seckington neere vnto Ta ‚Ä¢ worth. And not farre from thence, King Edward the 4. as vnfortunately ≈øought again≈øt that ≈øtout make-King, Richard Neuil Earle of Warwicke: neere vnto which, vpon Blacklow-hill, Pierce Gaue≈øton (that proud and new-rai≈øed Earle of Cornwall) was beheaded by Guy Earle of Warwicke, a≈ø≈øi≈øted with the Earles of Lanca≈øter and Hereford. And ≈øurely, by the te≈øtimony of Iohn Ro≈ø≈øe, and others, this County hath beene better repleni≈øhed with people; who maketh complaint of whole Towne≈øhips depopulations, altogether laid wa≈øte by a pui≈ø≈øant Armie of feeding ≈øheepe.

(5) Notwith≈øtanding, many faire Townes it hath, and ≈øome of them matchable to the mo≈øt of England. The chiefe thereof is Couentree, a Citie both ≈øtately for building, and walled for defence: who≈øe Citizens hauing highly offended their fir≈øt Lord Leofricke, had their priuiledges infringed, and them≈øelues oppre≈ø≈øed with many hauie Tributes; who≈øe wife Lady Godina pitying their e≈øtates, vnce≈ølantly ≈øued for their peace, and that with ≈øuch importunacie, as hardly could be ≈øaid whether was greater, his hatred, or her loue: at la≈øt ouercome with her continuall interce≈ø≈øions, he granted her ≈øuir, vpon an vnciuill, and (as he thought) an vnacceptable condition which was, that ≈øhe ≈øhould ride naked thorow the face of the Citie, and that openly at high noone-day. This notwith≈øtanding ≈øhe thankfully accepted, and performed the act accordingly enioyned: for this Lady G ‚Ä¢ di ‚Ä¢ a ≈øtripping her ≈øelfe of all rich attire, let loo≈øe the treffes of her faire haire, which on euery ≈øide ≈øo couered her nakedne≈ø≈øe, that no part of her body was vnciuill to ≈øight; whereby ≈øhe redeemed the former freedomes, and remi≈ø≈øion of ≈øuch heauie Tributes. Who≈øe memory I wi≈øh may remaine honourable in that Citie for euer, and her pitie followed by ≈øuch po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing Ladies.

This Citie had grant to choo≈øe their yearely Magi≈øtrates, a Maior and two Bailiffes, and to build about and embattle a wall, by King Edward the 3. whom Henry the 6. corporated a Countie of it ≈øelfe, and changed the names of their Bailifs into Sherifs: and the wals then were built as they now ≈øtand; thorow which open 13 gates for entrance, be≈øides 18. other Towers thereon for defence. At Gofford-gate in the Ea≈øt hangeth the ≈øhield-bene of a wild Bore, farre bigger then the greate≈øt Oxe-bone: with who≈øe ≈ønout the great pit called Swan≈øwell was turned vp, and was ≈ølaine by the famous Guy, if we will beleeue report.

Next vnto this Citie, in account and commerce, is Warroicke, vpon the North-west banke of Auon, built by Gurgun≈øtus, the ≈øonne of Bel ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e, as Iohn Ro≈ø≈øe, Monke of the place, ≈øaith, 375. yeares before the birth of Chri≈øt: by Ninius called Caer-Guaruic and Caer-Leon; and by learned Cambden judged to be PRAESIDIVM, the Romane Garri≈øons Towne. The ≈øituation of this place is mo≈øt plea≈øant, vpon a hill ri≈øing from the Riuer, ouer which is a ≈øtrong and faire Stone bridge, and her ≈øharpe ≈øtreame vpon the Towne ≈øide checked with a mo≈øt ≈øumptuous and ≈øtately Ca≈øtle, the decayes whereof, with great co≈øt and curious buildings, the right worthy Knight Sir Foulke Greuil (in who≈øe per≈øon ≈øhineth all true vertue and high nobilitie) hath repaired: who≈øe merits to me ward I doe acknowledge, in ≈øetting this hand free from the daily imployments of a manuall trade, and giuing it full libertie thus to expre≈ø≈øe the inclination of my minde, him≈øelfe being the Procurer of my pre≈øent e≈øtate.

It ≈øeemeth this Towne hath beene walled about, as appeareth by the Trench in ≈øome places ≈øeene, and two very faire Gates, who≈øe pa≈ø≈øages are hewed out of the Rocke, as all other into the Towne are: ouer whom two beautifull Chappels are built; that towards the Ea≈øt called S Peters, and that on the South-we≈øt, S Iames.

Two faire Churches are therein ≈øeated, called S. Maries and S. Nicholas: but the≈øe in, and about
the Towne ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, S. Laurence, S. Michaels, Iohn Bapti≈øt, and Iohn of Ieru≈øalem, be≈øide the Nunnery in the North of the Towne: who≈øe North Pole is eleuated in Latitude 52. degrees, 45 minutes, and is ≈øeated from the fir≈øt point in the We≈øt of Longitude, 18 degrees and 45 minutes, being yearely gouerned by a Bailiffe, twelue Brethren, twentie foure Burge≈ø≈øes for Common Coun≈øell, a Recorder, a Towne-Clerke, and one Sergeant their Attendant.

(7) Places of mo≈øt memorable note ob≈øerued in this Shire, are Shugbury, where the precious ≈øtone A≈øtroites is found: Of-Church, which was the Palace of great Offa the Mercian, and the buriall-place of S. Fremund his ≈øonne: Che≈øterton, where the famous Fo≈ø≈øe-way is ≈øeene. At Leamington, ≈øo far from the Sea, a Spring of Salt-water boileth vp: and at Newenham Regis mo≈øt ≈øoueraigne water again≈øt the Stone, Greene wounds, Vlcers, and Impo≈øtumes; and drunke with Salt loo≈øeth, but with Sugar bindeth the body; and turneth wood into ≈øtone as my ≈øelfe ≈øaw by many ≈øticks that therein were fallen‚ñ™ ≈øome part of them A≈øh, and ≈øome part of them Stone: and Guy-Cliffe, where the famous Earle Guy, after many painefull exploits atchieued, retired, and vnknowne, lead an Hermits life, and was la≈øtly there buried.

(8) The chiefe≈øt Commodities in this Countie growing, are Corne, whereof the Red Hor≈øe Vale yeeldeth mo≈øt abundantly; Woolls in great plentie; Woods and Iron, though the producer of the one will be the de≈øtruction of the other. Such honourable Families as haue beene dignified with the Earledome of this Shire-Townes name ≈øince the Normans Conque≈øt, in the great Map it ≈øelfe are in≈øerted, and by their ≈øeuerall names expre≈ø≈øed.

This County is ≈øtrengthned with eight ≈øtrong Ca≈øtles, traded with fifteene Market-Townes, inriched with many faire buildings, and by the deuotion of many Nobles, had many foundations of religious Mona≈øteries therein laid. The chiefe≈øt were at Stoneley, Warwicke, Thellisford, Roxhall, Bal≈øhall, K ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ gworth,
Couentree, Combe, Nun-eaton, A≈øley, Ather≈øton, and Polle≈øworth; all which came to their period in the raigne of King Henry the eight, when their rich Reuenewes were alienated to his v≈øe, and tho≈øe ≈øtately buildings either ouer-turned or be≈øtowed vpon his Courtiers: but yet to Gods glory, and his diuine ≈øeruice, one hundred fiftie eight Pari≈øh-Churches therein remaine, di≈øper≈øedly ≈øeated in the nine Hundreds of this Shires Diui≈øion.

div.head: NORTHAMPTON-SHIRE. CHAPTER XXVII.
div.p: NORTHAMPTON-SHIRE, ≈øituated neere vnto the midde≈øt of England, lyeth ≈øepartted vpon the North from Lincoln-≈øhire by the Riuer W ‚Ä¢ land; from Hammington-≈øhire on the Ea≈øt is parted by the water Nene: her South is bounded with Buckingham and Oxford ≈øhires, and the We≈øt from Warwicke with Watling-≈øtreet-way, Auon, and Weland, is diuided from Leice≈øter-≈øhire.

(2) The forme of this Countie is large and narrow, broade≈øt in the South-we≈øt; and thence ≈øhooting ≈øtill le≈ø≈øer like vnto a Horne, nor not much vnlike to the forme of Cornwall: and from the entrance of Cherwell into this Shire, vnto the fall of Weland and Nene neere vnto Crowland, are by mea≈øure fortie ≈øixe miles; and the broade≈øt part is from Ou≈øe vnto Auon, which is not fully twentie miles: the whole in circumference one hundred and nineteene miles‚ñ™

(3) The aire is good, temperate, and healthfull: the ≈øoile is champion, rich, and fruitfull, and ≈øo plenteou≈øly peopled, that from ≈øome A≈øcents, thirtie Pari≈øh-Churches, and many more Wind-milles at one view may be ≈øeene: notwith≈øtanding the ≈øimple and gentle ≈øheepe, of all creatures the mo≈øt harmele≈ø≈øe, are now become ≈øo rauenous, that they begin to deuoure men, wa≈øte fields, and depopulate hou≈øes, if not whole Towne-≈øhips, as one merily hath written.

(4) The antient people knowne to the Romans, and recorded by Ptolemie, were the Coritani, who po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed this Country, and were branched further thorow Leice≈øter, Lincolne, Nottingham, Rutland, and Darbie-≈øhires: the≈øe ioyning with the Irenians, with them were fettered with the chaines of ≈øubiection, when for Claudius, Publius O≈øtrius Scapula entred his Lieutenant≈øhip in Britaine, and in
battle ≈øubdued all betwixt the Riuers Nene and Sabrina. But when the Romans were content to let goe that which ≈øo long was de≈øired, and had co≈øt ≈øo much in the getting, the Saxons, a mo≈øt warlike Nation put into the≈øe parts, and made it a portion of their Mercian Kingdome: but their gouernment al≈øo growne out of date, the Normans ≈øeated them≈øelues in the≈øe faire po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, the branches of whole Stemmes are ≈øpread abroad in the≈øe parts, mo≈øt fruitfull and faire.

(5) Commodities ari≈øing in this Shire, are chiefly gotten by tillage and plough, whereby corne ≈øo plentifully aboundeth, that in no other Countie is found more, or ≈øo much: the pa≈øtures and woods are filled with Cattle, and euery where ≈øheepe loaden with their fleeces of wooll.

(6) The chiefe Towne in this Shire is Northampton, whereof the Countie taketh name, which for circuit, beautie, and building, may be ranked with the mo≈øt of the Cities of our Land. It is ≈øeated at the meeting and confluence of two Riuers, the greater whereof beareth to name Nen. This Towne hath beene built all of ≈øtone, as by many foundations remaining to this day is ≈øeene, and is walled about both ≈øtrong and high, excepting the We≈øt, which is defended by a Riuer parted into many ≈øtreames. In the depredations of the Danes, Suen their King ≈øet this Towne on fire, and afterwards it was ≈øorely a≈ø≈øulted by the di≈øobedient Barons of King Iohn, who named them≈øelues, The Ar ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ie of God: But the loyaltie of this Towne ≈øtood nothing ≈øo ≈øure vnto King Henry his ≈øonne, whence the Barons with di≈øplayed Banners ≈øounded the Battle again≈øt their Soueraigne. And yet after this a woefull Field of Englands ciuill diui≈øion was fought, whence Richard Neuil the ≈øtout Earle of Warwicke, lead away pri≈øoner that vnfortunate man King Henry the ≈øixth. Vpon the We≈øt part of this Towne ≈øtandeth a large Ca≈øtle, mounted vpon an hill, who≈øe aged countenance well ≈øheweth the beautie that ≈øhe hath borne, and who≈øe gaping chinkes doe daily threaten the downefall of her walles. To this vpon the South the Townes wall adioyneth, and in a round circuit meeteth the Riuer in the North, extending in compa≈ø≈øe two thou≈øand one hundred and twentie pa≈øes: who≈øe
fire ≈øo plea≈øed the Students of Cambridge, that thither they remoued them≈øelues vpon the Kings Warrant, in minde to haue made it on an Vniuer≈øitie: from whence the North-pole is eleuated 52. degrees 36. ≈øcruples for Latitude, and in Longitude is remoued from the We≈øt 19 degrees and 40 ≈øcruples; being yearely gouerned by a Maior, two Bailiffes, twelue Magi≈øtrates, a Recorder, Towne-Clerke, a Common Coun≈øell of fortie eight Burge≈ø≈øes, with fiue Sergeants to execute bu≈øine≈ø≈øe.

(7) But the deuotions of the Saxon-Kings made Peterborow more famous, formerly called Medde≈øwell, where Wolphere King of Mercia began a mo≈øt ≈øtately Mona≈øtery to the honour of S. Peter, for ≈øatisfaction of the bloud of his two ≈øonnes, whom he had murdered in ca≈øe of Chri≈øtianitie: but him≈øelfe being for the like made away by his mother, his brother Penda continued the worke, with the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of his brother Ethelred, and two ≈øi≈øters, Kineburga and Kine≈øwith. This among the Dani≈øh De≈øobutions was ca≈øt downe, yet was it againe re≈øtored to greater beautie by Ethelwold Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter, with the helpe of King Edgar, and of Adulph his Chancellour, who vpon pricke of Con≈øcience, that in bed with his wife had ouerlaid and ≈ømoothered an Infant their onely ≈øonne, laid all his wealth vpon the reedifying of the place, and then became Abbot thereof him≈øelfe. The Cathedrall is mo≈øt beautifull and magnificall, where, in the Quire lie interred two vnfortunate Queenes: on the North ≈øide Katharine Dewager of Spaine, the repudiate wife of King Henry the eight, vnder an Hear≈øe couered with blacke Saye, hauing a white Cro≈ø≈øe in the mid≈øt: and on the South-≈øide, Mary Queene of Scotland, who≈øe Hearte is ≈øpread ouer with blacke Veluet‚ñ™ The Cloy≈øter is large, and in the gla≈ø≈øe-windowes very curiou≈øly portraied the Hi≈øtory of Wolphere the Founder, who≈øe Royall Seat was at Wedon in the ≈øtreet, conuerted into a Mona≈øtery by S Werburg his holy daughter, and had beene the Roman Station, by Antonine the Emperour called Bannauenna. So likewi≈øe Norman-che≈øter was the ancient Citie Durobriuae, where their Souldiers kept, as by the monies there daily found is mo≈øt apparent.

(8) Hou≈øes of Religion deuoted to Gods Seruice by the pious intents of their well-meaning Founders were at Peterborow, Peakirk, Pipewell, Higham, Dauintree, Sulby, Sau≈øecombe, Sewarde≈øug, Gare, S Dewy, S Michell, Luffeild, Catesby, Brvth, Barkley, Fini≈øhead, Fotheringhay, Wedon, and With ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ p, be≈øides them in Northampton, all which felt the ≈øtormes of their owne de≈øtruction, that raged again≈øt them in the Raigne of King Henry the eight, who di≈øper≈øed their Reuenewes to his owne Coffers and Courtiers, and ulled the ≈øtones a≈øunder or their ≈øeeming euer-≈øure Foundations; and in the time of young Edward, his ≈øonne, who≈øe minde was free from wronging the dead, the Tombes of his owne Predece≈ø≈øours were not ≈øpared, when as Edward ≈ølaine at Agincourt, and Richard at Wakefield, both of them Dukes of Yorke, were after death a≈ø≈øaulted with the weapons of de≈øtruction, that ca≈øt downe their mo≈øt faire Monuments in the Collegiate Church of Fotheringhay Ca≈øtle.

(9) Eight Princely Families haue enioyed the Title of the Earledome of Northampton, whereof the la≈øt, Henry Hawara, late Lord Priuie Seale, a mo≈øt honourble Patron to all learned proceedings (that I may acknowledge my dutifull and humble Seruice) hath mo≈øt honourably a≈ø≈øi≈øted and ≈øet forward the≈øe my endeuours.

(10) This Shires diui≈øion, for ≈øeruice to the Crowne, and imployment of bu≈øine≈ø≈øes, is into twentie Hundreds, hath beene ≈øtrengthned with ten Ca≈øtles, and is ≈øtill traded with ten Market-Townes, and God honoured in three hundred twentie-≈øixe Pari≈øh-Churches.

div.head: HVNTINGTON-SHIRE. CHAPTER XXVIII.
div.p: HVNTINGTON-SHIRE, (part of the leui vnder the Romane Monarch of Mertia in the Saxon Heptarchy) is ≈øeuered with Nene, the North-bounder from Northampton≈øhire, to which it in part adioyneth We≈øt; from Bedford and Cambridge, by mearing Townes on the South; and from Ely, by a ≈øence of water Ea≈øt, theworke of Nature, Benwicke Streame, or of Art, Canutus Delph: ≈øeuered when Alfred, or before him, Offa ≈øhared the open circuit of their Empery into Principalities: that by re≈øidency of ≈øubordinate rule, Peace at home might be maintained; Fortaine offence (by apt a≈ø≈øembly of the Inhabitants) re≈øi≈øted; Taxe and Reuenew of the Crowne laid more euenly, and ea≈øierly leuyed; Iu≈øtice at mens dores with le≈ø≈øe charge and iourney admini≈øtered: all cau≈øes Ciuill hauing a right and ≈øpeedy di≈øpatch, in the County or Earles monethly Court, as Criminall in his Lieutenant the Sheriffes Turne, twice a yeare. In forme of a Lozeng this Shire lyeth, of po≈øiture temperate, and is 52. degrees, 4. ≈øcruples remoued from the Aequator: the Hilly Soyle to the Plough-man gratefull: the Vale, contiguous to the Fennes, be≈øt for Pa≈øture, in which to no part of England it giueth place: Woods are not much wanted, the Riuers ≈øeruing Coale, as the Moores Turffe, for fuell.

(2) This Content was (as the whole Continent) Forre≈øt, vntill Canutus gaue this Law of grace, Vt qui≈øque tam in agris, quam in ≈øiluis excitet agitet
que feras. Long were were the hands of Kings to pull (of old) the Subiects right into Regall plea≈øure, when Perambulation & Proclamation onely might make any mans land Forre≈øt. It is in the fir≈øt Williams time a Phra≈øe in Record not rare, Silua bu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
Maner ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
FORIS EST mi≈ø≈øa in Siluam Reg ‚Ä¢ s, from which word of power, Forre≈øt may ≈øeeme not vnaptly
to be deriued. Cum videbat Henricus primus tres Bi≈ø≈øas, fitting his Forre≈øt of Lyfield, he cau≈øed Hu≈øculphus his Raunger to keepe them for his Game, as the Record doth te≈øtifie. Thus did the ≈øecond of his name, and the fir≈øt Richard, in many parts: well therefore may the Exchequer-Booke call the Forre≈øt Iu≈øtice for Vert and Veni≈øon, not Iu≈øtum ab≈øolut√®, but Iu≈øtum ≈øecundum Legem Forre≈øta. That Fore≈øta is defined, Tuta ≈øerarum ≈ø ‚Ä¢ ain, may ≈øeeme to confine the Forre≈øters office onely to his Games care, which of ancient was as well ouer Minerall and Maritimall reuenew. The office of Baldwme the great Forre≈øter of Flanders, Non agrum tantum ≈øpectabat, ≈øed et Maris cu≈øtodiam, ≈øaith Tullius, out of the old Charters of the French Kings. And ≈øee how iu≈øt this ≈øquares to our Legall practi≈øe, for of A≈ø≈øarts, Purpre≈øtures, E ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ prousment, Greenebugh, Herbage, Paunage, Fowles, Mils, Hony, Mine ‚Ä¢ , Quarries, and Wreacks at Sea, did the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ inerall Iu≈øtice of the Forre≈øt here enquire. His Subiects of this Shire, Henry the 2. from ≈øeruitude of his bea≈øts, (who≈øe Grand-father pro ‚Ä¢ eris homines incarc ‚Ä¢ rauit, exhareditauit, mutilauit, „Äà‚óä„Äâ ) did pretend by Charter to enfranchi≈øe, except Wabridge, Saple, Herthy, his owne Demaines.
