But ≈øuch was the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe by encrochments, vnder his two ≈øucceeding Sonnes, that it drew on the oppre≈ø≈øed people to importune a new the Soueraignes redre≈ø≈øe, which was by the great Charter of the third Henry fruitle≈øly effected His ≈øonne in the 7. of his Raigne, by a Perambulation, re≈øuming backe the fruit of his fathers goodne≈ø≈øe, and ≈øo retaining, vntill in his 29. yeare by Petition, and purcha≈øe of his people (for they gaue him a full Fifteene) he confirmed the former Charter, and by Iury, View and Perambulation ≈øetled that Boundary of Forre≈øt, which contented the people, became the ≈øquare of vniuer≈øall Iu≈øtice in this kinde, and left in this Shire no more then the three former (his owne grounds) Forre≈øt.

(3) This Shire hath foure Centuriatae or Hundreds, and had of old time fiue, the≈øe ≈øo called, Quia prima in≈øtitutione ex Hederum aliquet centenarijs compo≈øitae. The≈øe are ≈øubdiuided into 79. Pari≈øhes, whereof fiue be≈øides the Shire-Towne haue Markets. The≈øe Pari≈øhes are mea≈øured by Hides, and
Carucks, or Plough-lands, more or le≈ø≈øe, as either richnes of Soile, or ≈øtrength of the Lord ≈øtrengthned or extended their limits, the Ma≈ø≈øe in whole containing of the fir≈øt ≈øort, 818. and of the other, 1136. The≈øe Hides the ancient and generall mea≈øure of land (except in Kent) where the account was by Solms; or Lincoln≈øhire, Vbinon ≈øunt Hida, ≈øed pro Hidis ≈øunt Carucatae) were e≈øteemed one hundred Acres, Non Normanico ≈øed Anglico numero, vna Hida pro ≈øexies viginti Acris, ‚Ä¢ uo produ ‚Ä¢ dec ‚Ä¢ es
„Äà‚óä„Äâ , as in the Booke of Dome≈øday Caruca the Teame-land (not Ca ‚Ä¢ ucata for they be different) was in quantitie of Acres, proportioned to the qualitie of Soile, but v≈øually in this Shire reputed 60. The
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rgata, or Yard-land, was a more or le≈ø≈øe part of the Hide, as the Acres in number varied, which I finde in this Countie from 18. to 42 but for the mo≈øt part 30 which was the halfe Ploughland And the Bouata or Oxgang (pre≈øumed in Law for Land in Granary) was ≈øuited in number of Acres to that Yard-land, of which it was a Moitie. Thus (except in the Fennes, laid out per Leucas & quarentenas, miles and furlongs) ≈øtands all a mea≈øurement of Land in this Shire, which containeth in Knights Fees, 53 one halfe, 2 fifts, and a twentieth part. And in full e≈øtimation of rent and worth, ro≈øe in the time of the Conquerour, to 912. l. 4. s. and now payeth in Fifteene to the King, 371. l. 9. s. 7. „Äà‚óä„Äâ and in tenth from the Clergie, 142. l. 6. s. q.

(4) This Countie in di≈øcition of Titles, and admini≈øtration of Iu≈øtice, did at the fir≈øt, as the Germans our Ance≈øtors, Iurape ‚Ä¢ Pagos & vicos reddere; Euery Towne≈øhip by their Friburgi, or Tenmentall, as Triers, and the Baron, Thain, or Head-lord there, or the Decanus (a good Freholder) his Deputie, as Iudge, determining all ciuill cau≈øes; a repre≈øentation of this remaineth ≈øtill in our Court-Lecte. Aboue this, and held 12. times a yeare, was our Hundred or Wapentake. Quae ≈øuper decem Decan ‚Ä¢ s & centum Friburgosiudicabat. Here the Iudges were the Aldermen, and Barons or Free-holders of that Hundred; Aegelwinus Aldermannus tenuit placitum cum toto Hundredo, ≈øaith the Booke of Ely. This Court had Cogno≈øcence of Cau≈øes Eccle≈øia≈øticall, as Temporall, therefore the Iudge or Alderman
ought to be ≈øuch as Dei leges & hominum iura ≈øtudebat promouere: thus it went although the Conquerour commanded, Ne Aliquis de legibus Epi≈øcopalibus amplius in Hundredo placita teneret. The next and highe≈øt in this Shire, was Generale pla ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ uÃÑ Comitatus, (the County or Sheriffes Count) to which were proper Placita Ciuilia vbi curia Deminorum probantur defeci≈ø≈øe. Et ≈øit placitum exurga ‚Ä¢
inter Vauafores duorum Dominorum tractetur in Comitatis. The Iudge was the Earle or Sheriffe. The Tryers Barones Comitatus (Freholders) Quiliberat in eo terr ‚Ä¢ habent, not Ciuill onely, but Probats of Wils, Que≈øtions of Tithes, Et debita verae Chri≈øtianitatis Iura, were heard, and fir≈øt heard in this Court. Therefore Epi≈øcopus, Presbyter Eccle≈øia, & Quatuor de melioribus villae, were a diuncts to the Sheriffe, Qui dei lege ‚Ä¢ & ≈øecul ‚Ä¢ negotia iu≈øta con≈øideratione difinirent. The Lay part of this liueth in a ≈øort in the Countie, and Sheriffe Turne; the Spirituall, about the raigne of King Stephen, by Soueraigne conniuence, ≈øuffered for the mo≈øt into the quarterly Synode of the Clergie, from whence in imitation of the Hundred Court, part was remitted to the Rurall Deaneries, of which this Shire had foure: And the≈øe againe haue beene ≈øince ≈øwallowed vp by a more frequent and ≈øuperiour Iuri≈ødiction, as ≈øome of our Ciuill Courts haue beene. There being now left in v≈øe for the mo≈øt in this Shire for Cau≈øes Criminall, View of Frankpl ‚Ä¢ g, by grant or pre≈øcription, A Se≈øsion of the Peace quarterly, and two Goale deliueries by the Soueraignes commi≈ø≈øion: and for Ciuill Cau≈øes, Courts of Manours, or of the County mon ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ bly, and twice by the Iudges of A≈øsi≈øe yearely

The Office of Execution and cu≈øtody of this County is the Sheralfey, of old inheritable, vntill Eu≈øtachius, who by force and fauour of the Conquerour di≈ø≈øei≈øed Aluric and his heyres, forfeited it to the Crowne; but ≈øince it hath pa≈ø≈øed by annuall election, and hath vnited to it the County of Cambridge.

(5) Hauing thus farre ≈øpoken of the Shire in generall, next in ob≈øeruation falleth the Shire-Towne Huntingdon, Hundandun, or the Hunters Downs, North, ≈øeated vpon a ri≈øing banke, ouer the
rich meadowing riuer Ow≈øe, interpreted by ≈øome Authors, the Downe of Hunters, to which their now common Seale (a Hunter) ≈øeemeth to allude. Great and populous was this in the fore-going age, the following hauing here buried of fifteene all but three, be≈øides the Mother-Church S. Maries, in their owne graues. At the raigne of the Conquerour, it was ranged into foure Ferlings or Wards, and in them 256. Burgen≈øes or Hou≈øholds: It an≈øwered at all a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øments for 50. Hides, the fourth part of Hur≈øting≈øton Hundred in which it ≈øtandeth. The annuall rent was then 30. l of which, as of three Minters there kept, the King had two parts, the Earle the third; the power of Coynage then and before, not being ≈øo priuatiuely in the King, but Borowes, Bi≈øhops, and Earles enioyed it; on the one ≈øide ≈øtamping the face and ≈øtile of their Soueraigne, in acknowledgement of ≈øubordinacie in that part of ab≈øolute power, and on the reuer≈øe their owne name, to warrant their integritie in that infinite tru≈øt.

(6) The Ca≈øtle ≈øuppo≈øed by ≈øome the worke of the Elder Edward, but ≈øeeming by the Booke of Dome≈øday, to be built by the Conquerour, is now knowne but by the ruines: It was the ≈øeate of Waltheof the great Saxon Earle, as of his ≈øucceeding heyres, vntill to end the que≈øtion of right betweene Se ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ice and the King of Scots, Henry the ≈øecond, laid it as you ≈øee; yet doth it remaine the head of that honour, on which in other Shires many Knights Fees, and ≈øixteene in this attended Here Dauid Earle of this and Argui≈øe, father of I≈øabel de Brus, founded the Ho≈øpitall of S. Iohn Bapti≈øt: And Lo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
tote here vpon the Fee of Eu≈øtace the Vicount, built to the honour of the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin, the Priory of Blacke Channons, valued at the Suppre≈ø≈øion, 232 l. 7. s. ob. Here at the North end was a hou≈øe of Fryers, and without the Towne at Hinchingbrooke, a Cloi≈øter of Nunnes, valued at 19. l. 9. s. 2. d. founded by the fir≈øt William, in place of S. Pandonia, at Elte≈øley (by him ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed) where neere the end of the la≈øt Henry the Family of the Cromwels began their Seat. To this Shire-Towne, and benefit of the neighbour Countries, this Riuer was nauigable, vntill the power of Grey, a mynion of the
time, ≈øtopt that pa≈ø≈øage, and with it all redre≈ø≈øe eyther by Law or Parliament. By Charter of King Iohn this Towne hath a peculiar Coroner, profit by Toll and Cu≈øtome, Recorder, Towne-Clerks, and two Bayliffes, (elected annually for gouernment) as at Parliament two Burge≈ø≈øes, for adui≈øe and a≈ø≈øent: and is Lord of it ≈øelfe in Fee-Farme.

The re≈øt of the Hundred (wherein this Shire-Towne lyeth) is the Ea≈øt part of the County, and of Hur≈øt a Pari≈øh in the center of it, named HVRSTINGSTON, it was the Fee-farme of Ram≈øey Abbey, which on a point of fertile land, thru≈øt out into the Fennes, is therein ≈øituate, founded in the yeare 969 to God, our Lady, and S. Benedicte, by Farle Aylwin of the Royall bloud, repleni≈øhed with Monkes from We≈øtbury, by O≈øwold of Yorke, and dedicated by D ‚Ä¢ n≈øtan of Canterburie, Archbi≈øhops. By Abbat Reg ‚Ä¢ ald 1114 this Church was redified, by Magna ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ll Earle of E≈ø≈øex, not long after ≈øpoyled and by Henry the Third, fir≈øt of all the Norman Princes, vi≈øited; when wa≈øted with the
„Äà‚óä„Äâ warres, Regalis men≈øae Ho≈øpitalitas it abbreuiata fuit, vt cum Abbatibus, Clericis & viris ≈øatis humilibus, ho≈øpitia quae≈øunt & prandia This Mona≈øtery (the ≈øhrine of two martyred Kings, Ethelbright and Ethelred, and of Saint „Äà‚óä„Äâ the Per≈øian Bi≈øhop) by humble pietie at fir≈øt, and pious charitie, a≈øcended ≈øuch a pitch of worldly fortune, that it transformed their Founder (religious pouertie) into their ruine, the attribute of Ra ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y the rich: for hauing made them≈øelues Lords of 387. Hides of land (whereof „Äà‚óä„Äâ in this Shire, ≈øo much as at an ea≈øie and vnder rent, was at the Suppre≈ø≈øion valued at 1983 l 15 s 3. d q. but by account of this time annually amounts to 7000 „Äà‚óä„Äâ ) they then began to affect popular command, and fir≈øt inclo≈øing that large circuit of land and water (for in it lyeth the Mile-≈øquare Meere of Ram≈øey) as a peculiar Seignory to them, called the Balent or Bandy (bounded as the Shire, from E ‚Ä¢ y, and from Norman-Cro≈ø≈øe with the Hundred Meere) by Soueraigne Grant they enioyed regall libertie. And then a≈øpiring a ≈øtep further, (to place in Parliament) made Broughton the head of their Baro ‚Ä¢ e, annexing to it in this Shire foure Knights Fees. Thus in
great glory it ≈øtood aboue 400. yeares, vntill Henry the Eight (among≈øt many other once bright Lamps of Learning and Religion in this State, though then ob≈øcured with tho≈øe blemi≈øhes to wealth and ea≈øe concomitant) di≈ø≈øolued the hou≈øe, although Iohn Warboys then Abbot, and his 60 blacke Monkes there maintained, were of the fir≈øt that vnder their hands and conuentuall Seale prote≈øted, Quod Romanus Pontifex non habet maiorem aliquam Iuri≈ødictionem collatam ≈øibi √† Deo in Regno Angliae quam quivis alius externus Epi≈øcopus. A Cell to this rich Mona≈øtery was S. Iuces Priory, built in that place of Slep, by Earle Adelmus, in the raigne of the la≈øt Edmund, where the incorrupted body of S. Ius there once an Hermit, in a vi≈øion reuealed, was by Ednothus taken vp in his Robes Epi≈øcopall, and dedicated in the pre≈øence of Siward Earle of this Countie, and that Lady of renowned piety Ethelfleda, to the ≈øacred memory of this Per≈øian Bi≈øhop. Not farre from this is Somer≈øham, the gift of the Saxon Earle Brithnothus to the Church of Ely, before his owne fatall expedition again≈øt the Danes: It is the head of tho≈øe fiue Townes, of which the Soke is compo≈øed, and was an hou≈øe to the See of Ely, well beautified by Iohn Stanley their Bi≈øhop: but now by exchange is annexed to the Crowne As the≈øe, ≈øo all the re≈øt of this Hundred, was the Churches land, except Rippon Regis ancient Demaine. To which Saple (re≈øerued Forre≈øt) adioyned, and the greater Stiuecly, giuen by the la≈øt Dauid Earle of Huntingdon, in Fee to his three Seruants, Sentlice, Lakerutle, and Camoys.

(8) NORMANS CROS the next Hundred, taketh name of a Cro≈ø≈øe aboue Stilton, the place where in former ages this Diui≈øion mu≈øtered their people, whence Wapentake is deriued: it had in it two religious hou≈øes, the elde≈øt in the confines of Newton and Che≈øterton, neere the Riuer of Auon, now Nene, founded (by the fir≈øt Abbe≈ø≈øe Kineburga the Daughter of Penda, and Wife of Aelfred, King of Northumberland) We≈øt ≈øide a Trench, where Ermin-≈øtreet-way cro≈ø≈øed ouer the Riuer by a Stone-bridge, who≈øe ruines are now drowned, whence the Roman Towne there ≈øea ‚Ä¢ ed on both ≈øides tooke the name Durobriua, as Traiectus Fluminis. But this Nunnery as rai≈øed, was al≈øo ruined
by the Danes before the Conque≈øt The other a Mona≈øtery of Ci≈øtertian blacke Monks, erected in honour of the Virgin Mary, by the ≈øecond Simon Earle of Huntington, at Saltry Iudeth, the Land of a Lady of that name, wife of Earle Waltheof, daughter to Lambert Earle of Le ‚Ä¢ us, Neece to the Conquerour by his Si≈øter, (her Mother) and Grand-mother to this Founder Malcome, & William, Kings of Scots, Earles of Hamingdon, and Heires of this Lady, ≈øtrengthened by ≈øeuerall Charters this pious worke. Many chiefe of that Line, as the la≈øt Earle Dauid, brother to King William, as I≈øabel, the wife of Robert d ‚Ä¢ Brus his Daughter heyre; and mo≈øt of the ≈øecond branch, her Progenie making here their Burials. This hou≈øe now leuell with the ground, maintained be≈øides the Abbot, ≈øixe Monkes, and 22 Hindes, and was at the Suppre≈ø≈øion valued at 199. l. 11. c. 8. d The Founders and Patrons of this Mona≈øtery were the Lords of the next place Connington, fir≈øt the ≈øeate of Turkillus Earle of the Ea≈øt-Angles, that inuited Swayn from Denmarke to inuade this Land: and who fir≈øt ≈øquared out the vnbounded mari≈øhes of this part, to the bordering Townes; his rule of proportion allowing to euery Pari≈øh tantum de Ma ‚Ä¢ i≈øco, quantum de ≈øicca terra in bredth, in which none, ≈øine licentia Domini might vel federe, vel ≈øalcare, but leauing mo≈øt to inter-common by vicinage. This Dane exiled (when the re≈øt of his Countreymen were by Edward Confe≈ø≈øor) his land here was giuen to Earle „Äà‚óä„Äâ
by who≈øe elde≈øt heire Matilda marryed to Dauid King of Scots, it went along in that Male line, vntill by death i≈ø≈øuele≈ø≈øe of Iohn Earle of Che≈øter and Huntingdon, it fell in partage, to his ≈øi≈øter I ‚Ä¢ abel de Brus, one of his heires, from who≈øe ≈øecond Sonne Bernard, the Familie of Cotton by lineall ≈øucce≈ø≈øion holdeth this Land, whereto Glarton the adioyning Pari≈øh is now by bountie of a ≈øecond branch annexed. It was in this Shire the head of the honour of Belleine, on which „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , Sib≈øon,
„Äà‚óä„Äâ , and Ve≈ø ‚Ä¢ yes Mannor in Che≈øterton attended: part of it is the fre ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Sea „Äà‚óä„Äâ , foure mile „Äà‚óä„Äâ bredth; ouer which when Emma, and her Children, the i≈ø≈øue of Canuti ‚Ä¢ , ≈øayled with ≈øome perill, her Husband in preuention of the like, from Bott≈øey in a ≈øtrait cour≈øe to the oppo≈øite firme
land, lined with his Attendant Swords that pa≈ø≈øage, which ≈øince hath borne the name of Swords Delph, Kings or Canutus dyke. This Seignory was granted by the Conquerour to Eu≈øtace Earle of Bollein, Brother to Lambert Earle of Leins, and Father to Godfrey King of Ieru≈øalem; reuerting it was giuen to Richard Earle of Cornwall, who granted out of it the two Meeres, Vbbe Meere and Brich Meere, in Fee-Farme to the Church of Ram≈øey Then after ≈øundry changes it came to Iohn of Gaunt, in exchange of the Earledome of Richmond, and ≈øo by de≈øcent fell againe into the Crowne Wa≈øhingley, (not farre off) from the ancient Lord of that name, by D ‚Ä¢ we, and Otter came to the Prices that now po≈ø≈øeth it. In Che≈øterton from Wad≈øheafe by Dennyes there is to the Beuils (an ancient name in this Shire) a Mannor de≈øcended. The re≈øt from Aegidius de Merke (who gaue there much to Roy≈øton Priory) pa≈ø≈øed by Amundeuill to Glouce≈øter, and ≈øo to Ve≈øey by exchange. In Elton, the hou≈øe rich in a beautious Chappell, from Denham to Sapcotes, and Saultre Beaumes, from that ≈øurname (neere the time of the Conque≈øt) by Louth to Cornwallis de≈øcended; as Bottlebridge by Gimels, Drayton, Louet, vnto Sherley the now Lord.

(9) LETTVNESTAN HVNDRED hath that name from Leighton, a Towne in the midde≈øt of it, giuen by Earle Waltheof to the Church of Lincolne, which after ≈øhared it into two Prebendaries. One, the Par≈øonage impropriate, which ≈øtill remaineth: the other (the Lord≈øhips) was re≈øumed by Henry the eight, and now by the Heire of Darcy matched to the Lord Clifton, is become the ≈øeate of his Barony. This Hundred had in it no hou≈øe of Religion, but Stonley a Priorie of ≈øeauen blacke Channons, of the order of S. Augu≈øtine, founded by the Bigrames, and at the Suppre≈ø≈øion valued at 62. l. 12. s 3. d ob. It ≈øtood within the reach of the great Mannor Kimbolton (once an Hundred) which was the land of Earle Harold the V≈øurper: after by Graunt it came with the Cha≈øe of Swine≈øheued to Fitz-Peter, from whom by Magnauil to Bohum (who in time of the „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Barons built there a Forcelet) and ≈øo to Stafford, by who≈øe attainturre for≈øaited, it was giuen by
Henry the eight to the Familie of Wingfield that now po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth it. At Bugden the See of Lincolne hath a ≈øeate, and was Lord of Spaldwick, and the Soke (giuen in compen≈øation from the Church of Ely, when rent from them, it was by the fir≈øt Henry made a Bi≈øhopricke) vntill of late that Church gaue vp their intere≈øt in Spaldwicke to the Crowne. Brampton was giuen by King Iohn at Mirabel, to Earle Dauid, and by Ada his younge≈øt Daughter fell to Ha≈øtings Earle of Pembroke, and now is reuerted to the King To the ≈øame Earle Dauid by gift of the former King came Alcumesbury, and by the bounty of Iohn Scot his ≈øonne to Segraue, and ≈øo to the Lord Barkley the late po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor. To Serlo de Quincy
‚Ä¢ arle of Winthe≈øter, was Ke≈øton by Henry the ≈øecond giuen, by who≈øe Heyre generall Ferrars, it came to the late Earle of E≈ø≈øex, and by exchange to the Crowne.

(10) TOVLESLAND HVNDRED, taketh name likewi≈øe of a Towne therein ≈øituate. In the out Angle of this, to the memory of S. Neotus a Monke of Gla≈øterbury, but the ≈øuppo≈øed ≈øonne to „Äà‚óä„Äâ King of the We≈øt-Saxons (who≈øe body from „Äà‚óä„Äâ in Cornwall was tran≈øferred to Arnalphesbury, then of Arnulphus a holy man, now Eynesbury named) Earle Alrick and Ethelfleda turned the Palace of Earle Elfred into a Mona≈øtery of blacke Monkes, which was razed by the Danes; but out of the a≈øhes of this, Roi≈øia (wife to Richard the ≈øonne of Earle Gilbert) to God, our Lady de Becco, and S. Neot (as a Cell to the Abbey of Becco in Normandy) erected vp of blacke Monkes in the yeare 1113. the late Priorie of S. Nedes, ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed by Henry the eight, and valued at 256. l. 15. d q. At Southo (the Land of Eu≈øtachius the Sheriffe) Louetote made the ≈øeate of that Seignory: on which in this Shire 13. Knights Fees and a halfe depended: But from his line by gift of Verdon and Ve≈øey drowned were the≈øe in the honour of Glouce≈øter. Neare to this at Cretingsbury dwelt Sir Adam de Cretings, famous in Edward the thirds warres of France, who≈øe Heyre Generall Wanton doth now po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe it. Staunton giuen by the fir≈øt William to Gilbert de Gaunt, after the death i≈ø≈øuele≈ø≈øe of De Rupes, e≈øcheated to the King, who gaue it to Ioan his ≈øi≈øter Queene of Scots. She on
the Abbey of Tarent be≈øtowed part, the re≈øt reuerting being giuen to Segraue de≈øcended to the Barons of Berkly, Godmanche≈øter, or Gormonche≈øter, (≈øo named of that Dane to whom Aelfred at his conuer≈øion granted ≈øome regiment in the≈øe parts) was the olde land of the Crowne, now the Inhabitants in fee farme, by grant of King Iohn, pro Sexies viginti libris pondere & numero. It is flat ≈øeated by as fruitfull and flowry Meadowes as any this Kingdome yeeldeth, and is the mo≈øt ≈øpacious of any one Pari≈øh in fertile tillage, oft hauing waited on their Soueraigne Lords with nine≈øcore Ploughes in a rurall pompe: Some from the name Gunice≈øter (which this often beareth in record,) ≈øuppo≈øe it the Citie where Machutus placed his Bi≈øhops Chayre. But for certaine it was that Romane Towne Duro≈øipont, of the Bridges named, ≈øo many hundred yeares (vntill the light of our Britain ‚Ä¢
Story ouer≈øhone it) forgotten. Thus as this Citie ≈øo the olde Families haue beene here with time outworne, few onely (of the many former) now remaining, who≈øe Surnames before the raigne of the la≈øt Henry were in this Shire of any eminency. But,
Non indignemur mortalia Nomina ≈øolui,
Cernimus exemplis Oppida po≈ø≈øe mort.
Let's not repine that Men and names doe dye,
Since ≈øtone-built Cities dead and ruin'd lye.
This De≈øcription I receiued from a right worthy and learned Friend.

div.head: RVTLAND-SHIRE. CHAPTER XXIX.
div.p: RVTLAND-SHIRE, the lea≈øt of any County in this Realme, is circulated vpon the North with Lincolne-≈øhire; vpon the Ea≈øt and South, by the Riuer Weland is parted from Northampton ≈øhire; and the We≈øt is altogether held in with Leice≈øter-≈øhire.

(2) The forme thereof is round, and no larger in compa≈ø≈øe then a light hor≈øe-man can ea≈øily ride about in a day‚ñ™ vpon which occa≈øion ≈øome will haue the Shire named of one Rut, that ≈øo rode. But others from the redne≈ø≈øe of the Soile, will haue it called Rutland, and ≈øo the old Engli≈øh-Saxons called it, for that Roet and Rut is in their tongue Red with vs, and may very well giue the name to this Prouince, ≈øeeing the earth doth ≈øtaine the wooll of her ≈øheepe into a reddi≈øh colour. Neither is it ≈øtrange, that the ≈øtaine of the ≈øoyle giues names vnto places, and that very many: for haue we not in Che≈ø≈øe-≈øhire the Red Rocke, in Lanca≈øhire the Red Banke, and in Wales, Rutland Ca≈øtle? To ≈øpeake nothing of that famous Red Sea which ≈øhooteth into the Land betwixt Egypt and Arabia, which gaue backe her waters for the I≈øraelites to pa≈ø≈øe on foote: all of them named from the colour of the Soile.

(3) The longe≈øt part of this Shire is from Caldecot in the South vpon the Riuer Ey,
„Äà‚óä„Äâ to Thi≈øtleton a ≈ømall Village ≈øeated in the North, not fully twelue miles: and from Timwell Ea≈øt-ward, to Wi≈ø≈øenden in the We≈øt, her broade≈øt extant, is hardly nine: the whole circumference about fortie miles.
(4) The ayre is good both for health and delight, ≈øubiect to neither extremity of heat nor cold, nor is greatly troubled with foggy mi≈øts.

The Soile is rich, and for Corne and tillage giues place vnto none. Woods there are plentie, and many of them imparked, hills feeding heards of Neate, and flockes of ≈øheepe; Vallies be≈øprinkled with many ≈øweet Springs; Graine in abundance, and Pa≈øtures not wanting: in a word, all things mini≈øtred to the content of life, with a liberall heart and open hand Onely this is obiected, that the Circuit is not great.
(5) The draught whereof, that I may acknowledge my dutie and his right, I receiued at the hands of the right Honourable Iohn Lord Harrington, Baron of Exton, done by him≈øelfe in his yonger yeares.

Neere vnto his hou≈øe Burley, ≈øtandeth Okham a faire Market-Towne, which Lord≈øhip the ≈øaid Baron enioyeth, with a Royaltie ≈øomewhat extraordinary, which is this: If any Noble by birth come within the precinct of the ≈øame Lord≈øhip, he ≈øhall forfeit as an homage a ≈øhooe from the hor≈øe whereon he rideth, vnle≈ø≈øe he redeeme it at a price with money In witne≈ø≈øe whereof, there are many Hor≈øe-≈øhooes nayled vpon the Shire-Hall doore, ≈øome of large ≈øize and ancient fa≈øhion, others new, and of our pre≈øent Nobilitie; who≈øe names are thereupon ≈øtamped as followeth:
Henry Ha≈øtings.
Roger Rutland.
Edward L. Ru≈ø≈øell, Earle of Bedford.
Raphe L. Euwer of Parram.
Henry L. Bertley.
Henry L. Mordant.
William L. Compton.
Edward L. Dudley.
Henry L. Win≈øor.
George, Earle of Cumberland.
Philip, Earle of Montgomery.
L. Willoughby.
P. L. Wharton.
The Lord Shandois.
Be≈øides many others without names.

That ≈øuch homage was his due, the ≈øaid Lord him≈øelfe told me; and at that in≈øtant a ≈øuit depended in Law again≈øt the Eirle of Lincolne, who refu≈øed to forfeit the penaltie, or to pay his ≈øine.

(6) Her ancient Inhabitants knowne to the Romones, and mentioned in Ptolemit, were the Coritan ‚Ä¢ , and by him branched thorow Leice≈øter, Lincolne, Nottingham, Darby-≈øhire and this; who with the Icemans were ≈øubdued by P. O≈øtorius vnder the yoke of Claudius the Roman Emperour: and at their departure, by conque≈øt the Saxons made it a Prounce vnto their Mercian Kingdome, who≈øe fortunes likewi≈øe comming to a full period, the Normans annexed it vnder their Crowne.

(7) This Countie King Edward Confe≈ø≈øor bequeathed by his Te≈øtament vnto Queene Eadgith his wife, and after her decea≈øe vnto his Mona≈øtery at We≈øtmin≈øter, which William the Conquerour cancelled and made voyd, be≈øtowing the Lands vpon others, the Tithes and the Church vnto tho≈øe Monkes‚ñ™

That the Ferrers here fir≈øt ≈øeated, be≈øides the credit of Writers, the Hor≈øe-≈øhooe who≈øe badge then it was, doth witne≈ø≈øe; where in the Ca≈øtle, and now the Shire-hall, right ouer the Seat of the
Iudge, a Hor≈øe-≈øhooe of iron curiou≈øly wrought, containing fiue foot and a halfe in length, and the bredth thereto proportionably is fixed. The Ca≈øtle hath beene ≈øtrong, but now is decayed, the Church faire, and the Towne ≈øpacious; who≈øe degree of Longitude is 19. 46. ≈øcruples, and the North poles eleuation in Latitude 53. degrees and 7. minutes.

(8) Let it not ≈øeeme offen ≈øiue, that I (to fill vp this little Shire,) haue in≈øerted the ≈øeate of a Towne not ≈øited in this County: for be≈øides the conueniency of place, the circuit and beautie, but e≈øpecially it being for a time an Vniuer≈øitie, did moue much; yea, and the fir≈øt in this Iland, if Iohn Hardings Author faile him not, that will haue Bladud to bring from Athens certaine Philo≈øophers, whom here he ≈øeated, and made publike profe≈ø≈øion of the Liberall Sciences, where (as he ≈øaith) a great number of Scholars ≈øtudied the Arts, and ≈øo continued an Vniuer≈øitie vnto the comming of Augu≈øtine, at which time the Bi≈øhop of Rome interdicted it; for certaine Here≈øies ≈øprung vp among the Britaines and Saxons. But mo≈øt true it is, that in the Raigne of King Edward the third, vpon debate falling betwixt the Southerne and Northerne Students at Oxford, many Schoole-men withdrew them≈øelues hither, and a while profe≈ø≈øed, and named a Colledge, according to one in Oxford, Bra≈øen-no≈øe, which retaineth that name vnto this day. This was ≈øo great a skarre vnto the other, that when they were recalled by Proclamation to Oxford, it was prouided by Oath, that no Student in Oxford ≈øhould publikely profe≈ø≈øeor reade the Arts at Stanford, to the preiudice of Oxford.

(9) As this Shire is the lea≈øt in circuit, ≈øo is it with the fewe≈øt Market-Townes repleni≈øhed hauing onely two. And from Societies that ≈øeed vpon the labours of others, was this Land the free≈øt: for be≈øides Rihall, where Tibba the F ‚Ä¢ lconers Godde≈ø≈øe was wor≈øhipped for a Saint, when Super≈øtition had well-neere put Gods true honour out of place, I finde very few; neither with more Ca≈øtles ≈øtrengthened then that at Okham, who≈øe ruines ≈øhew that a Ca≈øtle hath beene there.
Diuided it is into fiue Hundreds, and therein are planted fortie eight Pari≈øh-Churches.

div.head: LEICESTER-SHIRE. CHAPTER XXX.
div.p: LEICESTER-SHIRE, lying bordered vpon the North with Nottingham-≈øhire; vpon the Ea≈øt, with Lincolne and Rutland; vpon the South with Northampton ≈øhire; and vpon the We≈øt with Watling-≈øtreet-way is parted from Warwick-≈øhire; the re≈øt being bounded with the con≈øines of Darby, is a Country Champion, abounding in corne, but ≈øpary of woods, e≈øpecially in the South and Ea≈øt parts, which are ≈øupplyed with pit-coales plenteou≈øly gotten in the North of this Prouince, and with abundance of Cattle bred in the hilles beyond the Riuer Wreak, which is nothing ≈øo well inhabited as the re≈øt.

(2) The Ayre is gentle, milde, and temperate, and giueth appetite both to labour and re≈øt: whole≈øome it is, and draweth mans life to a long age, and that much without ≈øickne≈ø≈øe; at Carleton onely ≈øome defect of pronunciation appeareth in their ≈øpeech.

(3) The ≈øoile thus con≈øi≈øting, the commodities are rai≈øed accordingly of Corne, Cattle, and Coales; and in the Rockes neere Beuer are ≈øometimes found the A≈øtroites, the Starre-like precious Stone.

(4) The ancient people that inhabited this Countie, were the Coritani, who were ≈øpread further into other Shires, but after that the Romans had left the Land to it ≈øelfe, this with many more fell to be vnder the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and gouernment of the Mercians, and their Kings, from whom the Engli≈øh enioyeth it at this day.

(5) In Circular-wi≈øe (almo≈øt) the compa≈ø≈øe of this Shire is drawne indifferently ≈øpacious, but not very thicke of Inclo≈øures, being from Ea≈øt to We≈øt in the broade≈øt part not fully 30. miles, and
from North to South but 24. the whole circumference about 196. miles; who≈øe principall Citie is ≈øet, as the Center, almo≈øt in the mid≈øt; from whom the Pole is eleuated 53. degrees and 4 minutes in Latitude, and for Longitude, 19. degrees, 22. minutes.

(6) From this Towne the Shire hath the name, though the name of her ≈øelfe is diuer≈øly written, as Legece≈øtria, Legora, Legeo-ce≈øter: by Ninius, Caer-Lerion; by Mathew of We≈øtmini≈øter (if we doe not mi≈øtake him) Wirall; and now la≈øtly, Leice≈øter: ancient enough if King Leir was her builder, eight hundred fortie and foure yeares before the birth of our Sauiour, wherein he placed a Flamine to ≈øerue in the Temple of Ianus, by him≈øelfe there erected, and where he was buried, if Ieffery ap Arthur ≈øay true: but now certaine it is, that Ethelred the Mercian Monarch made it an Epi≈øcopall See, in the yeare of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus 680. wherein Sexwulph of his election became the fir≈øt Bi≈øhop: which ≈øhortly after was thence tran≈ølated, and therewith the beautie of the Towne began to decay; vpon who≈øe de≈øolations that erectifying Lady Edel≈øted ca≈øt her eyes of compa≈ø≈øion, and both reedified the buildings, and compa≈ø≈øed it about with a ≈øtrong wall, where, in ≈øhort time the Cities trade ≈øo increa≈øed, that Matthew Paris in his le≈ø≈øer Story reporteth as followeth; Lege-ce≈øter (≈øaith he) is a right wealthy Citie, and notably defended; and had the wall a ≈øure foundation, were inferiour to no Citie what≈øoeuer. But this pride of pro≈øperitie long la≈øted not vnder the Normans, for it was ≈øore oppre≈ø≈øed with a world of calamities, when Robert Bo≈ø≈øu the Crouch-backe Earle of that Prouince, rebelled again≈øt his Soueraigne Lord King Henry the ≈øecond: whereof heare the ≈øame Author Paris ≈øpeake: Through the ob≈øtinate ≈øtubborne≈ø≈øe of Earle Robert (≈øaith he) the noble Citie Leice≈øter was be≈øieged and throwne downe by King Henry, and the wall that ≈øeemed indi≈ø≈øoluble, was vtterly raced, euen to the ground. The peeces of who≈øe fragments ≈øo fallen downe, remained in his dayes like to hard rockes, through the ≈øtrength of the Morter cementing whole lumpes together: and at the Kings command the Citie was ≈øet on fire and burnt, the Ca≈øtle raced, and a heauit impo≈øition laid vpon the Citizens, who with
great ≈øummes of money bought their owne Bani≈øhments: but were ≈øo v≈øed in their departure, that for extreame feare many of them tooke Sanctuary, both at S. Edmunds and S. Albanes. In repentance of the≈øe mi≈øchiefes, the Author thereof, Earle Robert, built the Mona≈øtery of S. Mary de Praetis, wherein him≈øelfe became a Canon regular, and for fifteene yeares continuance in ≈øad laments ≈øerued God in continuall prayers. With the like deuotion, Henry the fir≈øt Duke of Lanca≈øter built an Ho≈øpitall for an hundred and ten poore people, with a Collegiate Church, a Deane, twelue Canons Prebendaries, as many Vicars, ≈øufficiently prouided for with reuenewes; wherein him≈øelfe lyeth buryed: and it was the greate≈øt ornament of that Citie, vntil the hand of King Henry the 8. lay ouer-heaiue vpon all the like foundations, and laid their a≈øpired tops at his owne feete.

The fortunes of another Crouch-backe (King Richard the V ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ per) were no le≈ø≈øe remarkable in this Citie then the former Robert was, both of them in like degree of di≈øhonourable cour≈øe of life, though of di≈øterent i≈ø≈øue at their deaths, the one dying penitent and of deuout e≈øteeme; the other leauing the ≈øtench of Tyranny to all following ages; who from this Citie ≈øetting forth in one day with great pompe, and in Battle aray, to keepe the Crowne ≈øure vpon his owne Helmet, in a ≈øore
„Äà‚óä„Äâ field, yeelded both it and his life, vnto the head and hands of Henry of Richmond his Conquerour: and the next day was brought backe, like a Hogge, naked and „Äà‚óä„Äâ and with contempt, without teares „Äà‚óä„Äâ buried in the G ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y-Fryers of this Citie; who≈øe ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion hath ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed the plot place of his graue, and onely the ≈øtone-che≈øt wherein he was laid (a drinking trough now for hor≈øes in a common In ‚Ä¢ e) retaineth the memory of that great Monarchs Funerall: and ≈øo did a ≈øtone in the Church and Chappell of S. Maries, inclo≈øe the corp≈øe of the proud and pontificall Cardinall Wol≈øey, who had prepared for him≈øelfe, as was ≈øaid, a farre more richer Monument.

(7) Otherplaces worthy of remembrance in this Shire were the≈øe: In the We≈øt, where a high Cro≈ø≈øe was erected, in former times ≈øtood the faire Citie Cleyce≈øter, the Romans BENONNES,
where their Legions lay, and where their two principall wayes cro≈ø≈øed each other, as the Inhabitants report; Loughborrow in the North-verge, was (as Marianus affirmeth) taken from the Britaines by Cuthwolfe their King, about the yeare of Chri≈øt 572.

At Redmore, neere Bo≈øworth, We≈øtward in this Countie, the Kingdome of England lay in hazard of one Battle, when King Richards Field was fought, where the Land at once was freed from a Tyrant and a wicked V≈øurper. Neither may we pa≈ø≈øe Lutterworth, as the lea≈øt in account, where the famous Iohn Wickliffe, Englands Morning-≈øtarre, di≈øper≈øed the clouds of all Papi≈øticall darkne≈ø≈øe, by preaching the Go≈øpell in that his charge; and ≈øtile of his pen, ≈øo piercing in power, that the man of Sinne euer ≈øince hath beene better knowne to the world.

(8) Religious hou≈øes by Princes erected, and by them deuoted to God and his ≈øeruice, the chiefe≈øt in this Shire were at Leice≈øter, Grace-Dieu, Kerby Bellers, and at Burton a Spittle for Lazers, a di≈øea≈øe then newly approched in this Land; for the erection whereof a common contribution was gathered thorow the Realme: the Patients in this place were not ≈øo much deformed in skin, as the other were in the defects for the ≈øoule; who≈øe skirts being turned vp to the ≈øight of the world, their ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ mes were di≈øcouered, and tho≈øe hou≈øes di≈ø≈øolued, that had long maintained ≈øuch Idolatrous ≈øinnes.
(9) This Shires diui≈øion is into ≈øix Hundreds, and in them are ≈øeated twelue Market-Townes for commerce, and containeth in her circuit two hundred Pari≈øh-Churches.

div.head: LINCOLN-SHIRE. CHAPTER XXXI.
div.p: THe County of Lincolne, by the Normans called Nicol≈øhire, is con≈øined on the North with Humber, on the Ea≈øt with the German Ocean, vpon the South is parted from Cambridge and Northampton-≈øhire by the Riuer Nyne; and on the We≈øt from Nottingham and York-≈øhires by Dun and Trent.

(2) The length of this Prouince extended from Barton vpon Humber in the North, vnto Stanford vpon the Riuer Nyne in the South, are miles by our Engli≈øh mea≈øure fiftie fiue, and the bredth thereof from Newton in the We≈øt, ≈øtretched vnto Wintbory vpon her Ea≈øt Sea containeth thirtie fiue. The whole in circumference about one hundred and eightie miles.

(3) The Ayre vpon the Ea≈øt and South part is both thicke and foggy, by rea≈øon of the Fennes and vn≈øolute grounds, but therewithall very moderate and plea≈øing. Her graduation being remoued from the Aequator to the degree of 53. and the windes that are ≈øent of her ≈øtill working Seas, doe di≈øper≈øe tho≈øe vapours from all power of hurt.

(4) The forme of this County doth ≈øomewhat re≈øemble the body of a Lute, who≈øe Ea≈øt coa≈øts lye bowe-like into the German Ocean, all along pe≈øtered with inlets of ≈øalt waters and ≈øands, which are neither firme nor ≈øafe for trauellers, as tho≈øe in the South proued vnto King Iohn who matching North-ward from Northfolke, again≈øt his di≈øloyall Barons, vpon tho≈øe wa≈øhes „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
and carriage by the ≈øodaine returne of the Sea, and ≈øofene≈ø≈øe of the ≈øands.

(5) Her Soile vpon the We≈øt and North is abundantly „Äà‚óä„Äâ , plea≈øant, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
pa≈øturage, areable and meadowing grounds: the Ea≈øt and South fenny and „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
barren; but for fowle and fi≈øh exceeding any other in the Realme; wherein, at ≈øome times and ≈øea≈øon of the yeare, hath beene taken in nets, in Augu≈øt, at one draught, aboue three thou≈øand Mallards, and other Fowles of the like kinde.

(6) The Shires commodities con≈øi≈øt chiefly in Corne, Cattle, Fi≈øh, Fowle, Flax and Alabla≈øter; as al≈øo in a Plai≈øter much e≈øteemed of by the Romans for their workes of Imagery; and whereof Plinie in his Naturall Hi≈øtory maketh mention. And the A≈øtroites, a precious ≈øtone, Star-like, pointed with fiue beames or rayes, anciently e≈øteemed for their vertue in victories, vpon the South-we≈øt of this County neere Beuer are found: not farre thence in our Fathers memory, at Harlaxton was ploughed vp a bra≈øen ve≈ø≈øell, wherein was inclo≈øed a golden Helmet of an ancient fa≈øhion, ≈øet with precious ≈øtones, which was pre≈øented to Kathren of Spaine, Wife and Dowager to King Henry the eight‚ñ™

(7) This Shire triumpheth in the births of Beauclerke, King Henry the fir≈øt, whom Selby brought forth, and of King Henry the fourth, at Bullingbrooke borne: but may as iu≈øtly lament for the death of King Iohn, herein poy≈øoned by S ‚Ä¢ non a Monke of Swyn≈øted Abbey; and of Queene Eleanor, wife to King Edward the fir≈øt, the mirrour of wedlocke, and loue to the Commons, who at Hardby, neere Bullingbrooke, his birth place, ended her life.

(8) Trade and commerce for proui≈øion of life is vented thorow thirtie one Market-Townes in this Shire, whereof Lincolne the Counties namer is chiefe, by Ptolemie and Antonine called Lindum, by Beda Linde-collma, and by the Normans, Nichol. Very ancient it is, and hath beene more magnificall, as by her many ouerturned ruines doth appeare, and farre more populous, as by Deme≈ødayes Booke is ≈øeene, where it is recorded that this Citie contained a thou≈øand and ≈øeauen Man≈øions, and nine hundred Burge≈ø≈øes, with twelue Lage-men, hauing Sac and Soc. And in the Normans time, ≈øaith Malmesbury, it was one of the be≈øt peopled Cities of England, being a place for trafficke of Merchandize
for all commerce by Land or Sea. Herein King Edward the third ordained his Staple for the Mart of Wools, Leather, and Lead; and no le≈ø≈øe then fiftie Pari≈øh. Churches did beautifie the ≈øame: but now containeth onely fifteene be≈øides the Cathedrall. Some ruines yet remaines both of Frieries and Nunneries, who lye now buried in their owne a≈øhes, and the Citie conquered not by warre, but by time and very age: and yet hath ≈øhe not e≈øcaped the calamitie of ≈øword, as in the time of the Saxons; whence Arthur enforced their Ho≈øt: the like al≈øo did Edmund to the de≈øtroying Danes; and by the Normans it ≈øuffered ≈øome dammage, where King Stephen was vanqui≈øhed and taken pri≈øoner; and againe, by the third Henry, that a≈ø≈øaulted and wan it from his rebellious Barons. By fire likewi≈øe it was fore defaced, wherein not onely the buildings were con≈øumed, but withall many men and women in the violence thereof peri≈øhed: as al≈øo by an Earth-quake her foundation was much weakened and ≈øhaken, wherein the faire Cathedrall Church, dedicated to the Virgin of Virgins, was rent in peeces. The gouernment of this Citie is committed yearely to a Maior, tow Sheriffes, twelue Aldermen in Scarlet, a Sword, a Hat of E≈øtate, a Recorder, Sword-bearer, and foure Sergeants with Maces: who≈øe ≈øituation on a ≈øleepe hill ≈øtandeth, for Longitude in the degree 20. 10. ≈øcruples, the Pole eleuated for Latitude from the degree 53. and 50. ≈øcruples.

(9) Much hath beene the deuotion of Princes in building religious hou≈øes in this Countie, as at Crowland, Lincolne, Markeby, Leyborne, Grenfeld, Aluingham, Newnersby, Grymmysby, New≈øted, El≈øham, Stay ‚Ä¢ feld, Syxhyll, Torke≈øey, Bryggerd, Thorneholme, Nuncotton, Fo≈ø≈øe, Heyings, Axholme Ile, Goykewell, S. Michaels neere Stamford, Swyn ‚Ä¢ ≈øhead, Spalding, Kirke≈øted, &c.

(10) Commotions in this Shire were ray≈øed the eight and twentieth of King Henry the Eight, where twentie thou≈øand making in≈øurrection, violently ≈øware certaine Lords and Gentlemen to their Articles. But no ≈øooner they heard of the Kings power comming, but that they di≈øper≈øed them≈øelues,
and ≈øued for pardon. And againe in the third yeare of King Edward the Sixt, in ca≈øe of Inclo≈øu ‚Ä¢ es, Lincolne, ro≈øe in ≈øeditious manner, as did they of Cornwall, Deuon-≈øhire, York-≈øhire, and Norfolke: but after ≈øome flaughters of their chiefe≈øt men, were reduced to former obedience.

The Shires diui≈øion is into three principall par ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , viz. Lind≈øey, Ke≈øteuen, and Holland, Lind≈øey is ≈øubdiuided into ≈øeauenteene Hundreds, „Äà‚óä„Äâ into eleuen, and Holland into three, containing in all thirtie one, wherein are ≈øituated thirtie Market-Townes, and ≈øixe hundred thirty Pari≈øh-Churches.

div.head: NOTTINGHAM-SHIRE. CHAPTER XXXII.
div.p: NOTTINGHAM-SHIRE (from Nottingham her chiefe≈øt Towne hath the name; and that, ≈øomewhat ≈øoftned from the Saxons Snoddenzaham, for the many Dennes or Caues wrought in her Rocks and vnder ground) lyeth bordered vpon the North & North we≈øt with York-≈øhire; vpon the Ea≈øt a good di≈øtance by Trent is parted froM, and with Lincoln-≈øhire altogether confined: the South with Leice≈øter-≈øhire; and the We≈øt by the Riuer Erwa≈øh is ≈øeperated from Darby-≈øhire.

(2) For forme long and Ouall-wi≈øe, doubling in length twice her bredth, who≈øe extreames are thus extended and di≈øtance ob≈øerued: From Finingley North to Sleanford in the South, are thirtie eight Engli≈øh miles; her We≈øt part from Teuer≈øall to Be≈øthorp in the Ea≈øt, are little more then nineteene; who≈øe circumference draweth much vpon one hundred and ten miles.

(3) The Ayre is good, whole≈øome and delectable: the Soile is rich, ≈øandy and clayie, as by the names of that Counties diui≈øions may appeare: and ≈øurely for Corne and Gra≈ø≈øe ≈øo fruitfull, that it ≈øecondeth any other in the Realme: and for Water, Woods, and Canell Coales abundantly ≈øtored.

(4) Therein groweth a Stone ≈øofter then Alabla≈øter, but being burnt maketh a plai≈øter harder then that of Paris: wherewith they flower their vpper roomes; for betwixt the Ioy≈øts they lay onely long Bulru≈øhes, and thereon ≈øpread this Plai≈øter, which being throughly dry becomes mo≈øt ≈øolide and hard, ≈øo that it ≈øeemeth rather to be firme ≈øtone then mortar, and is trod vpon without all danger.
In the We≈øt neere Work≈øop groweth plentie of Liquorice, very delicious and good.

(5) More South in this Shire, at Stoke, in the Raigne of King Henry the ≈øeauenth, a great battle was fought by Iohn De-la-Pole Earle of Lincolne, which Richard the V≈øurper had declared his heire apparant; but Richard lo≈øing his life, and De-la Pole his hopes, in ≈øeeking here to ≈øet vp a Lambert, fell downe him≈øelfe: and at Newarke after many troubles King Iohn got his peace with the end of his life.

(6) Trade and commerce for the Counties proui≈øion is frequented in eight Market-Townes in this Shire, whereof Nottingham is both the greate≈øt and be≈øt: a Towne ≈øeated mo≈øt plea≈øant and delicate vpon a high hill, for buildings ≈øtately, and number of faire ≈øtreets, ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing and ≈øurmounting many other Cities, and for a ≈øpacious and mo≈øt faire Market-place, doth compare with the be≈øt Many ≈øtrange Vaults hewed out of the Rockes, in this Towne are ≈øeene; and tho≈øe vnder the Ca≈øtle of an e≈øpeciall note, one for the ≈øtory of Chri≈øts Pa≈ø≈øion engrauen in the Walls, and cut by the hand of Dauid the ≈øecond King of Scots, whil≈øt he was therein detained pri≈øoner. Another wherein Lord Mortimer was ≈øurpri≈øed in the non-age of King Edward the Third, euer ≈øince beating the name of Mortimers Hole; the≈øe haue their ≈øtaires and ≈øeuerall roomes made artifically euen out of the Rockes: as al≈øo in that hill are dwelling hou≈øes, with winding ≈øtaires, windowes, chimneys, and roome aboue roome, wrought all out of the ≈øolide Rocke. The Ca≈øtle is ≈øtrong, and was kept by the Danes again≈øt Burthred, Ethelred, and Elfred, the Mercian, and We≈øt-Saxon Kings, who together laid their ≈øiege again≈øt it: and for the further ≈øtrength of the Towne, King Edward, ≈øurnamed the Elder, walled it about, whereof ≈øome part as yet remaines, from the Ca≈øtle to the We≈øt-gate, and thence the foundation may be perceiued to the North; where in the mid≈øt of the way ranging with this banke, ≈øtands a gate of Stone, and the ≈øame tract pa≈ø≈øing along the North part may well be
perceiued: the re≈øt to the Riuer, and thence to the Ca≈øtle are built vpon, and thereby buried from ≈øight: who≈øe circuit, as I tooke it, extendeth two thou≈øand one hundred and twentie pa≈øes.

(7) In the Warres betwixt Stephen and Maud the Empre≈ø≈øe, by Robert Earle of Gloce≈øter the≈øe Wells were ea≈øt downe, when al≈øo the Towne it ≈øelfe ≈øuffered the calamitie of fire: but recouered to her former e≈øtate, hath ≈øince increa≈øed in beautie and wealth, and at this day is gouerned by a Maior and ≈øixe Aldermen, clad in Scarlet, two Sheriffes, two Chamberlaines, a Towne-clerke, and ≈øixe Sergeants with Maces, their Attenders: who≈øe po≈øition hath the Pole eleuated fiftie three degrees. 25. minutes in Latitude, and hath the Meridian nine degrees and 25. minutes. This Towne hath beene honoured by the≈øe Princes titles, and the≈øe Princes dignified with the Earledome of Nottingham, who≈øe ≈øeuerall Armes and Names are in the great Map expre≈ø≈øed.

Religious hou≈øes that haue beene erected and now ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed in the compa≈ø≈øe of this Countie, chiefly were New≈øted, Lenton, Shelford, Southwell, Thurgarton, Blith, Welbeck and Radford; in Nottingham the White and Gray Fryers, be≈øides a little Chappell dedicated to Saint Iohn. All which ≈øhew the deuotions of tho≈øe former times: which their remembrance may moue, if not condemne vs, that haue more knowledge, but farre le≈ø≈øe pietie.

The Shires diui≈øion is principally into two: which the Inhabitants terme the Sand and the Clay; but for Tax ‚Ä¢ to the Crowne, or ≈øeruice for State, is parted into eight Wapentakes or Hundreds, wherein are ≈øeated 168. Pari≈øh Churches.

div.head: DARBY-SHIRE. CHAPTER XXXIII.
div.p: DARBY-SHIRE, lyeth inclo≈øed vpon her North parts with Yorke-≈øhire; vpon the Ea≈øt with Nottingham-≈øhire; vpon the South with Leice≈øter-≈øhire; and vpon the We≈øt is parted with the Riuers Doue and Goyt from Stafford and Che≈ø≈øe-≈øhires.

(2) It is in forme ≈øomewhat triangle, though not of any equall di≈øtance, growing from her narrow South-point ≈øtill wider, and in the North is at the broade≈øt: for from Stretton neere the head of Me≈øe, to New-Chapell ≈øeated neere the head of Derwent, the two extreames from North to South are thirtie eight miles: but from the Shire-Oakes vnto the meeting of Mer≈øey and Goyt, the broade≈øt part of all this Shire, is not fully twentie nine; the whole in circumference extendeth to an hundred and thirtie miles.

(3) The ayre is good and very healthfull: the ≈øile is rich, e≈øpecially in her South and Ea≈øt parts: but in the North and We≈øt is hilly, with a blacke and mo≈ø≈øie ground, both of them fa≈øt handed, to the Ploughers paines, though very liberall in her other gifts: who≈øe natures thus di≈ø≈øenting, the Riuer Derwent doth diuide a≈øunder, that taketh cour≈øe thorow the heart or mid≈øt of this Countie.

The ancient people that po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the≈øe parts in the times of the Romans a≈ø≈øaults, were the Coritani, whom Ptolemie di≈øper≈øeth thorow Northampton-≈øhire, Leice≈øter, Rutland, Lincolne, Nottingham, and this Shire, who were all of them ≈øubdued by P. O≈øtorius Scapula, Lieutenant in this Prouince for Claudius the Emperour. But Romes Empire failing in Britaine, by the inte≈øtine Warres among them≈øelues, the Saxons (a more ≈øauage and fearefull Nation) ≈øoone brought it vnder their ≈øubiection,
and made this a Prouince vnto their Mercians Kingdome, whom the We≈øt-Saxons fir≈øt wanne and againe lo≈øt to the Normans.

(5) It is ≈øtored with many Commodities, and them of much worth; for be≈øides Woods and Cattle, Sheepe and Corne, euery where ouer-≈øpreading the face of this Countie, the Mill-≈øtone, Cry≈øtall, and Allabla≈ø ‚Ä¢ er, the Mines of Pit-coale, Iron, and Lead, are of great price: whereof the la≈øt is mentioned in Flinie, who writeth that in Britaine, in the very cru≈øt of the ground, without any deepe digging, is gotten ≈øo great ≈øtore of Lead, that there is a Law expre≈øly made of purpo≈øe, forbidding men to make more then to a certaine ≈øtint. Who≈øe ≈øtones are plenteou≈øly gotten in tho≈øe Mountaines, and melted into Sowes, to no ≈ømall profit of the Countrey. There is found al≈øo in certaine veines of the earth, Subium which the Apothecarits call Antimonium, and the Al ‚Ä¢ thmi≈øts hold in great e≈øteeme.

(6) Places for commerce, or memorable note, the fir≈øt is Darby, the Shire-Towne, called by the Danes De ‚Ä¢ aby, ≈øeated vpon the We≈øt banke of Derwent, where al≈øo a ≈ømall Brooke ri≈øing We≈øtward, runneth thorow the Towne vnder nine Bridges, before it meets with her farre greater Riuer Derwent, which pre≈øently it doth, after ≈øhe hath pa≈ø≈øed Tenant Bridge in the South-Ea≈øt of the Towne. But a Bridge of more beautie, built all of Free-≈øtone, is pa≈ø≈øed ouer Derwent in the North-Ea≈øt of the Towne, whereon ≈øtandeth a faire ≈øtone Chapell, and both of them bearing the names of S. Maries: fiue other Churches are in this Towne, the chiefe≈øt whereof is called A ‚Ä¢ hallowes, who≈øe Steeple or Bell-Tower being both beautifull and high, was built onely at the charges of young men and maids, as is witne≈ø≈øed by the in≈øcription cut in the ≈øame vpon euery ≈øquare of the Steeple. Among the mi≈øerable de≈øolations of the Danes, this Towne bare a part, but by Lady Ethelfleda was againe repaired, and is at this day in ‚Ä¢ orporated with the yearely gournment of two Bailiffes, elect out of twentie-foure brethren, be≈øides as many Burge≈ø≈øes of Common Coun≈øell, a Recorder, Towne-Clerke, and two Sergeants with Mace: who≈øe Graduation is ob≈øerued from the Equator to be 53. degrees 25. ≈øcruples, and from the fir≈øt point in the We≈øt, 19. degrees 2. ≈øcruples.

(7) Little-Che≈øter (by the Romi≈øh Mony there daily found) ≈øeemeth to haue beene ancient, and that a Colonie of the Roman Souldiers there lay. Yet of farre greater fame was Repandunum, now Repton, where Ethelbald the ninth King of the Mercians, and fifteenth Monarch of the Engli≈øhmen, ≈ølaine at Segge≈øwald by the trea≈øon of his Subiects, was interred: and whence Burthred, the la≈øt King of that people, was expul≈øed with his Queene Ethel≈øwith, by the rage of the Danes, after twentie two yeares raigne. But with a more plea≈øing eye we may behold Melborne, the memoriall of Engli≈øhmens great valour, where in that Ca≈øtle was kept Pri≈øoner Iohn Duke of Burbon, taken captiue in the Battle of Agincourt, and therein detained the ≈øpace of nineteene yeares.

(8) Things of ≈øtranger note are the hot Water-≈øprings, bur≈øting forth of the ground at Buxton, where out of the Rocke within the compa≈ø≈øe of eight yards, nine ≈øprings ari≈øe, eight of them warme, but the ninth very cold. The≈øe run from vnder a faire ≈øquare building of free-≈øtones, and about three-≈øcore paces off, receiue another hot ≈øpring from a Well, inclo≈øed with foure flat ≈øtones, called Saint Annes; neere vnto which, another very cold ≈øpring bubled vp. The report goeth among the bydwellers, that great cures by the≈øe waters haue beene done: but daily experience ≈øheweth, that they are good for the ≈øtomacke and ≈øinewes, and very plea≈øant to bathe the body in. Not farre thence is Elden hole, whereof ≈øtrange things haue beene told, and this is confidently affirmed, the waters that trickle from the top of that Caue (which indeed is very ≈øpacious, but of a low and narrow entrance) doe congeale into ≈øtone, and hang as ickles in the roofe. Some of them were ≈øhewed at my being there, which like vnto ≈øuch as the fro≈øt congealeth, were hollow within, and grew Taper-wi≈øe towards their points, very white, and ≈øomewhat Cry≈øtall-like. And ≈øeauen miles thence, vpon a mounted hill, ≈øtandeth a Ca≈øtle, vnder which there is a hole or Caue in the ground of a marueilous capacitie, which is commonly called The Deuils Ar≈øe in the Peake, whereof Gerua≈øe of Tilbury hath told many pretie tales, and others doe make it one of the wonders of our Land.

(9) As in other Counties the deuotions of the religious haue beene made apparent in the erection of places for Gods peculiar ≈øeruice; ≈øo in this haue beene founded eight of that nature, which were Dale, Detelege, Darby, Rep ‚Ä¢ on, Bechif, Grai ‚Ä¢ ≈øley, Fauerwell, and Pollewerke: who≈øe peace and plentie ≈øtood ≈øecure from all danger, till the blu≈øtering windes ari≈øing in the Raigne of King Henry the eight, blew off the pinacles of their beauteous buildings, and ≈øhooke a≈øunder the reuenewes of tho≈øe Foundations which neuer are like againe to be laid.

(10) This Shire is diuided into ≈øixe Hundreds, wherein haue beene ≈øeated ≈øeauen Ca≈øtles, and is ≈øtill traded with eight Market-Townes, and repleni≈øhed with one Hundred and ≈øixe Pari≈øh-Churches.

div.head: STAFFORD-SHIRE. CHAPTER XXXIIII.
div.p: STAFFORD-SHIRE, who≈øe ≈øituation is much about the middle of England, meeteth vpon the North with Che≈ø≈øe-≈øhire and Darby, and that in a Triangle point, where three ≈øtones are pitched for the bounds of the≈øe Shires; it is parted from Darby ≈øhire on the Ea≈øt with Dowe and with Trent; the South is confined with Warwicke and Worce≈øter-≈øhires, and the We≈øt butteth again≈øt the Countie of Shrop-≈øhire.

The forme thereof is ≈øomewhat Lozeng-like, that is, ≈øharpe at both ends, and broade≈øt in the mid≈øt. The length extending from North to South, is by mea≈øure fortie foure miles; and the bredth from Ea≈øt to We≈øt, twenty ≈øeauen miles; the whole in circumference one hundred and fortie miles.
(3) The ayre is good and very healthfull, though ouer-≈øharpe in her North and Moreland, where the ≈ønow lyeth long, and the winde bloweth cold.

(4) The Soile in that part is barren of Corne, becau≈øe her hilles and Mores are no friends vnto Tillage: the middle is more leuell, but therewithall wooddie, as well witne≈ø≈øeth that great one, called the Cank. But the South is mo≈øt plenteous in Corne and Pa≈øturage.

(5) Her ancient Inhabitants were the CORNAVII, whom Ptolemie placeth in the Tract that containeth Shrop-≈øhire, Worce≈øter-≈øhire, Che≈ø≈øe-≈øhire, and this: all which were po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Mercian-Saxons when their Heptarchy flouri≈øhed. And Tameworth in this Shire was then held their Kings Court. The Danes after them often aflayed herein to haue ≈øeated, as witne≈ø≈øeth Ternall, then Th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
tenhall, by interpretation, The habitation of Pagans,
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ brued with their bloud by King Edward the elder.
But the Inhabitants of this Prouince Beda tearmes The midland Engli≈øhmen, becau≈øe to his ≈øeeming it lay in the heart of the Land, which when the Normans had made Conque≈øt of all, many of them ≈øet downe their re≈øt here, who≈øe po≈øteritie at this day are fairely and further branched into other parts.

(6) The Commodities of this Countie con≈øi≈øt chiefly in Corne, Cattle, Alabla≈øter, Woods, and Iron, (if the one proue not the de≈øtruction of the other) Pit-coale, Fle≈øh and Fi≈øh, whereof the Riuer Trent is ≈øaid to ≈øwarme: and others ari≈øing and running thorow this Shire, doe ≈øo batten the ground, that the Meadowes euen in the mid≈øt of Winter grow greene; ≈øuch are Dowe, Manifold, Churnot, Hun≈øye, Yenden, Tean, Elith, Trent. Tyne, and Sowe; whereof Trent is not onely the principall, but in e≈øteeme accounted the third of this Land.

(7) Stafford the Snire-Towne, anciently Betheney, from Bertelin, a reputed holy man that therein lead an Hermits life, was built by King Edward the elder, incorporated by King Iohn, and vpon the Ea≈øt and South parts was walled and trenched by the Barons of the place; the re≈øt from Ea≈øt to North was ≈øecured by a large Poole of water, which now is become faire Meadow grounds. The tract and circuit of the≈øe welles extended to twelue hundred and fortie pa≈øes, thorow which foure Gates into the foure winds haue pa≈ø≈øage, the Riuer Sowe running on the South and We≈øt of the Towne. King Edward the ≈øixt did incorporate the Burge≈ø≈øes, and gaue them a perpetuall ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, who≈øe gouernment is vnder two Bailiffes yearely elected out of one and twentie A≈ø≈øi≈øtants, called the Common Coun≈øell, a Recorder, whereof the Dukes of Buckingham haue borne the Office, and as yet is kept a Court of Record, wherein they hold Plea without limitation of ≈øumme; a Towne-Clerke al≈øo, (from who≈øe Pen I receiued the≈øe In≈øtructions) and to attend them two Sergeants at Mace. This Towne is ≈øited in the degree of Latitude 53. 20. ≈øcruples, and of Longitude 18. and 40. ≈øcruples.

(8) But Leichfield, more large, and of farre greater ≈øame, is much her ancient, knowne vnto Beda by the name of Licidfeld, which Ro≈ø≈øe doth interpret to be The field of deadbodies, for the number of Saints vnder the rage of Diocle≈øia ‚Ä¢
there ≈ølaine: vpon which cau≈øe the Citie beareth for her Armes an E≈øchocheon of Landskip, with diuers Martyrs in diuers manner ma≈ø≈øacred. Here O≈øwin King of Northumberland ouer-comming the Pagan-Mercians, built a Church and made it the See of Duina the Bi≈øhop; who≈øe ≈øucce≈ø≈øors growne rich, with golden rea≈øons ≈øo ouercame King Offa, and the Adrian the Pope, that an Archiepi≈øcopall Pale was granted Bi≈øhop Eadulph, to the great di≈øgrace of Lambert Arch-bi≈øhop of Canterbury. In this Church were interred the bodies of Wul≈øhere and Celred, both of them Kings of the Mercians. But when the mindes of men were ≈øet altogether vpon gorgeous building, this old foundation was new reared by Roger Clinton, Bi≈øhop of this See, and dedicated to the Virgin Mary and Saint Chad, and the Clo≈øe inwalled by Bi≈øhop Langton. The gouernment of this Citie is by two Bailiffes and one Sheriffe, yearely cho≈øen out of twentie-foure Burge≈ø≈øes, a Recorder, a Towne-Clerke, and two Sergeants their Attendants.

(9) Hou≈øes of Religion erected in this Shire, were at Leichfield, Stafford, De la Cro≈ø≈øe, Cru ‚Ä¢ den, Trentham, Burton, Tamworth, and Woluer-hampt ‚Ä¢ n. The≈øe Votaries abu≈øing their Founders true pieties, and heaping vp riches with di≈ødaine of the Laitie, laid them≈øelues open as markes to be ≈øhot at; whom the hand of the skilfull ≈øoone hit and quite pierced, vnder the ayme of King Henry the eight, who with ≈øuch Reuenewes in mo≈øt places relieued the poore and the Orphane, with Schooles and maintenance for the training vp of youth: a worke no doubt more acceptable to God, and of more charitable v≈øe to the Land.

(10) With 13. Ca≈øtles this Countie hath beene ≈øtrengthned, and „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Market-Townes her Commodities traded, being diuided into fiue Hundreds, and „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ one hundred and thirtie Pari≈øh-Churches.

div.head: SHROP-SHIRE. CHAPTER XXXV.
div.p: SHROP-SHIRE, is both large incircuit, well peopled, and very fruitfull for life. It lieth circulated vpon the North with the County Palatine of Che≈øter; vpon the Ea≈øt altogether with Stafford-≈øhire; vpon the South with Worce≈øter, Hereford, and Raduor-≈øhires; and vpon the We≈øt with Mountgomery and Denbigh.

(2) The forme thereof is almo≈øt ciruclar or round, who≈øe length from Weo ‚Ä¢ erto ‚Ä¢
below
‚Ä¢ odlane South, to Ouer neere vnto the Riuer Trent in the North, is thirtie foure miles: the broade≈øt part is from Tong in the Ea≈øt, to O≈øwe≈øtre ≈øited at the head of Morda in the We≈øt, twentie and fiue miles; the whole in circuit about, extending to one hundred thirtie and foure miles.

(3) Whole≈øome is the Aire, delectable and good, yeelding the Spring and the Autmne Seede time and Harue≈øt, in a temperate condition, and affoordeth health to the Inhabitants in all ≈øea≈øons of the yeare.

(4) The ≈øoile is rich, and ≈øtandeth mo≈øt vpon a reddi≈øh Clay, abounding in Wheat and Barley, Pit-coales, Iron, and Woods; which two la≈øt continue not long in league together. It hath Riuers that make fruitfull the Land, and in their waters containe great ≈øtore of fre≈øh-fi≈øh, whereof Seuer ‚Ä¢ e is the chiefe, and ≈øecond in the Realme, who≈øe ≈øtreame cutteth this Countie in the midde≈øt, and with many windings ≈øporteth her ≈øelfe forward, leauing both pa≈øtures and meadowes be ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed with flowers and greene colours, which euery where ≈øhe be≈øtoweth vpon ≈øuch her attendants.

(5) This Riuer was once the bounds of the North-Britaines, and diuided their po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion from the Land of the Saxons, vntill of latter times theirs began to decay, and the Wel≈øh to increa≈øe, who
enlarged their li≈øts to the Riuer Dee. So formerly had it ≈øeparated the Ordouices from the Cornauji, tho≈øe ancient Inhabitants mentioned by Ptolemie. The Ordouices vnder Caractachus purcha≈øed great honour, while≈øt he a Prince of the Silures remoued his warres thence among them, where a while he maintained the Britaines libertie with valour and courage, in de≈øpight of the Romans. His Fort is yet witne≈ø≈øe of his vnfortunate fight, ≈øeated neere Clune Ca≈øtle, at the confluence of that Riuer with Temd, where (in remembrance of him) the place is yet called Caer-Caradoc, a Fort of his, wonne by P. O≈øtorius Lieutenant of the Romans, about the yeare of grace 53. The Cornauji were feared vpon the North of Scuerne, and branched into other Counties, of whom we haue ≈øaid.

(6) But when the ≈øtrength of the Romans was too weake to ≈øupport their owne Empire, and Britaine emptied of her Souldiers to re≈øi≈øt, the Saxons ≈øet foot in this mo≈øt faire ≈øoile, and made it a part of their Mercian Kingdome: their line likewi≈øe i≈ø≈øued to the la≈øt period, and the Normans beginning where the≈øe Saxons left, the Wel≈øhmen tooke aduantage of all pre≈øent occa≈øions, and brake ouer Seuerne vnto the Riuer Dee; to recouer which, the Normans fir≈øt Kings often affayed, and Henry the ≈øecond with ≈øuch danger of life, that at the ≈øiege of Bridge-north he had beene ≈ølaine, had not Sir H ‚Ä¢ bert Syncler receiued the arrow aimed at him, in ≈øtepping betwixt that Shaft and his Soueraigne, and therewith was ≈øhot thorow vnto death. In the like danger ≈øtood Henry Prince of Scotland, who in the ≈øtrait ≈øiege of Ludlow, begirt by King Stephen, had beene plucked from his ≈øaddle with an iron hooke from the wall, had not Stephen pre≈øently re≈øcued him, Anno 1139.

(7) This then being the Marches of England and Wales, was ≈øore afflicted by bloudy broiles, which cau≈øed many of their Townes to be ≈øtrongly walled, and thirtie two Ca≈øtles to be ≈øtrongly built: la≈øtly, into this Countie the mo≈øt wi≈øe King Henry the ≈øeauenth ≈øent his elde≈øt ≈øonne Prince Arthur, to be re≈øident at Ludlow, where that faire Ca≈øtle became a mo≈øt famous Princes Court. And here King Henry the eight ordained the Coun≈øell of the Marches, con≈øi≈øting of a Lord Pre≈øident,
as many Coun≈øellers as the Prince ≈øhall plea≈øe, a Secretary, an Atturney, a Soliciter, and foure Iu≈øtices of the Counties in Wales, in who≈øe Court were pleaded the cau≈øes depending and tearmely tried for the mo≈øt part in pre≈øence of that honourable Pre≈øident.

(8) But the Shire-Towne Shrewesburie, for circuit, trade, and wealth, doth farre exceed this, and is inferiour to few of our Cities; her buildings faire, her ≈øtreets many and large, her Citizens rich, her trade for the mo≈øt part in the ≈øtaple commodities of Cloth and Free≈øes; her wals ≈øtrong, and of a large compa≈ø≈øe, extending to ≈øeauenteene hundred pa≈øes about, be≈øides another Bulwarke ranging from the Ca≈øtle, downe vnto, and in part along the ≈øide of Seuerne: thorow which there are three entrances into the Towne, Ea≈øt & We≈øt ouer by two faire ≈øtone-bridges with Towers, Gates, and Barres, and the third into the North, no le≈ø≈øe ≈øtrong then them, ouer which is mounted a large Ca≈øtle, who≈øe gaping chinkes doe doubtle≈ø≈øe threaten her fall. This Towne is gouerned by two Bailiffes, yearely elected out of twentie-foure Burge≈ø≈øes, a Recorder, Towne-Clerke, and Chamberlaine, with three Sergeants at Mace: the Pole being rai≈øed hence from the degrees of Latitude 53. 16. minutes, and from We≈øt in Longitude 17. degrees 27. minutes.

(9) Yea, and ancienter Cities haue beene ≈øet in this Shire: ≈øuch was Roxalter, or Wroxce≈øter, lower vpon Seuerne, that had beene Vricomum the chiefe≈øt Citie of the Cornauij; V≈øoconia, now Okenyate, neere vnto the Wrekin: and vnder Red-Ca≈øtle the ruines of a Citie, whom the vulgar report to haue beene famous in Arthurs dayes: but the peeces of Romi≈øh Coines in the≈øe three doe well a≈ø≈øure vs that therein their Legions lodged; as many other Trenches are ≈øignes of warre and of bloud. But as ≈øwords haue beene ≈øtirring in mo≈øt parts of this Prouince, ≈øo Beads haue beene bid for the pre≈øeruation of the whole, and places erected for the maintenance of Votaries, in whom at that time was imputed great holine≈ø≈øe: in Shrewesbury many, at Cou ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ere, Stowe, Dudley, Bromefeld, Wigmore, Hamond,
Lyle≈øhill, Bildas, Bi≈øhops-ca≈øtle, and Wenloke, (where in the Raigne of Richard the ≈øecond; was likewi≈øe a rich Mine of Copper.) But the ≈øame bla≈øts that blew downe the buds of ≈øuch plants, ≈øcattered al≈øo the fruits from the≈øe faire trees, which neuer ≈øince bare the like, nor is likely any more to doe.

That onely which is rare in this Prouince, is a Well at Pichford in a priuate mans yard, whereupon floteth a thicke skum of liquid Bitumen, which being cleare off to day, will gather the like againe on the morrw: not much vnlike to the Lake in the Land of Iewry.
This Shire is diuided into fifteene Hundreds, wherein are ≈øeated foureteene Market-Townes; and hath in it one hundred and ≈øeauentie Churches for Gods ≈øacred and diuine Seruice.

div.head: The Countie Palatine of CHESTER. CHAPTER XXXVI.
div.p: CHESSE-SHIRE; the Countie Palatine of Che≈øter, is parted vpon the North from Lanca-≈øhire with the Riuer Mercy; vpon the Ea≈øt by Mercey, Goit, and the Dane, is ≈øeparated from Darby and Stafford-≈øhires; vpon the South toucheth the Counties of Shrop-≈øhire and Flint; and vpon the We≈øt with Dee is parted from Denbigh ≈øhire.

(2) The forme of this Countie doth much re≈øemble the right wing of an Eagle, ≈øpreading it ≈øelfe from Wirall, and as it were with her pinion, or fir≈øt feather, toucheth Yorke ≈øhire, betwixt which extreames, in following the windings of the Shires diuder from Ea≈øt to We≈øt, are 47. miles: and from North to South twentie-≈øixe miles. The whole circumference about one hundred fortie two miles.

(3) If the affection to my naturall producer blind not the judgement of this my ≈øuruey, for aire and ≈øoile it equale the be≈øt, and farre exceeds her neighbours the next Counties: for although the Climate be cold, and toucheth the degree of Latitude 54. yet the warmth from the Iri≈øh Seas melteth the Snow, and di≈ø≈øolueth the Ice ≈øooner there then in tho≈øe parts that are further off; and ≈øo whole≈øome for life, that the Inhabitants generally attaine to many yeares.

(4) The Soile is fat, fruitfull, and rich, yeelding abundantly both profit and plea≈øures for man. The Champion grounds make glad the hearts of their Tillers: the Meadowes imbrodered with diuers ≈øweet ≈ømelling flowers; and the Pa≈øture makes the Kines vdders to ≈øtrout to the paile, from whom and wherein the be≈øt Chee≈øe of all Europe is made.

(5) The ancient Inhabitants were the CORNAVII, who with Warwicke-≈øhire, Worce≈øter-≈øhire,
Stafford-≈øhire, and Shrop-≈øhire, ≈øpread them≈øelues further into this Countie, as in Ptolemie is placed; and the Cangi likewi≈øe if they be the Ceangi, who≈øe remembrance was found vpon the ≈øhore of this Shire, on the ≈øurface of certaine pieces of Lead, in this manner in≈øcribed; IMP. DOMIT. AVO. GER. DE CEANG. The≈øe Cangi were ≈øubdued by P. O≈øtorius Seapula, immediately before his great victory again≈øt Caractacus, where, in the mouth of Deua he built a Fortre≈ø≈øe at the backe of the Ordouices, to re≈øtraine their power, which was great in tho≈øe parts, in the raigne of Ve≈øpa≈øian the Emperour. But after the departure of the Romanes, this Prouince became a portion of the Saxon Mercians Kingdome: notwith≈øtanding (≈øaith Ran Higden) the Citie it ≈øelfe was hold by the Britaines vntill all fell into the Monarchy of Egbert.

Of the di≈øpo≈øitions of the ≈øince Inhabitants heare Lucian the Monke (who liued pre≈øently after the Conque≈øt) ≈øpake; They are found (≈øaith he) to differ from the re≈øt of the Engli≈øh, partly better, and partly equall. In fea≈øting they are friendly, at meat chearefull, in entertainement liberall, ≈øoone angry, and ≈øoone pacified, laui≈øh in words, impatient of ≈øeruitude, mercifull to the afflicted, compa≈øsionate to the poore, kinde to their kindred, ≈øpary of labour, void of di≈øimulation, not greedie meating, and far from dangerous practi≈øes.

And let me adde thus much, which Lucian could not; namely, that this Shire hath neuer beene ≈øtained with the blot of rebellion, but euer ≈øtood true to their King and his Crowne: who≈øe loyaltie Richard the ≈øecond ≈øo farre found and e≈øteemed, that he held his per≈øon mo≈øt ≈øafe among them, and by authoritie of Parliament made the Countie to be a Principalitie, and ≈øtiled him≈øelfe Prince of Che≈øter.

King Henry the third gaue it to his elde≈øt ≈øonne Prince Edward, again≈øt whom Lewlyn Prince of Wales gathered a mightie Band, and with them did the Conntie much harme, euen vnto the Cities gates. With the like ≈øcarre-fires it had oft times beene affrighted, which they la≈øtly defenced with
a Wall made of the Wel≈øh-mens heads, on the South ≈øide of Dee in Hanbridge.

The Shire may well be ≈øaid to be a Seed-plot of Gentilitie, and the producer of many mo≈øt ancient and worthy Families: neither hath any brought more men of valour into the Field, then Che≈ø≈øe-≈øhire hath done, who by a generall ≈øpeech, are to this day called The Chiefe of men: and for Natures endowments (be≈øides their noblene≈ø≈øe of mindes) may compare with any other Nation in the world: their limmes ≈øtraight and well-compo≈øed, their complexions faire, with a chearefull countenance; and the Women for grace, feature, and beautie, inferiour vnto none.

(6) The Commodities of this Prouince (by the report of Ranulphus the Monke of Che≈øter) are chiefly Corne, Cattle, Fi≈øh, Fowle, Salt, Mines, Metals, Meares, and Riuers, whereof the bankes of Dee in her We≈øt, and the Vale Royall in her mid≈øt, for fruitfulne≈ø≈øe of pa≈øturage equals any other in the Land, either in graine from the Cow.

(7) The≈øe, with all other proui≈øion for life, are traded thorow thirteene Market-Townes in this Shire, whereof Che≈øter is the faire≈øt, from whom the Shire hath the name. A Citie rai≈øed from the Fort of O≈øtorius, Lieutenant of Britaine for Claudius the Emperour, whither the twentieth Legion (named Victrix) were ≈øent by Galba to re≈øtraine the Britaines: but growne them≈øelues out of order, Iulius Agricola was appointed their Generall by Ve≈øpafian, as appeareth by Monies then minted, and there found; and from them (no doubt) by the Britaines the place was called Caer Legion, by Ptolemie, Deunana; by Antonine, Dena; and now by vs We≈øt-Che≈øter: but Henry Brad≈øhawe will haue it built before Brute, by the Giant Leon Gaue ‚Ä¢ , a man beyond the Moone, and called by Marius the vanqui≈øher of the Picts.

Ouer Deua or Dee a faire ≈øtone-bridge leadeth, built vpon eight Arches, at either end whereof is a Gate, from whence in a long Quadren-wi≈øe the wals do incompa≈ø≈øe the Citie, high and ≈øtrongly built, with foure faire Gates, opening into the foure windes, be≈øides three Po≈øternes, and ≈øeauen
Watch-Towers, extending in compa≈ø≈øe one thou≈øand nine hundred and fortie paces.

On the South of this Citie is mounted a ≈øtrong and ≈øtately Ca≈øtle, round in forme, and the ba≈øe Court likewi≈øe inclo≈øed with a circular wall. In the North is the Mini≈øter, fir≈øt built by Earle Leofrike to the honour of S. Werburga the Virgin, and after mo≈øt ≈øumptuou≈øly repaired by Hugh the fir≈øt Earle of Che≈øter of the Normans, now the Cathedrall of the Bi≈øhops See. Therein lyeth interred (as report doth relate) the body of Henry the fourth, Emperour of Almane, who leauing his Imperiall E≈øtate, lead la≈øtly therein an Hermites life.

This Citie hath formerly beene ≈øore defaced; fir≈øt by Egfrid King of Northumberland, where he ≈ølew twelue hundred Chri≈øtian Monkes, re≈øorted thither from Bangor to pray. Againe by the Danes it was ≈øore defaced, when their de≈øtroying feete had trampled downe the beautie of the Land. But was againe rebuilt by Edelfleada the Mercian Lady, who in this Countie, and Forre≈øt of Delamer, built two fine Cities, nothing of them now remaining, be≈øides the Chamber in the Forre≈øt.

Che≈øter in the dayes of King Edgar was in mo≈øt flouri≈øhing e≈øtate, wherein he had the homage of eight other Kings, who rowed his Barge from S. Iohns to his Pallace, him≈øelfe holding the Helme, as their ≈øupreme.

This Citie was made a County incorporate of it ≈øelfe by King Henry the ≈øeauenth, and is yearely gouerned by a Mator, with Sword and Mace borne before him in State, two Sheriffes, twentiefoure Aldermen, a Recorder, a Towne-Clerke, and a Sergeant of Peace, foure Sergeants, and ≈øixe Yeomen.

It hath beene accounted the Key into Ireland, and great pitie it is that the Port ≈øhould decay as it daily doth, the Sea being ≈øtopped to ≈øcoure the Riuer by a Cau≈øey that thwarteth Dee at her bridge. Within the wals of this Citie are eight Pari≈øh-Churches, S. Iohns the greater and le≈ø≈øer: in the Suburbs are the White Fryers, Blacke-Fryers, and Nunnery now ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, From which Citie the Pole
is eleuated vnto the degree 53. 58. minutes of Latitude, and from the fir≈øt point of the We≈øt in Longitude vnto the 17. degree and 18. minutes.

(8) The Earledome whereof was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed from the Conquerour, till it fell la≈øtly to the Crowne, the la≈øt of whom (though not with the lea≈øt hopes) is Prince Henry, who to the Titles of Prince of Wales, and Duke of Cornwall, hath by Succe≈ø≈øion and right of Inheritance, the Earledome of Che≈øter annexed to his other mo≈øt happy Stiles: Vpon who≈øe per≈øon I pray that the Angels of Iacobs God may euer attend; to his great glory, and Great Britaines happine≈ø≈øe.

(9) If I ≈øhould vrge credit vnto the report of certaine Trees, floating in Bagmere, onely again≈øt the deaths of the Heyres of the Breretons thereby ≈øeated, and after to ≈øinke vntill the next like occa≈øion: or inforce for truth the Prophecie which Leyland in a Poeticall fury fore≈øpake of Bee≈øton Ca≈øtle, highly mounted vpon a ≈øteepe hill: I ≈øhould forget my ≈øelfe and wonted opinion, that can hardly beleeue any ≈øuch vaine predictions, though they be told from the mouthes of credit, as Bagmere Trees are, or learned Leyland for Bee≈øton, who thus writeth:
The day will come when it againe ≈øhall mount his head aloft,
If ‚Ä¢ a Prophet may be heard from Seers that ≈øay ≈øo oft.

With eight other Ca≈øtles this Shire hath beene ≈øtrengthned, which were Ould-Ca≈øtle, Shoclath, Shotwitch, Che≈øter, Poulefourd, Dunham, Fr ‚Ä¢ de≈øham, and Haulten: and by the Prayers (as then was taught) of eight religious hou≈øes therein ≈øeated, pre≈øerued; which by King Henry the eight were ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed: namely, Stanlowe, I ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ree, Maxf ‚Ä¢ ld, Norton, Bunbery, Combermere, Rud-heath, and Vale-Royall, be≈øides the White and Blacke Fryers, and the Nunnery in Che≈øter.
This Counties diui≈øion is into ≈øeauen Hundreds, wherein are ≈øeated thirteene Market-Townes, eightie-≈øixe Pari≈øh-Churches, and thirtie eight Chappels of ea≈øe.

div.head: LANCA-SHIRE. CHAPTER XXXVII.
div.p: THE Countie Palatine of Lanca≈øter (famous for the foure Henries, the fourth, fift, ≈øixt, and ≈øeauenth, Kings of England, deriued from Iohn of Gaunt Duke of Lanca≈øter) is vpon the South confined and parted by the Riuer Mer≈øcy, from the Countie Palatine of Che≈øter; the faire Countie of Darby-≈øhire bordering vpon the Ea≈øt; the large Country of Yorke≈øhire, together with We≈øtmerland and Cumberland, being her kinde neighbours vpon the North, and the Sea called Ma ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Hebernicum embracing her vpon the We≈øt.

(2) The forme thereof is long, for it is ≈øo inclo≈øed betweene Yorke ≈øhire on the Ea≈øt ≈øide, and the Iri≈øh Sea on the We≈øt, that where it boundeth vpon Che≈øhire on the South-≈øide, it is broader, and by little and little more Northward it goeth (confining vpon We≈øtmerland) the more narrow it groweth It containeth in length from Brathey Northward, to Halwood South-ward, fiftie ≈øeauen miles; from Denton in the Ea≈øt, to F ‚Ä¢ rmby by Altmouth in the We≈øt, thirtie one; and the whole circumference in compa≈ø≈øe, one hundred three-≈øcore and ten miles.
(3) The Aire is „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , not troubled with gro≈ø≈øe vapours or foggy mi≈øts, by rea≈øon whereof the „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ long and healthfully, and are not ≈øubiect to ≈øtrange and vnknowne de≈øea≈øes.

(4) The Soile for the generalitie is not very fruitfull, yet it produceth ≈øuch numbers of Cattle, of ≈øuch large proportion, and ≈øuch goodly heads, and hornes, as the whole Kingdome of Spaine doth ≈øcarce the like‚ñ™ It is a Country repleni≈øhed with all nece≈ø≈øaries for the v≈øe of man, yeelding without any great labour, the commoditie of Corne, Flaxe, Gra≈ø≈øe, Coales, and ≈øuch like. The
Sea al≈øo adding her ble≈ø≈øing to the Land, that the people of that Prouince want nothing that ≈øerues either for the ≈øu≈øtenance of nature, or the ≈øafetie of appetite‚ñ™ They are plentifully furni≈øhed with all ≈øorts of Fi≈øh, Fle≈øh, and Fowles. Their principall fuell is Coale and Turffe, which they haue in great abundance, the Gentlemen re≈øeruing their woods very carefully, as a beautie and principall ornament to their Mannors and hou≈øes. And though it be farre from London (the capitall Citie of this Kingdome) yet doth it euery yeare furni≈øh her and many other parts of the Land be≈øides, with many thou≈øands of Cattle (bred in this Country) giuing thereby and otherwayes a firme te≈øtimony to the world, of the ble≈ø≈øed abundance that it hath plea≈øed God to enrich this noble Dukedome withall.

(5) This Counties ancient Inhabitants were the Brigantes, of whom there is more mention in the de≈øcription of Yorke≈øhire, who by Claudius the Emperour were brought vnder the Roman ≈øubiection, that ≈øo held and made it their Seat, ≈øecured by their Garri≈øons, as hath beene gathered as well by many in≈øcriptions found in walles and ancient monuments fixed in ≈øtones, as by certaine Altars erected in fauour of their Emperours. After the Romans, the Saxons brought it vnder their protection, and held it for a part of their Northumbrian Kingdome, till it was fir≈øt made ≈øubiugate to the inua≈øion of the Danes, and then conquered by the victorious Normans, who≈øe po≈øterities from thence are branched further into England.
