(6) Places of antiquitie or memorable note are the≈øe: the Towne of Manche≈øter (≈øo famous, as well for the Market-place, Church, and Colledge, as for the re≈øort vnto it for clothing) was called Mancunium by Antonine the Emperour, and was made a Fort and Station of the Romans.

Ribleche≈øter (which taketh the name from Rhibell, a little Riuer neere Clithero) though it be a ≈ømall Towne, yet by tradition hath beene called the riche≈øt Towne in Chri≈øtendome, and reported to haue beene the Seat of the Romans, which the many Monuments of their Antiquities, Statues, peeces
of Coine, and other ≈øeuerall in≈øcription, digd vp from time to time by the Inhabitants, may giue vs ≈øufficient per≈øwa≈øion to beleeue.

But the Shire-Towne is Lanca≈øter, more plea≈øant in ≈øituation, then rich of Inhabitants, built on the South of the Riuer Lon, and is the ≈øame Longouicum, where (as we finde in the Notice Prouinces) a company of the Longo ‚Ä¢ icarians vnder the Lieutenant Generall of Britaine lay. The beautie of this Towne is in the Church, Ca≈øtle, and Bridge: her ≈øtreets many, and ≈øtretched farre in length. Vnto this Towne King Edward the third granted a Maior and two Bailiffes, which to this day are elected out of twelue Brethren, a≈ø≈øi≈øted by twentie-foure Burge≈ø≈øes, by whom it is yearely gouerned, with the ≈øupply of two Chamberlaines, a Recorder, Towne-Clerke, and two Sergeants at Mace. The eleuation of who ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Pole is in the degree of Latitude 54 and 58. ≈øcruples, and her Longitude remoued from the fir≈øt We≈øt „Äà‚óä„Äâ vnto the degree 17 and 4 ‚Ä¢ . ≈øcruples.

(7) This Country in diuers places ≈øuffereth the force of many flowing Tides of the Sea, by which (after a ≈øort) it doth violently rent a≈øunder one part of the Shire from the other: as in Fourne≈ø≈øe, where the „Äà‚óä„Äâ di≈øplea≈øed that the ≈øhort ≈øhould from thence ≈øhoot a maine way into the We≈øt, hath not ob≈øtinately cea≈øed from time to time to fla≈øh and mangle it, and with his fell irruptions and boy≈øterous Tides to de ‚Ä¢ oure it.

Another thing there is, not vnworthy to be recommended to memory, that in this Shire, not far from Fourne≈ø≈øe Fell ‚Ä¢ s, the greate≈øt ≈øtanding water in all England (called Winander-Mere) lieth, ≈øtretched out for the ≈øpace of ten miles, of wonderfull depth, and all paued with ≈øtone in the bottome: and along the Sea-≈øide in many places may be ≈øeene heapes of ≈øand, vpon which the people powre water, vntill it recouer a „Äà‚óä„Äâ humour, which they afterwards boile with Turffes, till it become white ≈øalt.

(8) This Country, as it is thus on the one ≈øide freed by the naturall re≈øi≈øtance of the Sea from
the force of Inua≈øions, ≈øo is it ≈øtrengthned on the other by many Ca≈øtles and fortified places, that take away the opportunitie of making Roades and Incur≈øions in the Country. And as it was with the fir≈øt that felt the fury of the Saxons crueltie, ≈øo was it the la≈øt and longe≈øt that was ≈øubdued vnder the We≈øt-Saxons Monarchie.

(9) In this Prouince our noble Arthur (who died laden with many trophics of honour) is reported by Ninius to haue put the Saxons to flight in a memorable battle neere Dugla≈ø≈øe, a little Brooke not farre from the Towne of Wiggin. But the attempts of warre, as they are ≈øeuerall, ≈øo they are vncertaine: for they made not Duke Wade happy in his ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, but returned him an vnfortunate vnterpri≈øer in the Battle which he gaue to Arduiph King of Northumberland, at Billangho, in the yeare 798 So were the euents vncertaine in the Ciuill Warres of Yorke and Lanca≈øter: for by them was bred and brought forth that bloudy diui≈øion and fatall ≈øtrife of the Noble Hou≈øes, that with variable ≈øucce≈ø≈øe to both parties (for many yeares together) mole≈øted the peace and quiet of the Land, and defiled the earth with bloud, in ≈øuch violent manner, that it exceeded the horrour of tho≈øe Ciuill Warres in Rome, that were betwixt Mariu ‚Ä¢
and Scylla, Pompey and Cae≈øar, Octauius and Antony; or that of the two renowned Hou≈øes Valoys and Eurbon, that a long time troubled the State of France: for in the diui≈øion of the≈øe two Princely Families there were thirteene Fields ≈øought, and three Kings of England, one Prince of Wales, twelue Dukes, one Marques, eighteene Earles, one Vicount, and three and twentie Barons, be≈øides Knights and Gentlemen, lo≈øt their liues in the ≈øame. Yet at la≈øt, by the happy marriage of Henry the ≈øeauenth, King of England, next heire to the Hou≈øe of Lanca≈øter, with Elizabeth daughter and heire to Edward the Fourth, of the Hou≈øe of Yorke, the white and red Ro≈øes were conioyned, in the happy vniting of tho≈øe two diuided Families, from whence our thrice renowned Soueraigne Lord King Iames, by faire ≈øequence and ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, doth worthily enioy the Di ‚Ä¢
deme: by the benefit of who≈øe happy gouernment, this Countie Palatine of Lanca≈øter is pro≈øperous in her Name and Greatne≈ø≈øe.

(10) I finde the remembrance of foure religious hou≈øes that haue beene founded within this Countie (and ≈øince ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed) both faire for ≈øtructure and building, and rich for ≈øeat and ≈øituation ‚Ä¢
namely, Bur≈øtogh, Whalleia, Holland, and Penwortham‚ñ™ It is diuided into ≈øixe Hundreds, be≈øides Fourne≈ø≈øe Felles and Lanca≈øters Liberties, that lie in the North part. It is beautified with 15 Market-Townes, both faire for ≈øituation and building, and famous for the concour≈øe of people for buying and ≈øelling. It hath twentie-≈øixe Pari≈øhes, be≈øides Chappels, (in which they duly frequent to diuine Seruice) and tho≈øe populous, as in no part of the Land more.

div.head: YORKE-SHIRE. CHAPTER XXXVIII.
div.p: AS the cour≈øes and confluents of great Riuers are for the mo≈øt part fre≈øh in memory, though their heads and fountaines lie commonly vnknowne: ≈øo the latter knowledge of great Regions, are not traduced to obliuion, though perhaps their fir≈øt originals be ob≈øcure, by rea≈øon of Antiquitie, and the many reuolutions of times and ages‚ñ™ In the delineation therefore of this great Prouince of York≈øhire, I will not in≈øi≈øt vpon the narration of matters neere vnto vs; but ≈øuccinctly run ouer ≈øuch as are more remote; yet neither ≈øo ≈øparingly, as I may ≈øeeme to dimini≈øh from the dignitie of ≈øo worthy a Country; nor ≈øo prodigally, as to ≈øpend time in the ≈øuperfluous prai≈øing of that which neuer any (as yet) di≈øprai≈øed. And although perhaps it may ≈øeeme a labour vnnece≈ø≈øary, to make relation of ancient remembrances, either of the Name or Nature of this Nation, e≈øpecially looking into the difference of Time it ≈øelfe (which in euery age bringeth forth diuer≈øe effects) and the di≈øpo≈øitions of men, that for the mo≈øt part take le≈ø≈øe plea≈øure in them, then in divulging the occurrents of their owne times: yet I hold it not vnfit to begin there, from whence the fir≈øt certaine direction is giuen to proceede; for (euen of the≈øe ancient things) there may be good v≈øe made, eitherby imitation, or way of compari≈øon, as neither the repetition, nor the repetition thereof ≈øhall be accounted impertinent.

(2) You ≈øhall therefore vnder≈øtand: That the Countie of Yorke was in the Saxon tongue called Ebona-yeyne, and now commonly Yorke≈øhire, farre greater and more numerous in the Circuit of her miles, then any Shire of England. Shee is much bound to the ≈øingular loue and motherly ca ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ of Nature, in placing her vnder ≈øo temperate a clime, that in euery mea≈øure ≈øhe is „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ .
If one part of her be ≈øtony, and a ≈øandy barren ground: another is fertile and richly adorned with Corne-fields. If you here finde it naked, and de≈øtitute of Woods, you ≈øhall ≈øee it there ≈øhadowed with Forre≈øts full of trees, that haue very thicke „Äà‚óä„Äâ , ≈øending forth many fruitfull and profitable branches. If one place of it be Moori≈øh, Mirie, and vnplea≈øant; another makes a free tender of delight, and pre≈øents it ≈øelfe to the eye, full of beautie and contentiue varietie.

(3) The Bi≈øhopricke of Durham fronts her on the North-≈øide, and is ≈øeperated by a continued cour≈øe of the Riuer Tees The Germaine Sea lieth ≈øore vpon her Ba≈øt ≈øide, beating the ≈øhores with her boi≈øterous waues and billowes. The We≈øt part is bounded with Lanca≈øhire, and We≈øtmerland. The South-≈øide hath Che≈øhire and Darbi≈øhire (friendly Neighbours vnto her) with the which ≈øhe is fir≈øt inclo≈øed: then with Nottingham and with Lincolne-≈øhires: after diuided with that famous Arme of the Sea Humber: Into which all the Riuers that water this Country, emptie them≈øelues, and pay their ordinary Tributes, as into the common receptacle and ≈øtore-hou≈øe of Neptune, for all the watery Pen≈øions of this Prouince.

(4) This whole Shire (being of it ≈øelfe ≈øo ≈øpatious) for the more ea≈øie and better ordering of her ciuill gouernment, is diuided into three parts: which according to three quarters of the world, are called The We≈øt-Riding, The Ea≈øt-Riding, and The North-Riding. We≈øt-Riding is for a good ≈øpace compa≈ø≈øed with the Riuer Ou≈øe, with the bounds of Lanca≈øhire, and with the South limits of the Shire, and beareth towards the We≈øt and South. Ea≈øt-Riding bends it ≈øelfe to the Ocean, with the which, and with the Riuer Derment ≈øhe is inclo≈øed, and lookes into that part where the Sunne ri≈øing, and ≈øhewing forth his beames, makes the world both glad and glorious in his brightne≈ø≈øe North-Riding extends it ≈øelfe Northward,
„Äà‚óä„Äâ in as it were, with the Riuer Tees and Derwent, and a long race of the Riuer Ou≈øe The length of this Shire, extended from Ha ‚Ä¢ thill in the South, to the mouth of Tees in the North, are neere vnto ≈øeauentie miles, the breadth from Flambrough-head to Horn-ca≈øtle vpon the
Riuer „Äà‚óä„Äâ , is foure≈øcore miles; the whole Circumference is three hundred and eight miles.

(5) The Soile of this County for the generalitie is rea≈øonable fertile, and yeelds ≈øufficiency of Corne and Cattle within it ≈øelfe. One part whereof is particularly made famous by a „Äà‚óä„Äâ of Stone, out of which the ≈øtones newly hewen be very ≈øoft, but ≈øea≈øoned with winde and „Äà‚óä„Äâ of them≈øelues doe naturally become exceeding hard and ≈øolide. Another, by a kind of „Äà‚óä„Äâ whereof it con≈øi≈øteth, which being burnt, and conueyed into the other parts of the Country, which are hilly and ≈øome what cold, ≈øerue to manure and enrich their Corne-fields.

(6) That the Romans flouri≈øhing in military prowe≈ø≈øe, made their ≈øeuerall ≈øtations in this Country, is made manife≈øt by their Monuments, by many In≈øcriptions fa≈øtned in the Walles of Churches, by many Columnes engrauen with Roman work ‚Ä¢ found lying in Church-yards, by many „Äà‚óä„Äâ Altars digd vp that were erected (as it ≈øhould ≈øeeme) to their Tutelar Gods (for they had locall and peculiar Topicke Gods, whom they honoured as Keepers and Guardians of ≈øome particular places of the Country) as al≈øo by a kinde of Brickes which they v≈øed: for the Romans in time of peace, to auoid and with≈øtand idlene≈ø≈øe, (as an enemy to vertuous and valorous enterpri≈øes) ≈øtill exerci≈øed their Legions and Cohorts in ca≈øting of ditches, making of High-wayes, building of Bridges, and making of Brickes, which hauing ≈øithence bin found, and from time to time digd out of the ground, proue the Antiquitie of the place by the Romane In≈øcriptions vpon them.

(7) No le≈ø≈øe argument of the pietie hereof, are the many Mona≈øteries, Abbyes and Religious hou≈øes that haue beene placed in this Country; which while≈øt they retained their owne ≈øtate and magnificence, were great ornaments vnto it: but ≈øince their di≈ø≈øolution, and that the teeth of Time (which deuours all things) haue eaten into them, they are become like dead carka≈ø≈øes, leauing onely ≈øome poore ruines and remaines aliue, as reliques to po≈øteritie, to ≈øhew of what beautie and magnitude they haue beene. Such was the Abbey of Whi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y, founded by Lady Hilda, daughter of the
grand-childe vnto King Edwine. Such was the Abbey built by Bolcon, which is now ≈øo razed and laid Ieuell with the earth, as that at this time it affords no appearance of the former dignitie. Such was Kirk≈øtall Abbey, of no ≈ømall account in time pa≈øt, founded in the yeare of Chri≈øt 1147. Such was the renowned Abbey called S. Maries in Yorke, built and endowed with rich liuings by Alan the third Earle of little Britaine in America; but ≈øince conuerted into the Princes hou≈øe, and is called The Mannour. Such the wealthy Abbey of Fountaines, built by T ‚Ä¢ ur≈øtin Arch bi≈øhop of Yorke Such was the famous Mona≈øtery founded in the Primitiue Church of the Ea≈øt-Saxons, by Wilfrid Arch-bi≈øhop of Yorke, and enlarged (being fallen downe and decayed) by Odo Arch-bi≈øhop of Canterbury. Such was Drax, a religious hou≈øe of Chanons. Such that faire Abbey built by King William the Conquerour at Silby (where his Sonne Henry the fir≈øt was borne) in memory of Saint German, who happily confuted that contagious Pelagian Here≈øie, which oftentimes grew to Serpentine head in Britaine.

The≈øe places for Religion erected, with many more within this Prouinciall Circuit, and con≈øecrated vnto holy purpo≈øes, ≈øhew the antiquitie, and how they haue beene ≈øought vnto by confluences of Pilgrimes in their manner of deuotions: The mid≈øt of which ≈øuper≈øtitious ob≈øcurities, are ≈øince cleared by the pure light of the Go≈øpell reuealed, and the skirts of Idolatry vnfolded to her owne ≈øhame and ignominie: And they made ≈øubiect to the di≈ø≈øolution of Times, ≈øeruing onely as antique Monuments and remembrances to the memory of ≈øucceeding Ages.

(8) Many places of this Prouince are famou≈øed as well by Name, being naturally fortunate in their ≈øituation, as for ≈øome other accidentall happine≈ø≈øe befallen vnto them. Hallifax, famous, as well for that Iohannes defacro Be≈øco, Author of the Sphere, was borne there, and for the Law it hath again≈øt ≈øtealing, and for the greatne≈ø≈øe of the Pari≈øh, which reckoneth in it eleuen Chappels, whereof two be Pari≈øh-Chappels, and in them to the number of twelue thou≈øand people.

In former times it was called Horton, and touching the alteration of the name, this prety ≈øtory is
related of it: namely, That a Clerke (for ≈øo they call him) being farre in loue with a maid, and by no meanes either of long pray≈øes or large promi≈øes, able to gaine like affection at her hands, when he ≈øaw his hopes fru≈øtrate, and that he was not like to haue his purpo≈øe of her, turned his loue into rage, and cut off the maides head, which being afterwards hung vpon an Ewe tree, common people counted it as an hallowed relique till it was rotten: And afterwards (≈øuch was the credulitie of that time) it maintained the opinion of reuerence and Religion ≈øtill: for the people re≈øorted thither on pilgrimage, and per≈øwaded them≈øelues, that the little veynes that ≈øpread out betweene the Barke and Body of the Ewe tree like fine threds, were the very haires of the maids head. Hereupon it was called by this name Haligfax, or Haly-fax, that is, Holy-Hayre.

Pomfret is famous for the Site, as being ≈øeated in a place ≈øo plea≈øant, that it brings forth Liquori ‚Ä¢ e and great plentie of Skiriworts, but it is infamous for the murther and bloud≈øhed of Princes: The Ca≈øtle whereof was built by Hildebert Lacy, a Norman, to whom William the Conquerour gaue this Towne, after Alrick the Saxon was thru≈øt out of it.

(9) But I will forbeare to be prolixe or tedious in the particular memoration of places in a Prouince ≈øo ≈øpatious, and onely make a compendious relation of Yorke, the ≈øecond Citie of England, in Latine called Eboracum and Eburacum, by Ptolemy, Brigantium (the chiefe Citie of the Brigants) by Ninius, Caer Ebrauc, by the Britaines, Caer Effro ‚Ä¢ . The Briti≈øh Hi≈øtory reports that it tooke the name of Ebrauc that founded it; but ≈øome others are of opinion, that Eburacum hath no other deriuation then from the Riuer Ou≈øe running thorow it: It ouer-ma≈øters all the other places of this Country for fairene≈ø≈øe, and is a ≈øingular ornament & ≈øafegard to all the North parts. A plea≈øant place, large, and full of magnificence, rich, populous, and not onely ≈øtrengthened with fortifications, but adorned with beautifull buildings, as well priuate as publike. For the greater dignitie thereof it was made an Epi≈øcopall See by Con≈øtantius, and a Metropolitane Citie by a Pall ≈øent vnto it from Homorius.
Egbert Arch-bi≈øhop of Yorke, who flouri≈øhed about the yeare ≈øeauen hundred fortie, erected in it a mo≈øt famous Library. Richard the third repaired the Ca≈øtle thereof being ruinous, and King Henry the eight appointed a Coun≈øell in the ≈øame, to decide and determine all the cau≈øes and Controuer≈øies of the North parts, according to equitie and con≈øcience: which Coun≈øell con≈øi≈øteth of a Lord Pre≈øident, certaine Coun≈øellers at the Princes plea≈øure, a Secretarie, and other Vnder-Officers.

The originall of this Citie cannot be fetcht out but from the romanes, ≈øeeing the Britaines before the Romanes came, had no other Townes then Woods fenced with Trenches and Rampiers, as Cae≈øar and Strabo doe te≈øtifie. And that it was a Colony of the Romanes, appeares both by the authoritie of Ptolemy and Antonine, and by many ancient In≈øcriptions that haue beene found there. In this Citie the Emperour Seuerus had his Palace, and here gaue vp his la≈øt breath; which mini≈øters occa≈øion to ≈øhew the ancient cu≈øtome of the Romanes, in the military manner of their burials.

His body was caried forth here by the Souldiers to the Funerall fire, and committed to the flames, honoured with the Iu≈øts and Turnaments both of the Souldiers and of his owne ≈øonnes: His a≈øhes be≈øtowed in a little golden pot or ve≈ø≈øel of the Prophyrat ≈øtone, were carryed to Rome, and ≈øhrined there in the monument of the Antoni ‚Ä¢ s. In this Citie (as Spartian ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s maketh mention) was the Temple of the Godde≈ø≈øe Bellona; to which Seuerus (being come thither purpo≈øing to offer ≈øacrifice) was erroneou≈øly led by a ru≈øticall Augur.

Here Fl Velerius Con≈øtantinus, ≈øurnamed Chlorus (an Emperour of excellent vertue and Chri≈øtian pietie) ended his life, and was Defied as appeares by ancient Coines: and his ≈øonne Con≈øtantine being pre≈øent at his Fathers death, forthwith proclaimed Emperour; from whence it may be gathered of what great e≈øtimation Yorke was in tho≈øe dayes, when the Romane Emperours Court was held in it. This Citie flouri≈øhed a long time vnder the Engli≈øh-Saxons Dominion, till the Danes like a mightie ≈øtorme, thundring from out the North-Ea≈øt, de≈øtroyed it, and di≈øtained it with the bloud of many
≈ølaughtered per≈øons, and wan it from O≈øbright and Flla Kings of Northumberland, who were both ≈ølaine in their pur≈øuite of the Danes: which Alcuine in his Epi≈øtle to Egelred King of Northumberland, ≈øeemed to pre ‚Ä¢ age before, when he ≈øaid; What ≈øignifieth that raining downe of bloud in S. Peters Church of Yorke, euen in a faire day, and de≈øcending in ≈øo violent and threatning a manner from the top of the roofe? may it not be thought that bloud is comming vpon the Land from the North parts?

Howbeit, At ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ ≈øtane recouered it from the Dani≈øh ≈øubiection, and quite ouerthrew the Ca≈øtle, with the which they had fortified it; yet was it not (for all this) ≈øo freed from warres, but that it was ≈øubiect to the Times fatally next following. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe, in the Conquerours time when (after many woefull ouerthrowes and trouble≈øome ≈øtormes) it had a pleasant calme of en≈øuing peace, it ro≈øe againe of it ≈øelfe, and flouri≈øhed afre≈øh, hauing ≈øtill the helping hand both of Nobility and Gentry, to recouer the former dignitie, and bring it to the perfection it hath: The Citizens fenced it round with new wals, and many towers and bulwarkes, and ordaining good and whole≈øome lawes for the gouernment of the ≈øame. Which at this day are executed at the command of a Lord Maior, who hath the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of twelue Aldermen, many Chamberlaines, a Recorder, a Towne-Clerke, ≈øixe Sergeants at Mace, and two E≈øquires, which are, a Sword-bearer, and the Common Sergeant, who with a great Mace goeth on the left hand of the Sword. The Longitude of this Citie, according to Mercators account, is 19. degrees, and 35. ≈øcruples: the Latitude 54. degrees and fortie ≈øcruples.

(10) Many occurrents pre≈øent them≈øelues with ≈øufficient matter of enlargement to this di≈øcour≈øe, yet none of more worthy con≈øequence then were tho≈øe ≈øeuerall Battles, fought within the compa≈ø≈øe of this Countie; wherein Fortune had her plea≈øure as well as in the proofe of her loue, as in the pur≈øuit of her tyranny; ≈øometime ≈øending the fruits of ≈øweet peace vnto her, and otherwhiles ≈øuffering her to ta≈øte the ≈øowrene≈ø≈øe of warre.

At Coni≈øhorough (in the Britaine tongue C ‚Ä¢ aer Conan) was a great battle fought by Hengi≈øt, Captaine of the Engli≈øh-Saxons, after he had retyred him≈øelfe thither for his ≈øafetie, his men being fled and ≈øcattered, and him≈øelfe di≈øcom≈øited by A ‚Ä¢ relius Ambro≈øius; yet within few dayes after he brought forth his men to battell again≈øt the Britaines that pur≈øued him, where the field was bloudy both to him and his; for many of his men were cut in pieces, and he him≈øelfe had his head chopt off, as the Briti≈øh Hi≈øtory ≈øaith; which the Chronicles of the Engli≈øh-Saxons deny, reporting that he dyed in peace, being ≈øurcharged and ouer-worne with the trouble≈øome toyles and trauels of warre.

Neere vnto Kirk≈øtall, O≈øwie King of Northumberland put Penda the Mercian to flight: the place wherein the Battle was ioyned, the Writers call Winwid Field, giuing it the name by the victory. And the little Region about it (in times pa≈øt called by an old name Elmet) was conquered by Eadwin King of Northumberland, the ≈øonne of Aela, after he had expelled Cereticus a Briti≈øh King, in the yeare of Chri≈øt, 620.

At Ca≈øterford (called by Antonine Legeolium and Legetium) the Citizens of Yorke ≈ølew many of King Ethelreds Army, and had a great hand again≈øt him, in ≈øo much as he that before ≈øtate in his throne of Maie≈øtie, was on a ≈øodaine daunted, and ready to offer ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion.

But the mo≈øt worthy of memory, was that Field fought on Pal ‚Ä¢ -Sunday, 1461. in the quarrell of Lanca≈øter and Yorke, where England neuer ≈øaw more pui≈ø≈øant Forces both of Gentry and Nobilitie: for there were in the field at one time (partakers on both ≈øides) to the number of one hundred thou≈øand fighting men. When the fight had continued doubtfull a great part of the day, the Lanca≈øtrians not able longer to abide the violence of their enemies, turned backe and fled amaine, and ≈øuch as took part with Yorke, followed them ≈øo hotly in cha≈øe, and kild ≈øuch a number of Noble and Gentlemen, that thirtie thou≈øand Engli≈øhmen were that day left dead in the field.

(11) Let vs now loo≈øe the point of this compa≈ø≈øe, and ≈øaile into ≈øome other parts of this Prouince,
to finde out matter of other memorable moment‚ñ™ Vnder Knan≈øbrough there is a Well called D ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
ping-well, in which the waters ≈øpring not out of the veynes of the earth, but di≈øtill and trickle downe from the rockes that hang ouer it: It is of this vertue and efficacie, that it turnes wood into ≈øtone: for what wood ≈øoeuer is put into it, will be ≈øhortly couered ouer with a ≈øtony barke, and be turned into ≈øtone, as hath beene often ob≈øerued.

At Giggle≈øwicke al≈øo about a mile from Settle (a Market-Towne) there are certaine ≈ømall ≈øprings not di≈øtant a quaits ca≈øt from one another: the middlemo≈øt of which doth at euery quarter of an houre ebbe and flow about the height of a quarter of a yard when it is highe≈øt, and at the ebbe falleth ≈øo low, that it is not an inch deepe with water. Of no le≈ø≈øe worthine≈ø≈øe to be remembred is S. Wilfrids Needle, a place very famous in times pa≈øt for the narrow hole in the clo≈øe vaulted roome vnder the ground, by which womens hone≈øties were wont to be tryed: for ≈øuch as were cha≈øte pa≈ø≈øe through with much facilitie; but as many as had plaid fal≈øe, were miraculou≈øly held fa≈øt, and could not creepe through. Beleeue if you li≈øt.

The credible report of a Lampe found burning (euen in our Fathers remembrance, when Abbeyes were pulled downe and ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed) in the Sepulchre of con≈øtantius, within a certaine vault or little Chappell vnder the ground, wherein he was ≈øuppo≈øed to haue beene buried, might beget much wonder and admiration, but that L. Zius confirmeth that in ancient times they had a cu≈øtome to pre≈øerue light in Sepulchres, by an artificiall re≈øoluing of gold into a liquid and farry ≈øub≈øtance, which ≈øhould continue bruning a long time, and for many ages together.

(12) This Yorke≈øhire picture I will draw to no more length, lea≈øt I be condemned with the Sophi≈øter, for in≈øi≈øting in the prai≈øe of Hercules, when no man oppo≈øed him≈øelfe in his di≈øcommendation. This Country of it ≈øelfe is ≈øo beautifull in her owne naturall colours, that (without much helpe) ≈øhe pre≈øents delightfull varieties both to the fight and other ≈øen≈øes.

div.head: THE BISHOPRICKE OF DURHAM. CHAPTER XXXIX.
div.p:
THe Bi≈øhopricke of Durham, containeth tho≈øe parts and Towne-≈øhips that „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ the Reuer Tees and Derwent, and all along the German-Sea
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ on the North wit ‚Ä¢
Northumberland, and their Iuri≈ødictions parted by the „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ touched by Cumberland, We≈øtmorland, and from „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Riuer Tees, and by the ≈øame water on her South, from Yorke-≈øhire
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
By the German-Sea.

(2) The forme thereof is triangle, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ for from her South „Äà‚óä„Äâ vnto the We≈øt-point, are about thirtie miles, from thence to the North-ea≈øt and „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ are likewi≈øe as many, and her ba≈øe along the Sea-≈øhore are twentie- „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Circumference, about one hundred and three miles.

(3) The ayre is ≈øharpe and very piercing, and would be more, „Äà‚óä„Äâ not that the „Äà‚óä„Äâ from the German-Seas did helpe much to di≈ø≈øolue „Äà‚óä„Äâ and ≈ønow: and the ≈øtore of coales therein growing and gotten, doe warme the body, and keepe backe the cold; which „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ be≈øides their owne v≈øe, doth yeeld great commodities vnto this Prouince, by trade thereof „Äà‚óä„Äâ other parts.

(4) For Soile, it con≈øi≈øteth much alike of Pa≈øtures, „Äà‚óä„Äâ , and „Äà‚óä„Äâ grounds: the Ea≈øt is the riche≈øt and mo≈øt champion, the South more moori≈øh, but „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ without either gra≈ø≈øe or graine, notwith≈øtanding „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ with as great gaine, both in rearing vp Cattle, and „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
groweth ≈øo neere to the vpper „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ wheeles doe turne
vp the ≈øame. Some hold their ≈øub≈øtance to be a clammie kinde of clay hardned with heat abounding in the earth, and ≈øo becomming concocted, is nothing el≈øe but Bitumen: for proofe whereof, the≈øe Coales haue both the like ≈ømell and operation of Bitumen: for being ≈øprinkled with water, they burne more vehemently, but with oyle are quite extingui≈øhed and put out.

(5) The ancient Inhabitants knowne vnto Ptolemie, were the Brigantes, of whom we haue ≈øpoken in the Generall of Yorke≈øhire, they being ≈øubdued by the romans; after whom the Saxons made it a part of their Northumberlands Kingdom; at fir≈øt a Prouince belonging to the Deirians, and enioyed by Ella their fir≈øt King; afterwards inuaded by the Danes, and la≈øtly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Normans: who≈øe ≈øite being ≈øo neere vnto Scotland, hath many times felt their fury, and hath beene as a Buckler betwixt them and the Engli≈øh; for which cau≈øe, the Inhabitants haue certaine freedomes, and are not charged with ≈øeruice as other Counties are, ≈øo that this with We≈øtmorland, Cumberland, and Northumberland, are not diuided into hundreds in tho≈øe Parliament Rolles whence I had the re≈øt: which want I mu≈øt leaue for others to ≈øupply.

(6) Ouer this Countie, the Bi≈øhops thereof haue had the Royalties of Princes, and the Inhabitants haue pleaded priuiledge not to pa≈ø≈øe in ≈øeruice of warre ouer the Riuer of Tees or Tyne; who≈øe charge (as they haue alledged) was to keepe and defend the corps of S Cuthbert their great adored Saint, and therefore they termed them≈øelues, The holy-werk-folkes. And the repute of this Cuthbert and his ≈øuppo≈øed defence again≈øt the Scots was ≈øuch, that our Engli≈øh Kings in great deuotion haue gone in pilgrimage to vi≈øit his Tombe, and haue giuen many large po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions to his Church: ≈øuch were King Egfred, Aelfred, and Guthrun the Dane, Edward and Athel≈øtan Monarch of England, and zealous Cannte, the greate≈øt of all, who came thither bare-footed, and at Cuthberts Tombe both augmented and confirmed their Liberties. This Saint then, of nothing made Durham become great, and William the Conquerour, of a Bi≈øhopricke made it a County Palatine: at that time William Careleph,
Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe, pulled downe the old Church which Aldwin had built, and with ≈øumptuous co≈øt laid the foundations of a new, wherein S. Cuthberts Shrine in the vacancy of the Bi≈øhops, was the Keeper of the Ca≈øtle-keyes.

In the We≈øt of this Church, and place called Gallile, the Marble Tombe of venerable Beda remaineth, who was borne at Iaerro in this Countie, and became a Monke at Weremouth, who≈øe painefull indu≈øt ‚Ä¢ es and light of learning in tho≈øe times of darkne≈ø≈øe are wonderfull, as the volumes which he wrote doe well declare. And had the idle Monkes of England imployed their times after his example, their Founders expectations had not beene fru≈øtrate, nor tho≈øe foundations ≈øo ea≈øily ouerturned. But the reuenge of ≈øinne euer following the actions of ≈øinnes, di≈ø≈øolued fir≈øt the largene≈ø≈øe of this Counties liberties, vnder the raigne of King Edward the Fir≈øt, and ≈øince hath ≈øhaken to peices tho≈øe places herein erected, vnder the raigne of King Henry the eight: ≈øuch were Durham, Sherborne, Stayndr ‚Ä¢ p, Iarro, ‚Ä¢ eremouth, and Egleton; all which felt the reward of their idlene≈ø≈øe, and wrath of him that is jealous of his owne honour.

(7) Things of rare note ob≈øerued in this Shire are three pits of a wonderfull depth, commonly called the Hell-Kettles, which are adioyning neere vnto Darlington, who≈øe waters are ≈øome what warme. The≈øe are thought to come of an Earth-quake, which happened in the yeare of Grace 1179. whereof the Chrenicle of Tin-mouth maketh mention, who≈øe record is this: On Chri≈øtmas day, at Oxe ‚Ä¢ hall in the Territorie of Darlington, within the Bi≈øhopricke of Durham, the ground heaued vp aloft, like vnto an high Tower „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ all that day, as it were vnmoueable, vntill the euening; „Äà‚óä„Äâ then fell with ≈øo horrible a noi≈øe, that it made all the neighbour dwellers ≈øore afraid: and the earth ≈øwallowed it vp, and made in the ≈øame place a deepe pit, which is there to be ≈øeene for a te≈øtimonie vnto this day.

(8) Of no le≈ø≈øe admiration are certaine ≈øtones lying within the Riuer Weere, at Butterbre neere Durham; from who≈øe ≈øides at the Ebbe and low water in the Summer, i≈ø≈øueth a certaine ≈øalt reddi≈øh
water, which with the Sunne waxeth white, and growing into a thicke ≈øub≈øtance, becommeth a nece≈ø≈øary ≈øal ‚Ä¢ to the v≈øe of the by-dwellers.

(9) And places of elder times had in a ‚Ä¢ rount by the Romans, were Benonium, now Binche≈øter, and C ‚Ä¢ ndereum, Che≈øter in the ≈øtreet, where their monies haue beene digged vp, and at Codercu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
≈øo much, that Egelrik Bi≈øhop of Durham was therewith made exceeding rich.
This County hath beene ≈øtrengthned with ≈øeauen ≈øtrong Ca≈øtles, is yet traded with ≈øixe Market-Townes, and Gods diuine honour in one hundred and eighteene Pari≈øh-Churches celebrated.

div.head: VVESTMORLAND: CHAPTER XL.
div.p: VVESTMORLAND, by ≈øome late Latine Writers is c ‚Ä¢ lled We≈øtmaria, and We≈øtmorlandia, by ≈øome later We≈øtmoria, and in our Engli≈øh Tongue We≈øtmorland It came to be thus named in our language by the ≈øituation, which in euery part is ≈øo plenteou≈øly full of Moores and high hils, teaching one to another, that We≈øtmorland (with vs) is nothing el≈øe but a We≈øterne moori≈øh Country. Hauing on the We≈øt and North-≈øide Cumberland, on the South-part Lanca-≈øhire, on the Ea≈øt-≈øide Yorke≈øhire, and the Bi≈øhopricke of Durham.

(2) The length thereof extended from Burton in her South, to Kirkland in her North-part is 30. miles: the broade≈øt part from Ea≈øt to We≈øt, is from the Riuer Eden to Dunbal ra≈øe-≈øtones, containing 24. miles, the whole circumference about 112. miles.

(3) The forme thereof is ≈øomewhat long and narrow: the Aire ≈øharpe and piercing, purging it ≈øelfe from the trouble of gro≈ø≈øe foggy mi≈øts and vapours, by rea≈øon of which the people of this Prouince are not acquainted with ≈øtrange di≈øea≈øes or imperfections of body, but liue long, and are healthfull, and attaine to the number of many yeares.

(4) The Soile for the mo≈øt part of it, is but barren, and can hardly be brought to any fruitfulne≈ø≈øe by the indu≈øtry and painfull labour of the husbandman, being ≈øo full of infertile places, which the Northern Engli≈øhmen call Moores: yet the more Southerly part is not reported to be ≈øo ≈øterile, but more fruitfull in the vallies, though contained in a narrow roome, betweene the Riuer Lone, and W ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ander mear, and it is all termed by one name. The Barony of Kendale or Candale, that is, the dale by Can, taking the name of the Riuer Can that runs through it.
(5) The ancient Inhabitants of this Country were the Brigantes, mentioned in the ≈øeuerall Counties of Yorke, Lanca≈øter, and Cumberland.

(6) It is not commended either for plentie of Corne or Cattle, being neither ≈øtored with arable grounds to bring forth the one, nor pa≈øturage to breed vp the other: the principall profit that the people of this Prouince rai≈øe vnto them≈øelues, is by cloathing.

(7) The chiefe≈øt place of which is Kandale or Kendale, called al≈øo Kirkeby Kendale, ≈øtanding on the banke of the Riuer Can. This Towne is of great trade and re≈øort, and for the diligent and indu≈øtrious practi≈øe of making cloath ≈øo excels the re≈øt, that in regard thereof it carrieth a ≈øupereminent name aboue them, and hath great vent & tra≈øhque for her wollen cloaths through all the parts of England. It challengeth not much glory for Antiquitie; onely this it accounteth a great credit, that it hath dignified three Earles with the title thereof, as Iohn Duke of Bedford, whom Henry the Fift (being his brother) aduanced to that honour, Iohn Duke of Sommer≈øet, and Iohn de Foix, whom King Henry the ≈øixt preferred to that dignitie for his honourable and tru≈øty ≈øeruices done in the French warres. It is a place of very ciuill and orderly gouernment, the which is mannaged by an Alderman, cho≈øen euery yeare out of his twelue Brethren, who are all di≈øtingui≈øhed and notified from the re≈øt by the wearing of purple garments The Alderman and his Senior Brother are alwayes Iu≈øtices of Peace and Quorum. There are in it a Towne-Clerke, a Recorder, two Sergeants at Mace, and two Chamberlaines. By Mathematicall ob≈øeruation the ≈øite of this Towne is in the degree of Longitude 17. 30. ≈øcruples, from the fir≈øt We≈øt point, and the Pole eleuated in Latitude to the degree 55. and 15. minutes

(8) Places of memorable note for Antiquitie are Vertera, mentioned by Antonine the Emperour; and Aballaba, which we contractly call Apelby. In the one, the Northerne Engli≈øh con≈øpired again≈øt William the Conquerour in the beginning of the Norman gouernment. In the other, the A ‚Ä¢ rel ‚Ä¢
an
Maures kept a ≈øtation in the time of the Romanes, and their high ≈øtreete is yet apparently to be ≈øeene by the ridges thereof which lead by Apelby to a place called Brouonacum, mentioned in the Booke of Prouinciall notices. The antique pieces of Romane Coyne other whiles digd vp hereabouts, and ≈øome In≈øcriptions not long ≈øince found, ≈øhew of what continuance they haue beene: although Time, which deuouteth all things, hath ≈øo fed vpon their carka≈ø≈øes many ages together, as it hath almo≈øt con≈øumed both hou≈øes and Inhabitants. For Apelby now is bare both of people and building; and were it not for the antiquitie that makes it the more e≈øteemable, in who≈øe Ca≈øtle the A≈ø≈øi≈øes are commonly kept, it would be little better in account then a village Verterae is long ≈øince decayed, and the name of it changed into Burgh: for it is commonly named Burgh vnder Sta ‚Ä¢ emore. In which, it is ≈øaid, a Romane Captaine made his abode with a band of Directores, in the declining age of the Romane Empire. The≈øe two places William of Newborough calleth Princely Holds, and writeth that William King of Scots a little before he him≈øelfe was taken pri≈øoner at Alnewicke, ≈øurprized them on a ≈øodaine, but King Iohn recouered them after, and liberally be≈øtowed them vpon Robert V ‚Ä¢ pont, for his many worthy ≈øeruices.

(9) There is mention made but of one religious hou≈øe that hath beene in all this Country, and that was a little Mona≈øtery ≈øeated neere vnto the Riuer Lod ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , built by Tho ‚Ä¢ as the ≈øonne of Go≈øpatricke, the ≈øonne of Orms: where there is a fountaine or ≈øpring that ebbes and flowes many times a day, and it is thought that ≈øome notable Act of Atchieuement hath beene performed there, for that there be huge ≈øtones in forme of Pyramides, ≈øome nine foot high, and fourteene foot thicke, ranged for a mile in length directly in a row, and equally di≈øtant, which might ≈øeeme to haue beene there purpo≈øely pitc ‚Ä¢ ed in memory thereof: but what that Act was is not now knowne, but quite worne out of remembrance by times iniurie.

(10) Other matters worthy ob≈øeruation are onely the≈øe: That at Amboglana, now called Amble-≈øide,
neere the vpper corner of Winander mear, there appeares at this day the ruines of an ancient Citie, which by the Briti≈øh-Brickes, by Romane-money oftentimes found there, by High-wayes paued leading vnto it, and other likelihoods, ≈øeemes to haue beene a worke of the Romanes: The Fortre≈ø≈øe thereof ≈øo long fenced with a ditch and rampire, that it tooke vp in length one hundred thirtie two Ells, and in bredth eight. There are al≈øo neere Kendale in the Riuer Can, two Catadupae or Waterfals, where the waters de≈øcend with ≈øuch a forcible downefall, that it compels a mightie noy≈øe to be heard, which the neighbour Inhabitants make ≈øuch v≈øe of, as they ≈øtand them in as good ≈øtead as Progno≈øtications: for when that which ≈øtandeth North from them ≈øoundeth more cleare, and with a louder eccho in their eares, they certainly looke for faire weather to follow: But when that on the South doth the like, they expect foggy mi≈øts and ≈øhowres of raine.
(11) This Prouince is traded with foure Market-Townes, fortified with the ≈øtrength of ≈øeuen Ca≈øtles, and hath 26. Pari≈øhes in it for the celebration of Diuine Seruice.

div.head: CVMBERLAND. CHAPTER XLI.
div.p:
CVMBERLAND, the furthe≈øt North-we≈øt Prouince in this Realme of England, confronteth vpon the South of Scotland, and is diuided from that Kingdome partly by the Riuer
‚Ä¢ ir≈øo ‚Ä¢ , then cro≈ø≈øing Eske, by a tract thorow Solome-Mo≈ø≈øe, vntill it come to the Solwaye Frith, by Ptolemie called the
„Äà‚óä„Äâ Baye. The North-we≈øt part is neighboured by Northumberland, more Ea≈øt-ward with We≈øtmerland, the South with Lanca≈øhire, and the We≈øt is wholly wa≈øhed with the Iri≈øh Seas.

(2) The forme whereof is long and narrow, pointing wedge-like into the South, which part is altogether pe≈øtred with copped-hilles, and therefore hath the name of Cop-land. The middle is more leuell, and better inhabited, yeelding ≈øufficient for the ≈øu≈øtenance of man: but the North is wilde and ≈øolitary, combred with hilles, as Copland is.
(3) The ayre is piercing, and of a ≈øharpe temperature, and would be more biting, were it not that tho≈øe high hilles breake off the Northerne ≈øtormes, and cold falling ≈ønowes.

(4) Notwith≈øtanding, rich is this Prouince, and with great varieties thereof is repleni≈øhed: the hilles, though rough, yet ≈ømile vpon their beholders, ≈øpread with ≈øheepe and cattle, the vallies ≈øtored with gra≈ø≈øe and corne ≈øufficient: the Sea affordeth great ≈øtore of fi≈øh, the land ouer-≈øpread with varietie of fowles, and the Riuers feed a kinde of Muskle that bringeth forth Pearle, where in the mouth of the Irt, as they lie gaping and ≈øucking in dew, the Country people gather and ≈øell to the Lapidaries, to their owne little, and the buyers great gaine. But the Mines Royall of Copper, whereof this Country yeeldeth much, is for v≈øe the riche≈øt of all: the place is at Ke≈øwick and Newland, where
likewi≈øe the Blacke Lead is gotten, who≈øe plentie maketh it of no great e≈øteeme; otherwi≈øe a commoditie that could hardly be mi≈ø≈øed.

(5) The ancient Inhabitants knowne to the Romans, were the Brigantes, whom Ptolemie di≈øper≈øeth into We≈øtmorland, Richmond, Durham, York-≈øhire, and Lanca-≈øhire. But when the Saxons had ouer borne the Britaines, and forced them out of the be≈øt, to ≈øeeke their re≈øting among the va≈øt Mountaines, the≈øe by them were entred into, where they held play with tho≈øe enemies maugre their force, and from them, as Mariama doth witne≈ø≈øe, the Land was called Cumber, of tho≈øe Kumbri the Britaines. But when the State of the Saxons was fore ≈øhaken by the Danes, this Cumberland was accounted a Kingdome it ≈øelfe; for ≈øo the Flower-gatherer of We≈øtmin≈øter recordeth: King Edmund (≈øaith he) with the helpe of Leoline Prince of South-Wales, wa≈øted all Cumberland, and hauing put out the eyes of the two ≈øonnes of Dunmail King of that Prouince, granted that Kingdome vnto Molcolm King of Scots, whereof their elde≈øt ≈øonnes became Prefects. This Prouince, King Stephen, to purcha≈øe fauour with the Scots, what time he ≈øtood in mo≈øt need of ayd, confirmed by gift vnder their Crowne; which Henry the ≈øecond notwith≈øtanding made claime vnto and got, as Newbrigen≈øis writeth, and laid it againe in the Marches of England: ≈øince when, many bickerings betwixt the≈øe Nations herein haue hapned, but none ≈øo ≈øore again≈øt the Scoti≈øh ≈øide, as was that at Sallome-Mo≈ø≈øe, where their Nobilitie di≈ødaining their Generall Oliuer Sinclere, gaue ouer the Battle, and yeelded them≈øelues to the Engli≈øh; which di≈øhonour pier ‚Ä¢ ed ≈øo deeply into the heart of King Iames the fift, that for griefe thereof he ≈øhortly after died.

(6) Many memorable Antiquities remaine and haue beene found in this County: for it being the Confines of the Romans Po≈ø≈øe≈øsions, was continually ≈øecured by their Garri≈øons, where remaine a ‚Ä¢
this day parts of that admirable wall built by Seuer ‚Ä¢ s: al≈øo another Fortification from W ‚Ä¢ rkinton to Elus Mouth, vpon the Sea-≈øhoare toward Ireland, by Stilico rai≈øed, when vnder Theodo≈øius he ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed
the rage of the Picts and Iri≈øh, and freed the Seas of the Saxons Pirats. Vpon Hard-knot hill, Moresby, Old Carleil, Pap-ca≈øtle along the Wall, and in many other places, their ruines remaine, with altars, and In≈øcriptions of their Captaines and Colonies, whereof many haue beene found, and more as yet lie hid.

(7) The chiefe≈øt Citie in this Shire is Carlile, plea≈øantly ≈øeated betwixt the Riuers Eden, Petterell, and Caud, by the Romans called Luguvallum; by Beda, Luell; by Ptolemy, Leucopibia; by Nu ‚Ä¢ tu ‚Ä¢ Caer-Lu ‚Ä¢ lid; and by vs Carlile. This Citie flouri≈øhing vnder the Romans, at their departure, by the furious outrages of the Scots and Picts was deiected, yet in the dayes of Egfrid King of Northumberland was walled about: but againe defaced by the ouer-running Danes, lay buried in her owne a≈øhes the ≈øpace of two hundred yeares; vpon who≈øe ruines at length Rufus ≈øet his compa≈ø≈øionate eye, and built there the Ca≈øtle, planting a Colony of Flemings to ≈øecure the Coa≈øts from the Scots, but vpon better adui≈øement remoued them into Wales. After him, Henry his brother and ≈øucce≈ø≈øour ordained this Citie for an Epi≈øcopall See: who≈øe ≈øite is placed in the degree of Longitude from the fir≈øt We≈øt part 17. and 2. ≈øcruples, and the Pole thence eleuated from the degree of Latitude 55. and 56. ≈øcruples.

(8) We≈øt from hence, at Burgh vpon the ≈øand, was the fatall end of our famous Monarch King Edward the fir≈øt, who there leauing his warres vnfini≈øhed again≈øt Scotland, left his troubles, and ≈øoone mi≈ø≈øed life, to his vntimely and ≈øoone lamented death.

(9) And at Salkelds vpon the Riuer Eden, a Monument of ≈øeuentie ≈øeuen ≈øtones, each of them ten foot high aboue ground, and one of them at the entrance fifteene, as a Trophie of Victory was erected. The≈øe are by the By-dwellers called Long Megge and her daughters.

(10) This County, as it ≈øtood in the fronts of a≈ø≈øaults, ≈øo was it ≈øtrengthned with twentie-fiue Ca≈øtles, and pre≈øerued with the prayers (as then was thought) of the Votaries in the hou≈øes erected at Carlile, Lenecoft, Wetherall, Holm ‚Ä¢ , Daker, and Saint Bees. The≈øe with others were di≈ø≈øolued by
King Henry the eight, and their reuenewes ≈øhadowed vnder his Crowne: but the Prouince being freed from charge of ≈øub≈øidie, is not therefore diuided into Hundreds in the Parlament Rowles, whence we haue taken the diui≈øions of the re≈øt: onely this is ob≈øerued, that therein are ≈øeated nine Market-Townes, fiftie eight Pari≈øh-Churches, be≈øides many other Chappels of ea≈øe.

div.head: NORTHVMBERLAND. CHAPTER XLII.
div.p: THe County of Northumberland, hath on the South the Bi≈øhopricke of Durham, being ≈øhut in with the Riuer Derwent, and with Tyne; the North is confined vpon Scotland, the We≈øt vpon part of Scotland and part of Cumberland: the Ea≈øt-≈øide lyeth altogether vpon the Sea, called Mare-Germanicum.

(2) The forme thereof is Triangle, and differs not much in the ≈øidings; for from her South-Ea≈øt vnto the South-We≈øt-point are neere vnto 40. miles; from thence to „Äà‚óä„Äâ North-point are ≈øixty miles, and her ba≈øe along the Sea-≈øhoare 45. miles: The whole in circum ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ is about one hundred fortie fiue miles.

(3) The Ayre mu≈øt needs be ≈øubtile and piercing, for that the Northernly parts are mo≈øt expo≈øed to extremitie of weathers, as great winds, hard fro≈øts, and long lying of ≈ønowes, &c. Yet would it be farre more ≈øharper then it is, were not the Germane Seas a ready meanes to further the di≈ø≈øolution of her Ice and Snow, and the plentie of Coales there gotten, a great helpe to comfort the body with warmth, and defend the bitter coldne≈ø≈øe.

(4) The Soile cannot be rich, hauing neither fertilitie of ground for Corne or Cattle, the mo≈øt part of it being rough, and in euery place hard to be manured, ≈øaue onely towards the Sea and the Riuer Tyne, where, by the great diligence and indu≈øtrious paines of good husbandry, that part is become very fruitfull.

(5) The ancient Inhabitants of this Country, mentioned by Ptolemie, were called OTTALINI, OTTADENI, and OTTADINI, which by an ea≈øie alteration (as M. Cambden ≈øaith) if it
had ‚Ä¢ ene called OTTATINI, ≈øignifying, about the Riuer Tyne, or on the further ≈øide of Tyne
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ this people were planted) there would haue beene much con≈øonance both with the name of the Inhabitants, and the Po≈øition and Site of the Prouince.

(6) The chiefe≈øt commoditie that enricheth this Countie, are tho≈øe Stones Linthancraces, which we call Sea-coales, whereof there is ≈øuch plentie and abundance digged vp, as they doe not onely returne a great gaine to the Inhabitants, but procure al≈øo much plea≈øure and profit to others.

(7) No place of this Prouince vents forth ≈øo many of the≈øe Sea-coales into other regions as Newca≈øtle doth, being the very eye of all the Townes in this County: for it doth not onely mini≈øter reliefe (by ≈øuch proui≈øion) to all other parts of England, but doth al≈øo farni≈øh the wants of forraine Countries with her plentie. By meanes of this and the intercour≈øe of traffique which it hath, the place is growne ex ‚Ä¢ eeding rich and populous. Before the Conquest it was called Monk-che≈øter: hauing beene ( „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ) in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Monkes: and Che≈øter being added, which ≈øignifies a bulwarke or place of defence, ≈øhewes that in ancient time it had beene a place of Fortification.

(8) After the Conque≈øt it got the name of Newca≈øtle‚ñ™ by the new Ca≈øtle which Robert the Sonne of William the Conquerour built there, out of the ground. What it was called in old time is not knowne, yet ≈øome are of opinion, that it may be thought to haue beene Gatro≈øentum for that Gate≈øhead, the ≈øuburbe (as it were) of the ≈øame, expre≈ø≈øeth in the owne proper ≈øignification that Briti≈øh name, Gatro≈øentum It is now mo≈øt enobled both by the Hauen (which Tyne maketh) of that notable depth, that it beareth very tall Ships, and is able to defend them again≈øt ≈øtormes and tempe≈øts. As al≈øo by many fauours and honours wherewith it hath beene dignified by p ‚Ä¢ ces: for Richard the ≈øecond, granted that a Sword ≈øhould be carried before the Maior, and Henry the ≈øixt made it a County con≈øi≈øting of a Corporation within it ≈øelfe. It is adorned with foure Churches, and fortified with ≈øtrong wals that haue eight gates. It is di≈øtant from the fir≈øt We≈øt line 21 degrees and 30 minutes,
and from the Equinoctiall liue towards the North-pole thirtie-foure degrees and fiftie-≈øeaven minutes.

(9) The vtmo≈øt Towne in England, and the ≈øtronge≈øt hold in all Britaine, is Barwicke. From whence it had the name is not certainely made knowne. Some fetch it from Berengarius, a Duke (neuer read of:) How≈øoeuer, this is better to be ≈øaid then tru≈øted: and whence ≈øoeuer it hath the name, it is ≈øeated betweene two mightie Kingdomes, ≈øhooting farre into the Sea, with the which, and the Riuer Tweed, it is almo≈øt encompa≈ø≈øed: and when≈øoeuer any di≈øcord fell betweene the two Nations, this place was the fir≈øt thing they tooke care of. It hath endured the brunts of diuers inroades and incur≈øions, and beene oftentimes both po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed and repo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Scots and Engli≈øh: But ≈øince it was reduced vnder the command of Edward the fourth, our Kings haue from time to time ≈øo ≈øtrengthened it with new workes and fortifications, as they cut off all hopes of winning it. The Gouernour of this Towne is al≈øo Warden of the Ea≈øt Marches again≈øt ≈øcotland. The Longitude of it according to Mathematicall ob≈øeruation, is 21. degrees and 43. minutes: the Latitude 55. degrees and 48. minutes.

(10) The Inhabitants of this County are a warlike people, and excellent light hor≈øemen, and are made fierce and hard by the ≈øeuerall encounters of the Scots, and not much vnlike them in neither, betwixt whom in this County, many Battles haue beene fought, and the ≈øucce≈ø≈øes oftentimes waued through very doubtfully, the victory ≈øometimes falling to the ≈øcots, ≈øometimes to the Engli≈øh. At Otterburne was one, in which three or foure times it ≈øtood doubtfully indifferent, till in the end the Scots got the vpper hand of the Engli≈øh: Howbeit, their glory was not made ≈øo illu≈øtrious by this Conque≈øt, but that it was as much darkened by the foile they receiued at A ‚Ä¢ wicke, where William King of Scots, was taken and pre≈øented pri≈øoner to Henry the ≈øecond. As al≈øo by that Battell at Brumridge, where King Athel≈øtan fought a pitcht field again≈øt Anlafe the Dane, Con≈øtantine King of Scots,
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
and Eugenius King of Cumberland, and that with ≈øuch fortunate ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, as it hath left matter ≈øufficient to fill the pennes of Hi≈øtorians. Flodden field al≈øo, memorable in the death of Iames the fourth, King of Scots, who was there ≈ølaine, and his Army ouerthrowne in a ≈øharpe fight, as he di≈øplayed his Banner (in great hope) again≈øt England, when King Henry the eight lay at the ≈øiege of Turnay in France

(11) Other Battles in this Countie haue beene, as that at Hexam (called by Bede, Hangu≈øtald) wherein Iohn Neuill, Marque≈ø≈øe Montacute, encountred the Leaders of the Lanca≈øtrian faction with much courage, and with greater ≈øucce≈ø≈øe put them to flight, for which he was made Earle of Northumberland by Edward the fourth As al≈øo that at Dil≈øton (by Bede called Diuel≈øhur ‚Ä¢ e,) where O≈øwald hauing the faith of Chri≈øt for his defence and armour, ≈ølew Cedwall the Britaine in a ≈øet battell, him≈øelfe ≈øtraight-wayes becomming a profe≈ø≈øed Chri≈øtian, and cau≈øing his people to be in≈øtructed in Chri≈øtian Religion.

(12) Many memorable antiquities are found in this Country along the wall, and in other places: As pieces of Coyne, In≈øcriptions, broken and vnperfect Altars, &c. (the ruines of the wall yet to be ≈øeene:) but none that de≈øerues more to be remembred then Wall-Towne (by Bede called Ad Muru ‚Ä¢ ) for that Segebert King of the Ea≈øt-Saxons was in it baptized in the Chri≈øtian Faith by the hands of Paulinus: and Haly≈øton, where the ≈øame Paulinus is ≈øaid to haue baptized many thou≈øands into the Faith of Chri≈øt, in the Primitiue Church of the Engli≈øh Nation.

(13) Bu≈øy-gap is a place infamous for robbing and theeuing, and is therefore rather remembred as a cautiatory note for ≈øuch as haue cau≈øe to trauell that way, then for any proper matter of worth it hath, that merits place with other parts of this Prouince.

Other matters of ob≈øeruation are onely the≈øe, that North Tyne (running through the Wall) waters two Dales, which breed notable light hor≈øe-men, and both of them haue their hils (hard by)
≈øo boggy, and ≈øtanding with water on the top, that no hor≈øemen are able to ride through them, and yet (which is wonderfull) there be many great heapes of Stones (called Lawes) which the neighbouring people are verily per≈øwaded were ca≈øt vp and laid together in old time, in remembrance of ≈øome that were ≈ølaine there. There is al≈øo a martiall kinde of men which lie out, vp and downe in little Cottages (called by them Sheals and Shealings) from Aprill to Augu≈øt, in ≈øcattering fa≈øhion, ≈øummering (as they terme it) their Cattle, and the≈øe are ≈øuch a ≈øort of people as were the ancient Nomades. The la≈øt, not lea≈øt, matter of note is this, that the Inhabitants of Morpeth ≈øet their owne Towne on fire in the yeare of Chri≈øt 1215. in the ≈øpight they bare to King Iohn, for that he and his Rutars ouer-ranne the≈øe Countries.
This County hath fiue Market-Townes in it for her trade of buying and ≈øelling, 26. Ca≈øtles for her ≈øtrength and fortification, and 460. Pari≈øh-Churches for diuine ≈øeruice.

div.head: MAN ILAND. CHAPTER XLIII.
div.p:
THe Ile of Man is termed by Ptolemy, M ‚Ä¢ neda; by Pliny, Menauia; by Oro≈øius, Menania by Beda, Menania ≈øecunda, and by Gyldas, „Äà‚óä„Äâ , and M ‚Ä¢ naw. The Britaine name it Men ‚Ä¢ w; the Inhabitants, Ma ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ge; and we Engli≈øhmen, The Ile of Man It boundeth North-ward vpon Scotland, South-ward vpon the Ile of Angle≈øey, Ea≈øt-ward vpon part of
„Äà‚óä„Äâ -≈øhire, and We≈øt-ward vpon the Coa≈øt of Ireland.

(2) The forme is long and narrow: for from „Äà‚óä„Äâ to the Mull-hils, where it is longe≈øt, it onely ≈øtretcheth it ≈øelfe to twentie nine miles; but from the wide≈øt part, which is from Peele-Ca≈øtle to Douglas-point, are ≈øcarce nine; the whole compa≈ø≈øe about, is foure≈øcore and two miles.

(3) The ayre is ≈øo cold and ≈øharpe, being bordering vpon the „Äà‚óä„Äâ parts, and for her ≈øhelter hauing but a wall of water. They haue few woods; onely they light ≈øometimes vpon ≈øo ≈øubterranean trees buried vnder the ground, by digging vp the earth for a ‚Ä¢ lammie kinde of „Äà‚óä„Äâ , which they v≈øe for fuell.

(4) The ≈øoile is rea≈øonable fruitfull both for Cattle, Fi≈øh, and Corne; yet it rather commendeth the paines of the people then the goodne≈ø≈øe of the ground; for by the indu≈øtry of the Inhabitants it ‚Ä¢ eeldeth ≈øufficiency of euery thing for it ≈øelfe, and ≈øendeth good ≈øtore into other Countries. It hath fields (by good manuring) plenteous of Barley and Wheat, but e≈øpecially „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ and from hence it comes that the people eate mo≈øt of all Oaten-bread. It beares abundance of „Äà‚óä„Äâ and Flaxe, and is full of mightie flockes of ≈øheepe and other Cattell: yet are they ≈ømaller in body then we haue in England, and are much like to the Cattle in Ireland that are neighbouring vpon it.

(5) This commoditie makes this Iland more happie then we are here: for the people are there free from vnnece≈ø≈øary commencements of Suites, from long and dilatory Pleas, and from friuolous feeing of Lawyers No Iudge or Clerks of the Court take there any penny for drawing In≈øtruments, or making of Proce≈ø≈øes All Controuer≈øies are there determined by certaine Iudges, without writings or other charges, and them they call Deem≈øters, and chu≈øe forth among them≈øelues, If any complaint be made to the Magi≈øtrate for wrongs eyther done or ≈øuffred, he pre≈øently taketh vp a ≈øtone, and fixeth his marke vpon it, and ≈øo deliuereth it vnto the partie plaintiffe, by vertue of which he both cals his aduer≈øary to appearance, and to produce his witne≈ø≈øes. If the ca≈øe fall out to be more litigious, and of greater con≈øequence then can ea≈øily be ended, it is then referred to twelue men, whom they terme The Keyes of the Iland. Another happine≈ø≈øe enricheth this Iland, namely the ≈øecuritie and gouernment thereof, as being defended from neighbour enemies by Souldiers that are pre≈øt and ready; for on the South-≈øide of the Ile ≈øtands Bala-Curi (the Bi≈øhops chiefe place of re≈øidence) and the Pyle, and a Block-hou≈øe ≈øtanding in a little Iland, where there is a coÃÑtinuall Garri≈øon of Souldiers. And it is ≈øo well managed for matter of rule and ciuill di≈øcipline, that tuery man there po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth his owne in peace and ≈øafetie. No man liues in dread or danger of lo≈øing what he hath. Men are not there inclined to robbing or theeuing, or licentious liuing.

(6) The Inhabitants of this Iland are for the mo≈øt part religious, and louing to their Pa≈øtors, to whom they doe much reuerence and re≈øpect, frequenting daily to diuine Seruice, without diui≈øion in the Church or innouation in the Common-weale. The wealthier ≈øort, and ≈øuch as hold the faire≈øt po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, doe imitate the people of Lanca-≈øhire, both in their hone≈øt carriage and good hou≈øe-keeping. Howbeit, the common ≈øort of people both in their language and manners, come nighe≈øt vnto the Iri≈øh, although they ≈øomewhat relli≈øh and fauour of the qualities of the Norwegians.

(7) Things not worthy to be buryed in the graue of obliuion are, that this Iland in the mid≈øt thereof ri≈øeth vp with hils, ≈øtanding very thicke; among≈øt which the highe≈øt is called Sceafull, from whence vpon a cleare and faire day, a man may ea≈øily ≈øee three Kingdomes at once; that is, Scotland, England, and Ireland. This Ile prohibits the cu≈øtomary manner ofbegging from doore to doore, dete≈øting the di≈øorders, as well Ciuill as Eccle≈øia≈øticall of neighbour Nations. And la≈øt, not lea≈øt, that de≈øerues to be committed to memory, is, that the women of this Country, where≈øoeuer they goe out of their doores, gird them≈øelues about with the winding-≈øheete that they purpo≈øe to be buried in, to ≈øhew them≈øelues mindfull of their mortalitie: and ≈øuch of them as are at any time condemned to dye, are ≈øowed within a ≈øacke, and flung from a rocke into the Sea.

(8) The whole I≈øle is diuided into two parts, South and North, whereof the one re≈øembleth the Scoti≈øh in ≈øpeech, the other the Iri≈øh. It is defended by two Ca≈øtles, and hath ≈øeauenteene Pari≈øhes, fiue Market-Townes, and many Villages.

div.head: A Chronicle of the Kings of MAN. CHAPTER XLIIII.
div.p: IT is here very pertinent to the purpo≈øe, to in≈øert a ≈ømall Hi≈øtory of this Iland, that the atchieuements heretofore had, may not be vtterly buryed, although they are waxen very old, and almo≈øt torne from remembrance by the teeth of Time. It is confe≈ø≈øed by all, that the Britaines held this Iland, as they did all Britaine. But when the Nations from the North ouerflowed tho≈øe South parts, like violent tempe≈øts, it became ≈øubiect to the Scots. Afterwards, the Norwegians who did mo≈øt hurt from the Northerne Sea by their manifold robberies, made this Iland and the Hebrides to be their baunt, and erected Lords and petry Kings in the ≈øame, as is expre≈ø≈øed in this Chronicle, written (as is reported) by the Monkes of the Abbey of Ru≈ø≈øin.

div.head: A Chronicle of the Kings of MAN.
div.p: ANno Dom. 1065. Edward, of ble≈ø≈øed memory, King of England, departed this life, and Harald the Sonne of Godwyn ≈øucceeded him in the Kingdome: again≈øt whom Harald Harfager (King of Norway) came into the field, and fought a Battle at Stainford-bridge: but the Engli≈øh obtaining the victory, put them all to flight. Out of which cha≈øe Godred, ≈øurnamed Crovan, the ≈øonne of Harald the blacke of I≈øeland, came vnto Godred the ≈øonne of Syrric, who Raigned then in Man, and honourably receiued him.
(2) The ≈øame yeare William the Ba≈øtard Conquered England, and Godred the ≈øon of Syrric died, his ≈øonne Fingal ≈øucceeding him.
(3) An. 1066. Godred Crovan a≈ø≈øembled a great Fleet, and came to Man, and ≈øought with the people of the Land, but receiued the wor≈øt, and was ouercome.

The ≈øecond time renewing his Forces and his Fleet, he failed into Man, and ioyned Battle with the Manksmen, but was vanqui≈øhed as before, and driuen out of the field. Howbeit, what he could not at fir≈øt bring to pa≈ø≈øe with power in tho≈øe two ≈øeuerall on≈øers, he afterward effected by policie. For the third time gathering a great multitude together, he arriued by night in the hauen called Ra ‚Ä¢
≈øey, and hid three hundred men in a Wood, which ≈øtood vpon the hanging hollow brow of an hill called Sceafull. The Sunne being ri≈øen, the Manksmen put their people in order of Battle, and with a violent charge encountred with Godred. The fight was hot for a time, and ≈øtood in a doubtfull ≈øu≈øpence, till tho≈øe three hundred men ≈øtarting out of the Ambu≈øh behinde their backes, began to foile the Manksmen, put them to the wor≈øt, and forced them to flie. Who ≈øeeing them≈øelues thus di≈øcomfited, and finding no place of refuge left them to e≈øcape, with pitifull lamentation ≈øubmitted them≈øelues vnto Godred, and be≈øought him not to put to the ≈øword ≈øuch poore remainder of them as was left aliue. Godred hauing compa≈ø≈øion on their calamities, (for he had beene nur≈øed for a time and brought vp among them) ≈øounded a retreat, and prohibited his Ho≈øt any longer perfuie. He being thus po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Ile of Man, dyed in the Iland that is called Ile, when he had raigned ≈øixteene yeares. He left behinde him three ≈øonnes, Lagman, Harald, and Olaue.

(4) Lagman the elde≈øt, taking vpon him the Kingdome, raigned ≈øeauen yeares. His brother Harald rebelled again≈øt him a great while; but at length was taken pri≈øoner by Lagman, who cau≈øed his members of generation to be cut off, and his eyes to be put out of his head, which crueltie this Lagman afterwards repenting, gaue ouer the Kingdome of his owne accord, and wearing the badge of the Lords Cro≈ø≈øe, tooke a iourney to Ieru≈øalem, in which he dyed.

(5) An 1075. all the Lords and Nobles of the Iland ‚Ä¢ hearing of the death of Lagman, di≈øpatched
Amba≈ø≈øadours to Murecard O-brien, King of Ireland, and reque≈øted that he would ≈øend ≈øome worthy and indu≈øtrious man of the Bloud Royall to be their King, till Olaue the ≈øonne of Godred came to full age. The King yeelding to their reque≈øt, ≈øent one Dopnald the ≈øonne of Tade, and charged him to gouerne the Kingdome (which by right belonged to another,) with lenitie and gentlene≈ø≈øe. But after be was come to the Crowne, forgetting, or not weighing the charge that his Lord and Ma≈øter had giuen him, ≈øwayed his place with great tyranny, committing many outrages and cruelties, and ≈øo raigned three yeares: till all the Princes of the Ilands agreeing together, ro≈øe vp again≈øt him, and made him flie into Ireland.

(6) An. Dom. 1111. Olaue the ≈øonne of Godred Crouan afore≈øaid, began his raigne, and raigned fortie yeares a peaceable Prince. He tooke to wife Affrica, the daughter of Fergus of Gal-way, of whom he begat Godred. By his Concubines he had Raignald, Lagman, and Harald, be≈øides many daughters, whereof one was married to Summerled, Prince of Herergaidel, who cau≈øed the ruine of the Kings of the Ilands. On her he begat foure ≈øonnes, Dulgal, Raignald, Engus, and Olaue.

(7) An. Dom. 1144 Godred the ≈øonne of Olaue, was created King of Man, and raigned thiritie yeares. In the third yeare of his raigne the people of Dublin ≈øent for him, and made him their King. Which Mure-card King of Ireland maligning, rai≈øed warre, and ≈øent O≈øibeley his halfe brother by the mothers ≈øide with 3000. men at Armes to Dublin, who by Godred and the Dublinians was ≈ølaine, and the re≈øt all put to flight. The≈øe atchieuements made, Godred returned to Man, and began to v≈øe tyranny, turning the Noblemen out of their inheritances. Whereupon one called Thorfin (vtters ≈øonne) being mightier then the re≈øt, came to Summerled, and made Dulgal (Summerleds ≈øonne) King of the Ilands: whereof Godred hauing intelligence, prepared a Nauie of 80. Shippes to meet Summerled. And in the yeare 1156. there was a Battle fought at Sea on Twelfth day at night, and many ≈ølaine on both ≈øides But the next day they grew to a pacification, and diuided the Kingdome
of the Ilands among them≈øelues. This was the cau≈øe of the ouerthrow of the Kingdome of the Iles.

(8) Ann 1158. Summerled came to Man, with a fleet of fiftie three ≈øaile, put Godred to flight, and wa≈øted the Iland. Godred vpon this cro≈ø≈øed ouer to Norway for ayde again≈øt Summerled. But Summerled in the meane time arriuing at Rhinfrin, and hauing gathered together: fleet of 160 ≈øhips, couerting to ≈øubdue all Scotland, by the ru≈øt iudgement of God, was vanqui≈øhed by a few, and both him≈øelfe and his ≈øonne ≈ølaine, with an infinite number of people.

(9) The fourth day after, Raignald, began to raigne, but Godred comming vpon him out of Norway with a great multitude of Armed men, tooke his brother Raignald, and be re≈øt him both of his eyes and genitall members. On the fourth Ides of Nouember, An. Dom. 1187. Godred King of the Ilands dyed, and his body was tran≈ølated to the Ile of Ely‚ñ™ He left behinde him three ≈øonnes, Raignald, Olaue, and Yuar. He ordained in his life time that Olaue ≈øhould ≈øucceed him, becau≈øe he onely was borne legitimate. But the people of Man ≈øeeing him to be ≈øcarce ten yeares old, ≈øent for Raignald, and made him their King. I his cau≈øed great diui≈øion, and many turbulent attempts betweene the two Brethren for the ≈øpace of thirtie eight yeares; which had no end, till at a place called Tnigualla there was a battle ≈øtrucke betweene them, wherein Olaue had the victory, and Raignald was ≈ølaine. The Monkes of Ru≈øsin tran≈ølated his body vnto the Abbey of S. Mary de Fournes, and there interred it in a place which him≈øelfe had cho≈øen for that purpo≈øe.

(10) An. 1230. Olaue and Godred Don (who was Raignalds ≈øonne) with the Norwegians came to Man, and diuided the Kingdome among them≈øelues. Olaue held Man, and Godred being gone vnto the Ilands, was ≈ølaine in the Ile Lodhus So Olaue obtained the Kingdome of the I≈ø≈øes. He dyed the twelfth Calends of Lune, Anno 1237. in Saint Patrickes Iland, and was buryed in the Abbey of Ru≈øsin.

(11) Harrold his ≈øonne ≈øucceeded him, being foureteene yeares of age, and raigned 12 yeares. In the yeare 1239. he went vnto the King of Norway, who after two yeares confirmed vnto him, his heyres and ≈øucce≈ø≈øours, vnder his Seale, all the Ilands which his predece≈ø≈øours had po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed.

(12) An. 1242. Harrold returned out of Norway, and being by the Inhabitants honourably receiued, had peace with the Kings of England and of Scotland. The ≈øame yeare he was ≈øent for by the King of Norway, and married his daughter. In the yeare 1249. as he returned homeward with his wife, he was drowned in a tempe≈øt neere vnto the coa≈øts of Radland.

(13) An Dom. 1249. Raignald the ≈øonne of Olaue, and brother to Harrold, began his raigne, and on the thirtieth day there of was ≈ølaine by one Yuar a Knight, in a meadow neere vnto the holy Trinitie Church, and lyeth buryed in the Church of S. Mary of Ru≈øsin.
(14) In the yeare 1252. Magnus, the ≈øonne of Olaue, came to Man and was made King. The next yeare following he went to the King of Norway, and ≈øtayed there a yeare.
(15) In the yeare 1265. Magnus (Olaues ≈øonne) King of Man, and of the Ilands, departed this life, at the Ca≈øtle of Ru≈øsin, and was buryed in the Church of S. Mary of Ru≈øsin.

(16) In the yeare 1266. the Kingdome of the Ilands was tran≈ølated, by rea≈øon of Alexander King of Scots, who had gotten into his hands the We≈øterne Ilands, and brought the Ile of Man vnder his dominion, as one of that number.

(17) An. 1340. William Montacute Earle of Salisbury wre≈øted it from the Scoti≈øh by ≈øtrong hand and force of Armes: and in the yeare 1393. (as Thomas Wal≈øingham ≈øaith) he ≈øold Man and the Crowne thereof vnto William Scroope for a great ≈øumme of money But he being beheaded for high Trea≈øon, and his goods confi≈øcate, it came into the hands of Henry the Fourth, King of England, who granted this Iland vnto Henry Percy Earle of Northumberland. But Henry Percy entring into
open rebellion the fift yeare following, the King ≈øent Sir Iohn Stanley and William Stanley to ≈øeize the Ile and Ca≈øtle of Man, the inheritance whereof he granted afterwards to Sir Iohn Stanley and his heyres by Letters Patents, with the Patronage of the Bi≈øhopricke, &c. So that his heyres and ≈øucce≈ø≈øours, who were honoured with the Title of Earles of Darby, were commonly called „Äà‚óä„Äâ of Man.

div.head: HOLY ILAND. CHAPTER XLV.
div.p: THis Iland is called Lindisfarne, by the Riuer Lied that is oppo≈øite vnto it on the Coa≈øt of Northumberland. Beda termeth it a Deiny Iland. The Britaine name it „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , for that it twice euery day ≈øuffreth an extraordinary inundation and ouer-flowing of the Ocean in manner of an Iland, which twice likewi≈øe makes it continent to the Land, and returning vnto her watrie habitation, layes the Shoare bare againe, as before. It is called in Engli≈øh, Holy-Iland, for that in ancient times many Monkes haue beene accu≈øtomed to retire them≈øelues thither, and to make it their receptacle for ≈øolitude: hauing on the We≈øt and South, Northumberland, and more South-Ea≈øtward the Iland Farne.

(2) The forme of it is long and narrow, the We≈øt ≈øide narrower then the Ea≈øt, and are both conioyned by a very ≈ømall ≈øpang of land that is left vnto Comes. The South is much „Äà‚óä„Äâ then the re≈øt It is from Ea≈øt to We≈øt, about two thou≈øand two hundred and fiftie pa≈øes; and from North to South, twelue hundred and fiftie pa≈øes; ≈øo that the circumference cannot be great.

(3) The ayre is not very good either for health or delight, as being ≈øeated on tho≈øe parts that are ≈øubiect to extremitie of cold, and greatly troubled with vapours and toggy mi≈øts that ari≈øe from the Seas.

(4) The ≈øoile cannot be rich, being rockie and full of ≈øtones, and vnfit for Corne and T ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ age. It is neither commended for hils to ≈øeed ≈øheepe, nor pa≈øtures to fit Cattle, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
repleni≈øhed with ≈øweet ≈øprings, or running riuellets, onely one excepted, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ≈øtanding pond. The onely thing this Iland yeeldeth, is a ≈øtand accomodate „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ and fowling.

(5) Notwith≈øtanding, this is very worthy of note concerning the ≈øame, which Alcun wrote in an Epi≈øtle to Egelred King of Northumberland, namely, that it was a place more venerable then all the places of Britaine, and that after the departure of S. Paulinus from Yorke, there Chri≈øtian Religion began in their Nation, though afterwards it there felt the fir≈øt beginning of mi≈øery and calamitie, being left to the ≈øpoyle of Pagans and M ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ oants.

(6) It is al≈øo remembred of this Iland, that ≈øometimes there hath beene in it an Epi≈øcopall See, which A ‚Ä¢ dan the Scot in≈øtituted (being called thither to Preach the Chri≈øtian Faith to the people of Northumberland) being thus delighted with the ≈øolitary ≈øituation thereof, as a mo≈øt fit place for retire. But afterwards when the Danes
‚Ä¢ i≈øled and robbed all the Sea-Coa≈øts, the Epi≈øcopall See was tran≈ølated to Durham.

(7) This Iland ≈øo ≈ømall in account either for compa≈ø≈øe or Commoditie, and ≈øo vnpeopled and vnprofitable, cannot be numerous in Townes and Villages. It hath in it onely one Towne, with a Church and a Ca≈øtle, vnder which there is a commodious Hauen, defended with a Block-hou≈øe, ≈øituate vpon in hill towards the South-Ea≈øt.

div.head: FARNEILE.
div.p: THis Ile South-ea≈øtward ≈øeuen miles from Holy Iland, ≈øheweth it ≈øelfe di≈øtant almo≈øt two miles from Bambrough Ca≈øtle. On the We≈øt and South it beareth vpon Northumberland, and on the North-ea≈øt-≈øide it hath other ≈ømaller Ilands adioyning to it, as Widopens & Staple Iland, which lie two miles off Bron≈øinan, and two le≈ø≈øer then the≈øe, which are called the Wambes.

(2) The forme of this Ile is round, and no larger in compa≈ø≈øe then may ea≈øily be ridden
in one halfe of a day. The bredth of it is but fiue miles, and the length no more. The whole circumference extends it ≈øelfe no further then to fifteene miles.

(3) The ayre is very vnwhole≈øome, and ≈øubiect both to many Dy≈øenteries and other di≈øea≈øes, by rea≈øon of the mi≈øtie fogges and exhalations that are thereunto drawne vp from the Ocean. It is many times troubled with vnu≈øuall tempe≈øts of windes, with boi≈øterous fury of ≈øtormy raines, and with ≈øeuerall and vncouth rages of the Sea.

(4) The ≈øoile cannot be fertile, being encircled about with craggy clifts; neither hath it in it much matter either of plea≈øure or profit. It can neither defend it ≈øelfe from cold, lacking fuell, as Wood, Coale, Turffes, &c. nor from famine, wanting food, as Corne, Pa≈øtures, Cattle, &c. The be≈øt commoditie it yeelds, is Fi≈øh and Fowle.

(5) This thing neuerthele≈ø≈øe is worthy to be remembred of it, which Beda (writing of the life of Cuthbert Bi≈øhop of Lindisfarne, that Tutelar Pa ‚Ä¢ ron of the Northerne Engli≈øhmen) reporteth, namely, that in this Ile he built a Citie fitting his gouernment, and erected certaine hou≈øes in the ≈øame; the whole building ≈øtanding almo≈øt round in compa≈ø≈øe, and reaching the ≈øpace of foure or fiue pearches. The wall about it he made higher then a mans height, to with-hold and keepe in the want on la≈øciuiou≈øne≈ø≈øe both of his thoughts and eyes, and to eleuate the whole intention of his minde vp to heauenly de≈øires, that he might wholly giue him≈øelfe to the ≈øeruice of God. But the≈øe are all made the ruines of time, as ≈øithence many other Monuments haue beene, of worthy antiquitie.

(6) I cannot report that there are now many hou≈øes ≈øtanding in it, much le≈ø≈øe Townes or Villages. Onely this, that it hath a Tower or place of Fortification belonging vnto it, placed well-neere in the middle part of the Ile.

div.head: GARNSEY.
div.p:
THis Iland lieth about fiue leagues Northwe≈øt from Ier≈øey, and is compa≈ø≈øed (like to her neighbour) with the Briti≈øh Sea. It lieth in length from Plymouth bay South-we≈øt, to Lancro≈ø≈øe de Ancke ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
Northea≈øt, thirteene miles: in bredth from S. Martins point Southea≈øt, to the Howe Northwe≈øt nine miles; and is in circuit thirtie ≈øixe miles. The Emperour Antonine hauing the rule and domination of France (at that time called Gaule, from whence the word Gallia is deriued) did name this Iland Sarnia, which afterward by the change of Times and corruption of Languages, was long ≈øince (and is at this day) called Garn≈øey.

(2) This Ile in forme and fa≈øhion ≈øtandeth in the Sea, much like to a Parke that is incompa≈ø≈øed round about with a Pale of Rockes, being very defen≈øible vnto the Iland from the attempting innouation of enemies.

(3) The Aire and Climate of this Ile hath little or no difference in temper or qualitie from that of Ier≈øey. And this de≈øerues to be remembred of it; that in this Ile is neither Toade, Snake, Adder, or any other venemous creature, and the other hath great plentie.

(4) It ≈øtandeth for the mo≈øt part vpon a rocke, very high in many places from the Sea. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe the Soile is very fruitfull, yeelding forth great plentie of gra≈ø≈øe for their Sheepe and other Cattell, which they haue to ≈øerue all v≈øes‚ñ™ Their fields in the Summer time are ≈øo naturally garni≈øhed with flowers of all ≈øorts, that a man (being there) might conceit him≈øelfe to be in a plea≈øant artificiall garden.

(5) The Inhabitants are not ≈øo much giuen to tillage as they of Ier≈øey, though the ≈øoile be as fruitfull. They haue of late taken great delight in planting and ≈øetting of trees of all ≈øorts, and e≈øpecially of Apples, by rea≈øon whereof they make much Cider. Their commodities are alike, and their helpes from the Sea no le≈ø≈øe, or rather more.

(6) In this Ile are many great ≈øteepe Rocks, among which is found a hard ≈øtone called by the Frenchmen Smyris, which we terme Emerill. This ≈øtone is ≈øeruiceable for many purpo≈øes, and many Trades, as Gla≈øiers, &c. but e≈øpecially for the Gold≈ømiths and Lapidaries, to cut their precious ≈øtones.

(7) It hath a head of Land vpon the North part thereof, the pa≈ø≈øage into which is ≈øo narrow, that a man would thinke that at euery Tyde (the Sea beating ≈øtrongly on both ≈øides) it were in a continuall danger to be ≈øundred from the other part of the Ile. This place is called S. Michaelin the Vale, where (in former times) ≈øtood a Priory, or a Couent of religious per≈øons, the ruines whereof are at this day to be ≈øeene.

(8) The gouernment of this Ile, in nature and forme re≈øembles the other of Ier≈øey, of whom ≈øhall be ≈øaid. The people in their Originall and Language alike al≈øo, but in their cu≈øtomes and conditions they come neerer the ciuill fa≈øhions of the Engli≈øh. Other matters of moment I finde not worthy to be recorded.
It hath ten Pari≈øhes, and one Market-Towne, being al≈øo a Hauen, and is called S. Peters Port, built clo≈øe by the Peere, and Ca≈øtle Cornet.

div.head: IERSEY.
div.p: THe two Ilands Ier≈øey and Garn≈øey, being the onely remaines of the Dukedome of Normandie, that in former times many yeares together was in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and vnder the command of the Kings of England, annexing thereunto a large Territory and glorious title to the Crowne, are both ≈øeated in the Sea called Mare Britannicum, the Ocean parting them a good di≈øtant a≈øunder, and are now both adiuncts, and within the circuit of Hamp≈øhire. For the fir≈øt (being the I≈øle of Ier≈øey) it lyeth vpon the Briti≈øh Sea, hauing on the North parts the coa≈øts of Hamp≈øhire, and on the South the Country of Normandy.

(2) This Iland is long, not much vnlike the fa≈øhion of an Egge. It containes in length from Sentwon Poole vpon the We≈øt, to Mount Orguil Ca≈øtle on the Ea≈øt, ten miles, and in bredth from Dubon point to Plymount-bay ≈øix miles: the whole circuit of the Iland being thirtie eight miles‚ñ™ It is di≈øtant from a little Iland called Alderney, about foure leagues. It was in old time called Cae≈øaria; whether from Iulius Octanius, or any the other Cae≈øars that followed, is vnknowne. But the French-men haue by corruption of ≈øpeech long time called it Ier≈øey.

(3) It is a very delight≈øome and healthfull Iland, and giueth a plea≈øant a≈øpect vnto the Seas.
