It lyeth Southward not farre from a craggie ridge of rocks, which is much feared of the Mariners, and makes the pa≈ø≈øage that way very dangerous, howbeit it ≈øerues for a forcible defence again≈øt Pirats, or any ≈øtrangers that attempt inua≈øion, and they are termed Ca≈øquets.

(4) The Soile is very fertile, bringing forth ≈øtore of Corne and Cattle, but e≈øpecially of ≈øheepe, that are of rea≈øonable bigne≈ø≈øe, the mo≈øt of them bearing foure hornes a peece: Their wooll very fine and white, of which the Inhabitants make their Ier≈øey ≈øtockings, which are ordinarily to be had in mo≈øt parts of England, and yeeld a great commoditie vnto the Iland.

(5) The fir≈øt originall of the Inhabitants ≈øprung either from the Normans, or Britaines, or both.
They ≈øpeake French, though after a corrupt manner, and haue continued their names, language, cu≈øtomes, and Country, without any, or little intermixture, the≈øe many hundred yeares, hauing beene vnder the juri≈ødiction of the Engli≈øh euer ≈øince the vntimely and vnnaturall death of Robert Duke of Normandie, elde≈øt ≈øonne to William the Conquerour.

(6) The people of this Country liue very plea≈øantly, as well by the profits of the Land, as the helpes and furtherances of the Sea, that yeelds vnto them (and e≈øpecially in Summer ≈øea≈øon) great ≈øtore of fi≈øh, but principally Conger and Lob≈øters, the greate≈øt and fatte≈øt vpon the coa≈øt of England Wood is very ≈øcant, for their be≈øt fuell is Turffe: ≈øome Coale they haue brought vnto them, but it is very deare; ≈øtraw, furre, and ferne ≈øeruing their ordinary v≈øes. The middle part of the Iland hath many prety Hils ri≈øing in it, yeelding a delightfull obiect vnto the vallies, that receiue from one another a mutuall plea≈øure.

(7) The Gouernour of the Ile is the Captaine thereof, who appointeth certaine Officers vnder him: the principall of whom, carrieth the name and title of a Bailiffe, that in ciuill cau≈øes hath the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of twelue Iurats to determine of differences, and mini≈øter Iu≈øtice: in criminall matters ≈øeuen: in matters of rea≈øon and con≈øcience, fiue. Their twelue are cho≈øen out of the twelue Pari≈øhes: ≈øo that no man goeth further to complaine, then to his owne Iurate in ordinary Controuer≈øies; but matters of moment and difficultie are determined before the Bailiffe in a generall meeting.
(8) This Ile hath two little Ilands adiacent; the one S. Albons, the other Hillary Iland. It hath twelue Pari≈øhes, and foure Ca≈øtles. No other Monuments of name or note.

div.head: THE DESCRIPTION OF WALES. CHAPTER I.
div.p:
ANtiquitie hath auouched, that the whole I≈øle of Britaine was diuided into three parts‚ñ™ The fir≈øt and faire≈øt lay contained within the French Seas, the Riuers of Seuerne, Dee, and Humber, called then
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ oyger, which name yet it retaineth in W ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øh; in Engli≈øh called England. The ≈øecond part occupied all the land Northward from Humber, to the Orkney Sea, called by the Latines, Mare Caledonium, or Deucaledonium, now famou≈øly knowne by the name of Scotland. The third part was this, lying betwixt the Iri≈øh Seas, the Riuers Seuerne and Dee, and was called Cambria, which name doth yet continue with them, though we, the Engli≈øh, call it Wales, as the people Wel≈øhmen, which is ≈øtrange and ≈øtrangers; for ≈øo at this day the dwellers of Tyroll in the higher Germany, whence our Saxons are ≈øaid to haue come, doe name the Italian (their next neighbour) a Wel≈øhman, and his language Wel≈øh.

(2) This opinion Ver≈øtegan doth altogether contradict, rather iudging by the ancient Tentonicks tongue, which the Germans ≈øpake, and wherein the G. is pronounced for W. that the≈øe Saxons called them Galli≈øh from the Go ‚Ä¢ les, whence their originall proceeded, rather then Walli≈øh from ≈øtrangers: which he thinketh could not be, con≈øidering their habitations ‚Ä¢ o neere vnto them; and that the like was in v≈øe, he proueth by the words of French, Gardian for Wardian, Corangalles for „Äà‚óä„Äâ yea, and Galles for Wales, calling our mo≈øt famous Edward, Prince of Galles, not Prince of Wales; in≈øomuch that the County of Lombardy, bordering along vpon the Germans, was of them called Gallia
Ci≈ø-alpina, and at this day Wel≈øh-land. So likewi≈øe doe the Netherlanders call the Inhabitants of Henal ‚Ä¢
and Artois, Wallen or Wallons, and ≈øome parts of Braban ‚Ä¢
and Flander ‚Ä¢ , Wel≈øh-Braban ‚Ä¢ , and Wel≈øh-Flanders, and all becau≈øe of the language or lineage of the Gaules. Neither do the meere Natiues of Wales know any other name of their Country then Cambria, of them≈øelues, then Cambri or Cumri, or of their language then Cambraoc. But leauing this opinion free to his affection, we will proceed‚ñ™

(3) Wales therefore being anciently bounded as before, the Saxons did afterwards win by force from the Britaines, all the plaine and champion Country ouer the Riuer Dee; and e≈øpecially Offa King of Mercia, made their limits ≈øtraiter, by making a ditch of great bredth & depth, to be a Meere betwixt his Kingdome and Wales. This ditch is in many places to be ≈øeene at this day, and beares the name of Claw ‚Ä¢ Offa, that is, Offaes Ditch. The Country betweene it and England is commonly called the Marches, and is for the mo≈øt part inhabited by Wel≈øhmen, e≈øpecially in North-Wales, euen to the Riuer Dee. This admirable Trench began at Ba≈øsingwerke in Flint≈øhire, betweene Che≈øter and Ruthlan, and ran along the hils to the South Sea, a little from Bri≈øtow, reaching aboue an hundred miles in length.

(4) Silue≈øter Giraldus makes the Riuer Wye to be the Meare betweene England and Wales, on the South part, called South-Wales: whence he a≈øcribeth the breadth of Wales vnto Saint Dauids in Meneuia, to be an hundred miles; and the length from Caerleon vpon Vske in Gwentland, to Holly head in Angle≈øey, an hundred miles, he might haue ≈øaid thirtie more.

(5) About the yeare of Chri≈øt 870. our Alfred raigning in England, Rodericus Magnus King of Wales did diuide it into three, Talaiths, Regions, or Territories, which were called Kingdomes. This Rodericus Magn ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
gaue Venedotia, Gwineth or North-Wales, to Anarawd his elde≈øt ≈øonne; to Cadeth his ≈øecond ≈øonne, Demetia, Deheubarth or South-Wales; and to Meruin his third ≈øonne, Powys.

(6) North-Wales had vpon the North ≈øide, the Iri≈øh Sea, from the Riuer Dee at Ba≈øsingwerke to Aberdyni: vpon the We≈øt and South-We≈øt, the Riuer Dyni, which diuideth it from South-Wales, and in ≈øome places from Powysland. And on the South and Ea≈øt, it is diuided from Powys, ≈øometimes with high hils, and ≈øometimes with Riuers, till it come againe to the Riuer Dee. It is generally full of high mountaines, craggie rockes, great woods, and deepe vallies, many ≈øtraight dangerous places, deepe and ≈øwift Riuers.

(7) This Land was of old time diuided into foure parts, M√¥n, Aruon, Meryonyth, and y Berued ‚Ä¢
wlan, or the middle Country, and each of the≈øe were againe diuided into ≈øeuerall Cantrenes, and they ≈øubdiuided into their Cymeden or Commots, wherein we follow that diui≈øion which was in the time of Llewylyn ap Gruffin, la≈øt Prince of Wales, according to a Copie imparted to me by a wor≈øhipfull friend and learned Antiquarie, as ≈øeeming farre more exact then that of Doctor Powels.

(8) Angle≈øey the chiefe≈øt, is ≈øeparated from the maine Land with the Riuer „Äà‚óä„Äâ , wherein at Aberfraw was the Princes Court, now a meane village. In this Iland is a faire Towne called Beaumari≈øh, and a common pa≈ø≈øage to Ireland at Caergy ‚Ä¢ i, in Engli≈øh, Holly-head.

(9) Aruon, the ≈øecond part of North-Wales, is now called Carnaruon≈øhire, the ≈øtronge≈øt Country within that Principalitie, giuing place to none for fertilitie of the ground, of for plentie of Wood-Ca≈øtle, Fi≈øh, and Fowle, &c. Here are the Townes of Ca ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ naruon, in old time called Caer-Segon ‚Ä¢ , and Bangor the Bi≈øhops See, with diuers other ancient Ca≈øtles, and places of memory. This portion hath on the North, the Sea and Moena ‚Ä¢ ; vpon the Ea≈øt and South-ea≈øt, the Riuer „Äà‚óä„Äâ , which diuideth it from Denbigh-≈øhire: and on the South-we≈øt is ≈øeparated from Merioneth, by Riuers, Mountaines, and Meares.

(10) Merioneth was the third part of Gwyneth, and keepeth the name till this day: is full of hilles, and much noted for the re≈øort of people that repaire thither to take Hertings. Vpon the North it
hath Aruon and Denbigh-land; vpon the South, Caerdigan-≈øhire; and vpon the Ea≈øt, Montgomery-≈øhire, heretofore part of Powys. In this Countie ≈øtandeth the Towne of Harleth, and a great Lake called Ilyn Tegyd. This Country is likewi≈øe full of Cattle, Fowle, and Fi≈øh, and hath in it great ≈øtore of redde Deere and Roes, but there is much ≈øcarcitie of Corne.

(11) Y Beruedhwlad was the fourth part of Gwyneth, and may be called in Engli≈øh, The middle Country: is inclo≈øed with hilles, on the Ea≈øt, We≈øt, and South-parts, and with the Sea Northward. It is plentifull of Cattle, Fi≈øh, and Fowle, as al≈øo of Corne: and is diuided in the midde≈øt with the Riuer Clwyd, to which run a number of other Riuers from the hilles. In this part is Dyffryn Clwyd, the faire≈øt Valley within Wales, containing eighteene miles in length, and ≈øeauen in breadth. In which is the Towne and Ca≈øtle of Ruthlan, neere vnto the Sea; and not farre thence, S. A≈ø≈øaph, an Epi≈øcopall ≈øeat, betweene the Riuers Clwyd and Elwy. Herein ≈øtands the faire Towne and goodly Ca≈øtle of Denbigh, ≈øituated vpon a Rocke, the greate≈øt Market-Towne of North-Wales: and from thence is ≈øeene the Towne and Ca≈øtle of Ruthyn, faire for pro≈øpect, and fruitfull for ≈øite. This part of North-Wales, hath the Sea vpon the North; Dee toward the Ea≈øt; Aruon, the Riuer Conwey, and Merionyth vpon the We≈øt; and the Country then called Powys, vpon the South.
And the≈øe were the Meares and bounds of the foure parts of Venedotia, Gwyneth, or North-Wales.

(12) The ≈øecond Talaith or Kingdome, was Mathraual or Powys. To this belonged the Country of Powys, and the Land betweene Wye and Seuerne. It had South-Wales vpon the South and We≈øt, with the Riuers Wye and Tywy, and other Meares: vpon the North, Gwyneth; and vpon the Ea≈øt, the Marches of England, from Che≈øter to Wye, a little aboue Hereford. This part was diuided into Powis Vadoc, Powis betweene Wye and Seuerne, and Powis Wenwynwyn In Powis Vadoc is the Ca≈øtle of Holt in Bromefeild, and the Ca≈øtle of Chirke in Chirkeland; the Ca≈øtle likewi≈øe of Whittington; and Lord≈øhip of O≈øwe≈øtrie, with others.

(13) The ≈øecond part of Powis, or the Territory belonging to Mathraual, is Powis betweene Wye and Seuerne, (or Gwy and Hauren) whereof ≈øome is at this day in Montgomery-≈øhire, ≈øome in Radnor-≈øhire, and ≈øome in Brecknock-≈øhire; and among ≈øundry other, hath the≈øe Townes and Ca≈øtles following.

Montgomery: The Ca≈øtle of Clyn: The Towne of Knighton: The Ca≈øtle of Cymaron: Pre≈øteyn: The Towne and Ca≈øtle of Radnor, called in Wel≈øh, Mae≈øyuet, which is at this day the Shire-Towne: The Towne of Kinton, and the Ca≈øtle of Huntingdon.

(14) The third part belonging to Mathranal (chiefe ≈øeat of Powys, after the Wel≈øh were driuen from Pengwern or Shrewsburie) was Powys Wenwynwyn; a Country full of Woods, Hilles, and Riuers, hauing in it among others, the Townes of Wel≈øh-Poole, Newtowne, Machinhaeth Aru≈øtly was anciently in this part, but afterward it came to the Princes of Gwyneth.
This may ≈øuffice, for the de≈øcription of that which in old time was called Gwyneth and Powys.

(15) It now remaineth that we de≈øcribe the la≈øt kingdome of Wales, called Demetia, Deheubarth, or the Talaith of Dineuowr, which although it was the greate≈øt, yet was it not the be≈øt, becau≈øe it was much mole≈øted with Flemings and Normans, and for that al≈øo diuers parts thereof would not obey their Prince, as in Gwent, and in Morganw ‚Ä¢ .

(16) This was diuided into ≈øixe parts, of which Caerdigan was the fir≈øt, and is a Champion Countrey, without much Wood. It hath Merionyth-≈øhire on the North: part of Powys vpon the Ea≈øt: Carmarden-≈øhire and Pembroke-≈øhire, with the Riuer Tiu ‚Ä¢ , vpon the South: and vpon the We≈øt, the Iri≈øh Sea. In this part is the Towne of Caerdigan vpon Tiu ‚Ä¢ , not farre from the Sea; as al≈øo the Towne of Aber≈øtwyth vpon the Riuer I≈øtwyth; and Lhanbadarneuowr, which in times pa≈øt was a great Sanctuary: there were al≈øo many Ca≈øtles; as of Stratneyrie, of Walter, of Lhanry≈øted, of Dyuer ‚Ä¢ h, and of Aber Roydell, &c.

(17) The ≈øecond part was called Dyuet, and at this day Penbroke-≈øhire. It hath vpon the North and We≈øt, the Iri≈øh Sea; vpon the Ea≈øt, Carmarden-≈øhire; and vpon the South, Seuerne. There are in it ≈øundry Townes and Hauens: among others, the≈øe: Penbroke: Tenby: Hereford We≈øt, with the goodly and many branched Hauen of Milford, called in Wel≈øh, Aberdangledhett: S. Dauids, or Meneui ‚Ä¢ , which is the chiefe≈øt See in Wales: Fi≈øcard, called Aberwayn: and Newport, named Tre≈ødreth.
(18) The third part was Caermarden-≈øhire, which is a Country accounted the ≈øtronge≈øt part of all South-Wales: as that which is full of high Mountaines, great Woods, and faire Riuers.

(19) The fourth, called Morganwe, now Glamorgan-≈øhire, hath on the South, the Seuerne Sea, which diuideth it from Deuon≈øhire and Cornewall: vpon the We≈øt and North-we≈øt, Carmarden-≈øhire: vpon the North-ea≈øt, Breckneck-≈øhire; and vpon the Ea≈øt, Monmouth-≈øhire.

(20) The fift, now called Gwent, and in Monmouth-≈øhire, hath in it the ancient Citie of Caerlbeon vpon Vske. There are al≈øo diuers Townes and Ca≈øtles, Chep≈øtow, Glyn≈øtrygul, R ‚Ä¢ s, Tynterne vpon the Riuer Wye, &c. This is a faire and fertile Country. It hath on the We≈øt, Glamorgan and Brecknock-≈øhires: vpon the North, Hereford-≈øhire: vpon the Ea≈øt, Gloce≈øter-≈øhire: with the Riuer Wye and the Riuer Seuerne vpon the South and South-ea≈øt.

(21) The la≈øt is Brecknock-≈øhire, for the mo≈øt part full of Mountaines, Woods, and Riuers. This Country is both great and large, being full of faire plaines and vallyes for Corne: it hath plentie of the thicke Woods, Forre≈øts, and Parkes. It is full al≈øo of cleere and deepe Riuers, of which Seuerne is the chiefe≈øt; although there be other faire Riuers, as Vske and the like.

(22) Thus farre concerning the ancient Wel≈øh diui≈øion by Talaiths: but the pre≈øent diui≈øion di≈øtributeth them more compendiou≈øly into two Countries, and twelue Shires, enacted ≈øo by Parlament vnder King Henry the eight. The Countries are North-Wales and South-Wales, which haue ≈øhared,
and as it were deuoured betweene them, all Powysland; each of which Countries containes ≈øixe Shires.

div.p: But whereas Monmouth-≈øhire, and Radnor, were anciently parts, the fir≈øt of South-Wales, the other of Powys-land: Monmouth-≈øhire by Act of Parlament al≈øo vnder the ≈øame King, was pluckt away wholly from Wales, and laid to England, one of who≈øe Counties and Shires, it was from that time forward, and is at this pre≈øent reckoned; and Radnor-≈øhire (as it were in lieu thereof) is comprehended in South-Wales. Humphrey H ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ yd a Wel≈øh Gentleman, in his Epi≈øtle and Map of old Wales, maketh mention of a We≈øt-Wales, which he calleth Demetia and Dy≈øer, the one the Latine, and the other the Briti≈øh name thereof: but becau≈øe it is wholly ≈øwallowed vp by this la≈øt diui≈øion, we will not perplex the Reader with ≈øuperfluous and impertinent recitals.

div.head: PEMBROKE-SHIRE. CHAPTER II.
div.p: PEMBROKE-SHIRE, the furthe≈øt Promontory of all We≈øt-Wales, lieth parted on the North from Cardigan-≈øhire with the Riuers Ty ‚Ä¢ y and Keach; and on the Ea≈øt is confronted by Caermarden-≈øhire; the South and We≈øt ≈øhooting farre into the Iri≈øh Seas, is with the ≈øame altogether wa≈øhed.

(2) The forme thereof is longer then it is broad; for from S: „Äà‚óä„Äâ South-point to Cardigan-bridge in the North, are twentie-≈øixe miles; the Ea≈øterne Landenie to S. Dauids point in the We≈øt, are twentie miles; the whole in circumference is nintie three miles.

(3) The Aire is pa≈ø≈øing temperate, by the report of Giraldus, who confirmeth his rea≈øon from the ≈øite of Ireland, again≈øt which it butteth, and ≈øo neere adioyned, that King Rufus thought it po≈ø≈øible to make a Bridge of his Shippes ouer the Sea, whereby he might pa≈ø≈øe to Ireland on foot.

(4) Anciently it was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Demetia, further branched into Cardigan and Caermarden-≈øhires, as in that County hath beene ≈øaid, and in the Saxons Conque≈øt and Heptarchte, by the Britaines forced into tho≈øe parts for refuge, whither Henry the fir≈øt, and third of the Normans King, ≈øent certaine Flemings (who≈øe Country was ouer-whelmed with the breaking „Äà‚óä„Äâ of the Seas) to inhabite the maritine Tract called Ro≈ø≈øe, lying We≈øt vpon the Riuer Dougledye. The≈øs Dutchmen (≈øaith Giraldus) were a ≈øtrong and ≈øtout Nation, inured to Warres, and accu≈øtomed to ≈øeeke gaine by Clothing, Traffique, and Tillage, and euer readie for the Field to fight it out: adding withall, that they were mo≈øt loyall to the Engli≈øh, and mo≈øt faithfull to the Engli≈øh-men. Whereupon Malmesbury writeth thus: Many a time did King William Rufus a≈ø≈øaile the Wel≈øh, but euer in vaine: which is to be wondred at, con≈øidering
his other fortunate ≈øucce≈ø≈øe. But (≈øaith he) it may be the vneuenne≈ø≈øe of the ground, and ≈øharpne≈ø≈øe of the aire, that maintained their courage, and impeached his valour: which to redre≈ø≈øe, King Henry his brother found meanes; for tho≈øe Flemings, who in regard of his mothers kindred by the fathers ≈øide, ≈øorely pe≈øtred and endammaged the Engli≈øh, he ≈øent into Wales, both to purge and di≈øburden his owne Kingdome, and to quell and keepe backe the courage of his enemies. The≈øe men here ≈øeated, deceiued not his expectation, but ≈øo carried them≈øelues in his quarrell, that they ≈øeldome communicated with their neighbours, ≈øo that to this day they ≈øpeake not the Language, and the Country is yet called Little England beyond Wales.

(5) The commodities of this Shire are Corne, Cattle, Sea-Fi≈øh, and Fowle, and in Giraldus his dayes of ≈øaleable Wines, the Hauens being ≈øo commodious for Ships arriuage: ≈øuch is that at Tenby, and Milford, an Hauen of ≈øuch capacitie, that ≈øixteene Creekes, fiue Bayes, and thirteene Roades, knowne all by ≈øeuerall names, are therein contained, where Henry of Richmond, of mo≈øt happie memory arriued with ≈øignall hopes of Englands freedome from vnder the gouernment of an v≈øurping Tyrant.

(6) Neere vnto this is Pembroke the Shire-Towne ≈øeated, more ancient in ≈øhew then it is in yeares, and more hou≈øes without Inhabitants, then I ≈øaw in any one Citie thorowout my ≈øuruey. It is walled long-wi≈øe, and them but indifferent for repaire, containing in circuit eight hundred and foure≈øcore pa≈øes, hauing three Gates of pa≈ø≈øage, and at the We≈øt end a large Ca≈øtle, and locked-cau≈øey, that leads ouer the water to the decayed Priory of Monton. The ≈øite of this Towne is in the degree of Longitude, as Mercator doth mea≈øure, 14. and 55. minutes, and the eleuation from the North-pole in the degree of Latitude 52.

(7) A Citie as barren is old Saint Dauids, neither clad with Woods, nor garni≈øhed with Riuers, nor beautified with Fields, nor adorned vvith Meadowes, but lieth alwayes open both to winde and
≈øtormes. Yet hath it beene a Nur≈øery to holy men; for herein liued Calph ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rnius, a Britaine Prie≈øt, who≈øe wife was Concha, ≈øi≈øter to Saint Martin, and both of them the parents of Saint Patricke the Apo≈øtle of Ireland. Deus a mo≈øt religious Bi≈øhop, made this an Archiepi≈øcopall See, remoued from I≈ø ‚Ä¢ a Legionum. This the Britaines call Tuy Dewy, the hou≈øe of Deui; we Saint Dauids: a Citie with few Inhabitants; yet hath it a faire Cathedrall Church, dedicated to Saint Andrew and Dauid, in the midde≈øt of who≈øe Quire lieth intombed Edmund Earle of Richmond, father to King Henry the ≈øeuenth: who≈øe Monument (as the Prebends told me) ≈øpared their Church from other defacements, when all went downe vnder the hammers of King Henry the eight. About this is a faire wall, and the Bi≈øhops Palace all of free ≈øtone, a goodly hou≈øe I a≈ø≈øure you, and of great receit, who≈øe vncouered tops cau≈øe the curious workes in the walles daily to weepe, and them to feare their downefall ere long.

(8) But Monton the Priorie, and S. Dogmels, places of deuout pietie erected in this Countie, found not the like fauour, when the commi≈ø≈øion of their di≈ø≈øolutions came downe again≈øt them, and the axes of de≈øtruction cut downe the props of their walles.

(9) This Shire hath beene ≈øtrengthned with ≈øixteene Ca≈øtles, be≈øides two Block-hou≈øes, commanding the mouth of Mi ‚Ä¢ ford Hauen, and is ≈øtill traded in fiue Market-Townes, being diuided into ≈øeuen Hundreds, and in them ≈øeated one hundred fortie fiue Pari≈øh-Churches.

div.head: RADNOR-SHIRE. CHAPTER III.
div.p: RADNOR-SHIRE lieth bordered vpon the North with the County Monmouth; vpon the Ea≈øt toucheth Shrop≈øhire and Hereford≈øhire: the Riuers Clarwen and Wye diuide it from Breknock in the South: and the We≈øt part doth ≈øhorten point-wi≈øe into Caerdigan-≈øhire.

(2) The forme thereof is in proportion triangle, euery ≈øide almo≈øt containing a like di≈øtance: for from We≈øt to North are twentie miles; from North to South, twenty two miles; and from South to We≈øt are twentie foure miles: the whole in circumference extending to foure≈øcore and ten miles.
(3) The Aire thereof is ≈øharpe and cold (as mo≈øt of Wales is) for that the ≈ønow lyeth and la≈øteth long vnmelted vnder tho≈øe ≈øhadowing high Hils and ouer-hanging Rockes.

(4) The Soile is hungry, though not barren, and that in the Ea≈øt and South the be≈øt: the other parts are rough and churli≈øh, and hardly bettered by painfull labour; ≈øo that the riches of the North and We≈øt con≈øi≈øteth chiefly in the brood of Cattell.

(5) Anciently this County was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Silures, a „Äà‚óä„Äâ people, and great with≈øtanders of the Romans impo≈øitions, who had not onely them to fight again≈øt, „Äà‚óä„Äâ withall the vnacce≈ø≈øible Mountaines, wherewith this Shire is ≈øo ouerpre≈ø≈øed and burdened, „Äà‚óä„Äâ many times I feared to looke downe from the hanging Rockes, whereunder I pa≈ø≈øed into tho≈øe deep ‚Ä¢ and darke dales, ≈øeeming to me an entrance into Limbo. Among the≈øe (as ≈øay our Hi≈øtorians) that hatefull Prince to God and Man, Vortiger, his Countries ≈øcourge, and la≈øt M ‚Ä¢ narke of the Briti≈øh bloud, by fire from Heauen was con≈øumed with his ince≈øtuous wife, for whom „Äà‚óä„Äâ nameth the Country where „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Ca≈øtle ≈øtood, Guartiger-Maur,
of who≈øe rubbi≈øh the Ca≈øtle Guthremion was rai≈øed, as ≈øome are of opinion‚ñ™ Yet they of North-Wales will haue his de≈øtruction and Ca≈øtel to ≈øtand in their parts ‚Ä¢ eere vnto Beth-Kelleck, whereof we will further ≈øpeake in the relation of his life. Fatall was this place al≈øo to Llewellin the la≈øt Prince of the Briti≈øh Race, who being betrayed by the men of Duelth, fled into tho≈øe va≈øt Mountaines of Radnor, where by Adam Francton he was ≈ølaine, and his head (crowned with Iuy) ≈øet vpon the Tower of London.

Places mo≈øt worthy of note in this Shire, are as en≈øueth: The fir≈øt is Radnor, from whom the County receiueth her Name, anciently Magi, where the Commander of the Pacen≈øian Regiment lay, and thought to be the Magnos in Antonine the emperours Suruey. This Towne is plea≈øantly ≈øeated vnder a hill, whereon ≈øtandeth mounted a large & ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle, from who≈øe Bulwarke a Trench is drawne along the We≈øt of the Towne, whereon a wall of ≈øtone was once rai≈øed, as by the remaines in many places appeareth. This Trench doth likewi≈øe inuerge her We≈øt ≈øide ≈øo farre as the Riuer, but after is no more ≈øeene: who≈øe Graduation is ob≈øerued to haue the Pole eleuated for Latitude 52. degrees, and 45 minutes; and for L ‚Ä¢ ngitude, from the fir≈øt point of the We≈øt ≈øet by Mercator 17. degrees and one minute.

Pre≈øiayn for beautious building is the be≈øt in this Shire a Towne of Commerce, wonderfully frequented, and that very lately‚ñ™ Next is Knighton, a Market-Towne likewi≈øe, vnder which is ≈øeene the Clawdh-Offa, or „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ who≈øe tract for a ≈øpa ‚Ä¢ e I „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ along the edge of the Mountaine; which was a bound „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ the Wel≈øh from the Engli≈øh, by the Mercian King Offa: and by Egbert the Monarke a Law „Äà‚óä„Äâ , by the in≈øtigation of his Wife, that it ≈øhould be pre≈øent death for the Wel≈øh to pa≈ø≈øe ouer the ≈øame, as Iohn Beuer the Monke of We≈øtmin≈øter reporteth: and the like vnder Harald, as Ioha of Salisbury writeth; wherein it was ordained, that what Wel≈øh-man ≈øoeuer ≈øhould be found with any weapon on this ≈øide of that Limit, which was Offaes Ditch, ≈øhould haue his right
hand cut off by the Kings Officers. The fourth place for account is Raihader Gowy, who be≈øides the great fall of Wye with a continuall noi≈øe, hath her Markets there kept vpon the Sabbath, which I there ob≈øerued, and here note for an offence.

(7) Many Riuers ari≈øe and run thorow this Shire, which were it not that the hils ≈øo clu≈øter together, might make the ≈øoyle both fertile and fat. Such are Teme, Lug, Ithon, Clowdok, Dulas, Comarton, Somegill, Guithel, Arro, Machaway, Edway, Hawye, Eland, Clarwen and Wye, be≈øides other Loughs that ≈øtand betwixt the hilles.
This Shire is diuided into ≈øixe Hundreds, wherein are ≈øeated three Forre≈øts, foure Market-Townes, ≈øixe Ca≈øtles, and fiftie two Pari≈øh-Chrches.

div.head: BREKNOCK-SHIRE. CHAPTER IIII.
div.p: BREKNOCK-SHIRE, in the Briti≈øh language Brechineau, (≈øo called, as the Wel≈øhmen relate, of a Prince named Brechanius, the father of an holy off-≈øpring, who≈øe twentie foure daughters were all of them Saints) is a County neither very large, not greatly to be pray≈øed or di≈øliked of, who≈øe bounds vpon the North is parted from Radnor with the Riuers Clarwen and Wye: the We≈øt lieth butted vpon by Cardigan and Caermarden-≈øhires: the South is confined by Glamorgan; and the Ea≈øt with Monmouth and Radnor-≈øhire, is wholly bound.

(2) The length of this Shire from North to South, betwixt Llanuth ‚Ä¢
and I≈øtradgunies, are twentie eight Engli≈øh miles; and her bredth from Ea≈øt to We≈øt, extended betwixt Fentri≈ø≈øo and E ‚Ä¢ ywell, are twentie miles; the whole in circumference, about one hundred and two miles.

This County is full of hils, and vneuen for trauell, which on the South part mount in ≈øuch height, that as Giraldus hath written, They make the aire much colder, and defend the Country from the exce≈øsiue heat of the Sunne, whereby acertaine naturall whole „Äà‚óä„Äâ of aire maketh it mo≈øt temperate: and on the Ea≈øt ≈øide, the Mountaines of Edgar and Ewias doe as ‚Ä¢ were fore-fence the ≈øame. Among which, there ari≈øe and run ≈øo many fruite ≈øprings that their vallies are thereby made mo≈øt fertile, yeelding in plentie both Corne and Gra≈ø≈øe.

(4) The ancient Inhabitants and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors of this Shire, with the re≈øt in this South Tract, were the Silures, much ≈øpoken of, and gr ‚Ä¢ at oppo≈øites to the Romanes, who≈øe Countries were fir≈øt made ≈øubiect by Iulius Froutinus, who be≈øi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s the valour of the enemy, had to ≈øtruggle with the Mountaines and Straits, as Tacitus tels vs; neither any more hard, we may well ≈øay, then them of this Shire; whereof
one in the South, and three miles from Breknock, is of ≈øuch height and operation, as is vncredible: and were it not that I haue witne≈ø≈øe to affirme what I ≈øhall ≈øpeake, I ≈øhould blu≈øh to let the report thereof pa≈ø≈øe from my pen: In my perambulations in the≈øe parts, remaining in Breknock to ob≈øerue the ≈øite of that Towne, the Aldermen or chiefe Seniors thereof regarding my paines, with friendly and courteous entertainments at my departure, no le≈ø≈øe then eight of them, that had beene Bailiffes of the Towne, came to vi≈øit me; where they reported vpon their credit and trials, that from the top of that hill, in the Wel≈øh called Mounch-denny, or Cadier Arthur, they had oftentimes ca≈øt from them, and downe the North-Ea≈øt Rocke, their Cloakes, Hats, and Staues, which notwith≈øtanding would neuer fall, but were with the aire and winde ≈øtill returned backe, and blowne vp: neither, ≈øaid they, will any thing de≈øcend from that Cliffe being ≈øo ca≈øt, vnle≈ø≈øe it be ≈øtone or ≈øome metalline ≈øub≈øtance: affirming the cau≈øe to be the Clouds, which are ≈øeene to racke much lower then the top of that Hill. As ≈øtrange tales are told of the Meer Llyn≈øauathan, two miles by Ea≈øt from Breknock, which at the breaking of her frozen I ‚Ä¢ e, maketh a fearefull ≈øound like vnto thunder. In which place, as is reported, ≈øometimes ≈øtood afaire Citie, which was ≈øwallowed vp in an Earthquake, and re≈øigned her ≈øtone-wals vnto this deepe and „Äà‚óä„Äâ water: whither vnto this day leadeth all the wayes in this Shire: which, as le ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed Cambdin ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ctureth, might be that Louentrium, which Ptolemy in this tract placeth; and the mo≈øt confirmed „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ name adioyning, being al≈øo called Leuenny, which Riuer al≈øo pa≈ø≈øeth through this „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ the ≈øame ≈øtreame, and no greater then wherewith ≈øhe fir≈øt entred in.

(5) The Townes for Commerce, are Hay, Bealt, and Breknock, two of them vnfortunate of their former greatne≈ø≈øe, whom warres and ≈øedition haue defaced a ‚Ä¢ lea≈øt downe. Hay vpon Wye and Dulas, plea≈øant for ≈øituation, in the rebellion of Owen Glendower ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ was di≈øwalled, depopulated, and
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
burnt, in who≈øe foundations for new repaires, many Romane Coines haue beene found; and thereby thought to be the ≈øeate of their Legions: and Buelth, now Bealt, though of good frequencie, yet not ≈øo great as when Ptolemie ob≈øerued her po≈øition for graduation, who calleth it Buleum Silurum, neither when it with the Country was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by Aurelius Ambro≈øius, by who≈øe permi≈ø≈øion Pa≈øcentius the ≈øonne of Vortiger ruled all, as Ninius writeth; nor yet as of later times, when Leolin the la≈øt Prince of the Britaines, was therein betrayed and ≈ølaine.

(6) Breknock the Shire-Towne, for buildings and beautie retaineth a better regard, who≈øe walles in Ouall-wi≈øe are both ≈øtrong and of good repaire, hauing three Gates for entrance, with tenne Towres for defence, and is in circuit ≈øix hundred and fortiepaces about, vpon who≈øe we≈øt part a mo≈øt ≈øumptuous and ≈øtately Ca≈øtle is ≈øeated, the like whereof is not commonly ≈øeene, who≈øe decayes approaching doe increa≈øe her ruines daily, and in the end is feared will be her fall‚ñ™ This Towne is ≈øeated vpon the meeting of two Riuers, Houthy and Vske, who≈øe yearely gouernment is committed to two Bailiffes, fifteene Aldermen, two Chamberlaines, two Con≈øtables a Towne-Clerke, and two Sergeants their Attendants: hauing the Poles eleuation in 52‚ñ™ 21. minutes of Latitude, and for Longitude is placed in the 16. and 32. minutes, as the Mathematicians doe mea≈øure them.
(7) This Shire is ≈øtrengthned with ‚Ä¢ ine Ca≈øtles, diuided into ≈øixe Hundreds, wherein are ≈øeated three Market-Townes, and fiftie „Äà‚óä„Äâ Pari≈øh-Churches.

div.head: CARDIGAN-SHIRE. CHAPTER V.
div.p: CARDIGAN-SHIRE, (in the Wel≈øh called Sire Aber-Tiui) is parted on the North from Merioneth-≈øhire with the Riuer Doui; by the Plinillimon hilles from Montgomery-≈øhire in part of her Ea≈øt; and the re≈øt from Breknock-≈øhire, with the water Towy; and with Tyuy altogether on the South from Caermarden-≈øhire: the We≈øt is wholly wa≈øhed with the Iri≈øh Sea.

(2) The forme thereof is horne-like, bowing compa≈ø≈øe, long and narrow, and growing wider ≈øtill towards the North: ≈øo that from Cardigan, the Shire-Towne and vttermo≈øt point: in the South, vnto the Riuer Doui, her farthe≈øt North bounder, are thirtie two miles: and from the head of Carwen in the Ea≈øt, to Abery≈øthwyth on her We≈øt, the broade≈øt part in the Shire, are onely fifteene: the whole in circumference is one hundred and three miles.

(3) The Aire is open and ≈øomewhat piercing; the ≈øoyle is hillie, and (Wales-like) vneuen: yet more plaine and champion towards the Sea, then in the Ea≈øt or North of the Land. For be≈øides that great and high hill called Plinil ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ on, a continuall range of le≈ø≈øer doth ≈øhoote along, yeelding in their vallies both goodly rich Pa≈øtures, and very large Pooles, which being a≈ø≈øi≈øted with Springs from the Rockes, doe branch them≈øelues, as veines in the bod ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ make fruitfull their pa≈ø≈øages vnto the Sea. In Tyuy one of the≈øe, as Giraldus
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
Beauer hath beene found, a creature liuing both by land and water, who≈øe ≈øtones the „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ in great price. His fore-feete are like vnto a dogge, but the hinder whole skinne, as is the „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ the dogge-like ≈øerue him on ≈øhore for to run; and the Goo≈øe-like as Oraes giue him ≈øwift „Äà‚óä„Äâ in ≈øwimming: this taile broad and gri≈øtly, he v≈øeth as a ≈øterne, wherewith on the ≈øudden „Äà‚óä„Äâ diuert his ≈øwift floating cour≈øe.
But this creature in the≈øe parts a long time hath not beene ≈øeene, who≈øe roome we may well ≈øay the Salmon hath po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, who ≈øtill coueting into fre≈øh water Riuers, at their downe-right falles v≈øeth this policie: He bendeth him≈øelfe backward, and taketh his taile in his mouth, and with all his ≈øtrength vnloo≈øing his circle on the ≈øudden (as a lath let goe) mounteth vp before the fall of the ≈øtreame; whereupon ≈øuch water-falles are called the Salmons leape: and in the≈øe Riuers many ≈øuch Salmons are caught.

(4) The commodities of this Shire chiefly con≈øi≈øt in Cattle, Sea-≈øowle, and Fi≈øh; Corne ≈øufficient, but of Woods ≈øome ≈øcarcitie: and at the head of I≈øtwyd are certaine veines of Lead, a merchandize of no meane regard or wealth.

(5) The ancient people that po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed this Prouince, were the Dimetae, by Ptolemie branched thorow the Tracts of Caermarden, Penbrooke, and this Shire; who in their ≈øtruglings again≈øt the Romans, did not a little relie vpon Caractacus their mo≈øt warlike King, (from who≈øe name, though vnlikely, ≈øome will haue the Shire called Cardigan) yet la≈øtly felt the fortune of ≈øubiection with the re≈øt, when Iulius Frontinus warred with the≈øe Mountaines. Scarce had the Normans ≈øetled their Kingdome in Britaine, but that they a≈ø≈øailed this Countie, as well to enioy ≈øo farre a Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, as to ≈øecure tho≈øe Seas from any inua≈øion again≈øt them: ≈øo that Rufus fir≈øt wre≈øted from the Wel≈øhmen the maritime Coa≈øts, and Henry the fir≈øt gaue the whole Countie to Gilbert de
„Äà‚óä„Äâ .

(6) This Gi ‚Ä¢ bert fortified „Äà‚óä„Äâ the Shire-Towne, with a Wall and ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle, who≈øe aged lineaments doe to this day „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ indu≈øtry both of nature and Art: for the Towne is ≈øeated vpon a ≈øteepe banke, her South „Äà‚óä„Äâ guarded with the deepe Riuer Tyny, and pa≈ø≈øable no way but by a bridge vnder the Ca≈øtle. They „Äà‚óä„Äâ taketh the aduantage of the ri≈øing rocks, and circulate the Towne euen round about. The Ca≈øtle is ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ gher built vpon a Rocke, both ≈øpatious and faire, had not ≈øtormes impaired her beautie, and time „Äà‚óä„Äâ her carka≈ø≈øe a very Anatomie. The walles range as thou ≈øee≈øt,
and are indifferent for repaire, hauing three wayes for entrance, and containe in compa≈ø≈øe ≈øix hundred and foure≈øcore pa≈øes: who≈øe po≈øition for Latitude is ≈øet in the degree 52. 33 minutes from the North-pole, and for Longitude from the fir≈øt We≈øt-point by Mercator, in the degree 15. and 10. minutes.

(7) This Shire, as it is little in circuit, ≈øo accordingly is be≈øprinkled with Towne-≈øhips, whereof foure onely haue the trade of Markets: neither finde I other remembrance of religious foundations, but at Cardigan, I≈øtradfleet, and at Llan-Badern-Vaur, where ≈øometimes was ≈øeated an Epi≈øcopall See, which (as Houeden writeth) was decayed many yeares ≈øince, when the people had wickedly ≈ølaine their Pa≈øtour. And yet Llan-Deui-breui, built, and ≈øo called in memory of the mo≈øt famous Dauid Bi≈øhop of Meneura, was in great e≈øteeme, where in a frequent Synod there holden, he refuted the Pelagian Here≈øie, ≈øprung vp againe in Britaine, both by the authoritie of holy Scripture, and al≈øo by miracle, as is reported, while the earth whereon he ≈øtood and preached, ro≈øe vp vnto a certaine height vnder his feet‚ñ™

(8) The Shires diui≈øion, for bu≈øine≈ø≈øes belonging either to the Crowne or Common-wealth, is into fiue Hundreds, wherein are ≈øeated for „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , and ≈øixtie foure Pari≈øh-Churches for Gods diuine and daily ≈øeruice.

div.head: CAERMARDEN-SHIRE. CHAPTER VI.
div.p: CAERMARDEN-SHIRE, ≈øo called from the chiefe Towne Caermarden, lieth bordered vpon the North with Cardigan-≈øhire; vpon her Ea≈øt, by Brecknock and Glamorgan-≈øhires; vpon the South, with a Bay of the Briti≈øh Seas; and vpon the We≈øt with Pembroke-≈øhire.

(2) The forme of this County is long, and ≈øhooteth it ≈øelfe from the South-we≈øt into the North and by-Ea≈øt, betwixt who≈øe furthe≈øt bounds are thirtie fiue Engli≈øh miles, and in her broade≈øt part twentie miles; the whole in circumferance about one hundred and two miles.

(3) This Shire is not altogether ≈øo pe≈øtred with hils as her bordering neighbours are: and tho≈øe that ≈øhe hath, neither ≈øo high nor ≈øo thicke, and therefore is better for Corne and Pa≈øturage, yea and in Woods al≈øo, ≈øo that for victuals this Countie is very well ≈øtored, which the ≈øtomacke doth as well di≈øge≈øt, the aire being whole≈øome, temperate, and plea≈øing‚ñ™

(4) Anciently the≈øe parts were po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Di ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tree, as Ptolemie, Gildas, and Ninius doe name them: though Plinie holds opinion that they were part of the Silures, with whom no doubt they were ≈øubdued to the Romans yoke by „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , when he ≈øtruggled with the rockie hils in tho≈øe Southerne parts And this Countie is „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ by Writers to be the very ≈øtrength of South Wales. In the We≈øt thereof, at Kilman ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
(as it „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øeeme) their Legions kept, where lately an earthen Po ‚Ä¢ hoarded with ≈øtore of „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Coines, was by the ≈øpade digged vp, being ≈øtamped vpon imba≈øed ≈øiluer, from the time of Co ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ odus vnto the fir≈øt Tribune≈øhip of Gordian the third, which fell in the yeare of Chri≈øt two hundred ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tie three: and among≈øt the≈øe were the Coines of Heluins Pertinax, Marcu ‚Ä¢ Opellius, Antonius Di ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ menianus, Iulius Verus Maximus, the ≈øonne of Maximu ‚Ä¢ , of Calius
Balbinus, of Clodius Pupienus, of Aquilta Senera, the wife of Helingaba ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , and of Sall-Barbia Orbi ‚Ä¢
na, peeces rarely found.

(5) The commodities of this Shire chiefly con≈øi≈øt in Cattle, Pit-coale, Fowle, and Sea-fi≈øh, whereof the Salmon is common among them, and that of ≈øuch greatne≈ø≈øe and plentie, as no place is better furni≈øhed therewith then the Shire-Towne Caermarden is.

(6) Which Towne by Ptolemie is called Maridunum; by Antonius the Empe ‚Ä¢ our, M ‚Ä¢ ridunum; by the Britaines, Caer-fridhin; and by vs, Caermarden. It is plea≈øantly ≈øeated vpon the South-we≈øt ≈øide of the Riuer Touy, that runneth thorow the midde≈øt of this Shire, and falleth South from hence into the Briti≈øh Sea, where before times was a conuenient Hauen for Ships „Äà‚óä„Äâ , but now is ≈øore pe≈øtred with Sands and Shelfes: notwith≈øtanding ≈øome ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels a≈øcend vp the Riuer, euen vnto the Bridge of this Towne, which is fairely built of free-≈øtone. And ouer the ≈øame, vpon a hanging Rocke, ≈øtandeth a very large Ca≈øtle, from who≈øe ≈øtone-wall another intermingled with bricke rangeth about the Towne, being in circuit one thou≈øand and foure hundred pa≈øes. The Inhabitants of this place doe not a little glory of their Merlin who (at they ≈øay) was therein borne, the ≈øonne of a bad Angell, or of an Incubus ≈øpirit, the „Äà‚óä„Äâ great Apollo, whom Geffrey ap Arthur would ranke with the South ≈øaying Seer, or rathe ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ true Prophets them≈øelues; being none other then a meere Seducer and phanta≈øticall Wizard. „Äà‚óä„Äâ how≈øoeuer Alani de In≈øulis in his Commentaries hath labourered to vnlocke tho≈øe darke and hidden „Äà‚óä„Äâ , wherewith his booke is pe≈øtred and full, yet was it not without cau≈øe forbid the reading by „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Councell of Trent, as vaine, and not worthy of countenance or credit.

At the entrance of the Normans, this Towne was brought vn ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ their obedience, and for a long time was di≈øtre≈ø≈øed with the calamities of warre, yet afterwards it is made by the Engli≈øh Princes the Chaucdry and Exchequer for all South-Wales: and at this day is yearely gouerned by a Maior, who
euer after is an Alderman and Iu≈øtice of the Peace, two Sheriffes elected out of ≈øixteene Burge≈ø≈øes, all of them in skarlet, a Sword-bearer, a Towne-Clerke, and two Sergeants with Maces: from whence the Pole is rai≈øed 52. degrees 15. minutes in Latitude, and for Longitude is in the degree 15. and 30. minutes from the fir≈øt point in the We≈øt, according to Mercator.

(7) Ea≈øt from this place are the ruines of Carreg-Ca≈øtle, which ≈øtood mounted on a high hill, vnder the which many vaults and ≈øpacious Caues farre into the ground are ≈øeene, wherein is thought the people vnable to fight, were therein ≈øecured in time of their Warres. Where al≈øo is a Well (take the report from Giraldus, who writeth it) that in this place twice in foure and twentie houres ebbing, and twice flowing, re≈øembleth the vn≈øtable motions of the maine Sea.

(8) This Shire is watered with twentie eight Riuers and Riuerets of name, ≈øtrengthned with ten Ca≈øtles, traded in ≈øixe Market-Townes, diuided into ≈øixe Hundreds, wherein are ≈øeated foure≈øcore and ≈øeauen Pari≈øh-Churches.

div.head: GLAMORGAN-SHIRE. CHAPTER VII.
div.p: GLAMORGAN-SHIRE, as ≈øome thinke, named from Prince Morgan the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor thereof, or according to others, is taken from Morgan an Abbey, founded by William Earle of Gloce≈øter, vpon the Sea-≈øhoare in the South of this Shire, lyeth bounded vpon that part altogether with the Briti≈øh Sea; the We≈øt by Loghor, is parted from Caermarden-≈øhire; the North butteth vpon the Countie of Brekn ‚Ä¢ ck; and the Ea≈øt by Remney is diuided from Monmouth.

(2) The forme of this Shire groweth ≈øtill wider from her We≈øt-point, ≈øpreaking her broade≈øt touch in the Ea≈øt, betwixt which extreames I finde by mea≈øure to be well-neere fortie Engli≈øh miles, and from North to South, not altogether twentie miles: the whole in circumference, about one hundred and twelue miles.

(3) The aire is temperate, and giues mo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ntent to the minde, then the ≈øoile doth fruit or ea≈øe vnto Trauellers. The hils being high and „Äà‚óä„Äâ , which from the North notwith≈øtanding are le≈ø≈øened as it were by degrees; and towards „Äà‚óä„Äâ Sea-coa≈øts, the Country becommeth ≈øomewhat plaine, which part is the be≈øt both for plentie ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Graine, and populous of Inhabitants. The re≈øt all Mountaine, is repleni≈øhed with „Äà‚óä„Äâ which is the be≈øt meanes vnto wealth that this Shire doth affoord; vpon who≈øe Hils you may ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ hold whole Heards of them feeding; and from who≈øe Rockes, mo≈øt cleare ≈øpringing waters „Äà‚óä„Äâ the vallies trickling, which ≈øportingly doe pa≈ø≈øe with a mo≈øt plea≈øant ≈øound, and did not a little „Äà‚óä„Äâ my wearied ≈øpirits among tho≈øe va≈øt Mountaines, imployed in their ≈øearch: who≈øe infancie at fir≈øt admitted an ea≈øie ≈øtep ouer; but growne vnto ≈øtrength, more boldly forbade me ≈øuch pa≈ø≈øage, and with a more ≈øterne countenance held on their iourney vnto the Briti≈øh Seas: and Taue among the≈øe is accounted for a chiefe.

(4) Vpon who≈øe fall, and Ea≈øt-banke, the faire≈øt Towne of all South-Wales is ≈øeated the „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Caerdid, the Engli≈øh Caerdiffe, which Fitz-Haimon fortified with a Wall and Ca≈øtle, in the raigne of King Rufus, when he and his Norman Knights had ouercome Rhe≈øe the Prince of the≈øe parts, and thru≈øt out Ie≈øtine from his lawfull po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. This Towne he made his owne Seat and Court of Iu≈øtice, enioyning his Con≈øorts to giue ayde to this honour, and to hold their portions in va≈ø≈øallage of him. Strong was the Ca≈øtle, as by the tru≈øt therein repo≈øed may well appeare, where the younge≈øt brother Beautlark kept captiue the elde≈øt Curtho≈øe, both of them ≈øonnes to the Conquerour, the ≈øpace of twentie ≈øixe yeares. This Ca≈øtle is large, and in good repaire, whence the Towne-wall went both South and Ea≈øt to the Riuers ≈øide, thorow which, foure Gates enter into the foure windes, and containe in compa≈ø≈øe nine hundred and twentie pa≈øes; and along the Riuer (a ≈øure defence) vpon her We≈øt ≈øide, three hundred more; ≈øo that the Towne containeth in circuit twelue hundred and foure≈øcore pa≈øes. But as the Taue is a friend to the Towne, in making a Key for arriuage of ≈øhipping; ≈øo is ≈øhe a foe to S. Maries Church in the South, with vndermining her foundations, and threatning her fall. The Towne is gouerned by a Maior, yearely elected out of twelue Aldermen, a≈ø≈øi≈øted with other twelue Burge≈ø≈øes, a Towne-Clerke, foure C ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øtables, and two Sergeants with Maces: who≈øe ≈øite is ob≈øerued from the North-Starre to lie in the degree of Latitude, 51. and 49. ≈øcruples; and from the fir≈øt point in the We≈øt, 16. and 53 ≈øcrup ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ .

(5) In the ≈øame graduation almo≈øt is ≈øited the ‚Ä¢ itie Landaf, wherein is a Ca≈øtle and Cathedrall Church, dedicated to S. Telean, Bi≈øhop of the ≈øame, without any other memorable matter worthy the ≈øpeaking of.

(6) But things of ≈øtrange note are the≈øe, by the report of
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ aldus, who affirmeth that in a Rocke or Cliffe vpon the Sea ≈øide, and Iland Barry, lying neere the South- ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øt point of this County, is beard out of a little Chinke (let him take heed what he ≈øaith) the noi≈øe as it „Äà‚óä„Äâ of Smiths at their worke; one whiles
the blowing of Bellowes to increa≈øe the heat, then the ≈øtroakes of the Hammer, and ≈øound of the „Äà‚óä„Äâ ; ≈øometimes the noi≈øe of the Grind-≈øtone in grinding of Iron tooles; then the hi≈øsing ≈øparkes of Steele-gads, as they flie from their beating, with the puffing noi≈øe of flames in a Furnace. And whether this is the place whereof Clemens Alexandrinus ≈øpeaketh, I determine not; where in his writings he hath the≈øe words: They that haue recorded Hi≈øtories (≈øaith he) doe ≈øay that in the Ile of Britaine, there is a certaine Hole or Ca ‚Ä¢ e vnder the bottome of an Hill, and on the top thereof a gaping Chinke, into the which when the winde is gathered, and to≈ø≈øed to and fro ‚Ä¢ in the wombe or concauitie thereof, there is heard aboue, a ≈øound of Cymbals: for the winde being driuen backe from his hole, is forced to make a loud ≈øound at her vent.

(7) More We≈øtward from hence, vpon the Riuer Ogmore, and neere vnto Newton, in a ≈øandie plaine about an hundred pa≈øes from Seuerne, there ≈øpringeth a Well, though not of the cleare≈øt water, where at the flowing and fulne≈ø≈øe of the Sea, can hardly any water be gotten; but at the ebbe and fall of tyde it walloweth vp amaine. The cau≈øe may be, as Polybius reports of the like at Cadys; Wherein the windie ayre, when it is depriued of his wonted i≈ø≈øues, forcibly returneth, ≈øhutting and ≈øtopping vp the pa≈ø≈øages and veines of the Spring, whereby „Äà‚óä„Äâ waters are kept in. But contrariwi≈øe, when the ≈øurface thereof is void and emptie of water, the vein ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ of the Source or Spring are vn≈øtopped and ≈øet free, which then boileth vp in great abundance.

(8) And vpon the ≈øame ≈øhoare more „Äà‚óä„Äâ and by We≈øt, on the top of a hill called Minyd-Margan, is erected a Monument in≈øcribed wit ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øtrange Character, and as ≈øtrange a conceit held thereof by the by-dwellers, who≈øe opinions are po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, that if any man reade the ≈øame, he ≈øhall ≈øhortly after die.

This Shire, as it is the furthe≈øt „Äà‚óä„Äâ of South-Wales, and lay open to forraine inua≈øion; ≈øo was is fortified with twentie-fiue ≈øtronge. Ca≈øtles, whereof times and ≈øtormes haue deuoured the mo≈øt: ≈øuch were Barry, Saint Doneitis, Den ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ owis, Morla≈øhe, Mene≈ø ‚Ä¢ e, Logho ‚Ä¢ , Llanddeny, Llanquian, Oxwich,
Oy≈øtermouth, Ognior, Pile, Porkery, Pe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ arth, Win≈øton, Newca≈øtle, Caerfly, Coche, Peullys, „Äà‚óä„Äâ , Kenfeage, Talla ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , Treer and Cothy.

Neither was the Countie ≈øo ill ≈øeated for ≈øufficiency of life, or barren of graine, but that therein were planted places for diuine pietie: ≈øuch were Neath, Margan, and Caerdif, be≈øides the Epi≈øcopall See of Landa ‚Ä¢ : which la≈øt ≈øtill remaineth; the other three ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed among the fall of their like, vnder King Henry the eight.
This Shire is diuided into ten Hundreds, wherein are ≈øeated ≈ø≈øixe Market-Townes, and one hundred and eighteene Pari≈øh-Churches.

div.head: MONMOVTH-SHIRE. CHAPTER VIII.
div.p: MONMOVTH-SHIRE, from Monmouth Towne, and that from Mounowe-water bearing name, is altogether inclo≈øed on the North, and is ≈øeparated from Hereford-≈øhire with the ≈øame Riuer, vpon the Ea≈øt both it and Wye diuides this County from Gloce≈øter-≈øhire. The South-≈øide wholly is wa≈øhed by the Seuerne Sea; and ≈øome of her We≈øt part by Rempney is parted from Glamorgan, and the re≈øt lyeth bordered vpon by Breknock-≈øhire.

(2) The forme thereof is Scallop-wi≈øe, both long and broad, ≈øhooting her North point to Llantony, and her South to the fall of Rempney, betwixt which two are twentie foure Engli≈øh miles: and from Chep≈øtowe Ea≈øt, to Blanagwent We≈øt, are not altogether nineteene miles: the whole in circuit draweth ≈øomewhat neere to ≈øeauentie ≈øeauen miles.

(3) The Ayre is temperate, healthfull an ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ , the ≈øoile is hilly, wooddy and rich, all places fruitfull, but no place barren. The Hils are „Äà‚óä„Äâ vpon by Cattle and Sheepe, the Vallies are laden with Corne and Gra≈ø≈øe, neuer vngratefull of „Äà‚óä„Äâ bandmans paines, nor makes fru≈øtrate his hope of expected increa≈øe; who≈øe ≈øprings abundantly ‚Ä¢ ≈øing in this Countie with many ≈øtreames, doe fatten the ≈øoile euen from ≈øide to ≈øide.

(4) Anciently the Sil ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ es inhabited this Shire, who≈øe chiefe Citie by the Emperour Antonine is named Venta Silarum, by the Wel≈øh Caer-went, and was by Tath ‚Ä¢
the Briti≈øh Saint, made an Academi ‚Ä¢ , and a diuine place for wor≈øhip. So like wi≈øe Caer-lion now, once I≈øca, was, where the ≈øecond Roman Legion called Augu≈øta lay, as by their Coines, Altars, Tables, and In≈øcriptions there found, and daily therein digged vp, doth euidently appeare.

By the report of Giraldus, in this Citie was the Court of great Arthur, whither the Romane Emba≈ø≈øadours re≈øorted vnto him, and as Alexander El≈øebin≈øis writeth, therein was a Schoole of two hundred Philo≈øophers, skilfull in A≈øtronomie and other Arts. Which is the more credible, for that A ‚Ä¢ phibalus, S. Albans in≈øtructer, was therein borne, and Iulius and Aaron, two noble Proto-Martyrs of great Britaine, in this Citiereceiued the Crowne of Martyrdome, where their bodies were al≈øo interred. But as all things finde their fatall period, ≈øo this Citie for beautie, circuit, and magnificall re≈øpect is laid in the ruines of her owne decay; neither may any more lament the lo≈ø≈øe of glory then Munmouths Ca≈øtle, which captiue-like doth yeeld to conquering Time. Her downe-ca≈øt ≈øtones from tho≈øe lo≈øtie turrets, doe ≈øhew what beautie once it bare, ≈øtanding mounted round in compa≈ø≈øe, and within her wals another mount, whereon a Towre of great height and ≈øtrength is built, which was the birth-place of our Conquering Henry, the great Triumpher ouer France, but now decayed, and from a Princely Ca≈øtle, is become no better then a regardle≈ø≈øe Cottage. In this Towne a beautifull Church built with three Iles is remaining, and at the Ea≈øt end a mo≈øt curiou≈øly built (but now decayed) Church ≈øtands, called the Monkes- „Äà‚óä„Äâ In the Mona≈øtery whereof, our great Antiquarie Geffrey, ≈øurnamed Munmouth, and Ap
„Äà‚óä„Äâ his Hi≈øtory of Great Britaine ‚Ä¢
who≈øe paines as they were both learned and great, ≈øo „Äà‚óä„Äâ bred great paines among the learned both to defend and to di≈øproue. The Townes ≈øituation is plea≈øant and good, ≈øeated betwixt the Riuers Monnowe and Wye: three Gates yet ≈øtand, be≈øides that Tower or Locke of the Bridge, and a Trench or tract of wall running betwixt the ‚Ä¢ on each ≈øide downe to the Riuer, containing in circuit about eight hundred paces. The Towne is „Äà‚óä„Äâ good repayre, and well frequented, gouerned by a Maior, two Bailiffes, fifteene Common Councellers, a Towne-Clerke, and two Sergeants for their Attendance. It is in Latitude remoued from the Equator 52. degrees and 8. minutes, and from the We≈øt point of Longitude is ≈øet in the degree 17. 36. minutes.

Religious Hou≈øes erected and ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed in this Shire, for greate≈øt account haue beene in C ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶
‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ on, Chep≈øtow, Gold-cliffe, Munmouth and Llantony; which la≈øt ≈øtood ≈øo ≈øolitary, and among hils, that the Sunne was not ≈øeene to ≈øhine there, but onely betwixt the houres of one and three.

This Shire is ≈øtrengthened with fourteene Ca≈øtles, traded with ≈øix Market-Townes, diuided into ≈øix Hundreds, wherein are ≈øituated one hundred twentie and ≈øeauen Pari≈øh-Churches, and is not accounted among the Wel≈øh-≈øhires, being ≈øubdued by Henry the ≈øecond, who pa≈ø≈øing the Naut Pen-carne, a ≈ømall Brooke and of no danger, yet held fatall by the Wel≈øh, ouer credulous to a Prophecy of Merlin Silue≈øter the Briti≈øh Apollo, who had fore≈øhewed that when a-≈øtout and frecled fac'd King (≈øuch as Henry was) ≈øhould pa≈ø≈øe ouer that Ford, then the power of the Wel≈øhmen ≈øhould be brought vnder; whereby their ≈øtout courage was ≈øoone abated, and the whole Countie the ≈øooner in ≈øubiection to the Engli≈øh.

div.head: MOVNTGOMERY-SHIRE CHAPTER IX.
div.p: MOVNTGOMERY-SHIRE, in the Briti≈øh ≈øpeech called „Äà‚óä„Äâ , and that of the principall Towne Mountgomery, lyeth bounded vpon the North with Denbigh-≈øhire, vpon the Ea≈øt with Shrop-≈øhire, on the South with Ra ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ or and Cardigan-≈øhires, and on the We≈øt with Merioneth-≈øhire.

(2) In forme it ≈øomewhat re≈øembleth a Peare or Pine-apple, as it were growing out of the We≈øt, and ri≈øing thence with many high Hilles and plentifull Spring ‚Ä¢ which water and make fruitfull the Soyle query where‚ñ™ who≈øe ≈øearching rilles with a longing de≈øire ha≈øte euer forward to finde an increa≈øe, and to „Äà‚óä„Äâ thei ‚Ä¢ growth into a bigger body whereof the S ‚Ä¢ uerne is the chiefe and the ≈øecond Riuer in the Land: who≈øe head ri≈øing from the ≈øpired mountaine Plymillimon, runneth not farre without the receits of other riuer ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ into her ≈øtreame, and with many wings doth ≈øpore her ≈øelfe thorow all the Ea≈øt part of this Shire.

(3) That this Riuer tooke her name from „Äà‚óä„Äâ , the beautifull „Äà‚óä„Äâ daughter of „Äà‚óä„Äâ begotten out of wedlock vpon E≈øtrildi ‚Ä¢
the daughter of „Äà‚óä„Äâ the „Äà‚óä„Äâ King, ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rinuaded this Land, and both of them drowned in this Riuer by Guen ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ lena King „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ uiuing widow: let „Äà‚óä„Äâ
relate, and Poets enlarge, whereof one among them in good account, thus writeth:
‚ÄîIn „Äà‚óä„Äâ pracipitatur Abren,
Nomen Abren „Äà‚óä„Äâ de Virgine, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
„Äà1 line„Äâ
Into this ≈øtreame faire Abren head-long ca≈øt,
Gaue name of Abren to tho≈øe waters wa≈øt,
Corruptly call'd Sabrina now at la≈øt.

(4) This Riuer maketh the Ea≈øt part of this Shire for fruitfulne≈ø≈øe to be compared with mo≈øt of the Land, and to exceed any other Shire in Wales: the We≈øt ≈øide is more hilly and le≈ø≈øe inhabited, yet ≈øurely tho≈øe mountaines breed innumerable of Cattle, e≈øpecially of hor≈øes, who≈øe portraiture for making and incomparable ≈øwiftne≈ø≈øe, Giraldus Cambren≈øis Arch-deacon of Breknocke doth greatly commend.

(5) The ancient Inhabitants that were ≈øeated in Gwineth and Powi≈øland, whereof this Shire was a part, were to the Romanes knowne by the name of ORDOVICES, a pui≈ø≈øant and couragious Nation, who≈øe hearts and hilles held them the longe≈øt free from the yoke of ≈øubiection, either of the Romans or Engli≈øh. for vnto the dayes of Domitian, they kept plea with the Romans,
„Äà‚óä„Äâ were not brought to the will of the Engli≈øh before the raigne of King Edward the fir≈øt. Tho≈øe ORDOVICES inhabited the Counties of Mountgomery, Merioneth, Caer ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , Denbigh, and Fl ‚Ä¢ t, which are of vs called now North-Wales, a people generous and of affable ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ , goodly for feature, faire of complexion, couragious of minde, courteous to ≈øtrangers, and that which is mo≈øt commendable, mo≈øt true and loyall to the Engli≈øh Crowne.

Townes for Trades and commerce in this Countie are fix the chiefe≈øt thereof and Shire-Towne is Mountgomery, very whole≈øome for ayre, and plea≈øant for ≈øituation, vpon an ea≈øie a≈øcent of an hill, and vpon another farre higher mounted, ≈øtands a faire and well-repaired Ca≈øtle, from the Ea≈øt Rocke whereof, the Towne hath beene walled, as by ≈øome part yet ≈øtanding, and the tract and trench of the re≈øt euen vnto the North-≈øide of the ≈øaid Ca≈øtle, may euidently be ≈øeene: who≈øe graduation for
Latitude is placed in the degree 53. and for Longitude 17. the lines cutting each other in the ≈øite of this Towne.

This Towne hath lately receiued the honour and Title of an Earledome, whereof Philip Herbert the ≈øecond ≈øonne of Henry Earle of Pembroke, was created the fir≈øt, in Anno 1605. And the Shire diuided into ≈øeauen Hundreds, wherein are ≈øeated ≈øixe Market-Townes, and fortie ≈øeauen Pari≈øh-Churches.

div.head: MERIONETH-SHIRE. CHAPTER X.
div.p: MERIONETH-SHIRE, which the Britaines call Sira-Verieneth, and in Latine Mer ‚Ä¢ inia; is bordered vpon the North by Carnar ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ on and Denbigh-≈øhires, vpon the Ea≈øt with Mongomery, vpon the South by the Riuer Dowy, is parted from Cardigan-≈øhire, and the We≈øt ≈øide altogether wa≈øhed with the Iri≈øh Seas, who≈øe rage with ≈øuch vehemency beateth again≈øt her bankes, that it is thought and ≈øaid, ≈øome quantitie of the Land hath beene ≈øwallowed vp by tho≈øe Seas.

(2) In forme this Shire ≈øomewhat re≈øembleth a Wel≈øh-Harpe, though ≈ømall is the Mu≈øicke that to her Inhabitants ≈øhe makes, being the roughe≈øt, and mo≈øt vnplea≈øant to ≈øee to (as Giraldus their owne Hi≈øtorian writeth) in all Wales. The ayre for great plea≈øure, nor ≈øoyle for great profit, I cannot greatly commend, vnle≈ø≈øe it be for the many and mightie great winds, that for the mo≈øt part therein doe rage, and the ≈øpired hils clu≈øtered together ≈øo neere and ≈øo high, as the ≈øame Author affirmeth, that Shepheards vpon their tops falling at oddes in the morning and challenging the field for fight, before they can come together to try out the quarrell, the day will be ≈øpent, and the heate of their fury ≈øhut vp with their ≈øleepe,

(3) The≈øe mountaines formerly did abound with Wolues, for who≈øe auoydeance Hdgar the peaceable, did impo≈øe (as Malmesbury writeth) a yearely Tribute of three hundred Wolues, vpon Ludwall Prince of that Country, whereby in three yeares ≈øpace they were quite de≈øtroyed: and now their faces are couered with fruitfull flockes of Sheepe, be≈øides Neate and other Cattell that therein abundantly doe gra≈øe, wherein the onely riches of this Shire doth con≈øi≈øt: for by rea≈øon of the vneuenne≈ø≈øe
of the ≈øoile and rocks ≈øo noere the face of the earth, the Plough cannot be „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
Corne pro≈øper, which ≈øome haue imputed to the idlene≈ø≈øe of the Inhabitants, wherein they haue beene greatly wronged.

(4) The≈øe people are a part of the Ordonices, of whom we haue ≈øpoken, who by the aduantage of the≈øe mountaines held out with the longe≈øt again≈øt the Romanes, and their necks not brought vnder the yoke of bondage, before the dayes of King Edward the fir≈øt; ≈øince when they haue attempted to ea≈øt off their ≈øubiection to the Engli≈øh, vpon who≈øe ≈øtirres rai≈øed by Owin Glendouer, who hauing beene a fauorite of King Richard the ≈øecond, and di≈øcontented by King Henry the fourth, in a quarrell with the Lord Grey of Ruthin, that intruded vpon his demaines, quarrelled with the King, and entred into open rebellion and confederacie with all other his rebels, drawing the Wel≈øh-men wholly to his ≈øide, in hope to haue had Princes re≈øtored of their owne bloud: and he maintained the ≈øame with wonderfull pride, policie, and ob≈øtinacie for a long time, vntill his con≈øederates followers and fauorates, and his owne courage, credit, and maintenance, were brought ≈øo low by that powerfull King, that in the end he peri≈øhed for very want of food.

(5) Their Townes are not many, neither tho≈øe that they haue of any ≈øtately buildings, whereof Bala, ‚Ä¢ olgethe, and Harlech are the Marke ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ : „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ in the North-ea≈øt of this Countie, in the Wel≈øh
„Äà‚óä„Äâ , in Engli≈øh, Pi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ le-meane, a great poole of water doth drowne at lea≈øt eight ≈øcore Acres of ground: who≈øe „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ the high land flouds though neuer ≈øo great, cannot „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ bigger by their „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ but if the „Äà‚óä„Äâ be ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ oubled with ouer great bla≈øts and tempe≈øts of wi ‚Ä¢ des, ≈øhe in as great a rage ri≈øeth and pa≈ø≈øeth her bankes, as if ≈øhe would encounter that enemy in fight Into the South whereof the two headed Dee with a pretie ≈øharpe ≈øtreame entreth, and thorow the ≈øame glideth without any mixture of the ≈øame water, as the Inhabitants beleeue; more ≈øtrongly conceited in their opinion for that the Salmon, v≈øually taken in Dee, is neuer
found in that Poole; and the fi≈øh called Guimad, bred in that Meart, neuer is ≈øeene in the Riuer-Dee. South thence neere Dolgelhr, in a lower hill, a great Rampire of ≈øtone and compa≈ø≈øe is ≈øeene, and hath beene ≈øome fortification or defence in warre: which whil≈øt we were curious to finde out ≈øome in≈øtructions thereof, by report this onely we learned, that it was called Caddoryrita Dren, according to the name of her neighbour and farre higher hill.

(6) Vpon the We≈øt and Sea-≈øhore of this Shire, Harlech a Market and Major Towne ≈øtandeth, bleake enough and barren, but onely for Fowle and Fi≈øh; hou≈øes not many, neither curiou≈øly built, wherein ≈øtandeth a little Chappell decayed and without v≈øe, in which lyeth buryed Sir Richard Thimblebye, an Engli≈øh Knight, who for the delight he tooke in that game, remoued his abode from a farre better ≈øoyle. Here al≈øo ≈øtandeth a mo≈øt ≈øtrong and beautifull Ca≈øtle, mounted vpon a hill, and with a double Bulwarke walled about, commanding the Sea, and pa≈ø≈øage of entrance of ≈øuch as ≈øeeke to inuade the Goa≈øt: And ≈øurely a great pitie it is to ≈øee ≈øo faire a worke fall to decay: the Con≈øtable whereof by Patent is euer the Major of this Towne; neere vnto which are two great Inlets of Seas, which at low water may be pa≈ø≈øed vpon the Sands with Guides. Vpon who≈øe ≈øhore, as vpon the Sea-coa≈øts in this Countie, abundance of Herrings are caught, for which cau≈øe they are much frequented in the ≈øea≈øon of the yeare, by many people from diuers Countries.

(7) This Towne being the chiefe≈øt of the Shire, the Pole ≈øhall be eleuated onely from thence, who≈øe height for Latitude ≈øtandeth in the degree 53. 29. minutes, and for Longitude in the 15. 47. minutes. The whole being diuided into ≈øixe Hundreds, wherein are ≈øeated thirtie ≈øeauen Pari≈øh-Churches.

div.head: DENBIGH-SHIRE. CHAPTER XI.
div.p: DENBIGH-SHIRE, called in Wel≈øh, Sire Denbigh, retyring more from the Sea within the Countrey, on this ≈øide of the Riuer Conwey ≈øhooteth Ea≈øtward in one place as farre as to the Riuer Dee: on the North, fir≈øt the Sea (for a ≈ømall ≈øpace) and then Plint-≈øhire encompa≈ø≈øeth it: on the We≈øt, Caernaruon and Merioneth-≈øhire; on the Ea≈øt, Che≈øhire and Shrop-≈øhire; and on the South, Mountgomery-≈øhire‚ñ™

(2) The forme thereof is long, growing wider ≈øtill towards the North-we≈øt, and narrower towards the Ea≈øt It is in length from Ea≈øt to We≈øt, one and thirtie miles, and in bredth from North to South, ≈øeauenteene miles: in the whole circuit and circumference, one hundred and fourteene miles.

(3) The ayre is very whole≈øome and plea≈øant, yet bleake enough, as expo≈øed to the windes on all ≈øides, and the high hilles, wherewith it is in many places enuitoned, long retaining the congealed ≈ønow. The tops whereof, in the Summer time, are the harue≈øt-mens Almanacks, by the ri≈øing of certaine vapours thereon in the mornings, and fore≈øhew a faire day en≈øuing.

(4) The ≈øoyle is but barren towards the We≈øt part: yet the middle, where it lieth flat in a valley, is mo≈øt fertile. The Ea≈øt ≈øide, when it is once pa≈øt the valley, findeth Nature to be a very ≈øparing niggard of her ≈øauours: but next vnto Dee it feeleth a more liberall extent of her ble≈ø≈øings. The We≈øt part is but here and there inhabited, and mounteth vp more then the other with bare and hungry hilles: yet the leane≈ø≈øe of the ≈øoyle (where the hils ≈øettle any thing flatting) hath beene now a good while begun to be ouercome by the diligent paines and carefull indu≈øtry of the husbandmen;
for they paring away the vpper coat of the earth into certaine Turffes, with a broad kinde of ≈øpade, pile them vp artificially on heapes, and fire them, ≈øo as being turned into a≈øhes, and throwne vpon the ground ≈øo pared, they fructifie the hungry barrenne≈ø≈øe and ≈øterilitie of ≈øoyle, and make the fields bring forth a kinde of Rie or Anull-corne, in ≈øuch plentie, as is hardly to be beleeued.

(5) The ancient Inhabitants of this Countrey were the Ordouices, who being al≈øo named Orde ‚Ä¢ ices, or Ordo ‚Ä¢ icae: a pui≈ø≈øant and couragious people, by rea≈øon they kept wholly in a mountainous place, and tooke heart euen of the ≈øoyle it ≈øelfe: for they continued longe≈øt free from the yoke both of Roman, and al≈øo of Engli≈øh dominion. They were not ≈øubdued by the Romans, before the dayes of the Emperor Domitian (for then Iulius Agricola conquered almo≈øt the whole Nation) nor brought vnder the command of the Engli≈øh, before the raigne of King Edward the fir≈øt; but liued a long time in a lawle≈ø≈øe kinde of libertie, as bearing them≈øelues bold vpon their owne magnanimitie, and the ≈øtrength of the Country.

(6) The Mountaines of this County yeeld ≈øufficiency of Neat, Sheepe, and Goats. The Vallies in mo≈øt places are very plenteous of Corne, e≈øpecially Ea≈øtward on this ≈øide, betwixt the Riuers of Alen and Dee; but the more We≈øterly part is heathy, and altogether barren. The heart of the Shire ≈øhewes it ≈øelfe beneath the hilles, in a beautifull and plea≈øant Vale, reaching ≈øeauenteene miles in length from South to North, and fiue miles, or thereabouts, in bredth, and lieth open onely toward the Sea. It is enuironed on euery ≈øide with high hilles, among≈øt which, the highe≈øt is Mo ‚Ä¢ llenlly, on the top whereof is a warlike Fen≈øe with Trench and Rampier, and a little fountaine of cleare water. From the≈øe hilles, the Riuer Cluyd re≈øorts vnto this Vale, and from the very ≈øpring-head (increa≈øed with beckes and brookes) doth part it in twaine, running thorow the mid≈øt of it; whereof in ancient time it was named Strat Cluyd: for Mariam ‚Ä¢ s maketh mention of a King of the Strat Cluyd of the Wel≈øh: And at this day it is commonly called Diffryn Cluyd, that is, The Vale of Cluyd.

This thing is worthy ob≈øeruation, as a matter memorable, both for admiration and antiquitie, that in the Pari≈øh of Llan-≈øanan within this Country, there is a place compa≈ø≈øe cut out of the maine rocke by mans hand, in the ≈øide of a ≈øtony hill, wherein there be foure and twentie ≈øeats to ≈øit in, ≈øome le≈ø≈øe, ≈øome bigger, where children and young men, comming to ≈øeeke their Cattell, v≈øe to ≈øit, and to haue their ≈øports. And at this day they commonly call it Arthurs round Table.

(7) Henry Lacy Earle of Lincolne, obtaining Denbigh by the grant of King Edward the fir≈øt, after the conuiction and beheading of Dauid brother of Llewellin for high Trea≈øon, was the fir≈øt that fortified it with a wall about, not large in circuit, but very ≈øtrong, and on the South-≈øide with a faire Ca≈øtle, ≈øtrengthned with many high Towers. But he gaue it ouer, and left the worke vnfini≈øhed, conceiuing griefe (as a ≈øorrowfull father) that his onely ≈øonne came to vntimely death, and was drowned in the Well thereof: The fame of this Towne ≈øpreads it ≈øelfe farre for repute, as being reckoned the mo≈øt beautifull place in all North-Wales: and it is of no le≈ø≈øe report, for the Ca≈øtle adiunct vnto it is impregnable for fortification. And this ≈øtrange accident happning there in the yeare 1575‚ñ™ de≈øerues not to be omitted, being left as a continuall remembrance of Gods mercifull prouidence and pre≈øeruation at that time: that whereby rea≈øon of great Earth-quakes, many people were put into great feare, and had much harme done vnto them both within and without their ho ‚Ä¢ ≈øes, in the Cities of Yorke, Worce≈øter, Gloce≈øter, Bri≈øtow, Hertford, and in other Countries adiacent, yet in the Shire-hall of Denbigh the bell was cau≈øed to toll twice, by the ≈øhaking of the earth, and no hurt or hindrance at all either done or receiued. The gouernment of this Towne is managed by two Aldermen, and two Bailiffes, who are yearely elected out of twentie fiue burge≈øtes, that are their a≈ø≈øi≈øtants. It hath one Recorder, one Towne-Clerke, and two Sergeants at Mace: and by ob≈øeruation of the Mathematickes, the Pole is eleuated in the degree of Latitude 53. and 49. ≈øcruples, and from the fir≈øt point in Longitude 16. and 45.

(8) This County, with them of Flint and Car ‚Ä¢ ar ‚Ä¢ on-≈øhires, are not diuided by prickes into their ≈øeuerall Hundreds, according to the re≈øt of this worke, the want of their particulars in the Parlament Rowles ≈øo cau≈øing it, which for the good of the≈øe three Shires, I earne≈øtly ≈øought to haue ≈øupplied from the Nomina Villarum, in their Sheriffes bookes, and had promi≈øe of them that might ea≈øily haue procured the ≈øame. But whether a fearele≈ø≈øe jealou≈øie po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed their ≈øpirits, left the riches of the≈øe Shires, by reuealing ≈øuch particulars, ≈øhould be further ≈øought into, I cannot ≈øay: yet this I haue ob≈øerued in all my Suruey, that where lea≈øt is to be had, the greate≈øt feares are po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed. Take the≈øe Shires therefore to be done as I could, and not as I would, that wi≈øh both the wealth of them all, and their e≈øteeme to be of better regard by tho≈øe that may doe them good.

(9) This Shire then is diuided into twelue Hundreds, for the readier ordering of bu≈øine≈ø≈øes nece≈ø≈øary to the State of the Country; wherein are placed three Market-Townes, fit for buying and ≈øelling, and other negotiations. It hath fiue Ca≈øtles to defend her ≈øelfe, and to offend her enemies, and fiftie ≈øeauen Pari≈øhes for Gods diuine ≈øeruice and wor≈øhip.

div.head: FLINT-SHIRE. CHAPTER XII.
div.p: FLINT-SHIRE, ≈øtretching out in length, broad at one end, and narrow at another, is not much vnlike in fa≈øhion to a wedge, a peece of which is cut off by the meeting of Che≈øhire and Denbigh-≈øhire, South-Ea≈øt in di≈øtance ≈øome foure miles. It borders Ea≈øt-ward with part of Che≈øhire, from whence it is guarded in length with the Riuer Dee vnto the North, which parteth Worrall and Flint-≈øhire, till you come to a little Iland called Hel ‚Ä¢ bree. Northward it is bounded with the Virgiuian Sea: on the We≈øt, a little Riuer, called Cluyd, parteth her and Denbigh-≈øhire a≈øunder: and on the South altogether by Shrop-≈øhire‚ñ™

(2) This Country is nothing mountainous, as other parts of Wales are, but ri≈øing gently all along the Riuer of Dee, makes a faire ≈øhew and pro≈øpect of her ≈øelfe to euery eye that beholds her, as well vpon the Riuer, being in mo≈øt places thereabouts foure or fiue miles broad, as vpon the other ≈øide thereof, being a part of Che≈øhire.

(3) The Aire is healthfull and temperate, without any foggie clouds or fennie vapours, ≈øauing that ≈øometimes there ari≈øeth from the Sea, and the Riuer Dee, certaine thicke and ≈ømoky-≈øeeming mi≈øts, which neuerthele≈ø≈øe are not found hurtfull to the Inhabitants, who in this part liue long and healthfully.

(4) The Clime is ≈øomewhat colder there then in Che≈øhire, by rea≈øon of the Sea, and the Riuer that engirts the better part of her; by which, the Northerne windes being long carried vpon the waters, blow the more cold; and that ≈øide of the Country vpward, that lieth ≈øhoaring vnto the top, hauing neither ≈øhelter nor defence, receiueth them in their full power, and is naturally a Bulwarke
from their violence vnto her bordering neighbours, that maketh the ≈ønow to lie much longer there then on the other ≈øide of the Riuer.

(5) The Soile bringeth forth plentie both of Corne and Gra≈ø≈øe, as al≈øo great ≈øtore of Cattle, but they be little. To ≈øupply which defect, they haue more by much in their numbers then in other places where they be bigger. Great ≈øtore of Fi≈øh they take in the Riuer of Dee, but little from the Sea, by rea≈øon they haue no Hauens or Creekes for boats. No great ≈øtore of woods either there or in any other part of Wales are found, it hauing beene a generall plague vnto all the Country euer ≈øince the head-≈øtrong rebellions of their Princes and great men again≈øt the Kings of England, that (in time) tooke away the principall helpes of their Innouations, by cutting downe their woods, whereof in this Shire there hath heretofore beene great plentie. Fruits are ≈øcarce, but milke, butter, and chee≈øe plentie, as al≈øo ≈øtore of hony, of the which they make a plea≈øant wine, in colour like (in ta≈øte not much vnlike) vnto Muskadine, which they call Mathegli ‚Ä¢ . Yea, and in the dayes of Giraldus Cambren≈øis, neere the place now called Holy-well, was a rich Mine of Siluer, in ≈øeeking after which, men pierced and pried into the very bowels of the earth.

(6) The ancient Inhabitants of this Country were the Ordouices, a ≈øturdie people again≈øt the Romans, but now mo≈øt kinde and gentle towards the Engli≈øh, and indeede make much of all ≈øtrangers, except they be cro≈ø≈øed, and then they are the contrary.

(7) Places of defence are the Ca≈øtles of Flint, Hawarden, vulgarly Harden, Treer, Rudland, Mold, Yowley, and Hope: of which, Flint and Harden are the two principall. The Ca≈øtle of Flint, famous for the benefit it receiued from two Kings, and for the refuge and reliefe it gaue vnto the third. It was founded by Henry the ≈øecond, fini≈øhed by Edward the fir≈øt, and long after gaue harbour and entertainment to that noble, but vnfortunate Prince, Richard the ≈øecond, comming out of Ireland, being within her walles a free and ab≈øolute King, but no ≈øooner without, but taken pri≈øoner by Henry Bullingbrooke,
Duke of Lanca≈øter, lo≈øing at that time his libertie, and not long after his life. This ≈øtandeth in the graduation of Latitude 53. 55. minutes, in Longitude 17.

For the Ca≈øtle of Hawarden, no record remaines of the fir≈øt founder, but that it was held a long time by the Stewards of the Earles of Che≈øter. Howbeit, their re≈øi≈øtances did not ≈øo generally con≈øi≈øt in the ≈øtrength of their Ca≈øtles and Fortifications, as in their Mountaines and Hils, which in times of danger ≈øerued as naturall Bulwarkes and Defences vnto them again≈øt the force of enemies. As was that which ≈øtandeth in a certaine ≈øtrait ≈øet about with woods, neere vnto the Riuer, Alen, called Coles-hull, that is, Coles-hill, where the Engli≈øh, by rea≈øon of their di≈øordered multitude, not ranged clo≈øe in good array, lo≈øt the field, and were defeated, when King Henry the ≈øecond had made as great preparation as might be to giue battle vnto the Wel≈øh, and the very Kings Standard was for≈øaken by Henry of E≈ø≈øex, who was Standard-bearer to the Kings of England in right of inheritance.

(8) This Country hath many ≈øhallow riuers in it, but none of fame and note, but Dee and Cluyde. Howbeit, there is a Spring not farre from Rudland Ca≈øtle, of great report and antiquitie, which is termed Fons Sacer, in Engli≈øh, Holy-Well, and is al≈øo commonly called S. Winefrids Well; of whom antiquitie thus reporteth: That Winefrid a Chri≈øtian Virgin, very faire and vertuous, was doated vpon by a young lu≈øtfull Prince or Lord of the Country, who not long able to rule his head-≈øtrong affections, hauing many times in vaine attempted and tryed her cha≈øtitie both by rich gifts and large promi≈øes, could not by any meanes obtaine his de≈øires; he therefore (in a place of aduantage) ≈øuddenly ≈øurprized and raui≈øhed her weake (yet re≈øi≈øting) body. After the deed done, the cruell Tyrant, to ≈øtop her cries and acclamations, ≈ølew her, and cut off her head: out of which place did ≈øuddenly ari≈øe a Spring that continueth to this day, carrying from the Fountaine ≈øuch a forcible ≈øtreame and current, as the like is not found in Chri≈øtendome. Ouer the head of the Spring there is built a Chappell of free ≈øtone, with Pillars curiou≈øly wrought and engraued, in the Chancell whereof, and
gla≈ø≈øe window, the picture of the Virgin is drawne, together with the memoriall of her life and death. To this Fountaine Pilgrims are accu≈øtomed to repaire in their zealous, but blind deuotion; and diuers others re≈øort to bathe in, holding firmely that the water is of much vertue.

There be many red ≈øtones in the bottome of this Well, and much greene mo≈ø≈øe growing vpon the ≈øides: the ≈øuper≈øtition of the people holding that tho≈øe red ≈øpots in the ≈øtones were drops of the Ladies bloud, which all the water in the Spring can neuer wa≈øh away; and that the mo≈ø≈øe about the wall was her haire, which though ≈øome of it be giuen to euery ≈øtranger that comes, yet it neuer wa≈øteth. But how≈øoeuer this be carried for truth by the tradition of time, the mo≈ø≈øe it ≈øelfe ≈ømels exceeding ≈øweet.
There is al≈øo hard by Kilken (a ≈ømall village) within this Countie, a little Well of no great note, that at certaine times ri≈øeth and falleth, after the manner of Sea-tydes.

(9) In the South part of this Country, diuided from the re≈øt, is a place (in ≈øome written Coppies of Antonine, called Bouium) which we now terme Banchor, fir≈øt a Citie, and afterwards a Mona≈øtery of famous memory, and the fir≈øt that is read of in the world: wherein (as Beda ≈øaith) were a great number of Monkes, and them diuided into ≈øeauen Companies, euery one hauing his ≈øeuerall Ruler a≈ø≈øigned. None of the≈øe Companies had le≈ø≈øe then three hundred per≈øons deuoted to prayer, and to get liuing by their owne labour, for them≈øelues and the poore: although it hath long ≈øince beene vtterly ruinate, ≈øo as now there is ≈øcarce ≈øeene the face and outward ≈øhew of a dead Citie or Mona≈øtery. It hath onely the names of two Gates remaining, one ≈øtanding a mile di≈øtant from another, and betwixt which the Riuer Dee now runneth, where are often times found many pieces of Romane Coyne, and other tokens of antiquitie. But of the≈øe ≈øhall be more mention made in the following Hi≈øtory.

Another like Mona≈øtry, but of le≈ø≈øer account, ≈øtood in the Vale beneath Varis (a little Citie placed
the Romans in the confines of this Shire and Deabigh-≈øhire) and vpon the Ranke of Elwy and Cluyd: This the Britaines call „Äà‚óä„Äâ , of the Riuer, the Engli≈øhmen, A≈øuph, of the Founder; and the Hi≈øtoriographers, A≈øphen≈øis.
