It is more famou≈øe for antiquitie, then for building o ‚Ä¢ brauery: for about the yeare 560 Kentigein Bi≈øhop of Gla≈ø ‚Ä¢ , being fled „Äà‚óä„Äâ out of Scotland, placed here a Bi≈øhops See, and erected a Mona≈øtry, gathering together 66 ‚Ä¢ . in a religious brotherhood, whereof 300. that were vnlearned, gaue them≈øelues to husbandrie, and to worke within the Mona≈øtery; the re≈øt to prayer and meditations. When he returned into Scotland, he ordained A≈øaph, a godly and vpright man, to be gouernous ouer this Mona≈øtery, of whom it tooke the name, and is called Saint A≈øaphs.

Another Mona≈øtry of great account was at Ba≈øingwarke in this County, neere vnto which began that admirable Ditch drawne thence vnto the mouth of „Äà‚óä„Äâ by King Offa, the Tract whereof I haue expre≈ø≈øed thorow this Shire, and will further ≈øpeake thereof in the following Hi≈øtory.
(10) This Shire is diuided into fiue Hundreds, fortified with ≈øeauen Ca≈øtles, hath onely one Market-Towne, and twentie eight Pari≈øhes, in which there is a continuall celebration of diuine Seruice.

div.head: ANGLESEY. CHAPTER XIII.
div.p: ANGLESEY was in the time of the Romans called Mona, by the Britaines Mon, and Tir-Mon, (that is) the Land of Mon, of the ancient Engli≈øh-Saxons Moneg: And at la≈øt, after the Engli≈øhmen had by their ≈øharpe and ≈øeuerall a≈ø≈øaults brought it vnder their rules, and became Lords thereof, it was termed Angle≈øey, as one would ≈øay, The Engli≈øhmens Iland.

(2) For, an Iland it is, albeit it be ≈øeuered from the Continent of Britaine, but with a ≈ømall and narrow ≈øtreight of the riuer Menai, and on all other parts beaten vpon with the ≈øurging and troublous Iri≈øh Sea, in which it lyeth ≈øomewhat ≈øquare-wi≈øe, not much different in length and breadth; being, where it reacheth out in length, from Beau-mari≈øh Ea≈øtward, to the vtmo≈øt Promontory We≈øt-ward, which we call Holy-head, twentie miles; and in breadth from Llanbaderik North-ward, to the point of Menai South-ward, ≈øeauenteene miles; the whole circuit or circumference amounting towards ≈øeauentie miles.

(3) The aire is rea≈øonable gratefull and healthfull, and not generally ≈øubiect to di≈øea≈øes, excepting certaine Agues at ≈øome times, which are occa≈øioned by the ≈øogs and mi≈øty exhalations, which ari≈øe from the Sea called Mare Virginium, with the which this Ile is encompa≈ø≈øed.

(4) The Commodities that commend (or rather beautifie) this Country, are in Corne and Cattle, wherewith it not onely enricheth it ≈øelfe exceedingly, but ≈øendeth out great proui≈øion thereof to others to ≈øupply their defects, and although the ground may ≈øeeme dry and ≈øtony, or vnplea≈øant and nothing ≈øightly, wherein for the outward qualitie it re≈øembleth ≈øome other parts of Wales, that are not ≈øo fruitfull, yet for the inward bounties of nature, it is farre vnlike: for aboue all the
Coa≈øts of Wales it is mo≈øt plentifull of Wheat, in≈øomuch as by Giraldus Cambren≈øis report, they are wont to ≈øay in Wel≈øh, by way of a Prouerbe, Mon Mam Combry, which is to ≈øay, Mon is the mother of Wales; for that when other Countries harue≈øt failes round about, or their proui≈øion is exhau≈øt and drawne dry, this alone, like a prouident and full-bre≈øted mother, is able to ≈øu≈øtaine the re≈øt Whereunto Nature mo≈øt prouidently hath added another benefit ≈øeruiceable and nece≈ø≈øary to the former, in that the Country produceth al≈øo tho≈øe kinde of ≈øtones which are called Mol ‚Ä¢ res, is of all other fitte≈øt to make Mill-≈øtones or Grind-≈øtones. In ≈øome places al≈øo it yeeldeth an earth of Alumino ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
qualitie, out of which ≈øome not long ≈øince began to make Alom and Copero≈øe, who (like vnfle≈øht Souldiers) gaue ouer their enterpri≈øe without further hope, becau≈øe at fir≈øt they ≈øaw it not an≈øwere their ouer-ha≈øtie expectations.

(5) The ancient Inhabitants of this Country were the Ord ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ices, mentioned before in the precedent Prouinces of Denbigh-≈øhire, Flint-≈øhire, and Carnaruon-≈øhire. And this very Iland was that ancient, and ≈øo much enobled ≈øeate of the Briti≈øh Druyds, who ≈øo amated the Army of Romane inuaders, as Tacitus reports, and as el≈øe-where we haue related in the ≈øixt Booke and ≈øeauenth Chapter of our en≈øuing Hi≈øtory.

(6) This Nation was attempted fir≈øt by Pa ‚Ä¢ linus Suetonius in the raigne of Nero, but brought vnder the Romane Empire by Iulius Agricola. When the Empire of the Romanes in Britaine began to decline and goe downeward, ≈øome out of Ireland entred into this I≈øle by ≈øtealth, and ne≈øtled them≈øelues there, as may be gathered by certaine mounts of earth entrenched about, and yet to be ≈øeene, which they call the I ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øh mens Cottages: as al≈øo by a place named of the Iri≈øh-men, yn Hieriey Gwidid, who did there (as is recorded) put the Britaines to flight, vnder the leading of Sinigus. The Norwegians al≈øo were often infe≈øtuous to this Iland; but King Ethelreds Fleet, hauing in the yeare 1000. ≈øcowred the Seas round about this I≈øle, far exceeded all both Iri≈øh and Norwegian depopulations, for they wa≈øted the Country in all ho≈øtile manner.

(7) After this, two Hughs, both Normans, did greatly afflict this Iland: The one being Earle of Che≈øter, the other of Shrewsbury; at which very time Magnus the Norwegian arriuing there, ≈øhot Hugh Earle of Shrewsbury through with an Arrow, and departed after he had ran≈øacked the Iland. It was afterwards grieuou≈øly infe≈øted by the Engli≈øhmen, who neuer gaue ouer from time to time to inuade it, vntill in the raigne of King Edward the fir≈øt, it was wholly brought vnder his ≈øubiection.

(8) The principall Towne in this I≈øle is Beaumari≈øh, which the ≈øaid King Edward the fir≈øt built in the Ea≈øt ≈øide thereof, and for the faire ≈øituation, though in a Mori≈øh place, gaue it the name which it now beareth, whereas in times pa≈øt it was called Bonouer; which he al≈øo fortified with a goodly Ca≈øtle.

(9) The Maior is the chiefe≈øt Magi≈øtrate of the Towno, who is yearely cho≈øen, and hath the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance and helpe of two Bailiffes, two Sergeants at Mace, and one Towne-Clerke: by who≈øe carefull diligence the affaires of this Towne are orderly managed and commanded: who≈øe Latitude is 54. and Longitude 15. 45. minutes.

(10) Not far from hence is Lhaanuais, in times pa≈øt a faire religious hou≈øe of the Friars Minors, which although it be now in a manner raced out of memory, yet antiquitie maketh mention that it hath beene of great regard among the Kings of England, who haue ≈øhewed them≈øelues very bountifull Patrons vnto that Couent, both in re≈øpect of the ≈øanctimonious life of ≈øuch as conuer≈øed there, as al≈øo becau≈øe there the bodies of very eminent per≈øons, as the daughter of King Iohn, the ≈øonne of a King of the Danes, as likewi≈øe of many great Lords, Knights, and Squires, were enterred, that were ≈ølaine in the warres again≈øt the Wel≈øh, in the time of many illu≈øtrious Kings of England.
(11) This I≈øle is reckoned to haue had anciently many Villages in it, euen to the number of three hundred three≈øcore and three; and the ≈øame euen at this day is very well peopled.

The diui≈øion of this Ile for di≈øpo≈øition of affaires that belong either to the ≈øtate of the Cro ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , or to the condition of the Country, is into ≈øix Hundreds: in which are ≈øeated two Market-Townes, and ≈øeuentie foure Pari≈øh-Churches for Gods diuine honour and wor≈øhip.

div.head: CAERNARVON-SHIRE. CHAPTER XIIII.
div.p: CAERNARVON-SHIRE, in Wel≈øh, Sire Caer-ar-von, ≈øo called becau≈øe it is iu≈øt ouer again≈øt Angle≈øey, (which the Britaines call Mon,) and in compo≈øition was termed al≈øo Snowden-Forre≈øt, before Wales was laid into Shires; the North-≈øide whereof and the We≈øt butteth vpon the Iri≈øh Sea, the South-≈øide is inclo≈øed with Merioneth, and the Ea≈øt with Denbigh-≈øhires, from which it is ≈øeuered by the Riuer Conwey.

(2) The forme thereof is much like a wedge, long and narrow toward the South, and growing ≈øtill wider towards the North: ≈øo that from Penenkel-point South-ward, to Orm≈ø-head-point Northward, are fortie miles, from the Riuer Conwey Ea≈øtward, to the Riuer Llenoy We≈øtward, miles twentie: and the whole circumference one hundred and ten miles.

(3) The Aire is ≈øharpe and piercing, by rea≈øon that the Country hath not naturall proui≈øion to en≈øconce her ≈øelfe again≈øt the extremitie of winds and weather: but e≈øpecially as may be thought, through the continuance of the Snow on the hils, which al≈øo exclude the Suns a≈øpect and warmth.

(4) The ≈øoile cannot be much commended for the fertilitie, except tho≈øe parts of the Sea-coa≈øts, which lye on the We≈øt towards Ireland: but for the heart of this Shire, it is altogether mountainous, as if Nature had a purpo≈øe here, by rearing vp the≈øe craggy hils ≈øo thicke together, ≈øtrongly to compact the ioynts of this our Iland, and to frame the Inland part thereof for a fit place of refuge to the Britaines, again≈øt tho≈øe times of aduer≈øitie which afterward did fall vpon them; for no Army though neuer ≈øo ≈øtrongly, or ≈øcarce any Trauellers, though neuer ≈øo lightly appointed, can finde pa≈ø≈øage among tho≈øe ≈øo many rough and hard Rockes, ≈øo many Vales and Pooles here and there, cro≈ø≈øing
all the wayes, as ready ob≈øtacles to repell any Inroades of forraine a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ailants. The≈øe Mountaines may not vnfitly be termed the Briti≈øh Alpes, as being the mo≈øt va≈øte of all Britaine, and for their ≈øteepne≈ø≈øe and craggine≈ø≈øe not vnlike to tho≈øe of Italy, all of them towring vp into the Aire, and round encompa≈ø≈øing one farre higher then all the re≈øt, peculiarly called Snowdon-Hill, though the other likewi≈øe in the ≈øame ≈øen≈øe, are by the Wel≈øh termed Cralg Er ‚Ä¢ ry, as much as Snowy Mountaines, taking their name as doth (by Plinies te≈øtimony) Niphates in Armenia, and Imaus in Schithia: For all the yeare long the≈øe lye mantelled ouer with Snow hard cru≈øted together, though otherwi≈øe for their height they are open and liable both to the Sunne to di≈ø≈øolue them, and the windes to ouer-≈øweepe them.

(5) The ancient Inhabitants of this Country were the Ordouices, of whom we haue ≈øufficiently ≈øpoken in the de≈øcription of the former Prouinces; neither need I in≈øi≈øt either vpon the plea≈øures or profits that this Country yeeldeth, by rea≈øon of the great affinity it hath both of Climate and Commodities with Denbigh-≈øhire and Flint-≈øhire before mentioned But this beyond the other in ≈øome places breeds certaine Shel-fi≈øhes, which being conceiued by an heauenly dew bring forth Pearles, in ancient times „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ of then now they are.

(6) Touching places of note, that Citie is very ancient which the Emperour Antonine calleth Segontium, taking name of a Riuer running by, which at this day is called Seront: ≈øome reliques of the walls whereof doe yet appeare, neere vnto a little Church con≈øecrated to the honour of Saint Publicius. This Citie Ninius calleth Caer Cu≈øtenith, which ≈øome interpret the Citie of Con≈øtantine. Indeed Mathew We≈øtmin≈øter ≈øaith (how true I know not) that Anno 1283. here was found the body of Con≈øtantius (Father to great Con≈øtantine) which King Edward the fir≈øt cau≈øed to be ≈øumptuou≈øly be≈øtowed in the Church of the new Citie, which he rai≈øed out of the ruines of the old, and is now called Ca ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ naruon, which giueth name to this whole Shire. The Towne it ≈øelfe yeeldeth a mo≈øt
excellent pro≈øpect towards the Sea, and is incompa≈ø≈øed (in a manner) round with the wals of the Ca≈øtle: ≈øo as we may ≈øay, it is a Citie within a Ca≈øtle, which taketh vp the whole We≈øt-≈øide of it: and great pitie it is, that ≈øo famous a worke ≈øhould not be perpetuous, or euer become the ruine of time, which is much feared, for the mercile≈ø≈øe vnderminings of the Sea, that with her daily and forcible irruptions neuer cea≈øeth to wa≈øh away the foundations of the Key. The people of this Towne are well approued for courte ‚Ä¢ ie, and al≈øo Ciuill gouernment, which is admini≈øtred by the Con≈øtable of the Ca≈øtle (who is euer Maior by Patent) hauing the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of one Alderman, two Bailiffes, two Sergeants at Mace, and one Towne-Clerke. The Towne≈ømen doe not a little glory that King Edward the ≈øecond was borne there, in a Tower of the Ca≈øtle called Eagle-Tower, and ≈øurnamed of Caer-nar-uon, he being the fir≈øt Prince of Wales of the Engli≈øh line. The ≈øite of this Towne according to Mathematicall ob≈øeruation is in the degree of Longitude 15. and 50. ≈øcruples from the fir≈øt We≈øt-point, and the Pole eleuated in Latitude 53. and 50.

Bangor the Bi≈øhops See, though it be now but a ≈ømall Towne, yet it was in time pa≈øt ≈øo large, that for the greatne≈ø≈øe thereof it was called Banchor Vaur, that is, Great Banchor; which Hugh Earle of Che≈øter fortified with a Ca≈øtle: But it hath beene long ≈øince vtterly ruinated and laid leuell with the ground, in ≈øo much as there is not any footing to be found, or other monuments left thereof, although they haue beene ≈øought with all diligent enquiry. This Bi≈øhops See hath within the Dioces ninetie ≈øix Pari≈øhes. But the ancient Church which was con≈øecrated vnto Daniel, ≈øometime Bi≈øhop thereof, was defaced and ≈øet on fire by that notorious Rebell Owen Glendowerdwy, who had a purpo≈øe al≈øo to de≈øtroy all the Cities of Wales, for that they ≈øtood for the King of England. And though the ≈øame Church was ≈øince repaired about the time of King Henry the ≈øeauenth, yet hath it ≈øcarce recouered the re≈øemblance of her former dignitie.

The Riuer Conwey (which limitteth this Shire on the Ea≈øt-≈øide) is in Ptolemy by corruption or ignorance of Tran≈øcribers called Toi≈øonius, in ≈øtead of Cononius, whence Canonium (a Towne mentioned by Antonine) tooke name: and albeit both it and its name be now vtterly extinct, yet is there a couert remembrance thereof in the new name of a poore Village, ≈øtanding among the rubbi≈øh thereof, called Caer-hean, (that is) The ancient Citie: Out of the ≈øpoyle whereof King Edward the fir≈øt, built a new Towne at the Riuers mouth, termed thereupon Aber-Conwey: (that is) the mouth of Conwey, which being formerly fortified by Hugh of Che≈øter, and ≈øtrongly ≈øituate and fenced both with wals & a faire Ca≈øtle by the Riuers ≈øide, de≈øerues rather the name of a Citie then a Towne, if it were more populous and traffiqued with Inhabitants Neither mu≈øt I here forget Newin, though but a ≈ømall Market-Towne, for that it plea≈øed the Engli≈øh Nobles Anno 1284 to honour it and the memory of King Arthur, with triumphant celebritie, after they had ≈øubdued the rebellious Ringleaders of Wales.

(7) Other matters of memorable note this Country affordeth not much, vnle≈ø≈øe perhaps this; That iu≈øt ouer again≈øt the Riuer Conwey, where it iflueth into the Sea, there ≈øometimes ≈øtood an ancient Citie named Diganwey, which many yeares agoe was con≈øumed by lightning, and ≈øo made vtterly de≈øolate, as many other monuments haue beene, of ancient and worthy memory. As likewi≈øe that in the Poole Lin-Peris, there is a kinde of Fi≈øh called there Torco ‚Ä¢ h, hauing a red belly, no where el≈øe ≈øeene. For touching the≈øe two other miracles famou≈øed by Giraldus and Gerua≈øius, that on tho≈øe his high hils there are two Pooles called the Meares, the one of which produceth great ≈øtore of fi≈øh, but all hauing onely one eye, and in the other there is a moueable Iland, which as ≈øoone as a man treadeth on, it forthwith floateth a great way off, whereby the Wel≈øh are ≈øaid to haue often ≈øcaped and deluded their enemies a≈ø≈øailing them: the≈øe matters are out of my Creed, and yet I thinke the Reader had rather beleeue them, then to goe to ≈øee whether it be ≈øo or no.

It is traded with fiue Market-Townes fit for bargaining, buying and ≈øelling, fortified with foure Ca≈øtles, and hath ≈øixtie eight Pari≈øh-Churches in it, where the Inhabitants concurre and meete together for the celebration of Diuine Seruice.

div.head: SCOTLANDS GENERALL DESCRIPTION. CHAPTER I.
div.p: SCOTLAND, the ≈øecond Kingdome of Great Britaine, and the North part of the Iland, hath on the Ea≈øt the Germane Ocean, on the North, the Orkneys, and Deucalidon Sea, the We≈øt affronted with Ireland, and the South hath the Riuer Tweed, the Cheuiot Hils, and the adiacent Tract, reaching to the Sulway Sands, whereby it is ≈øeparated from England.

(2) This Kingdome is faire and ≈øpacious, and from the≈øe South-borders ≈øpreadeth it ≈øelfe wide into the Ea≈øt and We≈øt, till againe it contracts it ≈øelfe narrower vnto the Northerne Promontories: furni≈øhed with all things befitting a famous Kingdome; both for Ayre and Soyle, Riuers, Woods, Mountaines, Fi≈øh, Fowle, and Cattle, and Corne ≈øo plenteous, that it ≈øupplyeth therewith other Countryes in their want. The people thereof are of good feature, ≈øtrong of body, and of couragious minde, and in warres ≈øo venturous, that ≈øcarce any ≈øeruice of note hath beene performed, but that they were with the fir≈øt and la≈øt in the field. Their Nobilitie and Gentry are very ≈øtudious of learning, and all ciuill knowledge; for which end they not onely frequent the three Vniuer≈øities of their owne Kingdome (S. Andrewes, Gla≈øco, and Edenbrough, the Nur≈øeries of Pietie, and Man≈øions of the ≈øacred Mu≈øes) but al≈øo much addict them≈øelues to trauell into forraine Countries.

(3) The Counties contained in this Kingdome are many, and euery where be≈øtrewed with Cities, Towne, and Borrowes, as is that of England: and, as England, I entended to de≈øcribe it, had I not beene happily preuented by a learned Gentleman of that Nation, who hath mo≈øt exactly begun,
and gone through the greate≈øt difficulties thereof; to build vpon who≈øe foundations, I hold it iniurious: and am ≈øo farre from any ambition to preuent his noble purpo≈øes, that I heartily with all happie furtherances thereto, with a longing de≈øire to ≈øee, by his indu≈øtrious labours, another Scene added to the perfecting of the Theatre of Britaines glory.

(4) Yet, in the meane while, le≈øt I ≈øhould ≈øeeme too difectiue in my intendments, let me without offence (in this third, though ≈øhort Booke) giue onely a generall view of that Kingdome, vpon ob≈øeruations from others; which to accompli≈øh by mine owne ≈øuruey (if others ≈øhould hap to faile, and my crazy-aged-body will giue leaue) is my chiefe de≈øire; knowing the Iland furni≈øhed with many worthy remembrances, appertaining both vnto them and vs, whom God now hath ≈øet vnder one Crowne: and the rather, for that their more Southerne people are from the ≈øame Originall with vs the Engli≈øh, being both alike the Saxon branches: as al≈øo, that the Picts anciently inhabiting part of that Kingdome, were the inborne Britaines, and ≈øuch as thither fled to auoid the Romane ≈øeruitude: who≈øe names began fir≈øt to be di≈øtingui≈øhed vnder Diocle≈øian the Emperour, when they were termed Picts for painting their bodies, like the Britaines, as ≈øuch Flauius Vigetius: which is more ≈øtrengthened, for that the Northerne Britaines conuerted by Saint Columb, are called Britaine Picts.

(5) But the Highland-men (the naturall Scot indeed) are ≈øuppo≈øed to de≈øcend from the Scythians, who with the Getes infe≈øting Ireland, left both their I≈ø≈øue there, and their manners, apparant in the Wild-Iri≈øh euen to this day: And from Scithae (as is thought) the name of Scot grew; for ≈øo the Netherlanders by Scutten expre≈ø≈øe indifferently the Scythian or Scot: ≈øo Gildas calleth the Iri≈øh-Britaines, Scythians: ≈øo King Elfeed in tran≈ølating the Hi≈øtorie of Oro≈øius, turneth Scotos into Scyttan: and ≈øo ≈øaith Wal≈øingham, from one and the ≈øame originall, Scythae, Scytici, Scotae, Scotici, take their names, as from Getae, Getici, Gothi, Gothici haue done.

(6) Their manner were alike, ≈øaith Diodorus, Siculus, and Strabo, and their garments not much different, as by Sidonius Apollinaris may be gathered, where he ≈øeemeth rather to de≈øcribe the moderne Wild-Iri≈øh, then the antike Gete. Notwith≈øtanding this Nations Originall by ≈øome hath beene deriued from Scota, the ≈øuppo≈øed Daughter of the Egyptian King Pharoah, that nouri≈øhed Mo≈øes, afterwards married vnto Gaithelus, the ≈øon of Cecrops, (Founder of Athens) who fir≈øt ≈øeating in Spaine, pa≈ø≈øed thence into Ireland, and la≈øtly into Scotland, where his Wife Scota gaue Name to the Nation; if we beleeue that they hit the marke, who ≈øhoot at the Moone.

(7) But that the Scythians came into Spaine, (be≈øides the Promontory bearing their Name Scythi ‚Ä¢ um) Silius Italicus, a Spanyard borne, doth ≈øhew, who bringeth the Concani, a Nation therein ≈øeated, from the Ma≈ø≈øagetae, which were the Scythians; and the Sarmatae, whom all confe≈ø≈øe to haue bin Scythians, were the builders (as he ≈øaith) of the Citie Su≈øanna in Spaine‚ñ™ And how from Spaine they po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelues of Ireland, (at the time when the Kingdome of Iulah flouri≈øhed,) Ninius the Di≈øciple of Eluodugus doth tell, and their owne Hi≈øtories of Nemethus and Delas, be≈øides Ci≈ønerus and others, doe ≈øhew; who were fir≈øt knowne by the name of Scots, as is gathered out of Prophyry (alledged by S. Ierome) in the raigne of Aurelianus the Emperour. Gildas calleth them the Iri≈øh-Spoilers: Giraldus, A Scoti≈øh Nation, de≈øcended from Ireland: which in regard of them by Eginbardus is termed The Ile of Scots: by Beda, The Ile inhabited by the Scots; and by other Hi≈øtorians, Scotland the great; as their ≈øeate in Britaine was called Scotland the le≈ø≈øe.

(8) The≈øe, when the Romane Empire was farre in the wane, bur≈øt into Britaine vnder Reuda their Captaine, who entring amitie with the Picts, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the North part of the Iland, and a≈ø≈øi≈øted them again≈øt the Britaines, then ready to fall, when the Romanes were gone. But the≈øe afterward entertaining di≈ø≈øentions among≈øt them≈øelues, put the hazard of their e≈øtates on the tryall and chance of one dayes battle, fought betwixt them in the yeare of Saluation, 740. Wherein the Picts not onely lo≈øt their
liues, but ≈øoone after euen their very name al≈øo, and Fortune crowning the Scots with victory, aduanced their Kingdome vnto ≈øuch fame and ≈øtrength, that the ≈øame hath long continued without any ab≈øolute conque≈øt or ≈øurpri≈øe, again≈øt the a≈ø≈øaults of what≈øoeuer enemies.

(9) Scotlands South part in Galloway, wa≈øhed with the warer of Solway Bay, toucheth degree 56. of Latitude, and thence inbo≈øoming many Loughes and In-lets vpon the Ea≈øt and We≈øt, extendeth it ≈øelfe vnto the degree 60 and 30 minutes; who≈øe Longitude is likewi≈øe laid betwixt the degree 13 and 19 and the ≈øame growne very narrow, being ≈øo neere the North-Pole, as lying directly vnder the hindermo≈øt Starres of the Greater Beare.

(10) The whole Kingdome is diuided into two parts by the great Riuer Tay; the South whereof is the more populous, and more beautified in manners, riches, and ciuilitie: the North more rude, retaining the cu≈øtomes of the Wild-Iri≈øh, the ancient Scot, in who≈øe ≈øeuerall Territories the≈øe Counties en≈øuing are contained.
South.
Teifidale.
Merch.
Laudien.
Lidde≈ødale.
E ‚Ä¢ kedale.
Annandale.
Nidde≈ødale.
Galloway.
Carricke.
Kyle.
Cunnigham.
Arran.
Cluide≈ødale.
Lennox.
Stirling.
Fife.
Strathorn.
Menteith.
Argile.
Ca ‚Ä¢ tire.
Lorne.
North.
Loq ‚Ä¢ abr ‚Ä¢ a.
Brdidalthin.
Perth.
Athol.
Anguis.
Merns.
Mar.
Buquhan.
Murrey.
Ro≈ø≈øe.
Sutherland.
Cathanes.
Strathnauer ‚Ä¢ .

(11) And the≈øe againe are ≈øubdiuided into Sherifdomes, Steward≈øhips, and ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ wickes, for the mo≈øt part inheritory vnto honourable Families. The Eccle≈øia≈øticall Gouernment is al≈øo ≈øubiect vnder two Metropolitan Arch-bi≈øhops, which are of S. Andrewes, (the Primate of Scotland,) and of Gla≈øco; who≈øe Iuri≈ødictions are as followeth.

Among≈øt the things worthy of note of Antiquitie in this Kingdome, mo≈øt memorable was that Fortification drawne from Abercorne vpon the Frith of Edenborough, vnto Aleluya, how Dunbritton, opening vpon the We≈øt Sea, where Iulius Agricola ≈øet the limit of the Romane Empire; pa≈øt which, ≈øaith Tacitus, there was no other bounds of Britaine to be ≈øought for: and that here the ≈øecond Legion Augu≈øta, and the 20. Legion Victrix, built a part of the Wall, certaine In≈øcriptions there digged vp, and re≈øerued at Dunloyr and Cader, doe witne≈ø≈øe: as al≈øo an ancient coped monument of an high and round compa≈ø≈øe, which, as ≈øome thinke, was a Temple con≈øecrated vnto the God Ter ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ : others, a Trophey rai≈øed by Carau≈øius, who fortified this Wall with ≈øeauen Ca≈øtles, as Ninius doth declare.

(12) At this place began the great and darke Wood Caled ‚Ä¢ nia, famous for the wilde white Buls
that therein were bred who≈øe Manes were Lion like, thicke and cuuled, of nature fierce and cruell, and ≈øo hatefull to mankinde, that they abhorred what≈øoeuer was by them handled or breathed vpon: the≈øe Woods ≈øtretched farre and wide with many turnings, darke ≈øhades, and dreadfull dens, and ≈øo famous in the Romane Writers, that they often v≈øed that name for all Britaine; who≈øe Inhabitants were the la≈øt in this Iland, that yeelded their neckes to the yoake of ≈øubiection, is ≈øhall appeare in our following Story.

(13) Ninian a Britaine is recorded to haue conuerted the South-Ficts vnto the Faith of Chri≈øt in the raigne of Theodo≈øius the younger, and the Church in Galloway bearing his name doth witnes it: ≈øo likewi≈øe in the ≈øame age Palladius ≈øent from Pope Coele≈øtine, became an Apo≈øtle vnto the Scots, who≈øe reliques lay en≈øhrined at Fordo ‚Ä¢
in Mernis, as was verily ≈øuppo≈øed: but that Chri≈øtianitie had beene formerly planted in this vttermo≈øt Prouince, is te≈øtified by Tertuilian, in ≈øaying the Britaines had embraced the faith farther then the Romans had power to follow or per≈øecute them, whereupon Peter Monke of „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Spaine, concludeth their conuer≈øion to be more ancient then the Southerne Britaines.

(14) But touching things ob≈øeruable for the pre≈øent, ≈øurely admirable is the report of the plenty of Cattle, Fi≈øh, and Fowle there abiding: their Neat but little, yet many in number: Fi≈øh ≈øo plentifull that men in ≈øome places (for delight) on hor≈øe-backe hunt Salmons with Speares: and a certaine Fowle, which ≈øome call Soland-Gee≈øe, ≈øpreading ≈øo thicke in the ayre, that they euen darken the Suns light; of who≈øe fle≈øh, feathers and oyle, the Inhabitants in ≈øome parts make great v≈øe and gaine; yea, and euen of fi≈øhes brought by them, abundant proui≈øion for diet, as al≈øo of the ≈øtickes (brought to make their ne≈øts) plentifull proui≈øion for fuell.

(15) With the≈øe, as of wonders I might ≈øpeake of the natures of tho≈øe two famous Loughes, Lomund and Ne≈ø≈øa, the latter whereof neuer freezeth in Winter, though neuer ≈øo extreame, and the
waters of the other mo≈øt raging in the faire≈øt and calme≈øt weather, wherein al≈øo floateth an Iland that remoueth from place to place, as the winde forceth her ≈øpongeous and vnfa≈øtned body. In Buquhan vpon the banket of Ratra is a Well, who≈øe trickling drops turne (in Piramidy-wi≈øe) into hard ≈øtone, and another neere Edenbrough that floateth with Bitumen. In Dee and Done, be≈øides the admired plenty of Salmons, is found a Shell-fi≈øh, called the Hor≈øe-mu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ll, wherein Pearles are engaendred, mo≈øt precious for Phy≈øicke, and ≈øome of them ≈øo Orient, that they giue not place to the choi≈øe≈øt.

(16) No le≈ø≈øe ≈øtrange then any the fore-mentioned waters, but more lamentable is the remembrance of the great in ‚Ä¢ ndation, happing by the ≈øodaine ri≈øing of Tay. which bare away the Walles and Towne of Berth, and with it the Cradle and yong ≈øonne of King William into the Sea, wherein the Royall In≈øant with many others peri≈øhed, the King and his Courtiers hardly e≈øcaping the danger with life. The ruine of this Towne rai≈øed another more famous, and more commodiou≈øly ≈øeated, euen Perth, ≈øince called Saint Iohns-Towne.

(17) Ilands and Ilets yeelding both beautie and ≈øubiection to this Scoti≈øh Kingdome, are the We≈øterne, the Orknayes, and the Shetlands, reckoned to be aboue three hundred in number; the Inhabitants for the mo≈øt part v≈øing the frugalitie of the ancient Scot.

(18) The We≈øterne lying ≈øcattered in the Deucalidoman Sea, were anciently ruled by a King of their owne, who≈øe maintenance was out of their common Coffers, and the Regall Authoritie neuer continued in line all ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, for (to preuent that) their Kings were not permitted to haue wiues of their owne, but might by their Lawes accompany with other mens: as the like Law was in the other parts of Scotland, that the Virginitie of all new wiues, ≈øhould be the Landlords prey, till King Malcolme enacted, that halfe a marke ≈øhould be paid for redemption. The re≈øidence of tho≈øe fore-mentioned Kings, was chiefly in Ila, Bunals, and Iona, now Columbkill, where (as Donald Munr ‚Ä¢ , who trauelled through the≈øe Ilands reporteth) are three Tombes, hauing the ≈øeuerall In≈øcriptions of the Kings of Scotland, of Ireland, and of Norway.

(19) Among the≈øe We≈øterne Ilands, the Hebrides, Skie, Mula, Ila, and Arran, are the greate≈øt: All of them plentifull of Corne, Woods, Salmons and F ‚Ä¢ errings, as others of Conies Deere, Hor≈øes, and Sheepe, where in ≈øome they are wilde, and in others without any owners; but the people vnciuill, and lacking Religion, they rather liue rudely in ≈øtate of nece≈ø≈øitie, then as Lords of the≈øe portions which God hath allotted them; and with a ≈øufferable ea≈øe, ignorant of ambition, enioy tho≈øe contentments, which ≈øome others (though they no great ≈øumme) doe more laboriou≈øly attaine vnto by the precepts of Philo≈øopie: for, feeding them≈øelues with competencie without any exce≈ø≈øe, they returne all the ouer-plus vnto their Lords, as doe the Inhabitants of Hirta and Rona; but alas, Religion not knowne among them, the≈øe penurious vertues are rather the cur≈øes of Cham, then the followings of Chri≈øt, who forbids vs to be too carefull for the morrow.

(20) The Iles of Orkenay vpon the North of Scotland, lying in a mo≈øt raging and tempe≈øtuous Sea, are about three and thirtie in number, whereof thirteene are inhabited, and the other repleni≈øhed with Cattle: in the≈øe are no venomous Serpents, nor other vgly vermin; the aire ≈øharpe and healthfull, and the ≈øoile apt to beare onely Oats and Barley, but not a ≈øticke of wood: among the≈øe, Pomonia is the greate≈øt, accounted and called the Maine-land, affording ≈øixe Minerals of Lead and Tinne, and in her chiefe Towne a Bi≈øhops See: wherein are ≈øeated twelue Pari≈øh-Churches, one of them very magnificent for ≈øo remote a Country.

(21) Of all the Romanes, Iulius Agricola fir≈øt di≈øcouered the Orkenays; yea, and ≈øubdued them, if we will beleeue Tacitus: but Pomponius Mela, that wrote thirtie yeares before him, doth mention them, and Iuuenal in Hadrians time after him, tels vs the Romanes had won them; and la≈øtly, Claudian nameth Saxons that were ≈ølaine in them and ≈øo doth Ninius name Octha and Ebi≈ø≈øus, Saxon Commanders, who in their rouing Pinnaces wa≈øted the Orknays. The≈øe Ilands Donald Bane the v≈øurper of the Scoti≈øh Crowne, gaue to the King of Norway for his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, and by the Norwegians were they
held the ≈øpace of an hundred and ≈øixtie yeares, vntill that Alexander the third King of Scotland, with ≈øword and compo≈øition got them from Magnus the fourth, King of Norway, which afterward King Haquin confirmed vnto King Robert Bruce: but la≈øtly, Chri≈øtian the fir≈øt, King of Norway and Denmarke, vtterly renounced all his right to tho≈øe Ilands, when he gaue his daughter in marriage vnto King Iames the third, which deed was further ratified by the Pope, who openeth the way to the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Kingdomes with his owne key.

(22) More North, and further then this Chart could well expre≈ø≈øe, lie the I≈øles of Shetland, of ≈øome thought to be Thule, and by the Commenter vpon Horace, the Fortunate Iland, where as Tzetz ‚Ä¢ s fabuleth, the ≈øoules of good men are ferryed into tho≈øe Elizia ‚Ä¢
fields that euer grow greene, and whence Iulius Cae≈øar could hardly be drawne, as Muretus hath written: but their fictions intended onely that the vertuous ≈øoules of the dead pa≈ø≈øed the vttermo≈øt bounds of earthly abode, and attained to an ouer-plea≈øing repo≈øe, and euer-flouri≈øhing happine≈ø≈øe; which whether they horrowed from the de≈øcription of Paradi≈øe, (taken both for a faire Garden and the ≈øoules happy re≈øt) I cannot define; but ≈øure they would not haue made tho≈øe fields alwayes greene, if they had ≈øeene how they lye euer couered with Ice and Snow, being in the 63. degree of Latitude, as Ptolemie hath placed it, where (for the mo≈øt part) is a continuall Winter: but for proofe that this was the Thule, be≈øides Ptolemies Po≈øiture, Saxo ‚Ä¢ Grammaticus betwixt Norway and Scotland hath placed it; and Solin ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , two dayes ≈øayling from the point of Caleoni ‚Ä¢
and Tacitus ≈øaith, that the Romanes kenned Th ‚Ä¢ le a farre off, as they ≈øayled about Britaine by the Orcad ‚Ä¢ s: and la≈øtly, Mela maketh it to face Berge a Citie in Norway.

div.head: IRELAND DESCRIBED. CHAPTER I.
div.p: THe Traditions of time haue deliuered vnto vs diuers names, whereby this famous Iland is recorded to haue beene called: yet none of more faire probabilitie, then that of Orpheus, Ari≈øtotle and Claudian, by whom it is named Ierna: by Iuuenal and Mela called Iuuerna: by Diodorus Siculus, Iris: by Martian of Heraclea, Ioyepnia: by Eu≈øtachius, Oyernia, and Bernia by the natiue Inhabitants, Eryn: by the Britaines, Yuerdon: the Wel≈øh-Bards in their Ballads, Tiruolas Totidanan, and Banno: and by the Engli≈øh, Ireland. But from whence the≈øe diuer≈øities were deriued, ari≈øe many opinions. Doubtle≈ø≈øe it is, that Hibernia, Iuuerna, and Ouernia, came from Ierna, ≈øpoken of by O ‚Ä¢ pheus and Ari≈øtotle; and the ≈øame Ierna, as al≈øo Iris, Iuerdhon, and Ireland, from Erin, the terme that the Inhabitants now v≈øe. From this Erin therefore (a word proper to the Nation) the originall is mo≈øt likely to be deduced.

(2) Some deriue Hiber ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a from Hiberno tempore, that is, from the winter ≈øea≈øon; ≈øome from Hiberus a Spaniard; ≈øome from a Duke named Irnalph; ≈øome againe from the ancient Riuer Iberus, and
„Äà‚óä„Äâ from Hiere, an Iri≈øh word, which ≈øignifieth the we≈øt, or a we≈øterne coa≈øt, whence Erin may al≈øo ≈øeeme to ≈øetch the deriuation: for it lieth furthe≈øt We≈øtward of any Region in all Europe. As al≈øo for that the Riuer running in the mo≈øt remote we≈øt-part of this Iland, is in Ptolemy called Iernus: like as the furthe≈øt We≈øterne Promontory in Spaine, from whence our Iri≈øh men came, is by Strabo called
Ierne, and the Riuer next vnto it, by Mela, Ierna: yea, and Spaine it ≈øelfe, for the We≈øterne ≈øituation, is called He≈øperia: the We≈øt-Cape of Africke, He≈øperium; and in Germany, We≈øtrich and We≈øtphale ‚Ä¢
from their po≈øition haue their names. Po≈øtelius (a man that rather followed his owne fancy, then the iudgement of others) fetcheth the originall of Ireland from the Hebrewes, as if Irin ≈øhould be as much as Iurin, that is, the Iewes land: which opinion I hold no better then tho≈øe that would haue it from the Winter-like ≈øtormes, although vpon euery winde the aire is cold there.

(3) Fe≈øtus Auienus, in that little booke which he entituled Ora maritima calleth Ireland, Sacram In≈øulam, that is, the holy Iland: to which opinion the people are ≈øoone drawne, by rea≈øon of the many Saints that the Iland is ≈øaid to produce, and the ble≈ø≈øed ≈øoile that affords no venomous creatures to retaine life. It is thought that Plutarch meant Ireland by his Ogygia, for her great antiquitie; and of latter times by
‚Ä¢ ≈øidore and Bede it was called Scots of tho≈øe Scots that inhabited it: and that thence the name of Scotland, together with the Scots them≈øelues, came into Britaine.

(4) For largene≈ø≈øe and circuit, in times pa≈øt, this Iland challenged the third place in ranke of all the Iles of the then knowne world: for thus haue Geographers left vs, that the Indian Taproba ‚Ä¢
for greatne≈ø≈øe was the fir≈øt, the Ile of Britaine the next, and this of Ireland the third: and for that cau≈øe doth Ptolemy call it the little Britaine. But how ≈øoeuer Strabo hath extended the bredth, as broad as the length, and others haue formed it in ≈øhape like an egge, yet latter dimen≈øions haue found it farre otherwi≈øe, twice longer then broad, and may be compared to the forelegge of a Beare, if the Si ‚Ä¢ ile breed no offence. Who≈øe Ea≈øt-≈øide hath on it that tempe≈øtuous Sea that cutteth her channell betwixt England and this Ireland: the We≈øt is wa≈øhed with the We≈øterne Ocean; the North with the „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Caledonian; and the South with the Vergiuian Sea.

(5) The aire of this Iland is delectable and whole≈øome, though neither ≈øo cleere nor ≈øub ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
of England, which (as Mela ≈øaith) is nothing fauourable for the ripening of Cor ‚Ä¢ e: but ≈øo gratefull to the ground, that it cau≈øeth gra≈ø≈øe to grow abund ‚Ä¢ ntly, not onely fre≈øh and long, but withall very ≈øweet for all Cattle, and in Winter is more ≈øubiect to winde then ≈ønow: and that I may v≈øe the words of Giraldus, It is of all Countries mo≈øt temperate, neither forcing the Inhabitants to ≈øeeke ≈øhade from the frying heat of Cancer, nor the chilling cold of Capricorne to driue them to the fire: but at all ≈øea≈øons mo≈øt milde, betwixt a ≈øufferable cold, and gentle warme heat.

(6) The ≈øoile (≈øaith Cambren≈øis) is vneuen, wooddy, wilde, wateri≈øh and boggy, ≈øo full of Loghs and Meeres, that great ponds of water are found vpon the high Mountaines. The≈øe indeed make the places ≈øomewhat dangerous vnto all new commers, by breeding of rheums dy≈ø≈øenteries and fluxes, who≈øe v≈øuall remedie is Vskebah, a whole≈øome Aqua vita, that drieth more, and enflameth le≈ø≈øe, then many other hot confections.

(7) The Commodities of this Kingdome chiefly con≈øi≈øt in Cattle, who≈øe feed is ≈øo ≈øweet and ≈øo ranke, that they will ≈øoone graze to a ≈øurfet, if they may be ≈øuffered to feed as they will. Their ≈øheepe are many, but beare not the be≈øt wooll, which twice are ≈øhorne within one yeare. Of the≈øe they make Mantles, Caddowes, and Couerle ‚Ä¢ s, vented from thence into forraine Countries. Their Hobbies likewi≈øe are of great e≈øteeme, and are an≈øwerable to the ‚Ä¢ ennets of Spaine. Bees are there in ≈øuch abundance, that hony is found in holes of old trees, and in re≈øts of the rockes. No annoyance of hurtfull Snake or venomous creatures; and to ≈øpeake all in a word, nothing wanting for profit or plea≈øure: for ≈øo much doth Giraldus affirme, in ≈øaying, that Nature had ca≈øt into this We≈øterne Kingdome of Zephyrus a more gracious eye then was ordinary.

(8) Touching the originall peopling of this faire Iland, if we will beleeue their records, they make antiquitie it ≈øelfe but young vnto them≈øelues, affirming the dam≈øell Cae≈øarea, and niece vnto
Noah, to haue found it out before the Floud; and that three hundred yeares after; when Ia ‚Ä¢ hets po≈øteritie tooke into the≈øe We≈øt-parts of the world, one Barthela ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
of his progeny, a S ‚Ä¢ ythian by birth, encouraged by the late ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of N ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rod (who now had intruded vpon the Monarchy of Syria) wandred ≈øo farre We≈øt, that Fortune at la≈øt ca≈øt him and his people vpon the coa≈øt of Ireland. There he ≈øetled with his three ≈øonnes, Languinna, Salarus, and Ruthurgus, who ≈øearching through euery creeke and corner of the Land, left their owne names by three notable places, Langui ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , Stragrus, and Mount Salanga, which the reuolution of times hath ≈øince called by other names, as S. Dominickhill, Ruthurgi, and Stag ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . Vnder the gouernment of the≈øe three ≈øonnes, and their off-≈øpring, this land was kept about three hundred yeares; at which time there arriued al≈øo in Ireland a Giant-like kinde of people of Nimrods race, who in bodily ≈øhape exceeded the proportion of v≈øuallmen, v≈øing their ≈øtrengths to winne „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ and to oppre≈øte with rapine and violence. The≈øe growing to numbers, accounted it nece≈ø ‚Ä¢ ary to preuent dominion, le≈øt the cur≈øe of ≈ølauery (prophecied by Noah) ≈øhould light vpon them: to preuent the which, they ≈øet vp a King of their owne; then quarrels bred daily, either parties purpo≈øing to hold their intere≈øt by their ≈øwords: again≈øt whom, la≈øtly a battle was fought, and an infinite company of Giants ≈ølaine‚ñ™ when al≈øo died mo≈øt of tho≈øe of the po≈øteritie of Iapheth, leauing them of Cham Lords of Iland.

(9) Whereupon Nemethus a Scythian, with his foure ≈øonnes, arriued in Ireland, and by ≈øtrong hand ≈øeated them≈øelues among the≈øe Grants; where for two hundred and ≈øixtie yeares they kept, but then no longer able to hold out again≈øt them, they left their ≈øtandings, and departed the land.

(10) Soone after, the fiue ≈øonnes of Dela, de≈øcended from the ≈øaid Nemethus, came into the≈øe coa≈øts, and with manly prowe≈ø ‚Ä¢ e droue the≈øe mi≈øcreants out of Ireland, whereby the ≈øeed of Cham was vtterly expelled, & the≈øe of Iapheth diuided the land into fiue parts, whereof they became them≈øelues Kings:
but falling at variance, gaue aduantage vnto others, among whom the BRITAINES ≈øet in a foot.

(11) But to make this Iland more famous, certaine Hi≈øtorians haue fetched their Kings from mo≈øt vncertaine Records, as namely from Gaothel the Grecian, and Scotia (the daughter of King Pharao, and nouri≈øher of Mo≈øes) his wife: who at that time, when I≈ørael were in Egypt, with a Colony came into Spaine, and after into Ireland, where he was made King, and in honour of his Queene, the land named Scotia, from whom al≈øo the Inhabitants tooke name: his po≈øteritie increa≈øing in the parts of Spaine, where fir≈øt they had ≈øeated, in proce≈ø ‚Ä¢ e of time ≈øought further aduentures vnder the foure ≈øonnes of Mile≈øius King of Spaine, who≈øe names were Hibernus, Hermion, Euer, and Erimon.

(12) The≈øe, by the direction ≈øufferance, and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Gurguntius, King of the Britaines, after that Ireland had beene very much di≈øpeopled by a contagious pe≈øtilence, ≈øeated them≈øelues, and from the elde≈øt, Hiberius, called the I ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ and Hibernia, as ≈øome are of opinion: the≈øe diuided the whole into fiue Pro ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nces, famou≈øly knowne by the names of Moun≈øter, Lein≈øter, Connaught, Vl≈øter, and M ‚Ä¢ ath in their mid≈øt: and from the≈øe the pre≈øent Iri≈øh repute them≈øelues to come. Yet ≈øurely, as I make no que≈øtion, but that this Iland became inhabited euen of old time, when mankinde againe ouer-≈øpred the face of the earth, ≈øo doubt I not, but that our Britaines pa≈ø ‚Ä¢ ed thereinto them≈øelues, ≈øuch infinite number of words in the Iri≈øh language yet in v≈øe, ≈øuch ancient names of Waters, I≈øles, Mountaines, and places, meerely Briti≈øh words, yet remaining, and the te≈øtimony of
‚Ä¢ acitus, who ≈øaith, that their manners were fa≈øhioned to the Britaines, inforceth ≈øo much; and Ptolemy before him, calleth that Iland by the name of little Britaine: all which ≈øhew a former intere≈øt for Ireland, then that which by conque≈øt vnder Henry the ≈øecond was made.

(13) That it euer was ≈øubiect to the Romans, is doubtfull, though Agricola did wi≈øh it, and Tacitus held mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary: yea, and in the diui≈øion of their Empire, Ireland, with Britaine and Thule, fell vnto Con≈øtantine the ≈øonne of Con≈øtantine the great; yet their manners vnreclaimed, and barbari≈øme retained long after tho≈øe dayes, doe witne≈ø≈øe no ≈øuch „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øowne, to be in that plot. But when Romes great Empire began to grow le≈ø≈øe, the Scots or Scythians grew mightie in Ireland: and as Oro≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
writeth, that I≈øland was wholly inhabited by the Scoti≈øh Nation in the dayes of Honorius, and Ar ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
dius, the Emperours: who≈øe warres and ≈ølaughter, Claudian doth lightly touch in this his Ver≈øe.

q.l: Scotorum cumulos fleuit glacialis Ierne.
The frozen Ireland wept to ≈øee, her Scots all ≈ølaine on h ‚Ä¢ apes to be.

div.p: (14) As the≈øe for the mo≈øt part, by the te≈øtimony of Ninius, were the ancient Inhabitants, ≈øo by other ancient Writers, their cu≈øtomes and manners are thus ≈øet forth: Strabo ≈øaith, The Inhabitants of Ireland are more rude then the Britaines, they feed vpon the fle≈øh of men, yea, and thinke it a point of worth to eat their dead parents: want only they accompany with women, making no difference of other mens wiues, their owne ≈øi≈øters, nor of their naturall mothers: but of the≈øe things (≈øaith he) we haue no certaine witne≈ø≈øe of ≈øufficient credit. Po ‚Ä¢ ponius Mela recordeth, that the Iri≈øh are vn ‚Ä¢ iuill, ignorant of vertues, and void of religion: And Solinus affirmeth, that after victory they drinke the bloud of the ≈ølaine, and be≈ømeare their owne faces therewith; ≈øo giuen to warre, that the mother at the birth of a man-childe, feedeth the fir≈øt meat into her infants mouth, vpon the point of her husbands ≈øword, and with he at ‚Ä¢ eni≈øh imprecations, wi≈øheth that it may die no otherwi≈øe then in warre or by ≈øword.

(15) But from the≈øe ancient and barbarous manners, let vs come to the conditions of their middle time; whom Giraldus Cambren≈øis de≈øcribeth as followeth: The Iri≈øh (≈øaith he) are a ≈øtrong and bold
people, martiall and prodigall in warre, nimble, ≈øtout, and haughtie of heart; carele≈ø≈øe of life, but greedie of glory; courteous to ≈øtrangers, con≈øtant in loue, light of beliefe, impatient of iniurie, giuen to fle≈øhly lu≈øts, and in enmitie implacable. At the baptizing of their Infants, their manner was, not to dip their right armes into the water, that ≈øo (as they thought) they might giue a more deepe and incurable blow; neuer calling them by the names of their Parents while≈øt they liued together, but at their death tooke it vpon them. Their women nur≈øed not the children they bare; and they that nur≈øed others, did affect and loue them much more then their owne.

(16) So much were they giuen to fanta≈øticall conceits, that they held it very ominous to giue their neighbours fire vpon May-day: to eat an old egge, endangered the death of their hor≈øe: and before they ca≈øt in their ≈øeed, they ≈øend ≈øalt into the field: to hang vp the ≈øhelles in the roofe, was a pre≈øeruatiue of the chickens from the kite: to ≈øet vp greene boughes at their doores in the Moneth of May, increa≈øed their kines milke; and to ≈øpit vpon Cattle, they held it good again≈øt Witchery, whereof Ireland was full.

(17) Super≈øtitious Idolatry among the wilde Iri≈øh was common, yeelding diuine honour vnto the Moone after the change, vnto whom they both bowed their knees, and made ≈øupplications; and with a loud voice would thus ≈øpeake vnto that Planet: Wee pray thee leaue vs in as good e≈øtate as thou found≈øt vs. Wolues they did make their God≈øibs, terming them Chari Chri≈øt, and ≈øo thought them≈øelues pre≈øerued from their hurts: the hoofes of dead hor≈øes they accounted and held ≈øacred: about childrens necks they hung the beginning of Saint Iohns Go≈øpell, a crooked naile of an hor≈øe-≈øhooe, or a peece of a Wolues skinne; and both the ≈øucking-childe and nur≈øe were girt with girdles finely plated of womans haire; ≈øo farre they wandred into the wayes of errour, in making the≈øe armes the ≈øtrength of their healths.

(18) Their wiues were many, by rea≈øon of diuorcements, and their maids married at twelue
yeares of age, who≈øe cu≈øtomes were to ≈øend to their louers, bracelets plated, and curiou≈øly wrought of their owne haire; ≈øo farre following Venus in the knots of the≈øe a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ urements. The men wore linnen ≈øhirts exceedingly large, ≈øtained with Saffron, the ≈øleeues wide, and hanging to their knees, ≈øtrait and ≈øhort tru≈øtes plated thicke in the skirts, their breeches clo≈øe to the thighes, a ≈øhort skeine hanging point downe before, and a mantle mo≈øt times ca≈øt ouer their heads. The women wore their haire plated in curious manner, hanging downe their backes and ≈øhoulders, from vnder ≈øoulden wreathes of fine linnen, rolled about their heads, rather loading the wearer, then delighting the beholder: for as the one was mo≈øt ≈øeemely, ≈øo the other was vn≈øightly: their neckes were hung with chaines and carkaneths, their armes wreathed with many bracelets, and ouer their ≈øide-garments the ≈øhagge rugge mantles purfled with a deepe Fringe of diuers colours, both ≈øexes accounting idlene≈ø ‚Ä¢ e their onely libertie, and ea≈øe their greate≈øt riches.

(19) In warres they were forward, and fought with battle-axes, who≈øe bearers were called Gallogla≈ø≈øes, the common Souldier but lightly armed, who ≈øerued with darts and ≈øharpe skeines; their Trumpet was a Bagge-pipe, and word for encounter, Pharroh; which at the fir≈øt on≈øet with great acclamation they vttered, and he that did not, was taken into the ayre, and carried into the vale of Kerr ‚Ä¢ , where transformed (as they did beleeue) he remained vntill he was hunted with Hounds from thence to his home.

(20) For the dying and dead they hired women to mourne, who expo≈øtulated with the ≈øicke, why he would die; and dead, at his Funerall ≈øuch out-cries were made, ≈øuch clapping of hands, ≈øuch howlings, and ge≈øtures, that one would thinke their ≈øorrowes vnrecouerable, holding the opinion of Pythagoras for the ≈øoules departed.

(21) Their dyet in nece≈ø≈øitie was ≈ølender, feeding vpon water-cre≈ø≈øes, rootes, mu≈øhromes, ≈øhamrogh, butter tempered with oat-meale, milke, whey, yea, and raw fle≈øh, the bloud being cru≈øhed out:
their v≈øe was al≈øo to let their kine bloud, which ≈øtanding a while, and comming to a ielly, with butter they did eat, as a very good di≈øh.

(22) That the Go≈øpell of Chri≈øt ≈øhould be preached in Ireland by Iames the Apo≈øtle, I will not affirme, though Vincentius hath ≈øaid it: neither will I, with the Scots, bring the Ilands conuer≈øion from a Chri≈øtian woman, who (as their Hi≈øtorians doe auouch) fir≈øt in≈øtructed the Queene, and the Queene her husband, and he againe his Subiects, till all became Chri≈øtians. But mo≈øt true it is, that the Scots fir≈øt receiued the doctrine of Chri≈øt in this Kingdome of Ireland; for thus writeth Pro≈øper: Coele≈øtin Pope of Rome ≈øent his Archdeacon Palladius into Britaine to with≈øtand the Pelagian here≈øie, who at one time did driue out the≈øe enemies of grace, and ordained a Bi≈øhop among the Scots, whereby that barbarous Nation embraced Chri≈øtianitie. Yet Ninius reporteth, that Palladius did nothing in neither, being taken away by vntimely death: but that S. Patricke, borne at E ‚Ä¢ burne in Clued≈ødale, the ≈øonne of Calphurus, by the ≈øi≈øter of S. Martin, was the fir≈øt Apo≈øtle for Ireland, who ≈øowed his heauenly ≈øeede with ≈øuch plentifull increa≈øe, that the ≈øoile it ≈øelfe ≈øhortly was called Sanctorum Patria, the Country of Saints: for who≈øe Sepulchre after his death ro≈øe as great variance, as was for Homer among≈øt them of Greece: they of Downe challenged his graue to be with them, vpon certaine Ver≈øes written on a Tombe, which a≈øcribes Patricke, Briget, and Columbe to be buried therein: they of Armagh lay claime by the warrant of S. Bernard, who ≈øaith, that Patricke in his life time there ruled, and after death there re≈øted. Gla≈øcenbury in England by ancient records will haue his bodie interred with them; and Scotland auoucheth his birth to be at Gla≈øco, and bones to re≈øt at Kirk-Patricke with them: of ≈øuch reuerent e≈øteeme was this Iri≈øh Apo≈øtle.

(23) This Patricke in his youth had beene taken captiue by the Iri≈øh Pirats, and for ≈øixe yeares continuance ≈øerued Mac ‚Ä¢ uain as his ≈ølaue, and keeper of his ≈øwine: in which deiected condition, ≈øo de≈øirous he was of the Lands ≈øaluation, that in his dreames he thought the Infants vnborne cryed
vnto him for Bapti≈øme; and redeeming him≈øelfe thence for a peece of gold found in the field, which a ≈øwine had turned vp, in his aged yeares came backe againe into Ireland, preached the Go≈øpell, conuerted the people, and la≈øtly became Archbi≈øhop of Armagh. Of who≈øe miracles and Purgatorie, I leaue others to ≈øpeake; that are more credulous in the one, and haue better lei≈øure to relate the other, and will ≈øhew thee Ireland as now it is, fir≈øt in generall, and then in parts.

div.head: THE PROVINCE OF MOVNSTER. CHAPTER II.
div.p: THis Prouince, called in Iri≈øh, Mown; in a more ordinary con≈øtruction of ≈øpeech, Wown; in Latine, Momonia; and in Engli≈øh, Moun≈øter; lieth open South ward to the Verginian Sea: North-ward it affronteth part of Connaught: The Ea≈øt is neighboured by L ‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ ≈øter: and the We≈øt is altogether wa≈øhed with the We≈øt Ocean.

(2) The length thereof extended from Ballatimore-Bay in her South, vnto the Bay of Galway in her North, are about nintie miles. Her broade≈øt part from Ea≈øt to We≈øt, is from Waterford-Hauen to Feriter Hauen, and containeth an hundred miles. The whole circumference, by following the prometaries and indents, are aboue fiue hundred and fortie miles.

(3) The forme thereof is quadrant or foure-≈øquare. The „Äà‚óä„Äâ milde and temperate, neither too chilling cold, not too ≈øcorching hot. The ≈øoyle in ≈øome parts is hilly, looking „Äà‚óä„Äâ with wooddy, wilde, and ≈øolitary mountaines: yet the vallies below are garni≈øhed with Corne-fields. And generally, all, both plea≈øant for fight, and fertile for ≈øoile.

(4) This Prouince is at this day diuided into two parts that is, the We≈øt-Moun≈øter, and the South-Moun≈øter. The We≈øt-Moun≈øter was inhabited i ‚Ä¢ old „Äà‚óä„Äâ by the „Äà‚óä„Äâ the Velabri, and the Vteri ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ : the South-Moun≈øter by the Oudi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
or
„Äà‚óä„Äâ , and the Cori ‚Ä¢ ndi. The Velabri and
„Äà‚óä„Äâ
are ≈øaid (by Oro≈øius) to haue dwelt in that part of the Country, where it lyeth outmo≈øt We≈øtward, and pa≈ø≈øing towards the Cantabrian Ocean, looketh a farre off to Gallitia in Spaine. The Luceni of Ireland (who ≈øeeme to haue deriued their name and originall from the Lucen ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
of Gall ‚Ä¢ tia, and of whom there ≈øtill remaine ≈øome reliques in the Barony of Lyxno ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ) are ≈øuppo≈øed to haue bin ≈øeated in tho≈øe parts that lie neighbouring vpon the banke of the Riuer Shemon.

(5) The generall Commodities of this Prouince, are Corne, Cattle, Wood, Wooll, and Fi≈øh. The la≈øt whereof, it affords in euery place plenty & abundance of all ≈øorts. But none ≈øo well knowne for the ≈øtore of Herrings that are taken there, as is the Promontory called Eraugh, that lies betweene Bantre and Ballatimore Bay, whereunto euery yeare a great Fleet of Spaniards and Portugals re≈øort (euen in the midde≈øt of Winter) to fi≈øh al≈øo for Cods.

(6) The principall Citie of the Prouince is Limericke, which the Iri≈øh call Loumeagh, compa≈ø≈øed about with the famous Riuer Shennon, by the parting of the Channell. This is a Bi≈øhops See, and the very Mart-Towne of Moun≈øter. It was fir≈øt wonne by Reymond le Gro≈ø≈øe an Engli≈øhman, afterwards burnt by Duncnald an Iri≈øh petty King of Thuetmond. Then in proce≈ø≈øe of time, Philip Breos an Engli≈øhman was infeoffed in it, and King Iohn fortified it with a Ca≈øtle, which he cau≈øed therein to be built. In this Ca≈øtle certaine Ho≈øtages making their abode in the yeare 1332 grew (as is reported) ≈øo full of pride and in≈øolency, that they flew the Con≈øtable thereof, and ≈øeized the Ca≈øtle into their owne hands. But the re≈øolute Citizens, that could neither brooke nor beare with ≈øuch barbareus crueltie, did in reuenge then ≈øhew ≈øuch manly courage and viuacitie, as they ≈øoone after recouered the Ca≈øtle againe, repaying the Ho≈øtages in ≈øuch ho≈øtile manner, as that they put them all to the ≈øword without partialitie. The po≈øition of this Towne is by Mercator placed for Latitude 53. degrees 20. minutes; and for Longitude, 9. degrees and 34. minutes. Neere vnto the Riuer that Ptolemy calleth Daucona, and Giraldus Cambren≈øis (by the alteration of ≈øome few letters) nameth Sauranus and Sauarenus, which i≈ø≈øueth out of Muskerey Mountaines, is ≈øeated the Citie Corke, graced al≈øo with another Epi≈øcopall dignitie (and with the Bi≈øhops See of Clon annexed vnto it) which Giraldus calleth Corragia, the Engli≈øhmen Corke, & the natiue Inhabitants of the Country Coreach. This Towne is ≈øo be≈øet on euery ≈øide with neighbouring mole≈øters, as that they are ≈øtill con≈øtrained to keepe watch and ward, as if there lay continuall ≈øiege again≈øt it. The Citizens of this place are all linkt
together in ≈øome one or other degree of affinitie, for that they dare not match their daughters in marriage into the Country, but make contracts of matrimony one with another among them≈øelues. In this place, that holy and religious man Briock is ≈øaid to haue his birth and breeding, who flouri≈øhed among the Gaules in that fruitfull age of Chri≈øtianitie, and from whom the Dioce≈ø≈øe of Sanbr ‚Ä¢ och in Britaine Armorua, commonly called S‚ñ™ Brieu, had the denomination.

(7) The Citie which the Iri≈øh and Britaines call Porthlargy, and the Engli≈øh, Waterford, though it be la≈øt in place, yet is it not lea≈øt in account, as being the ≈øecond Citie of all Ireland, as well for the conuenience and commodiou≈øne≈ø≈øe of the Hauen, that affords ≈øuch nece≈ø≈øary aptitude for trade and traffique, as al≈øo for the faithfull loyaltie which it hath alwayes ≈øhewed to the Imperiall Crowne of England: for euer ≈øince it was wonne by Richard Earle of Pembrook ‚Ä¢ , it ≈øtill performed the obedience and peaceable offices of dutie and ≈øeruice vnto the Engli≈øh, as they continued their cour≈øe in the conque≈øt of Ireland: whence it is that the Kings of England haue from time to time endowed it with many large Franchi≈øes and Liberties, which King Henry the ≈øeauenth did both augment and confirme.

(8) Although ≈øince the time of S. Patricke, Chri≈øtianitie was neuer extinct in this Country, yet the gouernment being haled into contrary factions, the Nobility lawle≈ø ‚Ä¢ e, and the multitude wilfull, it hath come to pa≈ø≈øe, that Religion hath waxed (with the temporall common ≈øort) more cold and feeble, being mo≈øt of them very irreligious, and addicted wholly to ≈øuper≈øtitious ob≈øeruations: for in ≈øome parts of this Prouince, ≈øome are of opinion, that certaine men are yearely turned into Wolues, and made Wolfe-men. Though this hath beene con≈øtantly affirmed by ≈øuch as thinke their cen≈øures worthy to pa≈ø≈øe for currant and credible; yet let vs ≈øuppo≈øe that happily they be po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with the di≈øea≈øe and maladie that the Phy≈øicians call Lycanthropy, which begetteth and engendreth ≈øuch like phanta≈øies through the malicious humours of Melancholy: and ≈øo oftentimes men imagine them≈øelues
to be turned and transformed into formes which they are not. Some againe embrace another ridiculous opinion, and per≈øwade them≈øelues, that he who in the barbarous acclamation and outcry of the Souldiers, which they v≈øe with great forcing and ≈øtraining of their voices, when they ioyne battaile, doth not howte and make a noi≈øe as the re≈øt doe, is ≈øuddenly caught from the ground, and carried as it were flying in the ayre, out of any Country of Ireland, into ≈øome de≈øert vallies, where he feedeth vpon gra≈ø≈øe, drinketh water, hath ≈øome v≈øe of rea≈øon, but not of ≈øpeech, is ignorant of the pre≈øent condition he ≈øtands in, whether good or bad: yet at length ≈øhall be brought to his own home, being ‚Ä¢ aught with the helpe of Hounds and Hunters. Great pitie that the foule fiend and father of darkne≈ø≈øe, ≈øhould ≈øo grieuou≈øly ≈øeduce this people with misbeliefe, and that the≈øe errours be not cha≈øed away with the truth of Chri≈øtian Religion, whereby as they carry much grace in their countenances, they may al≈øo not be void of the inward grace of their ≈øoules and vnder≈øtanding.

(9) This Prouince hath beene fore wa≈øted in the rebellions of De≈ømond, to who≈øe ayde Pope Gregory the thirteenth, and Philip King of Spaine, ≈øent certaine companies of Italians and Spaniards, who arriued not farre from Dingle, fortified them≈øelues, & gaue it the name of Fort de Ore, founding loud threats again≈øt the whole Country. But A ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ur
„Äà‚óä„Äâ
Grey, Lord Deputie of Ireland, at the fir≈øt on≈øet decided their quarrell, by ≈øheathing his ≈øword in their bowels: and De≈ømond fearefully flying into the woods, was by a Souldier cut ≈øhorter by the head. And againe, when the Kingdome of Ireland lay bleeding, and put almo≈øt to the hazard of the la≈øt ca≈øt, Don Iohn D' Aquila, with 8. thou≈øand Spaniards (vpon confidence of the excommunications of Pius the fift, Gregory the thirteenth, & Clement the eight, Popes, all of them di≈øcharging their cur≈øes like vnto thunder bolts again≈øt Queene Elizabeth of ble≈ø≈øed memory) landed neere vnto Kin≈øale pre≈øuming that the rebellions of Tyrone had turned the hearts of the Iri≈øh for Rome: Sir Charles Blunt Lord Montioy, in the depth of Winter, and with his tired Souldiers, ≈øo d ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nted their Spani≈øh hearts, that with one victory he repre≈ø≈øed their bragging boldne≈ø≈øe, and recouered the Iri≈øh that were ready to reuolt.

(10) God hath oftentimes ≈øhewed his tender loue and affection to this people, in laying his fatherly cha≈øti≈øements and afflictions vpon them, ≈øometimes by windes, ≈øometimes by famine and dearth, and ≈øometimes againe by opening his hand of plenty into their laps to conuert them to him≈øelfe, and to diuert their hearts from ≈øuper≈øtitions. In the yeare 1330 about the Fea≈øt of Saint Iohn
„Äà‚óä„Äâ , there be an ≈øuch a dea ‚Ä¢ th of Co ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e in this Country, by the abundance of raine and the inundation of waters (which continued vntill Michaelmas following) that a Cranoc of Wheat was ≈øold for „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , a Cranoc of Oats for eight ≈øhillings, a Cranoc of Pea≈øe, Beanes, and Barley for as much. „Äà‚óä„Äâ wind ‚Ä¢ s the ≈øame yeare were ≈øo mightie, that many were hurt, and many ≈ølaine outright by the fall of hou≈øes that was forced by the violence of the ≈øame. The like whereof were neuer ≈øeene in Ireland. In the yeare 1317 there was ≈øuch a dearth of Corne and other victuals, that a Cranoc of Wheat was ≈øold for twentie three ≈øhillings. And many Hou≈øholders, that before time had ≈øu≈øtained and „Äà‚óä„Äâ a great number, were this yeare driuen to beg, and many fami≈øhed. In the time of which
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ mine, the mercy of God ≈øo di≈øpo≈øed, that vpon the 27. day of Iune, in the yeare 1331‚ñ™ there came to land ≈øuch a mightie multitude of great Sea-fi≈øhes (that is) Thur≈øheds, ≈øuch as in many ages pa≈øt had neuer beene ≈øeene, that the people were much comforted in this di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, and receiued great reliefe and ≈øu≈øtenance by the ≈øame.

(11) Places of Rel ‚Ä¢ gion in this Country, were the two Abbies at Yoghall, called the North-Abbey and South-Abbey: The two Abbies at Limericke, S. Francis Abbey, and S Dominicke Abbey: The two Abbies at Corke, the Abbey of the Ile, and S. Frances Abbey: and the famous Abbey (in times pa≈øt) of the holy Cro≈ø≈øe which hath had many priuiledges and liberties granted vnto it, in honour of a peece of Chri≈øts Cro≈ø≈øe, that was (as they ≈øay) ≈øometimes pre≈øerued there. Thus were Chri≈øtians per≈øwaded in ancient times‚ñ™ And it is a wonder in what Troopes and A≈ø≈øemblies people doe (euen yet) conflow thither vpon deuotion, as vnto a place of holine≈ø≈øe and ≈øanct ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e; ≈øo firmely are
they ≈øettled in the Religion of their Fore-fathers, which hath beene increa≈øed beyond all mea≈øure by the negligent care of their Teachers, who ≈øhould in≈øtruct their ignorance, and labour to reduce them from the errors they per≈øeuere in.

This Prouince is gouerned by a Lord Pre≈øident, who hath one a≈ø≈øi≈øtant, twelue learned Lawyers, and a Secretary to keepe it in dutie and obedience. It was in times pa≈øt diuided into many parts, as Towoun, that is, North-Moun≈øter; De≈øwoun, that is, South-Moun≈øter; Hierwoun, that is, We≈øt-Moun≈øter; Mean-woun, that is, Middle Mona≈øter; and Vrwoun, that is, the Front of Moun≈øter. But at this day it is di≈øtingui≈øhed into the≈øe Counties; Kerry, De≈ømond, Limericke, Tipperary, Holycro≈ø≈øe, Waterford, and Corke: which County in times pa≈øt had beene a Kingdome, containing with it De≈ømond al≈øo: for ≈øo in the Grant giuen by King Henry the ≈øecond vnto Robert Fitz-Stephen, and to Miles de Cogan, it is called in the≈øe words: Know yee that I haue granted the whole Kingdome of Corke, excepting the Citie and Cantred of the Ou≈øtmans, to hold for them and their heires, of me and Iohn my ≈øonne, by the ≈øeruice of ≈øixtie Knights. The County of Waterford, King Henry the ≈øixt gaue vnto Iohn Talbot Earle of Shrewsburie, with the name, ≈øtile, and title of Earle of Waterford, which was afterward againe a≈ø≈øumed to the Crowne. Touching the County of Holy-Cro≈ø≈øe, as the opinion of that much frequented Abbey is much le≈ø≈øened, ≈øo that County is ≈øwallowed vp altogether in the County
‚Ä¢ ipperary. It is fortified with fiue ≈øtrong Ca≈øtles, traded with ≈øixe Market-Townes, and diuided as followeth.
MOVNSTER
L ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ericke.
Kery.
Corke.
Waterford.
De≈ømond.
Holy Cro≈ø≈øe in
Tipporary.

div.head: LEINSTER. CHAPTER III.
div.p: THis Country, the Natiues call Leighnigh, the Britaines Lein; in Latine, Lagenia; in the ancient liues of the Saints, Lagen; and in Engli≈øh, Lein≈øter. It lieth Ea≈øtward along Hibernicum Sea: on Connaught ≈øide We≈øtward it is bounded with the Riuer Shanon; the North with the Territorie of Louth, and the South with part of the Prouince of Moun≈øter. This Country butteth vpon England, as Moun≈øter and Connaught doe vpon Spaine.

(2) The forme thereof is triangle, and ≈øides not much vnequall, from her South-Ea≈øt vnto the We≈øt-point about 80. miles, from thence to her North-We≈øt about 70. miles, and her Ea≈øt Coa≈øt along the Iri≈øh Sea-≈øhore, eightie miles: the circumference vpon two hundred and ≈øeauentie miles.

(3) The aire is cleare and gentle, mixt with a temperate di≈øpo≈øition, yeelding neither extremitie of heat or cold, according to the ≈øea≈øonable times of the yeare, and the naturall condition of the Continent. The ≈øoile is generally fruitfull, plentifull both in fi≈øh and fle≈øh, and in other victuals, as butter, chee≈øe, and mile. It is fertile in Corne, Cattle, and pa≈øture grounds, and would be much more, if the husbandman did but apply his indu≈øtry, to which he is inuited by the commodiou≈øne≈ø≈øe of the Country. It is well watered with Riuers, and for the mo≈øt part well woodded, except the Countie of Diuelin, which complaines much of that want, being ≈øo de≈øtitute of wood, that they are compelled to v≈øe a clammie kinde of fat turffe for their fuell, or Sea-coale brought out of England.

(4) The Inhabitants of the≈øe parts in Ptolemies dayes were the Brigantes, Mena ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , Cauci, and Blain; from which Blani may ≈øeeme to be deriued and contracted the latter and moderne names of this Country, Lein, Leighnigh, and Lein≈øter. The Mena ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
(as the name doth after a ≈øort imply) came from
the Menapians, a Nation in Low Germany, that dwelt by the Sea-Coa≈øts. The≈øe Brigantes, ca ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed al≈øo Birgantes, Florianus del Campo (a Spaniard) labours to fetch from the Brigants of his owne Country, of whom an ancient Citie in Spaine (called Brigantia) tooke the name. But they may ≈øeeme rather to deriue their denomination from the Riuer Birgus, about which they inhabited; for to this the very name is almo≈øt ≈øufficient to per≈øwade vs.

(5) The commodities of this Country doe chiefly con≈øi≈øt in Cattle, Sea-fowle, and Fi≈øh. It breeds many excellent good hor≈øes, called Iri≈øh Hobbies, which haue not the ≈øame pace that other hor≈øes haue in their cour≈øe, but a ≈øoft and round amble, ≈øetting very ea≈øily.

(6) This Country hath in it three Riuers of note, termed in old time the three ≈øi≈øters, Shour, Neor, and Barraeo, which i≈ø≈øue out of the huge Mountaine (called by Giraldus, Bladina Montes) as out of their mothers wombe, and from their ri≈øing tops de≈øcending with a downefall into ≈øeuerall Channels, before they emptie them≈øelues into the Ocean, ioyne hand in hand all together in a mutuall league and combination.

(7) Places very dangerous for ≈øhipping are certaine fiats and ≈øhallowes in the Sea, that lie ouer again≈øt Holy-point, which the Marriners call the Grounds. Al≈øo the ≈øhelues of ≈øand that lie a great way in length oppo≈øite to Newca≈øtle, which ouer-looketh them into the Sea from the top of an high hill adioyning.

(8) In this Prouince are placed many faire and wealthy Townes, as Kilkenny, which for a Burrough-Towne excels all the midland Burroughs in this Iland. Kildare, which is adorned with an Epi≈øcopall See, and much graced in the fir≈øt infancy of the Iri≈øh Church, by rea≈øon of Saint Bridgid a venerable Virgin, had in great account and e≈øtimation for her virginitie and deuotion, as who was the Di≈øciple of S. Patricke of ≈øo great fame, renowne, and antiquite: Al≈øo Weisford (a name giuen vnto it by the≈øe Germans, whom the Iri≈øh terme Ou≈øtmans) a Towne though inferiour to ≈øome, yet as
memorable as any, for that it became the fir≈øt Colony of the Engli≈øh, and did fir≈øt ≈øubmit it ≈øelfe vnto their protection, being a≈ø≈øaulted by Fitz Stephen, a Captaine worthily made famous for his valour and magnanimitie.

(9) But the Citie which fame may iu≈øtly celebrate alone, beyond all the Cities or Townes in Ireland, is that which we call Diuelin, Ptole ‚Ä¢ ie Eblana, the Latini≈øts Dublinium, and Dublinia; the We≈øt-Britaines, Dinas Dulm; the Engli≈øh-Saxons in times pa≈øt, Duplin; and the Iri≈øh, Balacleigh, that is, the Towne vpon hurdles: for it is reported that the place being fenni≈øh and moori≈øh, when it fir≈øt began to be builded, the foundation was laid vpon hurdles.

(10) That it is ancient, is per≈øwaded by the authoritie of Ptol ‚Ä¢ mie. That it was grieuou≈øly rent and di≈ømembred in the tamultuous warres of the Danes, and brought afterwards vnder the ≈øub ‚Ä¢ ection of Eadgar King of England, (which his Charter al≈øo confirmeth, wherein he calleth it the noble Citie of Ireland) is written by Saxo Grammaticus. That it was built by Harold of Norway, which may ≈øeeme to be Harold Har ‚Ä¢ ager, when he had brought the greate≈øt part of Ireland into an awfull obedience vnto him, we reade in the life of Griffith ap S ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ an Prince of Wales. At length it yeelded vnto the valour and protection of the Engli≈øh, at their fir≈øt arriuall into Ireland, by whom it was manfully defended from the fierce a≈ø≈øaults as well of Au≈øcoulph Prince of the D ‚Ä¢ blinians, as afterwards of Gottard King of the I≈øles: ≈øince which time it hath ≈øtill augmented her flouri≈øhing e≈øtate, and giuen approued te≈øtimony of her faith and loyaltie to the Crowne of England, in the times of any tumultuous ≈øtreights and commotions.

(11) This is the royall ≈øeat of Ireland, ≈øtrong in her munition, beautifull in her buildings, and (for the quantitie) matchable to many other Cities, frequent for trafficke and intercour≈øe of Merchants‚ñ™ In the Ea≈øt Suburbs, Henry the ≈øecond, King of England (as H ‚Ä¢ ueden reporteth) cau≈øed a royall Pallace to be erected: and Henry Loundres, Archbi≈øhop of Diuelin, built a Store-hou≈øe about the
yeare of Chri≈øt 1220. Not farre from it is the beautifull Colledge con≈øecrated vnto the name of the holy Trinitie, which Queene Elizabeth of famous memory dignified with the priuiledges of an Vniuer≈øitie. The Church of S. Patricke being much enlarged by King Iohn, was by Iohn Comin Archbi≈øhop of Dublin, borne at Eue≈øham in England, fir≈øt ordained to be a Church of Prebends in the yeare 1191. It doth at this day maintaine a Deane, a Chanter, a Chancellor, a Trea≈øurer, two Archdeacons, and twentie two Prebendaries.

This Citie in times pa≈øt, for the due admini≈øtration of Ciuill Gouernment, had a Prouo≈øt for the chiefe Magi≈øtrate. But in the yeare of mans redemption 1409 King Henry the fourth granted them libertie to chu≈øe euery yeare a Maior and two Baili≈øtes, and that the Maior ≈øhould haue a gilt ≈øword carried before him for euer. And King Edward the ≈øixt (to heape more honour vpon this place) changed the two Bailiffes afterwards into Sheriffes: ≈øo that there is not any thing here wanting that may ≈øerue to make the e≈øtate of a Citie mo≈øt flouri≈øhing.

(12) As the people of this County doe about the neighbouring parts of Diuelin come neere≈øt vnto the ciuill conditions and orderly ≈øubiection of the Engli≈øh: ≈øo in places farther off they are more tumultuous, being at deadly feuds among≈øt them≈øelues, committing oft times Man-≈ølaughter one vpon another, and working their owne mi≈øchiefes by mutuall wrongs: for ≈øo the Iri≈øh of Lein≈øter wa≈øted Lein≈øter with many Townes in the ≈øame Prouince in the yeare 1294. And in the yeare 1301. the men of Lein≈øter in like manner rai≈øed a warre in the winter ≈øea≈øon, ≈øetting on fire the Towne of Wyk ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ lo, Rathdon, and others, working their owne plague and puni≈øhment by burning vp their ≈øu≈øtenance, and lo≈øing their Ca≈øtle by depredation.

(13) Matter of ob≈øeruation, and no le≈ø≈øe admiration among them, is the Giants dance, commonly ≈øo called, and ≈øo much talked of, which Merlin is ≈øaid by Art Magicke to haue tran≈ølated out of this Territorie vnto Salisburie Plaine: which how true it is, I leaue to the vaine beleeuers of miracles, and to the credulous ob≈øeruers of antiquitie.

(14) In this County haue beene erected many famous Mona≈øteries, Abbies, and religious hou≈øes, con≈øecrated to deuout and holy purpo≈øes: As the Mona≈øtery of Saint Maries of Ou≈øtmanby,
‚Ä¢ ounded for preaching Friers, vnto which of late dayes the Iudiciall Courts of the Kingdome haue beene tran≈ølated: al≈øo the magnificent Abbey called S. Thomas Court at Dublin, builded and endowed in times pa≈øt with many large priuiledges and reuenewes of King Henry the ≈øecond, in expiation of the murther of Thomas Arch-bi≈øhop of Canterbury. Likewi≈øe Tiutern Mona≈øtery, or the notable Abbey which William Mar≈øhall Earle of Pembrooke founded, and called De roto, for that he had vowed to God (being to≈ø≈øed at Sea with many a ≈øore and dangerous tempe≈øt) to erect an Abbey where≈øoeuer he came to land, and being (after ≈øhipwracke) ca≈øt vpon land in this place, he made performance of his vow accordingly.

This Prouince containeth the Counties of Kilkenny, Caterlogh, Queenes Ceunty, Kings Countie, Kildare, Ea≈øt-Meath, We≈øt-Meath, Weisford, and Dublin (to ≈øay nothing of
‚Ä¢ icklo and Fernes, which either be already, or el≈øe are to be annexed vnto it) and ≈øubdiuided into ofreene Market-Townes. It hath beene fortified with the ≈øtrength of many Ca≈øtles again≈øt the power of enemies, and is thus diuided:
Counties,
Ea≈øt Meath.
We≈øt Meath.
Kilkenny.
Caterbough.
Queenes County.
Kings County.
Kildare.
Weisford.
Dublin.

div.head: THE PROVINCE OF CONNAVGHT. CHAPTER IIII.
div.p: THis Prouince named by Giraldus Cambren≈øis, Conachtia, and Conacia, by the Iri≈øh, Conaughty, and by Engli≈øh-men, Connaught: is bounded Ea≈øt-ward, with part of the County of Lein≈øter; North-ward, with part of Vl≈øter; We≈øt-ward, with the We≈øt-maine Ocean; and on the South, it is confined with a part of the Prouince of Moun≈øter, clo≈øed in with the Riuer Sbennon, and butting again≈øt the Kingdome of Spaine.

(2) The forme thereof is long, and towards the North and South ends, thinne and narrow; but as it growes towards the middle, from either part it waxeth ≈øtill bigger and bigger: extending in length from the Riuer Shennon in her South, to Enis Kelling in her North, 126. miles, and the broade≈øt part is from Tromer in her Ea≈øt, to Barragh-Bay in her We≈øt, containing about foure≈øcore miles. The whole in circuit and compa≈ø≈øe is aboue foure hundred miles.

(3) The aire is not altogether ≈øo pure and cleare, as in the other Prouinces of Ireland, by rea≈øon of certaine moi≈øt places (couered ouer with gra≈ø≈øe) which of their ≈øoftne≈ø≈øe are v≈øually termed Boghes, both dangerous, and full of vaporous and foggie mi≈øts.

(4) This County as it is diuided into ≈øeuerall portions, ≈øo is euery portion ≈øeuerally commended for the ≈øoile, according to the ≈øea≈øonable times of the yeare. Twomond or the County Clare, is ≈øaid to be a Country ≈øo conueniently ≈øituated, that either from the Sea or Soile there can be nothin wi≈øht for more, then what it doth naturally afford of it ≈øelfe, were but the indu≈øtry of the Inhabitants an≈øwerable to the re≈øt. Galway is a land very thankfull to the painefull husbandman, and no le≈ø≈øe commodious and profitable to the Shepheard. Maio, in the Roman Prouinciall called Mageo, is repleni≈øhed
both with plea≈øure and fertility, abundantly rich in Cattle, Deere, Hawkes, and plenty of Hony. Slego (coa≈øting vpon the Sea) is a plenteous Country for feeding and rai≈øing of Cattle. Le-Trim (a place ri≈øing vp throughout with hilles) is ≈øo full of ranke gra≈ø≈øe and forrage, that (as Solinus reporteth) if Cattle were not kept ≈øometimes from gra≈øing, their fulne≈ø≈øe would endanger them. And Ro≈øco ‚Ä¢ en is a Territory, for the mo≈øt part plaine and fruitfull, feeding many Heards of Cattle, and with meane husbandry and tillage, yeelding plentie of Corne, As euery particular part is thus ≈øeuerally profitable by in-bred commodities; ≈øo is it no le≈ø≈øe commended (in the generalitie) for the many accomodate and fit Bayes, Creekes, and nauigable Riuers, lying vpon her Sea-coa≈øts, that after a ≈øort inuite and prouoke the Inhabitants to nauigation.

(5) Such as in ancient time made their abode and habitations in this Prouince, were the GANGANI, who were al≈øo called CONCANI, AVTERI, and NAGNATAE. As the Luceni (that were next neighbours vnto them) came from the Luceniji (in Spaine) ≈øo tho≈øe Gangam and Coneani may ≈øeeme al≈øo to haue fetcht their deriuation from the Concan (Nation of the ≈øelfe-≈øame Country) both by the affinitie of name, and vicinitie of place. In Strabo, according to the diuer≈øitie of reading, the ≈øame people are named Coniaci and Coni≈øci: and Silius te≈øtifieth them at the fir≈øt to haue beene Scythians, and to haue v≈øed ordinarily to drinke hor≈øes bloud (a thing nothing ≈øtrange among the wilde Iri≈øh euen of late dayes.) And ≈øome may al≈øo happily ≈øuppo≈øe that the Iri≈øh name Conaughty, was compounded of Concani and Nagnatae. How≈øoeuer, it is ≈øure that the≈øe were the ancient Inhabitants of this Country, as is to be ≈øeene in Ptolemie.

(6) The principall Citie of this Prouince, and which may worthily be accounted the third in Ireland, is Galway, in Iri≈øh, Galliue, built in manner much like to a Tower. It is dignified with a Bi≈øhops See, and is much frequented with Merchants, by rea≈øon whereof, and the benefit of the Road and Hauen, it is gainfull to the Inhabitants through traffique and exchange of rich commodities,
both by Sea and Iland. Not farre from which, neere the We≈øt ≈øhoare that lies indented with ≈ømall in-lets and out lets in a row, are the Ilands called Arran, of which many a fooli≈øh fable goes, as if they were the Ilands of the liuing, wherein none died at any time, or were ≈øubiect to moralitie; which is as ≈øuper≈øitious an ob≈øeruation, as that v≈øed in ≈øome other corners of the Country, where the people leaue the right armes of their Infants males vnch ‚Ä¢ ≈øtned (as they terme it) to the end that at any time afterwards, they might giue a more deadly and vngracious blow when they ≈øtrike: which things doe not onely ≈øhew how palpably they are carried away by traditious ob≈øcurities, but doe al≈øo intimate how full their hearts be of inueterate reuenge.
