(7) This ‚Ä¢ ouince pre≈øents no matter more worthy of memory, then the battle of Knoe-toe (that is) The ‚Ä¢ ull of axes, vnder which, the greate≈øt rabble of Rebels, that were euer ≈øeene before in Ireland (rai≈øed and gathered together by the Arch-Rebels of that time, William Burk O Brien, Mac-Nomare, and O-Carrol) were after a bloudy ouerthrow di≈øcomfited and put to flight by the noble ≈øeruice of Girald F ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ z-G ‚Ä¢ rald Earle of
‚Ä¢ ildare‚ñ™ And the ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion of certaine Iri≈øh (the po≈øteritie of Mac-William) who v≈øurping a tyrannie in the≈øe parts, raged ≈øometimes vpon them≈øelues, with mutuall iniuries, and oppre≈ø≈øed the poore people a long time with extorting, pilling, and ≈øpoiling; ≈øo as they left ≈øcarce one hou≈øe in the Country vnrifled, or vnra≈øed; but were bridled and repre≈ø≈øed (euen in our remebrance) by the ≈øeueritie and re≈øolution of the Commi≈ø≈øioner of tho≈øe their vniu≈øt doings, would be a meanes to draw the people away from the due obedience to their Prince: ≈øuch therefore as refu≈øed to obey the lawes, and ≈øided with the tumultuous, with all care and diligence he ≈øoone ≈øcattered, forcing their Forts, and driuing them into woods and lurking holes (for troubling the ble≈ø≈øed e≈øtate of tranquilitie) till the Lord Deputie, who tooke pitie of them, vpon their humble ≈øupplication, commanded by his mi≈ø≈øiues, that they ≈øhould be receiued vpon tearmes
of peace. But they being a ≈øtiffenecked people, tooke armes againe, entred a-fre≈øh into actuall rebellion, draue away booties, made foule vprores, and vpon faire promi≈øes procured the aid of the Scotti≈øh Ilanders, from out of the Hebrides: whereupon the Gouernour a≈ø≈øembled an Armie, and pur≈øued them with ≈øuch powerfull violence through the Woods and Forre≈øts, that after ≈øixe or ≈øeauen weekes, being grieuou≈øly hunger-bitten, they ≈øubmitted them≈øelues in all humilitie. The Auxiliarie Forces al≈øo of the Scots, he by day and night affronted ≈øo neere, and followed ≈øo hardly, that he put them to flight, after he had killed and drowned about three thou≈øand of them in the Riuer Moin.

(8) About the yeare 1316. there was ≈øuch a great ≈ølaughter made of the Iri≈øh in this Prouince of Connaught, through a quarrell that aro≈øe there betweene two Lords or Princes, that there were ≈ølaine on both ≈øides about foure thou≈øand men; and ≈øo great a tribulation at that time came vpon the people, that they did deuoure and eat one another, ≈øo as of 10000. there remained not aboue 200. liuing. And it is reported for truth, that the people were then ≈øo hunger-≈øtarued, that in Church-yards they tooke the dead bodies out of their graues, and in their ≈øculs boiled the fle≈øh, and fed vpon it: yea, and that women did eat their owne children. Thus appeared the ire and anger of God, in puni≈øhing their ≈øinnes, and ≈øeeking their conuer≈øion.

(9) Places memorable, are, Inis Ceath, well knowne by the Mona≈øtery of Colman (a deuout Saint) founded for Scots and Engli≈øhmen; and Inis Bouind, which Bede calleth, White Cal≈øe I≈øle. Al≈øo Ma ‚Ä¢ o, a Mona≈øtery built (as Bede writeth) for thirtie men of the Engli≈øh Nation. Likewi≈øe the Barony of Boile, vnder Carlew hilles, where in times pa≈øt was a famous Abbey built, together with the Abbey of Beatitude, in the yeare of grace 1152: The≈øe Abbeyes and Mona≈øteries erected at the fir≈øt for religious ≈øeruices, and through ignorance and other ob≈øeurities diuerted ≈øince vnto ≈øuper≈øtitious v≈øes, are now made the ruines of time.

(10) The Prouince of Connaught is at this day ≈øtrengthned with foureteene Ca≈øtles, traded with nine Market-Townes, and diuided as en≈øueth.
Counties.

or

Ro≈øcomen.

div.head: THE PROVINCE OF VLSTER. CHAPTER V.
div.p: THis Prouince, called by our Wel≈øh-Britaines Vltw, in Iri≈øh Cui Guilly, in Latine Vltonia, and Vlidia, in Engli≈øh V ‚Ä¢ ≈øier; on the North is diuided by a narrow Sea from Scotland; South-ward it extends it ≈øelfe to Connagh and Lein≈øter; the Ea≈øt part lieth vpon the Iri≈øh Sea; and the We≈øt part is continually beaten with the boi≈øterous rage of the maine We≈øt Ocean. This Prouince and furthe≈øt part of Ireland, affronteth the Scoti≈øh Ilands, which are called the Hebrides, and are ≈øcattered in the Seas betweene both Kingdomes; who≈øe Inhabitants at this day is the Iri≈øh-Scot, ≈øucce≈ø≈øour of the old Scythian.

(2) The forme thereof is round, reaching in length from Coldagh-Hauen in her North, to Kilmore in her South, neere an hundred miles; and in bredth from Black-Abbey in her Ea≈øt, to Calebegh point in her We≈øt, one hundred thirtie and odde miles: The whole in circumference, about foure hundred and twentie miles.

(3) This Country ≈øeldome feeleth any vn≈øea≈øonable extremities, the quicke and flexible windes cooling the heat of Summer, and ≈øoft and gentle ≈øhowers mollifie the hardne≈ø≈øe of the Winter. Briefly, the frozen nor torrid Zone haue not here any v≈øurpation; the clouds in the aire very ≈øweet and plea≈øant, yea, and when they are mo≈øt impure, are not vnwhole≈øome, nor of long continuance, the rough windes holding them in continuall agitation.

(4) This equall temperature cau≈øeth the ground to bring forth great ≈øtore of ≈øeuerall Trees, both fit for building, and bearing of fruit; plentifull of gra≈ø≈øe for the feeding of Cattle, and is abundantly furni≈øhed with Hor≈øes, Sheepe and Oxen; the Riuers likewi≈øe pay double tribute, deepe enough to ‚Ä¢ arry Ve≈ø≈øels either for plea≈øure or profit, and Fi≈øh great ≈øtore, both for their owne v≈øes,
and commoditie of others. Salmons in ≈øome Riuers of this County abound more in number then in any Riuer of Europe. To ≈øpeake (in generall) though in ≈øome places it be ≈øomewhat barren, troubled with Loughes, Lakes, and thicke Woods, yet is it euery where fre≈øh, and full of Cattle and forrage, ready at all times to an≈øwer the husbandmans paines. But nature is there ≈øo little beholding to Art or Indu≈øtry, that the various ≈øhew vpon bankes, the ≈øhady groues, the greene meadowes, hanging hilles, and fields fit for Corne, (if they were manured) doe ≈øeeme to be angry with their Inhabitants for ≈øuffering all to grow wild and harbarous, through their owne negligence.
(5) This Country in Ptolemies dayes was wholly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Volutij, Darni, Robogdji, and Erdini, who branched and ≈øpred them≈øelues into the ≈øeuerall parts that I≈øland.

(6) The people of this Prouince were accu≈øtomed in controuer≈øies and ≈øolemne prote≈øtations, to ≈øweare by S. Patrickes Staffe, which oath they feared more to breake, then if they had ≈øworne by the holy Euangeli≈øt‚ñ™ Their ancient cu≈øtome in making their King, was this: A white Cow was taken, which the King mu≈øt kill, and ≈øeeth the ≈øame in water whole, then mu≈øt he bathe him≈øelfe therein ≈øtarke naked; and ≈øitting in the Cawdron wherein it was ≈øod, accompanied with his people round about him, he and they v≈øed to eat the fle≈øh and drinke the broath wherein he ≈øate, without cup, or di≈øh, or v≈øe of hand. How farre the≈øe pre≈øcriptions and cu≈øtomes were different from the conformities of other ciuill Monarchies, we may well perceiue by the≈øe and other like ob≈øeruations of tho≈øe gro≈ø≈øe times, and as yet they are more barbarous then is any other part of the I≈øland be≈øides.

(7) Hi≈øtorians relating of Ireland, tell of ≈øeuerall I≈ølands in the ≈øeuerall Prouinces: ≈øome full of Angels, ≈øome full of Deuils; ≈øome for male onely, ≈øome for female; ≈øome where none may liue, ≈øome where none can die; and ≈øuch effects of trees, ≈øtones, and waters, that a man (but of ea≈øie conceit) may well e≈øteeme them as heedle≈ø≈øe as vncertaine. So al≈øo S. Patrickes Purgatorie (a thing of much note in the Tract of this Prouince) is a vault or narrow caue in the ground, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
(called Erne Liffer) much ≈øpoken of, by rea≈øon of (I wot not what) fearefull walking ≈øpirits and dreadfull apparitions, (or rather ≈øome religious horrour) which (as ≈øome ridiculou≈øly dreame) was digd by Vly≈ø≈øes when he went downe to parley with tho≈øe in hell. This is the caue which the Inhabitants in the≈øe dayes call
‚Ä¢ llanu ‚Ä¢ Frugadory, that is, The I≈øle of Purgatory, and S. Patricks Pargatory: for ≈øome per≈øons, le≈ø≈øe deuout then credulous, affirme that S. Patricke (or rather Patricius Secundus an holy Abbot of that name) labouring the conuer≈øion of the people of this Prouince, and much inforcing the life to come, they replied contemptuou≈øly vnto him, that vnle≈ø≈øe they ≈øaw proofes of tho≈øe joyes and paines he preached, they would not lo≈øe the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of their pre≈øent plea≈øures, in hope or feare of things to come, they wi≈øt not when Whereupon (as they ≈øay) he obtained at Gods hands by earne≈øt prayer, that the puni≈øhments and torments which the godle≈ø≈øe are to ≈øuffer after this life, might be there pre≈øented to the eye, that ≈øo he might more ea≈øily root out the ≈øinnes and Heatheni≈øh errours, that ≈øtucke ≈øo fa≈øt in the hearts of the Iri≈øh. But touching the credit hereof (although common fame, and ≈øome records doe vtter it) I neither will vrge the beliefe, nor regard, ≈øeeing it is no Article of our Creed.

(8) Matters memorable within this Prouince are the≈øe: fir≈øt, that the Bi≈øhops of Ireland were wont to be con≈øecrated by the Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury in regard of the „Äà‚óä„Äâ which they had in this Country; vntill ≈øuch time as Iohn Pap ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
a Cardinall was ≈øent thither from Pop ‚Ä¢
Eugenius the fourth, to reforme Eccle≈øia≈øticall di≈øcipline in this Iland, which „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ≈øo loo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , that there were tran≈ølations, and pluralities of Bi≈øhops, according to the „Äà‚óä„Äâ and plea≈øure of the Metropolitane‚ñ™ Al≈øo that the Iri≈øh-men were accu≈øtomed to leaue and for≈øake „Äà‚óä„Äâ wedded wiues at their owne free willes, whereof Lanfrancke Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury complained vnto Theraelua ‚Ä¢
a King of Ireland. And had not this Nation beene corrupted with this vice, euen vnto the≈øe our dayes; both the right of lineall ≈øucce≈ø≈øion had beene more certaine among them, and the Gentry and
Comminaltie had not in ≈øuch cruelties imbrued them≈øelues, with ≈øuch effu≈øion of their owne kindreds bloud, about their inheritances and legitimation.

(9) The principall place in this Tract is Armagh, neere vnto the Riuer Kalin, which (albeit it maketh a poore ≈øhew) is the Archiepi≈øcopall See and Metropolitane of the whole I≈øland. Before Saint Patricke had built there a faire Citie, for ≈øite, forme, quantitie, and compa≈ø≈øe, modelled out (as he ≈øaith) by the appointment and direction of Angels, this place was named Drumfalrch; the Iri≈øh tell much that it receiued the name of Queene Armacha: but the better opinions are, that it is the ≈øame which Bede calleth Dearmach, and out of the Scoti≈øh and Iri≈øh language interpreteth it, The Field of Oakes. Here (as S. Bernard writeth) S. Patricke the Apo≈øtle of Ireland ruled in his life time, and re≈øted after death: in honor of whom it was of ≈øuch venerable e≈øtimation in old time, that not onely Bi≈øhops and Prie≈øts, but Kings al≈øo and Princes were (in generall) ≈øubiect to the Metropolitane thereof in all obedience, and to his gouernment alone. Among the Archbi≈øhops of this Prouince, S. Malachy is famou≈øed, who fir≈øt prohibited Prie≈øts marriage in Ireland, and (as S. Bernard ≈øaith, who wrote his life at large) borrowed no more of the natiue barbarou≈øne≈ø≈øe of that Country, then Sea-fi≈øhes doe ≈øaltne≈ø≈øe of the Seas. Al≈øo Richard Fitz Ralf (commonly called Armachanus) is of famous memory, who turning the edge of his ≈øtile, about the yeare 1355. began to oppo≈øe his opinion again≈øt the Order of Mendicant Friers, as dete≈øting in Chri≈øtians ≈øuch voluntary begging. The chiefe Fort in this Tract is Enis Kelling, defended by the Rebels in the yeare 1593 and wonne by Dowdall a mo≈øt valiant Captaine: neere vnto which is a great downfall of water, termed The Salmon Leape: of which there is a common ≈øpeech currant among the Inhabitants, that it was once firme ground very populous and well husbanded with tillage; till it was ≈øuddenly ouer flowne with waters, and turned into a Lake, for ≈øome filthy abominable acts of the people again≈øt Nature committed with bea≈øts.

(10) The places of Religion, ≈øeque≈øtred from other worldly ≈øeruices, and con≈øecrated to holy purpo≈øes, erected in this Prouince, were: The Abbey which ≈øheweth it ≈øelfe at Donegal: The Mona≈øtery of Derie, where the Iri≈øh Rebell Shane O-N ‚Ä¢ al receiued ≈øuch an ouerthrow (by Edward Randolph, renowned for his ≈øeruice in the behalfe of his Country) that he could neuer after recouer the lo≈ø≈øe he ≈øu≈øtained at that time: The Mona≈øtery neere vnto the Riuer Laffer: The famous Mona≈øtery at the Bay of Knockfergus, of the ≈øame in≈øtitution, name, and order, as was that ancient Abbey in England, neere vnto Che≈øter, called Danchor: Al≈øo Mellifont Abbey, founded by Donald a King of Vriel, and much commended by S Bernard: And la≈øtly, the mo≈øt renowned Mona≈øtery, built at Armagh in the yeare of our Saluation 610. out of which very many Mona≈øteries were afterwards propagate both in Britaine and Ireland. The≈øe places were farre and neere frequented and ≈øought vnto by great confluences of Pilgrims, till Time proued their deuotions to be erronious, and the pure light of the word reuealed, opening the eyes of their vnder≈øtanding, hath taught them to ≈øhake off the ≈øhame of ≈øuch Super≈øtitions.

(11) That the people of this County might be kept within the bounds of their dutie, this Prouince hath beene ≈øecured with fiftie ≈øixe Ca≈øtles and Forts; and for trade of commerce, nine Market-Townes appointed, being diuided into the≈øe Counties en≈øuing.
